(Code 1974, § 2-2; Ord. No. 661, § 1, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 687, § 1, 5-23-2005; Ord. No. 709, § 3, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 775, § 1, 5-6-2013; Ord. No. 783, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Sec. 2-62. - City clerk. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority of chapter IV, section 4.7(c) of the City Charter, the city council does hereby increase the annual salary of the city clerk to $65,574.00 per year effective upon election certification, November 2015; $66,230.00 per year effective November 1, 2016: 
(1)  Certified municipal clerk, by the Institute of Municipal Clerks, and accreditation by the state as an election inspector training coordinator shall receive 100 percent of the stated salary. 
(2)  A non-certified municipal clerk and accredited training coordinator, shall receive 75 percent of the stated salary. 
(b)  In addition, fringe benefits shall include health, prescriptive drug, dental and optical insurance coverages, which are subject to periodic adjustment, and shall mirror those provided to other non-union employees, incorporating equivalent benefit levels, co-payments, deductibles and premium sharing, and excepting residency incentives, as well as a group life insurance policy rounded to the nearest $1,000.00 of salary, including accidental death and dismemberment during their term of office, shall be paid for the city clerk. The city clerk may elect supplemental life insurance through the city's group insurance carrier subject to the provisions of the insurance company, but the cost of the supplemental coverage must be paid by the city clerk. 
(c)  A city clerk with five years of continuous service shall receive $500.00 and an additional $50.00 for each year of service thereafter, payable on the payroll cycle following the employee's anniversary date. 
(Ord. No. 746, § 1, 3-7-2011; Ord. No. 784, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 746, § 1, adopted March 7, 2011, repealed the former § 2-62, and enacted a new § 2-62 as set out herein. The former § 2-62 pertained to the salary of city clerk and derived from the Code of 1974, § 2-3; Ord. No. 662, adopted June 2, 2003 and Ord. No. 709, adopted May 21, 2007. 
Sec. 2-63. - Duties and salary of the treasurer. 
(a)  As part of the 2011 consolidation and reorganization of city departments, and pursuant to section 4.9 of the Charter, the duties of the city treasurer shall be reduced to those which may be required under state law and those incorporated in the City's Charter at section 4.16.(a)(c)(d) and(e). All other duties and responsibilities performed by the treasurer at the time of enactment of this section, including but not limited to, those set forth in Charter section 4.16(b) for the collection of fees and other receivables, shall hereinafter be transferred to, consolidated and reside with, and become duties and responsibilities of the office of the city controller, to be performed in addition to those currently held and performed by the controller and set forth in section 4.13 of the Charter. 
(b)  Pursuant to the authority of chapter IV, section 4.7(c) of the City Charter, the city council does hereby increase the annual salary of the city treasurer to the sum of $12,000.00 per year, effective upon election certification, November 2015. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 785, § 1, adopted May 21, 2015, changed the catchline from "duties of the treasurer" to the current catchline. Ord. No. 745, § 1, adopted February 22, 2011, repealed the former § 2-62, and enacted a new § 2-62 as set out herein. The former § 2-62 pertained to the salary of city treasurer and derived from the Code of 1974, § 2-3; Ord. No. 663, adopted June 2, 2003 and Ord. No. 709, adopted May 21, 2007. 
Sec. 2-64. - Use of the title of city administrator. 
(a)  The administrative assistant officer shall have the authority to use the title of city administrator in performing the administrative duties of such position, except to the extent that the Charter expressly prohibits such use. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed as creating any new administrative office or the combination thereof, but solely the authorization to use an administrative title in addition to the title set forth in the Charter. 
(Code 1974, § 2-5) 
Charter reference- Administrative assistant officer, § 4.11. 
Sec. 2-65. - Local officer's compensation commission. 
(a)  Pursuant to Public Act 106 of 1978, a local officer's compensation commission shall be created, which shall determine the salaries of each elected official. 
(b)  The commission shall consist of five members, provided the city's population is 20,000 or less, or seven members should it exceed 20,000. 
(c)  The members of the commission shall be registered electors of the city appointed by the mayor, and subject to confirmation by a majority of the members elected and serving on the city council. Each member of the five-member commission shall have a term of office of five years, except that of the member's first appointed, one each shall be appointed for terms of one, two, three, four and five years. The first member shall be appointed within 30 days after the effective date of the ordinance [Ordinance No. 709]. Members other than the first member shall be appointed before October 1 of the year of appointment. Vacancies shall be filled only for the remainder of an unexpired term but shall serve until a successor is appointed. A member or employee of the legislative, judicial or executive branch of the government, or member of the immediate family, shall not be eligible to serve as a member of the commission. 
(d)  The commission shall determine the salary only for the following city elected officials for a period not to exceed two years: clerk, treasurer, and assessor beginning with the first Monday following the Tuesday general election in each odd numbered year. The determination of the commission shall be the established salary unless the council, by resolution adopted by two-thirds of the members elected to and serving on the legislative body, rejects it. The salary determinations of the commission shall be effective 30 days following its filing with the city clerk, unless rejected as provided herein by the council. If the determination is rejected, the then existing salary of such elected officials shall continue. 
(e)  The commission shall meet for not more than 15 session days in each odd-numbered year, providing separate opportunities for consultation with each affected elected official and administration, and, after examining internal and external comparables, shall make its determination within 45 calendar days of its first meeting but before the city's regular general election. A majority of the members of the commission shall constitute a quorum for conducting the business of the commission. The commission shall not take action or make a determination without a concurrence of a majority of the members appointed and serving on the commission, irrespective of the existence of a quorum. The commission shall elect a chairperson from among its members. The members shall not receive compensation, but shall be entitled to actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their official duties. 
(f)  The business which the commission may perform shall be conducted only at a public meeting of the commission held in compliance with the Michigan Open Meetings Act. 
(g)  Any writing prepared, owned or used in the possession of, or retained by the commission in the performance of an official function shall be available for public inspection and compliance with the Michigan Freedom of Information Act. 
(h)  After one year following the date the ordinance [Ordinance No. 709] goes in effect, the procedure for establishing the compensation of elected officials may be changed by charter amendment or revision. 
(Ord. No. 709, § 2, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 2-66. - Veteran's preferences. 
(a)  In accordance with Public Act 205 of 1897, honorably discharged veterans, as defined by 1965 PA 190, shall be preferred for appointment and employment by the city. 
(b)  To qualify, the veteran's qualifications must be at least comparable to other applicants in the estimation of the hiring authority. 
(c)  This provision shall not preclude the city from hiring a nonveteran applicant if the city reasonably believes that the nonveteran applicant is substantially better qualified than the veteran. 
(d)  This provision shall not apply to heads of departments, members of commissions and boards, or heads of institutions appointed directly the mayor under the provisions of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 766, § 1, 1-7-2013) 
Secs. 2-67-2-69. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-70. - Director of police and fire services. 
    There is hereby established an administrative office to oversee and coordinate the delivery of public safety services between the police and fire departments pursuant to the authority of chapter IV, section 4.9 of the City Charter, which shall bear the designation of: "Director of Police and Fire Services." 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 10-28-2013) 
Sec. 2-71. - Duties of the director of police and fire services. 
(a)  The director shall be responsible for the overall management of the police and fire departments as well as emergency communications and shall plan, develop and direct a complete program of police, fire and emergency communications service to enforce laws and ordinances, protect the lives and property of the public and to preserve overall peace in the city pursuant to the authority of chapter IV, section 4.9 of the City Charter. 
(b)  The director may perform any or all of the essential job functions, duties and responsibilities of an officer in either department including but not limited to: Planning, organizing and directing all aspects of departmental operations, recruitment and hiring of departmental personnel and coordination of proper supervision, work assignments and workload, performance evaluation, training and professional development opportunities; directing internal and high profile investigations; participating as a team member in the labor negotiation process for all bargaining units and for the administration of collective bargaining agreements, including grievances and arbitrations; develop policies and procedures to improve efficiency and safety; review and recommend ordinance additions and modifications; prepare and administer departmental budgets and enforce adherence thereto; prepare, monitor and control departmental grants; develop and maintain cooperative relations with outside law enforcement and fire agencies, including mutual aid compacts and inter-local agreements; establish, coordinate and monitor task force assignments, requirements and training; act as departmental spokesperson and direct public relations; respond to public safety emergencies and major crime scene and accidents as warranted; establish departmental uniforms; and attend and participate in meetings of the city council as required. 
(c)  The mayor and council may assign by resolution, such other duties and responsibilities to the director as deemed necessary and appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 781, § 1, 3-17-2014) 
Secs. 2-72-2-90. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - ENGINEERING AND BUILDING DEPARTMENT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 

Sec. 2-111. - Established. 
    There is hereby established an administrative office of the city to be known as the city engineering and building department. 
(Code 1974, § 2-15) 
Sec. 2-112. - City engineer to perform duties of health officer. 
(a)  The duties and responsibilities of the city engineer include the responsibilities of the city's health officer as set forth in the following sections: 
(1)  Chapter 54, article II, regarding food and food establishments. 
(2)  Chapter 22, article VI, regarding massage parlors and schools. 
(3)  Such other sections of the Code referencing a health officer, unless otherwise provided for in this Code. 
(b)  The city engineer shall be authorized to retain the services of any appropriate and duly qualified and licensed clinicians to advise and assist the engineer in the performance of duties where clinical expertise may be warranted or required. 
(Code 1974, § 2-17) 
Sec. 2-113. - Code officials; appearance tickets. 
(a)  The city engineer shall be authorized to appoint, with the approval of the council, certain employees of the city engineering and building department, including the building inspector, field and housing inspector, electrical inspector, plumbing inspector, and mechanical inspector, as code officials for enforcing violations of certain city codes through the issuance of appearance tickets before the local district court, when such code officials are assigned, as part of their employment duties, to conduct an investigation concerning an ordinance violation. 
(b)  Those persons authorized in subsection (a) of this section may issue and serve upon a person an appearance ticket if they have reasonable cause to believe that a person has committed an offense within the class of offenses described in this section. 
(c)  An appearance ticket shall mean a complaint or notice upon which an authorized code official shall record an occurrence which involves the commission of one or more code violations by the person cited and directs a designated person to appear in a designated local criminal court on a designated future time in connection with his alleged commission of a designated violation of local ordinance for which the maximum permissible penalty does not exceed 90 days in jail and a fine of $500.00. Each citation shall be numbered consecutively, shall be on an appropriate form, and shall consist of the following parts: 
(1)  The original copy shall be a complaint or notice to appear issued by the code official and shall be filed with the court in which the appearance is to be made. 
(2)  The first copy shall be the abstract of court record. 
(3)  The second copy shall be retained by the local code official. 
(4)  The third copy shall be delivered to the alleged violator. 
(Code 1974, § 2-18) 
Sec. 2-114. - City engineer to perform duties of director of public services. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the city engineer shall include the responsibilities formerly held by the administrator of the department of public works, and set forth in section 4.21 of the City Charter, city resolutions, policy manuals, and organizational charts. 
(Ord. No. 757, § 2, 12-19-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 757, § 2, adopted December 19, 2011, set out provisions intended for use as § 2-113. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 2-114. 
Secs. 2-115-2-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 98. 

Sec. 2-131. - Established. 
    As part of the 2012 consolidation and reorganization of city departments, and pursuant to section 4.9 of the Charter, the duties of the department of public works/services which may be required under state law and those incorporated in the city's charter at section 4.21, shall be transferred to the department of engineering. All other duties and responsibilities performed by the director of the department of public services/works at the time of enactment of this section, including but not limited to, those set forth in Charter section 4.21, shall hereinafter be transferred to, consolidated and reside with, and become duties and responsibilities of the office of the city engineer, to be performed in addition to those currently held and performed by the engineer and set forth in section 4.18 of the Charter. 
(Code 1974, § 2-28; Ord. No. 757, § 1, 12-19-11) 
Secs. 2-132-2-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- Finance, ch. VIII; borrowing power of city, ch. X. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-12(3); any ordinance making or approving any appropriation or budget saved from repeal, § 1-12(5); downtown development plan and tax increment financing plan #98-1, § 26-101 et seq.; taxation, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Uniform Budgeting and Accounting Act, MCL 141.421 et seq.; Revised Municipal Finance Act, MCL 141.2101 et seq.; keeping of public moneys, MCL 129.11 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-161. - Acceptance of checks. 
    The departments and agencies of the city are authorized to accept a personal check in payment of any tax or fee; provided that the city council may by resolution require that any or all types of payments to a city department or agency be made by United States currency, cashier's check, certified check, or money order, and that the city controller or his designated agent may require that any or all further payments to the city from an individual who has previously tendered payment to the city by instrument which was dishonored when presented for payment be made only by United States currency, cashier's check, certified check, or money order. 
(Code 1974, § 13-61) 
Sec. 2-162. - Dishonored checks. 
(a)  Acceptance of any payment to the city by any negotiable instrument, including bank check, is upon the condition that, if the instrument is for any reason dishonored after being duly presented for payment, there shall be assessed a service charge in the amount established by the council to recover the costs incurred by the city in bank charges, labor costs, and miscellaneous expenses associated with the handling of the dishonored instrument, in addition to any other penalties permitted by law. 
(b)  Any permit or license issued by the city upon payment of a fee made by instrument, including bank check, shall be automatically revoked if the instrument is dishonored after being duly presented by the city for payment. 
(Code 1974, §§ 13-62, 13-63) 
State Law reference- Fee authorized, MCL 600.2952. 
Sec. 2-163. - Vehicle storage fees. 
    Vehicles in the custody or possession of the city pursuant to seizure or forfeiture shall be subject to a storage fee calculated on a 24-hour period, or any fraction thereof, as established by the council, payable by the title owner of the vehicle prior to, or at the time of, retrieval. 
(Code 1974, § 13-64) 
Sec. 2-164. - Property taxes. 
(a)  All taxes paid after February 14 of each year shall be subject to a one percent property tax administration fee and a late penalty charge equal to three percent of the tax by the city. 
(b)  All taxes paid after August 31 of each year, shall be subject to a one percent property tax administration fee and a late penalty charge equal to three percent of the tax by the city. 
(Ord. No. 665, § 1, 10-20-2003) 
Secs. 2-165-2-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT RESERVE FUND[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Public improvements fund, MCL 141.261 et seq. 

Sec. 2-181. - Fund continued. 
    Pursuant to Public Act No. 177 of 1943 (MCL 141.261 et seq.), the public improvement reserve fund heretofore established is continued. 
(Code 1974, § 27-1) 
Sec. 2-182. - Purpose. 
    Moneys accumulated in the public improvement reserve fund shall not be transferred, encumbered or otherwise disposed of, except for the purpose of acquiring, constructing, extending, altering, repairing or equipping public improvements or public buildings which the city may by the provisions of its Charter or the general law be authorized to acquire, construct, extend, alter, repair or equip. 
(Code 1974, § 27-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 141.262. 
Sec. 2-183. - Source of funds. 
(a)  The controller is hereby directed to allocate and credit the public improvement reserve fund with moneys now on hand or hereafter acquired which are derived from unexpended moneys on hand at the end of any fiscal year, received in payment of taxes by the city, which moneys are not allocated by budget appropriations, and are otherwise unencumbered. 
(b)  The city council may annually, by and in accordance with the budgetary procedure set forth in the Charter, include in the annual budget or appropriation bill an item of money to be raised by taxation in the year, which money when collected shall be credited to the public improvement reserve fund. 
(c)  The city council may from time to time during any fiscal year transfer moneys from the contingent fund to the public improvement reserve fund or may direct that any miscellaneous revenues derived from sources other than taxation, and not otherwise encumbered, be credited to the public improvement reserve fund. 
(Code 1974, § 27-3) 
Sec. 2-184. - Restrictions on use of funds. 
    All moneys or credits hereafter assigned, transferred and appropriated to the public improvement reserve fund shall be held in the fund as reserve for the use by the city for general public improvements that are specifically authorized by the city council to be constructed at some future time. Moneys so accumulated in the fund shall not be transferred, encumbered or otherwise disposed of except for the construction of public improvements as provided in this division. 
(Code 1974, § 27-4) 
Sec. 2-185. - Investment of funds. 
    The moneys accumulated in the public improvement reserve fund shall from time to time, upon authority of the city council, be invested by the controller in such securities as are authorized by the Charter and the general laws of the state for the investment of sinking and interest funds for the repayment of outstanding bond issues of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 27-5) 
Sec. 2-186. - Manner of authorizing disbursements. 
(a)  Whenever the city council determines the need and advisability to acquire any public improvement, the cost of which is to be defrayed wholly or in part by moneys from the public improvement reserve fund, the provisions of the Charter shall be complied with by the city council, which shall cause to be prepared maps, plans, specifications, and estimates of costs of the proposed improvements and the adoption of a specific resolution authorizing the improvement. 
(b)  Separate proceedings shall be taken for each separate type or kind of public improvement to be authorized. 
(c)  The city council shall provide for the transfer of all or part of the costs of such improvement from the public improvement reserve fund; provided that, if any part of the cost of any improvement is to be paid for by special assessment, the moneys from the public improvement reserve fund shall only be used to defray such part of such public improvement as shall have been determined by the city council to be of general benefit to the entire city. 
(Code 1974, § 27-6) 
Secs. 2-187-2-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SELF-INSURANCE FUND 

Sec. 2-211. - Established. 
    There is hereby created a fund to be known as the City of Trenton Self-Insurance Fund, referred to in this division as the "fund." 
(Code 1974, § 2-220) 
Sec. 2-212. - Purpose. 
    It is hereby established and declared to be the purpose of the city self-insurance fund to offset insurance costs through the use of self-insurance programs as specifically approved by the city council on an annual basis. 
(Code 1974, § 2-221) 
Sec. 2-213. - Claims. 
    The self-insurance fund may be used to pay claims or judgments which are not covered under insurance policies or deductible limits where insurance exists, or where insurance policy limits have been exhausted due to a judgment in excess of policy limits. The claim or judgment may include court costs, witness or subpoena fees, court filing fees, investigation reports, service company fees, deposition costs, attorneys' fees, expert witness fees, transcript fees, appeal fees and/or bonds, and any other cost directly related to the defense of or a prosecution of the city's legal or equitable interests. 
(Code 1974, § 2-222) 
Sec. 2-214. - Administration. 
    The self-insurance fund shall be under the control and responsibility of the city treasurer and the city controller as to the accounting and investment of the monies in the fund. The city controller shall give periodic financial reports as to the status of the fund, or as requested by the city council. The fund shall be held apart from the general fund or any other funds of the city and all receipts and disbursements shall be separately accounted for in accordance with acceptable accounting standards. Any disbursement from the fund to a claimant or for any expense connected therewith requires the prior approval of the city council. Transfer within the fund for investment purposes does not require the prior approval of the city council, but does require notification to the city council. All disbursements from the fund or within the fund require the signature of both the controller and the city treasurer. Transfers into the fund shall be approved by the city council. The city controller and the city treasurer shall have the responsibility of the investment of the fund balance so as to provide sound security and retain liquidity and may, with the consent of the city council, utilize recognized investment services. 
(Code 1974, § 2-223) 
Sec. 2-215. - Authorization of payments. 
    The city council has the sole authority for the authorization of the payment of any monies from the fund for the purposes set forth in this division. 
(Code 1974, § 2-224) 
Secs. 2-216-2-219. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - HEALTH CARE FUND 

Sec. 2-220. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a fund to be known as the City of Trenton Health Care Fund, referred to in this division as "fund", pursuant to Public Act 149, of 1999. 
(Ord. No. 683, § 1, 3-21-2005) 
Sec. 2-221. - Purpose. 
    It is hereby established and declared to be the purpose of the city's health care fund is for the accumulation and investment of funds to assist in providing for health care benefits for retired city employees. 
(Ord. No. 683, § 1, 3-21-2005) 
Sec. 2-222 - Claims. 
    The health care fund may be used to pay claims by qualified employees for eligible benefits and, at the discretion of the council, those benefits which are not covered under other insurance policies, including certain co-payments and deductibles or; for the purpose of purchasing additional insurance coverage. 
(Ord. No. 683, § 1, 3-21-2005) 
Sec. 2-223. - Administration. 
    The health care fund shall be under the control of a board consisting of the treasurer and the two citizen members of the Trenton Fire and Police Pension Board of Directors, appointed by the mayor with the consent of the council. The city controller shall be responsible for an accounting of monies in the fund. The city controller shall make periodic financial reports as to the status of the fund, or as requested by the city council. The fund shall be held apart from the general fund or any other funds of the city and all receipts and disbursements shall be separately accounted for in accordance with acceptable accounting standards. Transfers within the fund for investment purposes do not require the prior approval of the city council. All disbursements from the fund or within the fund require the signature of the city treasurer and one other board member or shall be approved by board resolution. Disbursements shall be restricted to the payment of claims as defined in section 2-222 and the payment of the expenses of the administration of the fund. Transfers into the fund shall be approved by the city council. The health care fund board shall have the responsibility of the investment of the fund balance in accordance with the investment limitations governing investment of assets of public retirement systems pursuant to Public Act 314 of 1965, as may be amended from time to time, so as to provide sound security and retain liquidity. 
(Ord. No. 683, § 1, 3-21-2005) 
Secs. 2-224-2-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PURCHASES AND CONTRACTS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Charter reference- Purchases, contracts and leases, ch. XII. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-241. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City purchasing agent and agent mean the purchasing agent of the city. 
    Contractual services means and includes all telephone, gas, water, electric light and power service; towel and cleaning service; insurance; leases for all grounds, buildings, office or other space required by the using agencies; and the rental, repair or maintenance of equipment, machinery and other city-owned personal property. The term shall not include professional and other contractual services which are in their nature unique and not subject to competition. 
    Supplies means and includes all supplies, materials and equipment. 
    Using agency means any department, agency, commission, bureau or other unit in the city government using supplies or procuring contractual services as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1974, § 2-138) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-242. - Accepting rebates or gifts. 
    The city purchasing agent and every officer and employee of the city are expressly prohibited from accepting, directly or indirectly, from any person to whom any purchase order or contract is or might be awarded, any rebate, gift, or money or anything of value whatsoever, except where given for the use and benefit of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 2-145) 
State Law reference- Conflicts of interest as to contracts, MCL 15.321 et seq. 
Sec. 2-243. - Performance bonds. 
    The city purchasing agent shall have the authority to require a performance bond before entering into a contract, in such amount as he shall find reasonably necessary to protect the best interests of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 2-146) 
Sec. 2-244. - Petty expenditures revolving fund established; use. 
    There is hereby established a the petty expenditures revolving fund. From this fund shall be paid all purchases of incidentals not in excess of $5.00 each, made by the heads of using agencies with the approval of the city purchasing agent. The city purchasing agent shall promulgate rules and regulations for use of the petty expenditures revolving fund. 
(Code 1974, § 2-147) 
Sec. 2-245. - Monthly statement on use of petty expenditures revolving fund; reimbursement of fund. 
    At the end of each month, the city purchasing agent shall render to the controller a statement showing the actual expenditures for each using agency made out of the petty expenditures revolving fund, and the city treasurer shall reimburse the revolving fund for such expenditures in the same manner as other expenditures of such using agencies are paid. 
(Code 1974, § 2-148) 
Sec. 2-246. - Control warehousing. 
(a)  The city purchasing agent shall control and supervise storerooms and warehouses and shall administer the storerooms revolving fund, which fund is hereby established. 
(b)  Requisitions from supplies in a storeroom or warehouse shall be credited by the agent to the storerooms revolving fund by a charge against the appropriation of the using agency. 
(c)  The city purchasing agent shall maintain a perpetual inventory record of all materials, supplies or equipment stored in storerooms and warehouses. 
(Code 1974, § 2-149) 
Sec. 2-247. - Price agreement contract procedure. 
    The head of the using agency shall have the authority to submit requisitions to the city purchasing agent for supplies available under the terms of a price agreement contract made by the city purchasing agent. 
(Code 1974, § 2-150) 
Sec. 2-248. - Emergency purchases by purchasing agent. 
(a)  In case of an apparent emergency which requires immediate purchase of supplies or contractual services, the mayor shall be empowered to authorize the city purchasing agent to secure by open market procedure as set forth in this article, at the lowest obtainable price, any supplies or contractual services not in excess of $500.00. 
(b)  A full report of the circumstances of an emergency purchase shall be filed by the city purchasing agent with the city council and shall be open to public inspection. 
(Code 1974, § 2-151) 
Sec. 2-249. - Emergency purchases by department head. 
(a)  In case of actual emergency, and with the consent of the city purchasing agent and the approval of the mayor, the head of any using agency may purchase directly any supplies whose immediate procurement is essential to prevent delays in the work of the using agency which may vitally affect the life, health or convenience of citizens in an amount not in excess of $500.00. 
(b)  The head of the using agency shall send to the city purchasing agent a requisition and a copy of the delivery record together with a full written report of the circumstances of the emergency. The report shall be filed with the city council as provided in section 2-248. 
(c)  The city purchasing agent shall prescribe by rules and regulations the procedure under which emergency purchases by heads of using agencies may be made. 
(Code 1974, § 2-152) 
Sec. 2-250. - Inspection and testing. 
(a)  The city purchasing agent shall inspect or supervise the inspection of all deliveries of supplies or contractual services to determine their conformance with the specifications set forth in the order or contract. 
(b)  The city purchasing agent shall have the authority to authorize using agencies having the staff and facilities for adequate inspection to inspect all deliveries made to such using agencies under rules and regulations which the city purchasing agent shall provide. 
(c)  The city purchasing agent shall have the authority to require chemical and physical tests of samples submitted with bids and samples of deliveries which are necessary to determine their quality and conformance with the specifications. In the performance of such tests, the city purchasing agent shall have the authority to make use of laboratory facilities of any agency of the city government or of any outside laboratory. 
(Code 1974, § 2-153) 
Sec. 2-251. - Surplus stock. 
(a)  All using agencies shall submit to the city purchasing agent, at such times and in such form as he shall prescribe, reports showing stocks of all supplies which are no longer used or which have become obsolete, worn out or scrapped. The city purchasing agent shall have the authority to transfer surplus stock to other using agencies. 
(b)  The city purchasing agent shall have the authority to sell all supplies which have become unsuitable for public use, or to exchange such supplies for or trade in such supplies on new supplies pursuant to provisions of the Charter. Sales under this section shall be made to the highest responsible bidder and in conformance with division 2 of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 2-154) 
Sec. 2-252. - Cooperative purchasing. 
    The city purchasing agent shall have the authority to join with other units of government in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interests of the city would be served thereby with approval of the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-155) 
Secs. 2-253-2-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BIDDING PROCEDURE GENERALLY[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Bidders on public works, MCL 123.501 et seq. 

Sec. 2-281. - Competitive bidding required. 
    All purchases of and contracts for supplies and contractual services, and all sales of personal property which has become obsolete and unusable, shall, except as otherwise specifically provided in this article, be based wherever possible on competitive bids. 
(Code 1974, § 2-189) 
Sec. 2-282. - Formal contract procedure. 
    All supplies and contractual services shall be purchased and all sales of personal property which has become obsolete and unusable shall be sold pursuant to the provisions of section 12.1 of the Charter. 
(Code 1974, § 2-190) 
Sec. 2-283. - Notice inviting bids. 
(a)  Publication in trade journals. Notice inviting bids may be published once in at least one trade journal at least five days preceding the last day set for the receipt of proposals. The trade journal notice shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased or sold, shall state where bid blanks and specifications may be secured, and shall state the time and place for opening bids. 
(b)  Notice to suppliers on bidders' list. The city purchasing agent shall also solicit sealed bids from all responsible prospective suppliers who have requested their names to be added to a bidders' list which the city purchasing agent shall maintain, by sending them a copy of such trade journal notice or such other notice as will acquaint them with the proposed purchase or sale. In any case, invitations sent to the vendors on the bidders' list shall be limited to commodities that are similar in character and ordinarily handled by the trade group to which the invitations are sent. 
(c)  Posting on bulletin board. The city purchasing agent shall also advertise all pending purchases or sales by a notice posted on the public bulletin board in the city hall. 
(Code 1974, § 2-191) 
Sec. 2-284. - Bid deposits. 
    When deemed necessary by the city purchasing agent, bid deposits shall be prescribed in the public notices inviting bids. Unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to return of any surety which the city purchasing agent has required. A successful bidder shall forfeit any deposit required by the city purchasing agent upon failure on his part to enter into a contract within ten days after the award. 
(Code 1974, § 2-192) 
Sec. 2-285. - Bids to be sealed. 
    Bids shall be submitted sealed to the city purchasing agent and shall be identified as bids on the envelope. 
(Code 1974, § 2-193) 
Sec. 2-286. - Tabulation of bids. 
    A tabulation of all bids received shall be posted for public inspection and a tabulation report forwarded to the city council for necessary action thereon. 
(Code 1974, § 2-194) 
Sec. 2-287. - Bids to be opened in public. 
    Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notices. 
(Code 1974, § 2-195) 
Sec. 2-288. - Bidders in default to city. 
    The city purchasing agent shall not accept the bid of a person who is in default on the payment of taxes, license fees or other moneys due to the city. 
(Code 1974, § 2-196) 
Sec. 2-289. - Authority of purchasing agent to award contracts. 
    The city purchasing agent shall have the authority to award contracts within the purview of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 2-197) 
Sec. 2-290. - Contracts to be awarded to lowest responsible bidder; manner of determining lowest responsible bidder. 
    Contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining who the lowest responsible bidder is, the city purchasing agent shall consider, in addition to price: 
(1)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required. 
(2)  Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference. 
(3)  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder. 
(4)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services. 
(5)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with the laws and ordinances relating to the contract or service. 
(6)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service. 
(7)  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies or contractual services to the particular use required. 
(8)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract. 
(9)  The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid. 
(Code 1974, § 2-198) 
Sec. 2-291. - Reasons to be stated when award is not given to lowest bidder. 
    When the award is not given to the lowest bidder, a full and complete statement of the reasons for placing the order elsewhere shall be prepared by the city purchasing agent and filed with the other papers relating to the transaction. 
(Code 1974, § 2-199) 
Sec. 2-292. - Procedure in case of tie bids. 
(a)  Local vendors. If all bids received are for the same total amount or unit price, quality and service being equal, the contract shall be awarded to a local bidder. 
(b)  Outside vendors. Where subsection (a) of this section is not in effect, the city purchasing agent shall award the contract to one of the tie bidders by drawing lots in public. 
(Code 1974, § 2-200) 
Sec. 2-293. - Contracts or purchases not to be subdivided. 
    No contracts or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1974, § 2-201) 
Secs. 2-294-2-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OPEN MARKET PROCEDURE 

Sec. 2-311. - Disposal of surplus items at public auction. 
    Upon approval of the city council, nothing in this article shall prohibit the use of a public auction as a method of disposing of obsolete and unusable items of personal property in lieu of formal sealed bids. 
(Code 1974, § 2-207) 
Sec. 2-312. - Number of bids required. 
    All open market purchases shall, wherever possible, be based on at least three competitive bids, and shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder in accordance with the standards set forth in section 2-290. 
(Code 1974, § 2-208) 
Sec. 2-313. - Manner of soliciting bids. 
    The city purchasing agent shall solicit bids required by this division by: 
(1)  Direct mail request to prospective vendors; 
(2)  Telephone; and 
(3)  Public notice posted on the bulletin board of the city hall. 
(Code 1974, § 2-209) 
Sec. 2-314. - Record of orders and bids. 
    The city purchasing agent shall keep a record of all open market orders and the bids submitted in competition thereon, and such records shall be open to public inspection. 
(Code 1974, § 2-210) 
Secs. 2-315-2-340. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ABANDONED, STOLEN AND UNCLAIMED PROPERTY 

Sec. 2-341. - Duty of police to take possession of property. 
    All stolen, abandoned, unclaimed or other property, except motor vehicles, taken or found by any police officer in the possession of any person arrested or charged with a violation of the law, or property or money taken on suspicion of having been feloniously obtained or being the proceeds of crime and for which there is no other claimant than the person from which it was taken, or lost property coming into the possession of the police department, and all property and money taken from any insane or intoxicated person otherwise incapable of taking care of himself, shall be deposited, handled and accounted for under regulations prescribed by the chief of police. 
(Code 1974, § 19-122) 
Sec. 2-342. - Claim of ownership. 
    The owner entitled to the possession of property coming into the possession of the police department pursuant to section 2-341 must claim the property within 60 days. If the owner fails to so claim such property, the finder may claim ownership, provided he does so within 30 days following the expiration of the 60-day period. If neither the owner nor finder claims ownership within the 90-day period provided in this section, the property shall be claimed by the city as personal property. 
(Code 1974, § 19-123) 
Sec. 2-343. - Sale, use or donation. 
    Unclaimed property reverting to the city under section 2-342 may be retained for use by the city, sold at an auction sale under the direction of the chief of police or, by resolution by the council, donated to any tax-exempt charitable organization operating within the city limits. In the event of an auction, the date, time, and place of any auction sale shall be advertised by publication in the official city newspaper at least seven days prior to the date of sale. 
(Code 1974, § 19-124) 
Secs. 2-344-2-370. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MUNICIPAL CIVIL INFRACTIONS 

Sec. 2-371. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized city official means a police officer or other personnel of the city authorized by this Code or any ordinance to issue municipal civil infraction citations or municipal civil infraction violation notices. 
    Bureau means the city municipal ordinance violations bureau as established by this article. 
    Municipal civil infraction action means a civil action in which the defendant is alleged to be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
    Municipal civil infraction citation means a written complaint or notice prepared by an authorized city official, directing a person to appear in court regarding the occurrence or existence of a municipal civil infraction violation by the person cited. 
    Municipal civil infraction violation notice means a written notice prepared by an authorized city official, directing a person to appear at the city municipal ordinance violations bureau and to pay the fine and costs, if any, prescribed for the violation by the schedule of civil fines adopted by the city, as authorized under sections 8396 and 8707(6) of the Revised Judicature Act of 1961 (MCL 600.8396, 600.8707(6)). 
(Code 1974, § 2-300) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-372. - Commencement of action. 
    A municipal civil infraction action may be commenced upon the issuance by an authorized city official of: 
(1)  A municipal civil infraction citation directing the alleged violator to appear in court; or 
(2)  A municipal civil infraction violation notice directing the alleged violator to appear at the city municipal ordinance violations bureau. 
(Code 1974, § 2-301) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 600.8703, 600.8707. 
Sec. 2-373. - Issuance and service of citations. 
    Municipal civil infraction citations shall be issued and served by authorized city officials as follows: 
(1)  The time for appearance specified in a citation shall be within a reasonable time after the citation is issued. 
(2)  The place for appearance specified in a citation shall be the 33rd District Court. 
(3)  Each citation shall be numbered consecutively and shall be in a form approved by the state court administrator. The original citation shall be filed with the district court. Copies of the citation shall be retained by the city and issued to the alleged violator as provided by section 8705 of the Revised Judicature Act of 1961 (MCL 600.8705). 
(4)  A citation for a municipal civil infraction signed by an authorized city official shall be treated as made under oath if the violation alleged in the citation occurred in the presence of the official signing the complaint and if the citation contains the following statement immediately above the date and signature of the official: "I declare under the penalties of perjury that the statements above are true to the best of my information, knowledge, and belief." 
(5)  An authorized city official who witnesses a person commit a municipal civil infraction shall prepare and subscribe, as soon as possible and as completely as possible, an original and required copies of a citation. 
(6)  An authorized city official may issue a citation to a person if: 
a.  Based upon investigation, the official has reasonable cause to believe that the person is responsible for a municipal civil infraction; or 
b.  Based upon investigation of a complaint by someone who allegedly witnessed the person commit a municipal civil infraction, the official has reasonable cause to believe that the person is responsible for an infraction and if the prosecuting attorney or city attorney approves in writing the issuance of the citation. 
(7)  Municipal civil infraction citations shall be served by an authorized city official as follows: 
a.  Except as provided by subsection (7)b of this section, an authorized city official shall personally serve a copy of the citation upon the alleged violator. 
b.  If the municipal civil infraction action involves the use or occupancy of land, a building or other structure, a copy of the citation does not need to be personally served upon the alleged violator, but may be served upon an owner or occupant of the land, building or structure by posting the copy on the land or attaching the copy to the building or structure. In addition, a copy of the citation shall be sent by first class mail to the owner of the land, building, or structure at the owner's last known address. 
(Code 1974, § 2-302) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 600.8705, 600.8707. 
Sec. 2-374. - Contents of citations. 
(a)  A municipal ordinance citation shall contain the name and address of the alleged violator, the municipal civil infraction alleged, the place where the alleged violator shall appear in court, the telephone number of the court, and the time at or by which the appearance shall be made. 
(b)  The citation shall inform the alleged violator that he may do one of the following: 
(1)  Admit responsibility for the municipal civil infraction by mail, in person, or by representation, at or by the time specified for appearance. 
(2)  Admit responsibility for the municipal civil infraction "with explanation" by mail by the time specified for appearance or in person, or by representation. 
(3)  Deny responsibility for the municipal civil infraction by doing either of the following: 
a.  Appearing in person for an informal hearing before a judge or district court magistrate, without the opportunity of being represented by an attorney, unless a formal hearing before a judge is requested by the city. 
b.  Appearing in district court for a formal hearing before a judge, with the opportunity of being represented by an attorney. 
(c)  The citation shall also inform the alleged violator of all of the following: 
(1)  That if the alleged violator desires to admit responsibility "with explanation" in person or by representation, the alleged violator must apply to the district court in person, by mail, by telephone, or by representation within the time specified for appearance and obtain a scheduled date and time for an appearance. 
(2)  That if the alleged violator desires to deny responsibility, the alleged violator must apply to the district court in person, by mail, by telephone, or by representation within the time specified for appearance and obtain a scheduled date and time to appear for a hearing, unless a hearing date is specified on the citation. 
(3)  That a hearing shall be an informal hearing unless a formal hearing is requested by the alleged violator or the city. 
(4)  That at an informal hearing the alleged violator must appear in person before a judge or district court magistrate, without the opportunity of being represented by an attorney. 
(5)  That at a formal hearing the alleged violator must appear in person before a judge with the opportunity of being represented by an attorney. 
(d)  The citation shall contain a notice in boldfaced type that the failure of the alleged violator to appear within the time specified in the citation or at the time scheduled for a hearing or appearance is a misdemeanor and will result in entry of a default judgment against the alleged violator on the municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, § 2-303) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 600.8709. 
Sec. 2-375. - Municipal ordinance violations bureau. 
(a)  Established. The city hereby establishes a municipal ordinance violations bureau as authorized under section 8396 of the Revised Judicature Act of 1961 (MCL 600.8396) to accept admissions of responsibility for municipal civil infractions in response to municipal civil infraction violation notices issued and served by authorized city officials, and to collect and retain civil fines and costs as prescribed by this Code or any ordinance. 
(b)  Location; supervision; employees; rules and regulations. The bureau shall be located at city hall, and shall be under the supervision and control of the city treasurer. The city treasurer, subject to the approval of the city council, shall adopt rules and regulations for the operation of the bureau and appoint any necessary qualified city employees to administer the bureau. 
(c)  Disposition of violations. The bureau may dispose only of municipal civil infraction violations for which a fine has been scheduled and for which a municipal civil infraction violation notice (as compared with a citation) has been issued. The fact that a fine has been scheduled for a particular violation shall not entitle any person to dispose of the violation at the bureau. Nothing in this article shall prevent or restrict the city from issuing a municipal civil infraction citation for any violation or from prosecuting any violation in a court of competent jurisdiction. No person shall be required to dispose of a municipal civil infraction violation at the bureau and any person may have the violation processed before a court of appropriate jurisdiction. The unwillingness of any person to dispose of any violation at the bureau shall not prejudice the person or in any way diminish the person's rights, privileges and protection accorded by law. 
(d)  Bureau limited to accepting admissions of responsibility. The scope of the bureau's authority shall be limited to accepting admissions of responsibility for municipal civil infractions and collecting and retaining civil fines and costs as a result of those admissions. The bureau shall not accept payment of a fine from any person who denies having committed the offense or who admits responsibility only with explanation, and in no event shall the bureau determine, or attempt to determine, the truth or falsity of any act or matter relating to an alleged violation. 
(e)  Municipal civil infraction violation notices. Municipal civil infraction violation notices shall be issued and served by authorized city officials under the same circumstances and upon the same persons as provided for citations as provided in section 2-373(6) and (7). In addition to any other information required by this Code or other ordinance, the notice of violation shall indicate the time by which the alleged violator must appear at the bureau, the methods by which an appearance may be made, the address and telephone number of the bureau, the hours during which the bureau is open, the amount of the fine scheduled for the alleged violation, and the consequences for failure to appear and pay the required fine within the required time. 
(f)  Appearances; payment of fines and costs. An alleged violator receiving a municipal civil infraction violation notice shall appear at the bureau and pay the specified fine and costs at or by the time specified for appearance in the municipal civil infraction violation notice. An appearance may be made by mail, in person, or by representation. 
(g)  Procedure where admission of responsibility not made or fine not paid. If an authorized city official issues and serves a municipal ordinance violation notice and if an admission of responsibility is not made and the civil fine and costs, if any, prescribed by the schedule of fines for the violation are not paid at the bureau, a municipal civil infraction citation may be filed with the district court and a copy of the citation may be served by first class mail upon the alleged violator at the alleged violator's last known address. The citation filed with the court does not need to comply in all particulars with the requirements for citations as provided by sections 8705 and 8709 of the Revised Judicature Act (MCL 600.8705, 600.8709), but shall consist of a sworn complaint containing the allegations stated in the municipal ordinance violation notice and shall fairly inform the alleged violator how to respond to the citation. 
(Code 1974, § 2-304) 
State Law reference- Municipal ordinance violations bureau, MCL 600.8396; municipal ordinance violation notices, MCL 600.8707. 
Sec. 2-376. - Schedule of civil fines. 
(a)  A schedule of civil fines payable to the municipal ordinance violations bureau for admissions of responsibility by persons served with municipal ordinance violation notices shall be established. 
(b)  A copy of the schedule, as amended from time to time, shall be posted at the bureau. 
(Code 1974, § 2-305)

(a)  The following city officials are hereby authorized to issue municipal civil infraction citations or notices of the following municipal civil infractions:

Sec. 2-378. - Failure to respond to citation or notice. 
    Any person who fails to answer a municipal civil infraction citation or a notice to appear in court for a municipal civil infraction, issued pursuant to this article or chapter 87 of Public Act No. 236 of 1961 (MCL 600.8701 et seq.) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1974, § 2-308) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 600.8727(9).

ARTICLE IX. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[11]

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-401. - Compensation of members. 
    Each member of an appointed board, appointed commission or council of the city shall receive $15.00 per meeting as full compensation for services. 
Secs. 2-402-2-420. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY BEAUTIFUL COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-421. - Continued. 
    There is hereby continued the city beautiful commission, which shall serve in an advisory capacity to the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-64) 
Sec. 2-422. - Composition; compensation of members. 
    The city beautiful commission shall be composed of nine members to be appointed by the mayor, subject to approval by a majority vote of the members of the city council. Members shall be compensated as provided in section 2-401. 
(Code 1974, § 2-65) 
Sec. 2-423. - Ex officio members. 
    The city beautiful commission shall consist of the following ex officio members, who shall have no voting powers on the commission: 
(1)  One representative from the mayor's office. 
(2)  One representative from the parks and recreation department. 
(3)  One representative from the engineering and building department. 
(4)  The chairperson of the planning commission. 
(Code 1974, § 2-67) 
Sec. 2-424. - Term of office of members. 
    The term of office of the members of the city beautiful commission shall be three years. 
(Code 1974, § 2-68) 
Sec. 2-425. - Vacancies. 
    Any vacancy in the city beautiful commission shall be filled by the mayor with the approval of the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Code 1974, § 2-69) 
Charter reference- Vacancies in boards and commissions, §§ 5.3, 17.7. 
Sec. 2-426. - Chairperson. 
    The city beautiful commission shall select its own chairperson, who shall serve for a term of one year, but who shall be subject to reelection if the other commission members so desire. 
(Code 1974, § 2-71) 
Sec. 2-427. - Objectives and purposes. 
    The objectives and purposes of the city beautiful commission shall be to keep the city beautiful in the following manner: 
(1)  Promote public education against the discarding of litter in the city's streets, alleys, sidewalks, gutters, parks and recreational areas or similar public places. 
(2)  Enlist the active support of interested individuals, businesses, industry, Trenton's National Farm and Garden Association, and schools and civic organizations that would share the same objectives. 
(3)  Encourage developers, absentee owners and businessmen to accept basic responsibilities in preserving and enhancing the beauty of public and private properties. 
(4)  Sponsor, plan and promote a special spring and fall fix-up, paint-up, cleanup campaign. 
(5)  Investigate, study, and recommend plans for improving the general health, sanitation, safety and cleanliness of the city. 
(6)  Encourage the placing, planting and preservation of trees, flowers and shrubbery, and sponsor and promote Arbor Week. 
(7)  Sponsor a program of general improvement of appearance of all properties in the city. 
(Code 1974, § 2-72) 
Sec. 2-428. - Assistance by city departments. 
    The several departments of the city shall work in harmony with the city beautiful commission and provide such necessary assistance and cooperation as may be necessary to assist the commission in carrying out its objectives and purposes. 
(Code 1974, § 2-73) 
Sec. 2-429. - Annual estimate of required funds. 
    The city beautiful commission shall annually prepare and present to the city council an estimate of any necessary costs and expenses required to carry on the work of the commission. 
(Code 1974, § 2-74) 
Secs. 2-430-2-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CIVIC COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-451. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a civic commission of the city, which is an advisory commission, and whose functions, duties and powers are as set forth in this division. 
(Code 1974, § 2-128) 
Sec. 2-452. - Composition; term of office of members; vacancies; compensation of members. 
    The civic commission shall consist of nine members, who shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the city council, as provided in Charter section 4.26. Members shall serve for three-year terms. Vacancies on the commission occurring before the expiration of any term shall be reported by the commission to the mayor and council, and filled by appointment as set forth in this section for the unexpired term. No person shall be eligible for appointment who is the holder of any public office, elective or appointive, under the Charter and who does not meet the eligibility requirements for appointment to public office. Members shall be compensated as provided in section 2-401. 
(Code 1974, § 2-129) 
Sec. 2-453. - Organization; meetings. 
    The civic commission shall immediately after appointment meet and organize by the election of one of its members as chairperson, and by the election of such other officers as it deems necessary. The commission will adopt bylaws for the orderly conduct of its meetings and for the proper process of its functions. Meetings of the commission will be held monthly, or as often as may be deemed necessary by the chairperson. 
(Code 1974, § 2-130) 
Sec. 2-454. - Purpose and functions; assistance by city agencies. 
(a)  The civic commission shall act as an advisory commission to the mayor and members of the city council to coordinate all civic events occurring within the city for such suggested events as the Christmas parade, Labor Day parade, Fourth of July events, Memorial Day, boat races, and City of Trenton Day. These events are listed in this section only by way of example and there is no requirement that all of such stated events be carried out, nor are the events limited to those stated in this section. 
(b)  The commission shall prepare and submit to the city council a projected program and budget within three months after its first meeting. 
(c)  Any person requesting participation of the city in a civic event shall file an application, which will be referred to the civic commission for its study, review and a recommendation to the city council for approval or disapproval of participation in the event, with a recommended city cost participation. 
(d)  The commission may call upon any municipal department, board or commission for such technical or advisory assistance as may be needed. 
(Code 1974, § 2-131) 
Secs. 2-455-2-470. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CULTURAL COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-471. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a cultural commission of the city, to act solely in an advisory capacity. 
(Code 1974, § 2-80) 
Sec. 2-472. - Composition; appointment of members. 
    The cultural commission shall consist of nine members, who shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the city council. The parks and recreation director shall serve as a nonvoting permanent member of the commission. 
(Code 1974, § 2-81) 
Sec. 2-473. - Qualifications of members. 
    No person shall be eligible for appointment to the cultural commission who is the holder of any elective or appointive city office. 
(Code 1974, § 2-82) 
Sec. 2-474. - Term of office of members. 
    The term of office of the members of the cultural commission shall be three years. 
(Code 1974, § 2-83) 
Sec. 2-475. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the cultural commission occurring before the expiration of any term shall be reported by the commission to the mayor and council and filled by appointment as set forth in section 2-472 for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1974, § 2-84) 
Charter reference- Vacancies in boards and commissions, §§ 5.3, 17.7. 
Sec. 2-476. - Officers; bylaws; meetings. 
    The cultural commission shall immediately after appointment meet and organize by the election of one of its members as chairperson, and by the election of such other officers as it deems necessary. It shall adopt bylaws for the orderly conduct of its meetings and for the proper process of its functions. Meetings of the commission shall be held monthly, and as often as may be deemed necessary by the chairperson. 
(Code 1974, § 2-85) 
Sec. 2-477. - Approval of expenditures. 
    Neither the cultural commission or any of its members shall incur any expense or create any obligation or liability upon the city. In the event any expenditure of city funds may be required in connection with the functioning of the cultural commission, prior approval of such expenditures shall first be obtained from the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-86) 
Sec. 2-478. - Filing of minutes. 
    A copy of the minutes of all cultural commission meetings shall be filed with the city clerk for submittal to the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-87) 
Sec. 2-479. - Powers and duties. 
    The cultural commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Act as an advisory commission to the city council. 
(2)  Consider, study and recommend plans for the development of citywide cultural programs. 
(3)  Promote, coordinate and develop the performing and creative arts by making recommendations for programs for cultural opportunities and experiences for the citizens of the city and, further, facilitate communication with the state council for the arts. 
(4)  Call on any municipal department, board or commission for such technical and advisory assistance as may be needed. 
(Code 1974, § 2-88) 
Secs. 2-480-2-500. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - HISTORICAL COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-501. - Continuation; purpose. 
    A historical commission for the city is considered advisable for promoting the recording of the origin and development of the Trenton area, and to that end the commission known as the Historical Commission of Trenton, Michigan, which shall act solely in an advisory capacity to the city council, is hereby continued. 
(Code 1974, § 2-94) 
State Law reference- Historical commissions authorized, MCL 399.172. 
Sec. 2-502. - Composition; appointment of members. 
    The historical commission shall be composed of nine members, to be appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval of a majority vote of the members of the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-95) 
Sec. 2-503. - Qualifications of members. 
    None of the members of the historical commission shall be employees of or hold any municipal office in the city. 
(Code 1974, § 2-96) 
Sec. 2-504. - Term of office of members. 
    The term of each member of the historical commission shall be three years. All members shall hold office until their successors are appointed. 
(Code 1974, § 2-97) 
Sec. 2-505. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the historical commission occurring other than through the expiration of the term of office shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor, with the approval of a majority vote of the members of the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-98) 
Charter reference- Vacancies in boards and commissions, §§ 5.3, 17.7. 
Sec. 2-506. - Compensation of members. 
    Members of the historical commission shall be compensated as provided in section 2-401. 
(Code 1974, § 2-99) 
Sec. 2-507. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The powers and duties of the historical commission shall be to collect, develop and compile historical data and information concerning the origin and development of the Trenton area, and advise the city council by periodic reports of its findings. 
(b)  The scope, powers and duties of the historical commission shall include the duty to recommend to the city council the following areas of responsibility pertaining to the historical museum: 
(1)  Operations. 
(2)  Development. 
(3)  Addition of artifacts. 
(4)  Maintenance. 
(5)  Special events and exhibits. 
(6)  Personnel and staffing (full- or part-time). 
(7)  Fund-raising activities. 
(8)  Receipt of gifts of historical importance in the name of the city. 
(9)  Other matters relating to the historical museum. 
(Code 1974, § 2-100) 
Sec. 2-508. - Annual estimate of required funds; approval of expenditures. 
    The historical commission shall annually prepare and present to the city council an estimate of necessary costs and expenses required to carry on the work of the commission, and the commission shall not obligate itself or the city in any financial undertaking unless and until first authorized and approved by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-101) 
Secs. 2-509-2-530. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - LIBRARY COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-531. - Continued; purpose. 
    An advisory library commission for the city is considered advisable for the study and review of existing facilities and policies of the library in the city and for recommending any improvements thereof, and to that end the Trenton Library Commission is continued and shall act solely in an advisory capacity to the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-120; Ord. No. 657, § 1(2-120), 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 2-532. - Composition; appointment of members; term of office of members. 
    The advisory library commission shall be composed of five members to be appointed by the mayor, subject to approval by a majority vote of the members of the city council. Members shall serve for terms of three years each. 
(Code 1974, § 2-121) 
Sec. 2-533. - Qualifications of members. 
    All members of the library commission shall be residents and electors of the city in compliance with the city Charter and shall be appointed from persons who are knowledgeable of library operations. 
(Code 1974, § 2-122; Ord. No. 657, § 1(2-122), 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 2-534. - Term of office of members. 
    The term of office of each member of the library commission shall be one year, and all members shall hold office until their successors are appointed. 
(Code 1974, § 2-123) 
Sec. 2-535. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies occurring on the library commission other than through the expiration of the term of office shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor, with the approval of a majority vote of the members of the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-124) 
Charter reference- Vacancies in boards and commissions, §§ 5.3, 17.7. 
Sec. 2-536. - Compensation of members. 
    Any member of the library commission who shall attend a duly called meeting of the commission shall receive as compensation thereof the sum of $10.00. Attendance records shall be furnished to the city controller. 
(Code 1974, § 2-125; Ord. No. 657, § 1(2-125), 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 2-537. - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the library commission shall be to collect, develop, and prepare necessary data and information on the existing library system service, formulate and recommend policies on operation of the library under generally accepted standards and guidelines developed by the American Library Association and the Michigan Library Association. The library commission shall make recommendations to the city council on hours of operation and improvements to the library. 
(Code 1974, § 2-126; Ord. No. 657, § 1(2-126), 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 2-538. - Annual estimate of required funds; approval of expenditures. 
    The library commission annually shall prepare and present to the city council an estimate of any necessary costs and expenses required to carry on the work of the commission, and the commission shall not obligate itself or the city in any financial undertaking unless and until first authorized and approved by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 2-127) 
Secs. 2-539-2-560. - Reserved.

(Code 1974, § 25-23)
