DIVISION 8. - YOUTH COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-591. - Established. 
    The city youth commission is hereby created. The youth commission shall serve in an advisory capacity to the city council, administration and other city officials. 
(Code 1974, § 2-132) 
Sec. 2-592. - Composition; appointment of members; compensation of members. 
    The youth commission shall consist of up to 15 members to be appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval of a majority vote of the members of the city council, all of whom shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1974, § 2-133; Ord. No. 660, § 1, 1-6-2003) 
Sec. 2-593. - Qualifications of members. 
    All members of the youth commission shall be residents of the city, enrolled in a public or private schools, who are not less than 13 and not more than 19 years of age. 
(Code 1974, § 2-134) 
Sec. 2-594. - Term of office of members. 
    The term of office of the members of the youth commission shall be one year or until a successor is appointed and approved. 
(Code 1974, § 2-135) 
Sec. 2-595. - Removal of members. 
    Members of the youth commission may be removed by the city council or by a unanimous vote of its members, not including the vote of the subject of removal. 
(Code 1974, § 2-136) 
Sec. 2-596. - Chairperson. 
    The youth commission shall select its own chairperson from among its members, who shall serve for a term of one year, but who may be reelected upon approval of the members. 
(Code 1974, § 2-137) 
Sec. 2-597. - Objectives and purposes. 
    The purpose of the youth commission is to identify issues and concerns of the community's youth and to make recommendations for projects and programs to address them for the betterment of the community. 
(Code 1974, § 2-137.1) 
Sec. 2-598. - Advisory board. 
    The youth commission shall be assisted from time to time by an advisory board consisting of five residents of 21 years of age or older, or owners of businesses located within the city limits who are 21 years of age or older, who shall be appointed by the mayor for a term of one year and shall serve as ex officio members of the commission. 
(Code 1974, § 2-137.2) 
Secs. 2-599, 2-600. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - BOARD OF REVIEW 

Sec. 2-601. - Establishment of alternates. 
    The city council shall appoint not more than two alternate members to the board of review for the same term as regular members of the board of review. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 1, 3-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-602. - Qualifications of alternates. 
    Each alternate member shall be a property tax payer of the city and shall qualify by taking the constitutional oath of office within ten days following appointment. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 1, 3-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-603. - Vacancies. 
    The city council shall fill any vacancy which occurs in the alternate membership in the Board of Review. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 1, 3-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-604. - Eligibility. 
    A member of the city council, or spouse, mother, father, sister, brother, son, or daughter of a council member, including an adopted child of member, or of the assessor, is not eligible to serve as an alternate member or to fill any vacancy. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 1, 3-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-605. - Duties. 
    An alternate member may be called upon by the assessor to perform the duties of a regular member of the board of review in the absence of a regular member or, for purposes of reaching a decision in issues protested in which a regular board member has abstained for reasons of conflict of interest. 
(Ord. No. 712, § 1, 3-3-2008) 
Secs. 2-606-2-700. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - HUMAN RIGHTS 

Sec. 2-701. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of the city that no person be denied equal protection of the laws; nor shall any person be denied the enjoyment of his or her civil or political rights or be discriminated against because of actual or perceived race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, height, weight, condition of pregnancy, marital status, physical or mental limitation, source of income, family responsibilities, sexual orientation, gender identity or HIV status. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-702. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meaning: 
    Age means chronological age. 
    Discriminate means to make a decision, offer to make a decision, or refrain from making a decision, based in whole or in part on the actual or perceived race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, height, weight, condition of pregnancy, marital status, physical or mental limitation, source of income, family responsibilities, sexual orientation, gender identity, or HIV status of another person, that person's relatives, or that person's associates. Discrimination based on sex includes sexual harassment, which means unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, and other verbal or physical conduct or communication of a sexual nature when (i) submission to such conduct or communication is, either explicitly or implicitly, made a term or condition of obtaining employment, public accommodations, or housing, (ii) submission to or rejection of such conduct or communication by an individual is used as a factor in decisions affecting such individual's employment, public accommodations or housing, and/or (iii) such conduct or communication has the purpose or effect of substantially interfering with an individual's employment, public accommodations or housing, or creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive employment, public accommodations, or housing environment. Discrimination based upon actual or perceived physical or mental limitation includes discrimination because of the use of adaptive devices or aids by an individual. 
    Family responsibilities means the state of being or the potential to become a contributor to the support of a person or persons in a family relationship. 
    Gender identity means a person's actual or perceived gender, including a person's gender identity, self-image, appearance, expression, or behavior, whether or not that gender identity, self-image, appearance, expression, or behavior is different from that traditionally associated with the person's sex at birth as being either female or male. 
    HIV status means the physical condition of a person who has, or has been diagnosed as having been infected with, the human immunodeficiency virus, whether or not that person has or has been diagnosed as having acquired immunodeficiency syndrome or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome related complex. 
    Housing facility means any dwelling unit or facility used for a person to regularly sleep and keep personal belongings including, but not limited to, a house, apartment, rooming house, housing cooperative, hotel, motel, tourist home, retirement home or nursing home. 
    Marital status means the state of being married, unmarried, divorced, or widowed. 
    Mental limitation means a limitation of mental capabilities unrelated to one's ability to safely perform the work involved in jobs or positions available to such person for hire or promotion; a limitation of mental capabilities unrelated to one's ability to acquire, rent and maintain property; or a limitation of mental capabilities unrelated to one's ability to utilize and benefit from the goods, services, activities, privileges and accommodations of a place of public accommodation. "Mental limitation" includes, but is not limited to, developmental and psychological disabilities. "Mental limitation" does not include any condition caused by the current use of alcohol or the current illegal use of a controlled substance. 
    Perceived means the perception of the person who acts, and not the perception of the person for or against whom the action is taken. 
    Physical limitation means a limitation or physical capabilities unrelated to one's ability to safely perform the work involved in jobs or positions available to such person for hire or promotion; a limitation of physical capabilities unrelated to one's ability to acquire, rent and maintain property; or a limitation of mental capabilities unrelated to one's ability to utilize and benefit from the goods, services, activities, privileges and accommodations of a place of public accommodation. "Physical limitation" includes, but is not limited to, blindness or partial sightedness, deafness or hearing impairment, muteness, partial or total absence of physical member, speech impairment and motor impairment. "Physical limitation" does not include any condition caused by the current use of alcohol or the current illegal use of a controlled substance. 
    Place of public accommodation means an educational, governmental, health, day care, entertainment, cultural, recreational, refreshment, transportation, financial institution, accommodation, business or other facility of any kind, whose goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages or accommodations are extended, offered, sold or otherwise made available to the public, or which receives financial support through the solicitation of the general public or through governmental subsidy of any kind. 
    Sexual orientation means male or female homosexuality, heterosexuality, or bisexuality, by orientation or practice. 
    Source of income means any legal source from which a person obtains money. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-703. - Discriminatory housing practices. 
(a)  No person shall discriminate in leasing, selling or otherwise making available any housing facilities. 
(b)  No person shall discriminate in the terms, conditions, maintenance, or repair in providing any housing facility. 
(c)  No person shall refuse to lend money for the purchase or repair of any real property or to insure any real property solely because of the location in the city of such real property. 
(d)  No person shall promote real estate transactions by representing that changes are occurring or will occur in an area with respect to race, religion or national origin. 
(e)  No person shall place a sign or other display on any real property which indicates that the property is for sale or has been sold when it is not for sale or has not recently been sold. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-704. - Discriminatory public accommodation practices. 
    No person shall discriminate in making available full and equal access to all goods, services, activities, privileges and accommodations of any place of public accommodation. No person shall prohibit a breastfeeding mother from or segregate a breastfeeding mother within any public accommodation where she and the child would otherwise be authorized to be. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-705. - Discriminatory employment practices. 
(a)  No person shall discriminate in the employment, compensation, work classifications, conditions or terms, promotion or demotion, or termination of employment of any person. 
(b)  No person shall discriminate in limiting membership, conditions of membership or termination of membership in any labor union or apprenticeship program. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-706. - Other prohibited practices. 
(a)  No person shall adopt, enforce or employ any policy or requirement, publish, post or broadcast any advertisement, sign or notice which discriminates or indicates discrimination in providing housing, employment or public accommodations. 
(b)  No person shall discriminate in the publication or distribution of advertising material, information or solicitation regarding housing, employment or public accommodations. 
(c)  No agent, broker, labor union, employment agency or any other intermediary shall discriminate in making referrals, listings or providing information with regard to housing, employment or public accommodations. 
(d)  No person shall coerce, threaten or retaliate against a person for making a complaint or assisting in the investigation regarding a violation or alleged violation of this chapter, nor require, request, conspire with, assist or coerce another person to retaliate against a person for making a complaint or assisting in an investigation. 
(e)  No person shall conspire with, assist, coerce or request another person to discriminate in any manner prohibited by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-707. - Information and investigation. 
    No person shall provide false information to any police officer investigating an alleged violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-708. - Conciliation agreements. 
    In cases involving alleged violations of this chapter, the city may enter into agreements whereby persons agree to methods of terminating discrimination or to reverse the effects of past discrimination. A violation of such an agreement shall be a violation of this chapter. The city attorney may commence a civil action to enforce a conciliation agreement. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-709. - Discriminatory effects. 
    No person shall adopt, enforce or employ any policy or requirement which has the effect of creating unequal opportunities according to actual or perceived race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, height, weight, condition of pregnancy, source of income, family responsibilities, sexual orientation, marital status, physical or mental limitation, gender identity or HIV status for a person to obtain housing, employment or public accommodation, except for a bona fide business necessity. Such a necessity does not arise due to a mere inconvenience or because of suspected or actual objection to such a person by neighbors, customers, or other persons. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-710. - Exceptions. 
    Notwithstanding anything contained in this chapter, the following practices shall not be violations of this chapter: 
(1)  For a religious organization or institution to restrict any of its facilities of housing or accommodations which are operated as a direct part of religious activities to persons of the denomination involved or to restrict employment opportunities for officers, religious instructors and clergy to persons of that denomination. 
(2)  For the owner of an owner-occupied one-family or two-family dwelling, or a housing facility or public accommodation facility, respectively, devoted entirely to the housing and accommodation of individuals of one sex, to restrict occupancy and use on the basis of sex. 
(3)  To limit occupancy in a housing project or to provide public accommodations or employment privileges or assistance to persons of low income, over 55 years of age, or who are handicapped. 
(4)  To engage in a bona fide effort to establish an affirmative action program to improve opportunities in employment for minorities and women. 
(5)  To discriminate based on a person's age when such discrimination is required by state, federal or local law. 
(6)  To refuse to enter a contract with an unemancipated minor. 
(7)  To refuse to admit to a place of public accommodation serving alcoholic beverages a person under the legal age for purchasing alcoholic beverages. 
(8)  To refuse to admit persons under 18 years of age to a business providing entertainment or selling literature which the operator of said business deems unsuitable for minors. 
(9)  For an educational institution to limit the use of its facilities to those affiliated with such institution. 
(10)  To provide discounts on products or service to students, minors and senior citizens. 
(11)  To discriminate in any arrangement for the sharing of a dwelling unit. 
(12)  To restrict use of lavatories and locker room facilities on the basis of sex. 
(13)  For a governmental institution to restrict any of its facilities or to restrict employment opportunities based on duly adopted institutional policies that conform to federal and state laws and regulations. 
(14)  To restrict participation in an instructional program, athletic event or on an athletic team on the basis of age or sex. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-711. - Penalties. 
(a)  A violation of any provision of this chapter is a civil infraction, punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00, plus the costs of investigation and prosecution. Upon a finding or an admission of responsibility, the court may issue and enforce any judgment, writ, or order necessary to enforce this chapter. 
(b)  Each day upon which a violation occurs shall constitute a separate violation. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to limit in any way the remedies, legal or equitable, which are available to the city or any other person for the prevention or correction of discrimination. Private actions and remedies shall be in addition to any actions for a violation which the city may take. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 2-712. - Nullification. 
    The provisions of this article shall become null and void upon the enactment of federal statute, or state legislation in Michigan, prohibiting those discriminatory practices set forth therein, including but not limited to the enactment of ENDA (Employment Non-Discrimination Act), or facsimile thereof. 
(Ord. No. 777, § 3, 11-12-2013) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; use of alcoholic beverages on premises, § 22-150; carrying while under the influence of alcohol, § 66-171; intoxicants in parks, § 70-117; additional restrictions on consumption and possession of alcoholic beverages, § 70-156. 
State Law reference- Michigan Liquor Control Act of 1998, MCL 436.1101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Consumption in public places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic liquor on the public highways, or consume any alcoholic liquors, except beer and wine, in public parks and places of amusement not licensed to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises. 
(b)  Except as in subsection (c) below, it shall be unlawful for any person to purchase, consume or possess any alcoholic liquor in any portion of the Kennedy Recreation Center, except on the Mezzanine Level of the Ice Arena, and then only when distributed by an establishment licensed by the state to serve alcohol at that location. 
(c)  Notwithstanding subsection (b), alcoholic liquor may be sold and served on the main floor of the Kennedy Recreation Center on a temporary basis upon issuance of a permit approved by the city council, to an appropriately licensed and city recognized non-profit organization authorized to utilize the center in conjunction with an approved special event. 
(Code 1974, § 4-1; Ord. No. 763, § 1, 5-21-12) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Public consumption of alcohol, MCL 436.1915. 
Sec. 6-2. - Sale to intoxicated persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly sell, give or furnish alcoholic liquor, beer or wine to any intoxicated person. 
(Code 1974, § 4-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 436.1707. 
Sec. 6-3. - Sale to underage persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give or furnish alcoholic liquor, beer or wine to any person under 21 years of age. 
(Code 1974, § 4-4) 
Cross reference- Underage persons, § 66-331 et seq. 
State Law reference- Sale to underage persons, MCL 436.1701. 
Sec. 6-4. - Purchase, consumption or possession by underage persons; furnishing fraudulent identification to underage person. 
(a)  In this section, the term "minor" means a person less than 21 years of age. 
(b)  A minor shall not purchase or attempt to purchase alcoholic liquor, consume or attempt to consume alcoholic liquor, possess or attempt to possess alcoholic liquor, or have any bodily alcohol content, except as provided by this section. It shall be an affirmative defense that a minor consumed the alcoholic liquor in a venue or location where that consumption is legal. A minor who violates subsection (1) hereunder is responsible for a civil infraction, while a minor who violates subsections (2) thru (6) herein is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by the following fines and sanctions: 
(1)  For the first violation, a fine of not more than $100.00, and may be ordered to participate in substance abuse prevention services or substance abuse treatment and rehabilitation services as defined in section 6107 of the Public Health Code (MCL 333.6107), and designed by the state administrator of substance abuse services, and may be ordered to perform community service and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his own expense as described in subsection (d) of this section. 
(2)  For a violation of this subsection following a prior conviction or juvenile adjudication for a violation of this subsection by imprisonment for not more than 30 days, but only if the minor has been found by court to have violated an order of probation, failed to successfully complete any treatment, screening or community service ordered by the court, or failed to pay any fine for that conviction or juvenile adjudication, a fine of not more than $200.00, or both, and may be ordered to participate in substance abuse prevention services or substance abuse treatment and rehabilitation services as defined in section 6107 of the Public Health Code (MCL 333.6107), and designated by the administrator of substance abuse services, to perform community service, and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his own expense as described in subsection (d) of this section. 
(3)  For a violation of this subsection following two or more prior convictions or juvenile adjudications for a violation of this subsection, by imprisonment for not more than 60 days, but only if the minor has been found by the court to have violated an order of probation, failed to successfully complete any treatment, screening or community service ordered by the court, or failed to pay any fine for that conviction or juvenile adjudication, a fine of not more than $500.00, or both, and may be ordered to participate in substance abuse prevention services or substance abuse treatment and rehabilitation services as defined in section 6107 of the Public Health Code (MCL 333.6107), and designated by the administrator of substance abuse services, to perform community service, and to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his own expense as described in subsection (d) of this section. 
(4)  For a violation of this section following a prior conviction of it or any other local ordinance substantially corresponding to MCL 436.1703, a person may be sentenced to imprisonment for not more than 30 days but only if the person has been found by the court to have violated an order of probation, failed to successfully complete any treatments, screening or community service ordered by the court, or failed to pay any fine for that conviction. 
(5)  For a violation of this section following two or more prior convictions of it or any other local ordinance substantially corresponding to MCL 436.1703, a person may be sentenced to imprisonment for not more than 60 days and a fine of not more than $500.00 or both, but only if the person has been found by the court to have violated an order of probation, failed to successfully complete any treatments, screening, or community service ordered by the court, or failed to pay any fine for that conviction. 
(6)  Upon violation of a term or condition of probation or upon the finding that the person is utilizing this section or the local ordinance of any other community substantially corresponding to this section, the court may enter an adjudication of guilt, and proceed as otherwise provided by law. There may be only one discharge or dismissal of this section as to an individual. The court shall maintain a non-public record of the matter while proceedings are deferred and the person is on probation. 
(c)  A person who furnishes fraudulent identification to a minor, or, notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, a minor who uses fraudulent identification to purchase alcoholic liquor, is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $100.00, or both. 
(d)  The court may order the person convicted of violating subsection (b) of this section to undergo screening and assessment by a person or agency as designated by the substance abuse coordinating agency as defined in section 6103 of the Public Health Code (MCL 333.6103), in order to determine whether the person is likely to benefit from rehabilitative services, including alcohol or drug education and alcohol or drug treatment programs. 
(e)  The secretary of state shall suspend the operator's or chauffeur's license of an individual convicted of violating subsection (b) or (c) of this section as provided in section 319 of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.319). 
(f)  A peace officer who has reasonable cause to believe a minor has consumed alcoholic liquor, or has any bodily alcohol content, may request the person to submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis or require such a test pursuant to a warrant. A peace officer may arrest a person based in whole or in part upon the results of a preliminary chemical breath analysis. The results of a preliminary chemical breath analysis or other acceptable blood alcohol test are admissible in a criminal prosecution to determine whether the minor has consumed or possessed alcoholic liquor. A minor who refuses to submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis as may be required in this subsection is responsible for a state civil infraction and may be ordered to pay a civil fine of not more than $100.00. 
(g)  A law enforcement agency, upon determining that a person less than 18 years of age who is not emancipated under Public Act No. 293 of 1968 (MCL 722.1 et seq.) allegedly consumed, possessed, purchased, or attempted to consume, possess, or purchase alcoholic liquor in violation of subsection (b) of this section, shall notify the parent, custodian, or guardian of the person as to the nature of the violation if the name of a parent, guardian, or custodian is reasonably ascertainable by the law enforcement agency. The notice required by this subsection shall be made not later than 48 hours after the law enforcement agency determines that the person who allegedly violated subsection (b) of this section is less than 18 years of age and not emancipated under Public Act No. 293 of 1968 (MCL 722.1 et seq.). The notice may be made by any means reasonably calculated to give prompt actual notice, including, but not limited to, notice in person, by telephone, or by first class mail. If an individual less than 17 years of age is incarcerated for violating subsection (b) of this section, his parents or legal guardian shall be notified immediately as provided in this subsection. 
(h)  This section does not prohibit a minor from possessing alcoholic liquor during regular working hours and in the course of his employment if employed by a person licensed by Public Act No. 58 of 1998 (MCL 436.1101 et seq.), by the state liquor control commission, or by an agent of the commission, if the alcoholic liquor is not possessed for his personal consumption. 
(i)  This section does not limit the civil or criminal liability of the vendor or the vendor's clerk, servant, agent, or employee for a violation of Public Act No. 58 of 1998 (MCL 436.1101 et seq.). 
(j)  The consumption of alcoholic liquor by a minor who is enrolled in a course offered by an accredited post-secondary educational institution in an academic building of the institution under the supervision of a faculty member is not prohibited by this section if the purpose of the consumption is solely educational and is a requirement of the course. 
(k)  The consumption by a minor of sacramental wine in connection with religious services at a church, synagogue, or temple is not prohibited by this section. 
(l)  Subsection (b) of this section does not apply to a minor who participates in either or both of the following: 
(1)  An undercover operation in which the minor purchases or receives alcoholic liquor under the direction of the person's employer and with the prior approval of the local prosecutor's office as part of an employer-sponsored internal enforcement action. 
(2)  An undercover operation in which the minor purchases or receives alcoholic liquor under the direction of the state police, the state liquor control commission, or a local police agency as part of an enforcement action unless the initial or contemporaneous purchase or receipt of alcoholic liquor by the minor was not under the direction of the state police, the commission, or the local police agency and was not part of the undercover operation. 
(m)  The state police, the state liquor control commission, or a local police agency shall not recruit or attempt to recruit a minor for participation in an undercover operation at the scene of a violation of subsection (b) of this section, section 801(2) of Public Act No. 58 of 1998 (MCL 436.1801(3), or section 701(1) of Public Act No. 58 of 1998 (MCL 436.701(1)). 
(n)  In a criminal prosecution for the violation of subsection (b), "any bodily alcohol content" means either of the following: 
(1)  An alcohol content of 0.02 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath or 67 milliliters of urine; 
(2)  Any presence of alcohol within a person's body resulting from the consumption of alcoholic liquor, other than the consumption of alcoholic liquor as part of a generally recognized religious service or ceremony. 
(Code 1974, §§ 4-1, 4-5; Ord. No. 670, § 1, 4-19-2004; Ord. No. 676, § 1, 10-18-2004; Ord. No. 696, § 1, 1-3-2006; Ord. No. 724, § 1, 2-16-2010; Ord. No. 792, § 1, 1-8-2017) 
Cross reference- Underage persons, § 66-331 et seq. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 436.1703. 
Sec. 6-5. - False representation to purchase alcohol. 
(a)  No person under 21 years of age shall use altered or false identification or otherwise falsely represent himself to be 21 years of age or older for the purpose of purchasing, acquiring, or attempting to purchase or acquire for himself, or for any other person, any alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  In addition to any other penalties, the court shall order the secretary of state to suspend, for a period of 90 days, the operator's or chauffeur's license of a person who is convicted of using fraudulent identification in violation of this section, and the operator's or chauffeur's license of that person shall be surrendered to the court. The court shall immediately forward the surrendered license and a certificate of conviction to the secretary of state. A suspension ordered under this section shall be in addition to any other suspension of a person's operator's or chauffeur's license. 
(Code 1974, § 4-9) 
Sec. 6-6. - False representation to gain entry. 
    No person shall use altered or false identification or otherwise make any false representation as to his age or the age of another for the purpose of gaining entry or attempting to gain entry to any establishment which sells, serves or furnishes alcoholic beverages. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(2), 4-10) 
Sec. 6-7. - Alcohol vapor devices. 
(a)  Alcohol shall mean the product of distillation of fermented liquor, whether or not rectified or diluted with water, but does not mean ethyl or industrial alcohol, diluted or not, that has been denatured or otherwise rendered unfit for beverage purposes. 
(b)  Alcohol vapor device shall mean any device that provides for the use of air or oxygen bubbled through alcoholic liquor to produce a vapor or mist that allows the user to inhale this alcoholic vapor through the mouth or nose. 
(c)  Except for research purposes pursuant to rules promulgated by the state liquor control commission, a person shall not use or offer for use, possess, sell, or offer for sale, an alcohol vapor device. 
(d)  A violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 699, § 1, 2-6-2006) 
ARTICLE II. - COST RECOVERY 

Sec. 6-8. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrase, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Controlled substances means a drug, substance or immediate precursor in Schedules 1-5 Pat 72 of the Michigan Public Health Code, Act 368 of 1978, as amended from time to time. 
    Emergency response means: 
(1)  The providing, sending or utilizing of public service, police, fire and rescue services by the city to an accident involving a motor vehicle where one or more of the drivers are operating a motor vehicle under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or controlled substance, or the combination of the two; 
(2)  The making of a traffic stop and arrest by a police officer when the driver is operating the motor vehicle while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or controlled substance, or combination of the two. 
    Expense of emergency response means the direct costs associated with the occurrence of an emergency response as defined in subsections (1) and (2) of the preceding paragraph, which ever is applicable, of this section. The expense of making an emergency response shall include the costs of providing police, firefighting, rescue, and emergency medical services at the scene of the accident or arrest, as well as the salaries or wages of the personnel responding to the accident or arrest. Further, the expenses shall include the costs of conducting and analyzing preliminary chemical breath analysis tests and chemical tests of the blood, urine, or breath to determine the amount or presence of alcohol or controlled substance in the blood and the costs of processing or analyzing other physical evidence. 
(Ord. No. 719, § 1, 5-4-2009) 
Sec. 6-9. - Civil liability. 
    Any person who is under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or any controlled substance, or the combination of the two, while operating a motor vehicle which results in the city's provision of an emergency response, shall be responsible and liable to the city for the expenses incurred by the city, in providing such response, not to exceed $125.00. 
(Ord. No. 719, § 1, 5-4-2009) 
Sec. 6-10. - Liability presumption. 
    For purposes of this article, it shall be presumed that a person is operating a motor vehicle under the influence of an alcoholic beverage if a chemical analysis of the driver discloses that the person has an alcohol content of 0.08 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine. 
(Ord. No. 719, § 1, 5-4-2009) 
Sec. 6-11. - Conflict with criminal liability. 
    This article shall be construed to be a responsibility and liability of a civil nature on the part of the driver and shall not be construed to conflict with, contravene or enlarge or reduce any criminal liability or responsibility including fines and costs imposed by a court on the driver pursuant to the state motor vehicle code for operating a motor vehicle under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or controlled substance. 
(Ord. No. 719, § 1, 5-4-2009) 
Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; sports, games and other amusements in parks, § 70-106. 
State Law reference- Carnival-Amusement Safety Act of 1966, MCL 408.651 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOWLING ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 10-31. - License. 
    No person shall conduct, maintain or operate any bowling establishment open to the public without first obtaining a license therefor. The annual fee for a license required by this section shall be as established by the city council. No such license shall be granted except upon approval of the police chief, the fire chief and the health officer. Such approval shall be granted upon a showing of compliance with all laws and ordinances. No person shall be granted a license pursuant to this section unless he is over 18 years of age. 
(Code 1974, §§ 5-33-5-36) 
Secs. 10-32-10-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DANCES AND DANCEHALLS 

Sec. 10-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Operator of a dancehall means any person operating a dancehall, including any lessee or manager, and, in the case of an unincorporated club or association, the member thereof who is designated by such organization as the operator. 
    Public dancehall means any room, place or space in which a public dance or public ball shall be held or where admission can be had by payment of a fee or by purchased possession and presentation of a ticket or token or in which a charge is made for care of clothing or other property, or where the public generally may gain admission with or without payment of a fee. 
(Code 1974, § 5-64) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-62. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to municipal dances, dances sponsored by the recreation commission, or dances sponsored by any of the student bodies of the public or parochial schools of the city or service, civic, fraternal or church organizations of the city, if the proceeds of such dance, or the benefits thereof, shall be devoted exclusively to the benefit of such student bodies or clubs, fraternities, organizations or churches. 
(Code 1974, § 5-65) 
Sec. 10-63. - Authority to make additional rules and regulations. 
    The city council is hereby authorized to make any rules or regulations governing the maintenance or operation of any place or establishment where dancing is permitted. No dancing will be permitted in any place or establishment failing to abide by or comply with such rules or regulations. 
(Code 1974, § 5-85) 
Sec. 10-64. - Permitting patrons to violate article. 
    The operator and his agents or servants shall not allow patrons of any public dance to do any of the acts prohibited by this article. 
(Code 1974, § 5-82) 
Sec. 10-65. - Right of entry of city officials. 
    The operator or person in charge of every public dance shall at all times open each and every portion of such public dancehall for the inspection of the police department or other city department for the purpose of enforcing any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 5-72) 
Sec. 10-66. - Permit or license. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to operate any public dancehall in the city without first having obtained either a permit, license or temporary license; however, the city council may issue temporary or probationary permits for the purpose of determining whether or not a license should be issued. It shall be unlawful for any person to hold any public dance or public ball in the city until the hall in which the public dance or public ball is to be held shall have been first duly licensed for such purposes. 
(b)  Fee. The license fee to operate any public dance shall be as established by the council. The annual license fee for all public dancehalls where dances are held and to which the public generally may gain admittance shall be as established by the city council, with the fee to be due January 15 of each year; however, the city council may issue a license for a dancehall for a 24-hour period. The license fee for such dancehall for a 24-hour period shall be as established by the city council. 
(c)  Inspection of premises; standards for premises. Before any such license shall be issued, the chief of police and the chief of the fire department shall inspect such premises where the license was applied for to determine that the premises comply with the rules and regulations of the fire department and the state fire code, and the rules and regulations of the board of health and the police department relating to the safety, health, convenience and comfort of the public. They should also determine that there is adequate ventilation, that there are sufficient toilet conveniences for both men and women, including sanitary towels, that there is at least one sanitary drinking fountain, that the fire exits are marked and lighted and have free and unobstructed means of exit, and that the premises are free of rubbish and flammable material. 
(d)  Suspension or revocation. Failure to comply with the provisions of this article shall be deemed good and sufficient cause for the summary suspension by the city council of any license issued under this section until such time as a hearing may be heard upon an application for the revocation of such license. Any license issued under this section may be permanently revoked by the city council after conducting a public hearing allowing the licensee to appear and present his reasons for not revoking the license. 
(Code 1974, §§ 5-68-5-70, 5-86, 5-87) 
Sec. 10-67. - Hours of operation. 
    No dancing shall be permitted between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:30 a.m., without first having obtained permission from the city council upon the recommendation of the chief of police. 
(Code 1974, § 5-71) 
Sec. 10-68. - Gambling. 
    Gambling or the use, possession or presence of gambling apparatus or paraphernalia is prohibited on the premises of any public dance. 
(Code 1974, § 5-76) 
Sec. 10-69. - Alcoholic beverages; intoxicated persons. 
(a)  The sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises of any public dance is specifically prohibited and no alcoholic beverages of any kind are to be allowed on the premises. 
(b)  No intoxicated person shall be allowed to dance or loiter on the premises of any public dance. 
(Code 1974, § 5-77) 
Cross reference- Public intoxication, § 66-204. 
State Law reference- Liquor in dancehalls, MCL 750.464a. 
Sec. 10-70. - Admittance of persons under 18 years of age. 
    Minors under 18 years of age shall not be permitted on the premises of any public dance, unless accompanied by a parent or guardian, or unless a special permit is granted by the city council for a particular occasion. 
(Code 1974, § 5-79) 
Sec. 10-71. - Lighting. 
    There must be adequate lighting at all times at every public dance. Every part of the premises shall be well lighted. 
(Code 1974, § 5-80) 
Sec. 10-72. - Responsibility of operator for acts of agents and employees. 
    Any operator under this article is hereby made responsible and accountable for the violation of any of the terms of this article by any of his agents or servants, whether or not the violation is committed with his knowledge. 
(Code 1974, § 5-81) 
Sec. 10-73. - Compliance with zoning regulations. 
    Any place or premises listed under the provisions of this article shall comply with chapter 110, pertaining to zoning. 
(Code 1974, § 5-83) 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 110. 
Sec. 10-74. - Police protection. 
    The operator of any public dance shall assist in the proper policing of the dancehall during operating hours by protecting the citizens in attendance there and shall provide at least three uniformed private police who will be present during all hours of the operation of the public dance. 
(Code 1974, § 5-84) 
Secs. 10-75-10-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Arcade means any premises open to the public wherein are assembled five or more mechanical amusement devices. 
    Location owner means any person who has control over the premises in which are located any mechanical amusement devices and who has contracted or permitted such mechanical amusement devices to be installed or operated in such premises for business purposes. 
    Mechanical amusement device means a machine that upon the insertion of a coin or a slug is operated, or may be operated, for use as a game, including but not limited to such coin-operated devices as pinball machines, electric rifle range machines, jukeboxes, claw, crane or digger machines actuated by a crank, coin-operated bowling alleys, shuffleboard, video or electronic devices or any other type of machine operated as a game of skill for use in connection with gambling and which when operated does not deliver, as a result of the application of an element of chance, any money, property, merchandise or other forms of consideration or which through its operation does not entitle a person to receive, as a result of the application of an element of chance, any money or property and which contains no automatic payoff device or provides for a payoff by any other means or in any other manner, excepting any game replay. 
    Operator means any person who is in charge of or who has control over the operation of any mechanical amusement device. 
    Owner means any person who owns, has title to, or has control over the operation of any mechanical amusement device. 
(Code 1974, § 5-127) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-102. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to mechanical amusement devices located and operated in private residences for the private and nonbusiness use of the family members therein and their guests. With respect to the use and operation of mechanical amusement devices by schools, churches, fraternal societies, or any other nonprofit organization or association, the city council may exempt such use from the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 5-139) 
Sec. 10-103. - Conduct on premises. 
    No owner, operator or location owner, by themselves, directly or indirectly, or acting through any agent, manager, lessee or employee, shall, with respect to the following conduct in or about the premises in which the mechanical amusement devices regulated by this article are located and being operated: 
(1)  Permit any indecent, immoral or profane language or any indecent, immoral or disorderly conduct to take place in or about such premises or, having knowledge of such language or conduct being conducted in or about such premises, fail to take active steps to cause such language or conduct to immediately cease; 
(2)  Permit the licensed premises and the area thereabout to become a gathering place for disorderly conduct of any type or fail to take active steps to eliminate such licensed premises becoming such a gathering place upon knowledge of such occurrence; 
(3)  Permit any individual to loiter in or about the premises or, having knowledge of such action, fail to take active steps to eliminate such conduct; 
(4)  Permit immoral, vulgar, lewd, obscene or improper conduct in or about the premises or, having knowledge of such acts occurring on the premises, fail to take active steps to eliminate such conduct; 
(5)  Permit gambling or the use, possession or presence of gambling paraphernalia in or about the premises or, having knowledge of such acts taking place in or about the premises, fail to take active steps to eliminate such conduct; 
(6)  Permit intoxicated individuals in or about the premises or, having knowledge of the presence of such persons in or about the premises, fail to take active steps to remove such persons from the premises; 
(7)  Permit any minor individual to be upon the premises in violation of section 66-333, pertaining to curfew hours, or, having knowledge of the presence of such persons in violation of this provision, fail to take active steps to remove such persons from the premises; 
(8)  Permit the possession, use, selling, distributing, or giving away of any alcoholic liquor or beer on the premises or, having knowledge of such occurrence on the premises, fail to take active steps to eliminate such conduct. The prohibition contained in this subsection shall not apply to the premises if a state liquor control commission license is in effect on the licensed premises; 
(9)  Permit the possession or use of any drug or narcotic or controlled substance, including marijuana, on the premises or, having knowledge of the occurrence of such conduct, fail to take active steps to eliminate such conduct; 
(10)  Permit noise or music to emanate from the premises which is disturbing to the surrounding areas or, having knowledge of the existence of such disturbing conduct, fail to take active steps to eliminate such conduct; 
(11)  Permit on the licensed premises any obstruction of a public view by the use of drawn shades, blinds or screens, either of a permanent or movable nature; or 
(12)  Permit a person under the age of 18 years to be or act as the operator of any mechanical amusement device. 
(Code 1974, § 5-137) 
Sec. 10-104. - Hours of operation. 
    No mechanical amusement devices shall be operated within the city between the hours of 12.00 midnight and 12:00 noon, except where an establishment is licensed by the state liquor control commission, in which event the state liquor control commission regulations shall apply. 
(Code 1974, § 5-136) 
Sec. 10-105. - Gambling; use of non-authorized devices. 
(a)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as permitting the issuance of a license for the operation of any slot machine or as permitting the use of any coin-operated machine in which is incorporated any gambling feature, and all use of such coin-operated machines for gambling purposes of any kind is hereby prohibited, excepting any game replay. 
(b)  No form of gambling shall be permitted in connection with the operation of any mechanical amusement devices licensed under this article. No form of any mechanical amusement device except those devices which are defined under this article shall be permitted to be located or operated in or about any premises in which mechanical amusement devices, as defined in this article, are permitted to be operated under a license issued pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1974, §§ 5-128, 5-138) 
Secs. 10-106-10-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-121. - Required. 
    No person, owner, operator, or location owner shall operate, cause to be operated, or in any way participate in the operation of or in any way give permission or consent to the operation of any mechanical amusement device within the city for business purposes or as an incidental part of some other type of business unless a license has been obtained from the city permitting the operation of such mechanical amusement device within the city. 
(Code 1974, § 5-129) 
Sec. 10-122. - Application. 
(a)  Application for license to operate any mechanical amusement device within the city shall be made and filed with the city clerk. Such application shall be made by the owner and/or operator of the mechanical amusement devices proposed to be operated within the city and shall state the full name and address, including the street and number, of the owner and/or operator of the mechanical amusement devices. If there is more than one owner and/or operator or if the firm is an association, firm, partnership, or other type of organization, the application shall state the full names and addresses, including the streets and numbers, of all the parties who have a financial or ownership interest in the mechanical amusement devices proposed to be operated within the city. 
(b)  If the owner-applicant is a club, society or corporation, the application shall contain a complete list of the officers of such club, society or corporation, with their names and addresses, and such application will also give the state in which such club, society or corporation is organized and the names of one or more persons whom such club, society or corporation desires to designate as its manager or person in charge of the operation of the mechanical amusement devices, together with their address. 
(c)  The application shall also state the following: 
(1)  The location or premises where such mechanical amusement device is to be operated, including the street and number, and the location owner of such premises. 
(2)  The name and address, including the street and number, of the proposed operator of the mechanical amusement devices proposed to be operated in the premises listed in the application, if such operator is a person different than the owner of the mechanical amusement devices. 
(d)  The application shall be signed by the owner-applicant, or in the case of a club shall be signed by its president and secretary. Any false or incorrect statements made on any such applications shall be immediate and substantial grounds for revocation of a license granted pursuant to such application. 
(Code 1974, § 5-130) 
Sec. 10-123. - Investigation; standards for premises; maximum number of devices. 
(a)  Investigation by police department. Prior to the issuance of a license to operate mechanical amusement devices within the city, the city police department shall make an investigation as to the character of the owner-applicant and of the operator if such party is different from the owner-applicant. If the applicant is a corporation, club, society or any other such business organization or entity, then the police department shall make such investigation with respect to the officers of such entity and of the person who is to have the general management of the business for and on behalf of such entity. The police department shall also make an investigation as to the type and nature of the mechanical devices proposed to be used. The city council may reject any application upon the finding by the police department that any of the persons named in the application are not of good moral character, or that any of such persons have previously been connected with any mechanical amusement device operation where the license has been revoked, or if the premises in which the mechanical amusement devices are to be operated are not suitable and proper for such operation to be conducted, as such relates to the public health, safety and general welfare of the city. No application shall be approved until the types of mechanical amusement devices proposed to be used are approved by the police department. 
(b)  Investigation by fire department. The city fire department shall cause an investigation to be made of the premises in which the proposed mechanical amusement devices are to be located to determine whether or not the premises and any electrical equipment proposed to be used therein comply with all of the applicable ordinances, rules and regulations and statutes regulating the premises and equipment. The application shall be rejected if the fire department shall find any existing violation of such codes, ordinances or statutes, or if the fire department shall find that there is a threat of a probable future violation of any such code, ordinance, statute or rule or regulation. 
(c)  Investigation by engineering and building department. Prior to the issuance of a license as provided for under this division, the city engineering and building department shall cause an investigation to be made of the premises in which mechanical amusement devices are proposed to be located and operated as a business to determine whether or not the building involved meets all of the requirements of the building code and other applicable city ordinances in order to determine whether or not the proposed use is permissible under chapter 110, pertaining to zoning, and whether or not the proposed location meets the off-street parking requirements of chapter 110. If the engineering and building department finds that the proposed use violates any of the provisions of the building code, chapter 110, or any other applicable city ordinance, the application for the license to operate the proposed mechanical amusement devices shall be denied. 
(d)  Location on ground floor; maximum number of devices. No license to operate a mechanical amusement device within the city shall be issued where the proposed location of such mechanical amusement device is other than on the ground floor of any structure or building. This provision may be waived by the city council on an annual basis upon a finding that there is no threat to the public's health, safety or welfare. The total number of machines to be installed in an establishment shall not cover in excess of 20 percent of the usable floorspace. Included in the allowable 20 percent usable floorspace there shall be an allowance, as directed by the building inspector, for the mechanical amusement device plus a reasonable amount of operational space. 
(Code 1974, § 5-131) 
Sec. 10-124. - Fee. 
    Each owner-applicant who makes application for a license to operate a mechanical amusement device within the city shall at the time of filing his application pay to the city an annual license fee for such license in the amount established by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 5-132) 
Sec. 10-125. - Expiration; transfer; contents; display. 
    All licenses issued for the operation of any mechanical amusement devices within the city are nontransferable and shall expire on December 31 of the year of issuance. Such license shall list and identify thereon the mechanical amusement devices covered by the license and such license shall be displayed at all times by the licensee in a conspicuous place in the premises in which the mechanical amusement devices are being operated. 
(Code 1974, § 5-133) 
Sec. 10-126. - Right of entry of city officials; periodic inspections. 
    The police and fire departments of the city and the officers thereof, as a condition of the issuance of the license contemplated by this division, shall have access at all times to all premises where mechanical amusement devices are operated within the city, and it shall be the duty of those departments to periodically investigate and inspect all premises in which mechanical amusement devices are operated in order to ensure that such devices are being operated in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 5-134) 
Sec. 10-127. - Revocation. 
    The city council may revoke any license issued under this division for any violation of any of the provisions of this article by the owner, operator, or location owner with respect to the operation of the mechanical amusement devices licensed under the provisions of this division. The city council may revoke any license issued under this division with respect to the operation of mechanical amusement devices within the city for any acts or conduct of customers, patrons, or other persons in or about the premises in which the mechanical amusement devices are being operated, which acts or conduct are in violation of any of the terms or provisions of this article and which acts or conduct are known to the owner, operator, or location owner. The city council may also revoke any license issued under this division upon a determination by the chief of the fire department that the premises in which the mechanical amusement devices are being operated or the manner in which the business is being conducted therein constitutes a fire hazard or for any violation of the applicable fire regulations or code of the city or other statutes of the state pertaining to fire prevention or safety. Any license so revoked by the city council shall not be reissued to the same licensee until at least one year has lapsed from the time of revocation. Any license revoked under the provisions of this division by the city council shall be revoked after a hearing before the council at a time and place to be set by the council for such hearing. Written notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be given to the licensee at least ten days prior to the date of hearing. 
(Code 1974, § 5-135) 
Secs. 10-128-10-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - POOL AND BILLIARD ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 10-151. - License. 
(a)  No person shall conduct, maintain or operate any place open to the public for playing pool or billiards without first obtaining a license therefor. The annual fee for such license shall be as established by the city council. No person shall be granted such a license unless he is over 18 years of age. 
(b)  No such license shall be granted except upon approval of the police chief, the fire chief and the health officer. Such approvals shall be given upon a showing of compliance with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1974, §§ 5-16-5-19) 
Sec. 10-152. - Hours of operation. 
    All billiard rooms and pool rooms within the city shall be closed not later than 12:00 midnight of each day and shall remain closed until 7:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(Code 1974, § 5-20) 
Sec. 10-153. - Admittance of persons under 18 years of age. 
    No person who is less than 18 years of age may remain or loiter in or about any pool or billiard room unless accompanied by a parent or guardian, nor shall the person licensed under this article permit any such minor to remain or loiter therein. 
(Code 1974, § 5-21) 
Sec. 10-154. - Visibility of premises. 
    No person licensed under this article shall permit on the licensed premises any obstruction of the public view by the use of drawn shades or blinds or screens, either permanent or movable. 
(Code 1974, § 5-22) 
Secs. 10-155-10-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - REBOUND TUMBLING AND SIMILAR DEVICES 

Sec. 10-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Moon-walk pad means a device of one-piece nylon webbing construction surrounding an interior pad which affords a full jumping area of not less than 30 feet by 30 feet, with an inside pad height of not less than 40 inches, and an overall outside height of not less than 15 feet. 
    Rebound tumbling center means a place where rebound tumbling equipment is provided and maintained for public use, located either inside or outside of a building. 
    Rebound tumbling equipment means a fabric bed or surface designed to provide resilience by virtue of its own elasticity or that provided by an elastic or spring suspension system or both, within a stable and tested frame and intended to be used for jumping, bouncing or acrobatic tumbling. 
(Code 1974, § 5-98) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-182. - License. 
    Every person exhibiting, showing or operating a rebound tumbling center or moon-walk pad, and charging a fee for such exhibition, showing or operation, shall procure a license therefor. The fee for such license shall be as established by the city council. 
(Code 1974, §§ 5-99, 5-100) 
Sec. 10-183. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  The operator of a rebound tumbling center or moon-walk pad shall procure and at all times maintain in full force and effect a policy of liability insurance for such rebound tumbling center or moon-walk pad insuring him against liability arising from personal injury with limits of not less than: 
(1)  Three hundred thousand dollars for any one occurrence. 
(2)  One hundred thousand dollars for any one person, per occurrence. 
(b)  The operator shall file a true copy of his insurance policy with the city clerk with the application for a license required by this article. 
(Code 1974, § 5-101) 
Sec. 10-184. - Annual inspection. 
    The city engineer shall inspect annually every rebound tumbling center and moon-walk pad. 
(Code 1974, § 5-115) 
Sec. 10-185. - Condition of equipment. 
    Rebound tumbling equipment and moon-walk pads shall be maintained in a state of good repair. Rebound tumbling equipment which has broken springs or broken webbing shall not be used. 
(Code 1974, § 5-102) 
Sec. 10-186. - Restrictions on use of equipment. 
    Each licensee under this article shall enforce and all customers using rebound tumbling equipment or moon-walk pads shall observe and obey the following provisions, which shall be printed in clear, easily read letters not less than one inch in size, and posted in one or more conspicuous and well-lighted locations on the premises: 
(1)  Not more than one person shall use any rebound tumbling device at any one time. 
(2)  No flips, twists or similar difficult routines shall be attempted unless under the immediate supervision of a qualified instructor, or until qualified as demonstrated by an officially acceptable certificate or as determined by the operator. In case of dispute with a patron, the operator's ruling shall be final. 
(3)  No equipment shall be used in street shoes or in bare feet. 
(4)  All patrons shall strictly and promptly comply with requests or requirements of the operator. 
(5)  No equipment shall be used while the person using the equipment is under the influence of any alcoholic beverage or when not in a condition to safely use the equipment, as determined by the operator. 
(6)  No person shall jump from apparatus to apparatus or to any point outside the frame of the apparatus. 
(7)  No actions shall be allowed which will or may seriously distract or interfere with a performer. 
(8)  No children under six years of age shall be permitted to use a rebound tumbling device unless accompanied by a responsible person. 
(9)  No smoking, eating or drinking while using the equipment shall be allowed. 
(Code 1974, § 5-103) 
Sec. 10-187. - Supervision of use. 
(a)  A rebound tumbling center, whenever open for use, shall be under the direct supervision of as many supervisors as are necessary to comply with the provisions of section 10-186. A moon-walk pad shall be under the direct supervision of at least one responsible person whenever open for use. 
(b)  The supervisor shall be observing all equipment units whenever they are in use. 
(c)  Each unit shall be numbered or otherwise clearly designated. 
(d)  A suitable loudspeaker system shall be maintained to enforce rules except where there are less than eight units. 
(e)  There shall be at least one supervisor on active supervising duty for each 12 units or fractional part thereof which are in use. 
(Code 1974, § 5-104) 
Sec. 10-188. - Qualifications of supervisors. 
    A rebound tumbling or moon-walk pad supervisor shall be: 
(1)  Eighteen years of age or over. 
(2)  Of good moral character. 
(3)  Trained and experienced in the supervision and control of personnel, both skilled and unskilled, in the art of rebound tumbling. 
(4)  Physically and otherwise fully fit to manage the facility. 
(Code 1974, § 5-105) 
Sec. 10-189. - Handling and reporting of accidents. 
    The operator of a rebound tumbling center or moon-walk pad shall: 
(1)  Direct to competent care for handling and disposition all accidents and injuries. 
(2)  Unless the city health officer agrees to accept a verbal report, report in writing to the city health officer all accidents which cause unconsciousness, broken or sprained extremities or bones, removal, breaking or loosening of teeth, hemorrhaging or lacerations which may require suturing and eye injuries. 
(3)  Maintain on the premises records of all medical aid or care administered. 
(4)  Keep, in place readily available at all times to himself and his employees, the telephone number of available emergency service. 
(Code 1974, § 5-106) 
Sec. 10-190. - Telephone. 
    The operator of a rebound tumbling center or moon-walk pad shall maintain on the premises a telephone which shall be available for emergency use at all times during which the rebound tumbling center or moon-walk pad is in operation. 
(Code 1974, § 5-107) 
Sec. 10-191. - First aid equipment. 
    The operator of a rebound tumbling center or moon-walk pad shall at all times maintain on the premises, and replenish as necessary, an adequate first aid kit of at least 16 units, as recommended by the American Red Cross First Aid Manual. 
(Code 1974, § 5-108) 
Sec. 10-192. - Sanitation and cleanliness of premises. 
    The operator of a rebound tumbling center or moon-walk pad shall keep the premises and all facilities in a clean condition. He shall provide, as needed to prevent litter, waste containers and appropriate signs. 
(Code 1974, § 5-109) 
Sec. 10-193. - Drinking and toilet facilities. 
    The operator of a rebound tumbling center shall provide on the premises drinking facilities which shall consist of either a sanitary drinking fountain or paper cups available in a suitable, sanitary dispenser. Toilet facilities shall be provided as required by this Code. 
(Code 1974, § 5-110) 
Sec. 10-194. - Layout of equipment. 
(a)  Rebound tumbling equipment shall be located on a level surface in such a way as to be within view of the operator or attendant at all times. 
(b)  The spacing of equipment units shall conform to the following minimum dimensions as measured from the inside edge of the frame of each device: 
(1)  Three feet between the sides of the units. 
(2)  Four feet between the ends of the units. 
(3)  Five feet from the ends of the nearest fence, building or other similar structure. 
(4)  Three feet from the sides or corners to the nearest fence, building or other similar structure. 
(c)  The area surrounding the rebound tumbling equipment shall be surfaced to prevent dust from creating a nuisance and shall have a reasonably level surface of pea gravel or equivalent type of material for safety and dust control. 
(Code 1974, § 5-111) 
Sec. 10-195. - Construction of pits. 
(a)  Pits for rebound tumbling centers shall be so constructed that they will not interfere with the operation of the equipment and of a depth not less than three feet and not more than four feet at the centers. 
(b)  The pits shall be so framed that the rebound tumbling equipment is held in a level position and is supported on a solid, stable surface. Lumber used as framing for pits shall not be less than two inches in thickness and shall be securely connected. 
(Code 1974, § 5-112) 
Sec. 10-196. - Broken springs. 
    Precautionary measures shall be taken to prevent broken springs on rebound tumbling equipment from disengaging from the assembly. 
(Code 1974, § 5-113) 
Sec. 10-197. - Padding. 
    The frames of rebound tumbling equipment shall be completely padded to provide reasonable safety. Pads two inches thick filled with cotton liners shall be deemed to meet this requirement. 
(Code 1974, § 5-114) 
Secs. 10-198-10-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - THEATERS AND SHOWS 

Sec. 10-221. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not extend to any exhibition by the pupils of any private or public school, or to any musical entertainment given by the members and for the benefit of any resident musical society, or to any exhibition of painting, engraving, sculpture or fine arts executed by a citizen of the city, or to any concert or musical entertainment, fair, festival or lecture for the benefit of any church or benevolent object, or to any entertainment by any civic, fraternal, government, religious, charitable or benevolent organization, or to any game, or to any exhibition, race, contest or military exhibition given or managed by any association, club or company that is not conducted for profit. 
(Code 1974, § 5-53) 
Sec. 10-222. - License. 
(a)  No person shall conduct a circus or show without obtaining a license therefor, which shall be known as a show license. 
(b)  No person shall conduct any exhibition, not otherwise licensed under this article, for which an admission fee is charged, without first obtaining a license therefor, to be known as an exhibition license. 
(c)  No person shall conduct a moving picture show, vaudeville, opera house, theater or other place for the giving of plays and other theatrical exhibitions, where an admission fee is charged, without first obtaining a license therefor, to be known as a theater license. 
(d)  The fees for licenses required by this section shall be as established by the city council. 
(Code 1974, §§ 5-47, 5-48) 
Sec. 10-223. - Bond; liability insurance. 
    The city council may, before authorizing the issuance of any license under this article, require the applicant for such license to deposit with the city clerk a cash bond or, in the discretion of the city council, a surety bond with good and sufficient sureties to be approved by the city council, conditioned that no damage will be done to the streets, sewers, trees or adjoining property, and that no dirt, paper, litter or other debris will be permitted to remain upon the streets or upon any private property by such person, and containing such other conditions as the city council may require, and the city council may require that the licensee procure public liability insurance, in such sums as the city council deems adequate for the protection of the public. 
(Code 1974, § 5-52) 
Sec. 10-224. - Display of theater admission prices. 
    The prices for admission to any theater shall be framed and hung at some conspicuous place at the entrance to the theater. 
(Code 1974, § 5-49) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 38; health and sanitation, ch. 54; animals generally in parks, § 70-103; injuring or interfering with animals or birds, § 70-105; animal pound fees, app. A, § A-11. 
State Law reference- Animal control ordinances authorized, MCL 287.290. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Restrictions on animals and birds not commonly kept as pets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any animal or bird within 300 feet of any dwelling, street, alley or public place or permit any animal or bird owned by him or in his possession or control to run at large in any street, alley or public place, or upon the premises of another, without express permission of the owner or occupant thereof, except such animals as are commonly kept or housed as household pets. 
(Code 1974, § 6-1) 
Sec. 14-2. - Disturbing birds or bird nests. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully injure, molest or disturb in any way any birds or any nest, eggs, young or brood of any birds; except that this provision shall not apply to any birds declared by any law or this Code to be pests. 
(Code 1974, § 6-2) 
Sec. 14-3. - Disposal of sick, injured or dead animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, throw or place any dead or fatally sick or injured animal, or part thereof, on any public or private place, or into or on the banks of any stream, lake, pond, sewer or other body of water. 
(Code 1974, § 6-4) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 74. 
Secs. 14-4-14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-31. - Pound established. 
    The city council shall provide a pound in which shall be impounded all dogs that may be found running at large, harbored or owned contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1974, § 6-28) 
Sec. 14-32. - Supervision of pound. 
    A dog warden to be appointed by the chief of police shall be in charge of the city dog pound. 
(Code 1974, § 6-29) 
Secs. 14-33-14-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 14-51. - Duty of police and other officers to impound certain animals. 
    It shall be the duty of every police officer, and every other person who may be appointed by the chief of police for that purpose, to promptly seize, take up and place in the pound all dogs or any other animal or fowl that may be found running at large, harbored or owned contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1974, § 6-9) 
Sec. 14-52. - Redemption of impounded animals; fees. 
(a)  No domestic pet or any other animal shall be released from the city pound to the owner or other authorized person until such owner or person shall pay to the city clerk or the animal control officer, for remittance to the city treasurer, the sum established by the city council for the care, custody and feeding of such animal while in custody, and until such person has procured and produced a proper license for the animal. 
(b)  If an animal is voluntarily surrendered to the pound for care or placement, the owner shall pay to the city a fee as established by the city council. 
(c)  If an animal is presented for, or subjected to, a euthanasia procedure by the pound, the owner shall pay to the city a fee as established by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 6-10) 
Sec. 14-53. - Release of animal upon oath of owner denying violation. 
    If the owner or person entitled to claim any dog or any other animal or fowl which has been seized shall deny, under oath, that such dog or any other animal or fowl was running at large or was unlawfully owned, possessed or harbored within the city at the time the animal or fowl was seized under the provisions of this chapter, then such dog or any other animal or fowl shall be released without the payment of the required sum; but in such case it shall thereupon be the duty of the officer having a knowledge of the facts to forthwith make complaint to a court of competent jurisdiction, charging the person keeping or harboring such dog or any other animal or fowl with the violation of this chapter for which such dog or any other animal or fowl was impounded. 
(Code 1974, § 6-11) 
Sec. 14-54. - Disposition or adoption of unclaimed dogs and cats. 
(a)  All dogs or cats not claimed or adopted and released within five days after being impounded shall be destroyed, or, if the animal is worthy and valuable, the dog or cat shall be sold at public auction to the highest bidder, at the hour of noon next succeeding such five days. However, any impounded dog or cat having been exposed to rabies or any dog or cat that has attacked a person shall be kept until such time and under such conditions as shall be required by the chief of police, and it shall be the duty of the animal control officer to notify the chief of police when there is any good reason to believe there is such a dog or cat in his possession. 
(b)  Dogs or cats may be adopted from the pound by paying the required impound fee, obtaining the required license for the dog or cat and neutering the dog or cat. 
(Code 1974, §§ 6-38, 6-56) 
Sec. 14-55. - Disposal of carcasses. 
    The carcasses of all dogs and cats that have been killed pursuant to this division shall be disposed of in such manner as shall be designated by the chief of police. 
(Code 1974, § 6-39) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 74. 
Sec. 14-56. - Record of impounded dogs and cats. 
    The police department shall maintain a complete record of all dogs and cats impounded under the provisions of this chapter and the disposition of such dogs and cats. 
(Code 1974, § 6-57) 
Secs. 14-57-14-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CRUELTY TO ANIMALS AND RELATED OFFENSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes related to animals, MCL 750.49 et seq. 

Sec. 14-81. - Cruelty to animals.
