    It shall be unlawful to overdrive, overload, drive when overloaded, overwork, torture, torment, deprive of necessary sustenance, cruelly beat, mutilate or cruelly kill, or cause or procure to be so overdriven, overloaded, driven when overloaded, overworked, tortured, tormented, deprived of necessary sustenance, cruelly beaten, mutilated or cruelly killed, any animal or bird, and no person having the charge or custody of any animal or bird, either as owner or otherwise, shall inflict unnecessary cruelty upon the animal or bird, or willfully fail to provide the animal or bird with proper food, drink, shelter or protection from the weather. The cropping of a dog's ears shall be considered to be mutilation or cruelty to an animal within the meaning of this section, unless such cropping is performed by a registered veterinary surgeon while the dog is under an anesthetic. 
(Code 1974, § 6-8) 
Sec. 14-82. - Coloring birds, rabbits or game. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to artificially color, spray or paint any rabbit, bird, game or fowl, or sell, offer for sale, or otherwise dispose of any such colored rabbit, bird, game or fowl. 
(Code 1974, § 6-3) 
State Law reference- Sale of artificially colored animals prohibited, MCL 752.91. 
Sec. 14-83. - Poisoning animals or fowl. 
    It shall be unlawful to throw or deposit poisoned meat, or any poison or harmful substances, in any street, alley or public place, or on any private premises within the city, for the purpose of destroying any animal or fowl. 
(Code 1974, § 6-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.437. 
Sec. 14-84. - Feeding animals unwholesome food or unclean water. 
    It shall be unlawful to feed any animal unwholesome or unsuitable food, or unclean water which is likely to cause or produce disease in the animal. 
(Code 1974, § 6-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.467. 
Sec. 14-85. - Sanitation of premises where animals or fowl are kept. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person keeping or harboring any animal or bird, or any person having possession, care, custody or control of any animal or bird, to keep, permit or allow the excretions, manure and/or offal therefrom to be or remain upon any public or private property not owned, rented or otherwise occupied by such person, unless consented to by such owner, tenant or occupant. 
(b)  Every person lawfully keeping or harboring any animal or bird, or any person having the possession, care, custody or control of any animal or bird, shall keep or cause to be kept all excretions, manure and/or offal therefrom which shall be deposited or accumulated from such animal or bird securely and closely confined to or buried upon his premises in such manner as will prevent it from being scattered onto either public or private property not owned, rented or otherwise occupied by such person, and shall so cover and care for it as to prevent any malodorous or offensive conditions to exist and to prevent any nuisance to arise therefrom. 
(c)  Violations of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(35), 6-7) 
Secs. 14-86-14-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DOGS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Dog Law of 1919, MCL 287.261 et seq. 

Sec. 14-111. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to own, maintain, keep or harbor any dog within the city without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(b)  Application. Application for a dog license shall be made to the city clerk and shall state the breed, sex, age, color and markings of the dog, and the name and address of the applicant and the last known previous owner. The application shall be accompanied by a certificate of a licensed veterinarian showing that the dog has been vaccinated against rabies. 
(c)  Fee. The fee for a license required by this section shall be as established by the city council. The license must be obtained and/or renewed by January 1, each year. 
(d)  Issuance of license and tag; design of tag. The city clerk shall issue to each applicant for a dog license, a license, together with a metal tag, which tag shall contain the number of the license dully stamped or engraved thereon, the year when issued, and date of expiration, together with the words "Trenton, Michigan, Animal License." 
(e)  Expiration. Any license issued prior to July 1, 2013, with an expiration date of July 1, 2013, must be renewed on or before that date and such renewal shall have as its expiration date December 31, 2014. 
(Code 1974, §§ 6-23-6-26, 6-27(a)-(c); Ord. No. 771, § 1, 3-18-2013) 
Sec. 14-112. - "Harboring" or "keeping" defined. 
    Any person allowing any dog habitually to remain and be lodged or fed within his house, store, building, enclosure or premises shall be considered as harboring or keeping the dog within the meaning of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 6-22) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-113. - Liability of owner; evidence of negligence. 
    Every owner and every person possessing or harboring a dog in the city shall be liable for damages for any and all injuries to persons or property that may be caused by such dog on any public highway or other public place, to be determined and collected in appropriate legal proceedings therefor, in which proceedings any failure or refusal by such owner to comply with the requirements of this article shall constitute prima facie evidence. 
(Code 1974, § 6-30) 
Sec. 14-114. - Running at large. 
    No person owning, possessing or harboring any dog shall permit the dog to run at large. A dog shall be deemed to be running at large under the provisions of this section when it is not under leash, securely tied or securely confined within an enclosure. Violations of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(3), 6-31) 
Sec. 14-115. - Noisy dogs. 
    No person shall harbor or keep any dog which, by loud, frequent or habitual barking, yelping or howling, shall cause annoyance to the neighborhood and people passing on the streets. Violations of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(4), 6-32) 
Cross reference- Noise control, § 38-161 et seq. 
Sec. 14-116. - Keeping vicious dogs, biting dogs, or dogs bitten by rabid animal. 
    No person shall harbor or keep a vicious dog or a dog that has been bitten by any animal known to have been afflicted with rabies or which shall have bitten any person. 
(Code 1974, § 6-33) 
Sec. 14-117. - Procedure when dog has bitten person or is suspected of being rabid. 
    Every person owning, keeping or harboring any dog that has been attacked or bitten by any other dog or animal known to be afflicted with or having symptoms of rabies, or which has bitten any person, or which has or is suspected to have contracted rabies, shall immediately notify the chief of police or his designee, and upon the demand of such officer shall immediately produce and surrender such dog for observation at the dog pound for a period of ten days; however, in the discretion of such officers, such dog may be quarantined for a like period of time on the premises of the owner or person who is keeping or harboring such dog. If at the end of such ten-day period such dog has not developed rabies, it shall be released from the dog pound or the quarantine. If the dog has developed rabies within such period of time, it shall be destroyed. 
(Code 1974, § 6-34) 
Sec. 14-118. - Dogs impounded second time for biting to be destroyed. 
    Whenever a dog is brought to the pound or is quarantined a second time for having bitten a person, such dog shall be destroyed, after having been held a sufficient time to meet the requirements of the chief of police for investigation. 
(Code 1974, § 6-35) 
Sec. 14-119. - Allowing quarantined dog to be off of quarantine premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to suffer or allow any dog that has been quarantined to be on the streets of the city or away from the quarantined premises. 
(Code 1974, § 6-36) 
Sec. 14-120 - Tethering of dogs. 
(a)  Tethering means the practice of securing a dog to a stationary object by means of a metal chain or coated steel cable for keeping a dog restrained in its movement. Tethering does not mean walking a dog on a leash, or for temporary grooming, or other professional service. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a person to: 
(1)  Continuously tether a dog for more than three hours per day; 
(2)  Tether a dog on a tether made of anything but a coated steel cable more than ten feet in length; 
(3)  Use a tether or any assembly or attachments thereto to tether a dog that shall weigh more than ten percent of the animal's body weight, or due to weight, inhibit the free movement of the animal within the area tethered; 
(4)  Tether a dog on anything except a buckle-type collar or harness, or tethering on a choke chain or around the dog's neck, or tethered to training collars such as choke or pinch-style collars, or in such a manner as to cause injury, strangulation, or entanglement of the dog on fences, trees, or other man made or natural obstacles; 
(5)  Tether a dog without access to shade when sunlight is likely to cause overheating, or appropriate shelter to provide insulation and protection against cold and dampness when the atmospheric temperature falls below 40 degrees Fahrenheit, or to tether a dog without securing its food and water supply so that it cannot be tipped over by the tether; 
(6)  Tether a dog in an open area where it can be teased by persons or an open area that does not provide the dog protection from attack by other animals; 
(7)  Tether a dog in an area composed entirely of bare earth subject to becoming wet and muddy in the event of precipitation, and without any dry surface area or cover for protection; 
(8)  Tether a dog less than four months of age; 
(9)  Tether more than one dog to a single tether; 
(10)  Tether a dog to a stationary object which would allow a dog to come within five feet of any property line; or 
(11)  Tether a dog without a swivel attached and/or equipped on both ends. 
(c)  The animal control officer, or his/her designee, may in his/her discretion temporarily order a more restrictive tethering requirement if circumstances require and it is not detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the dog. 
(d)  Penalty. A person found responsible for violating section 14-120 shall be deemed responsible for a municipal civil infraction in the amount of $100.00 per day. Any person found liable for violating this section three or more times in a one year time span shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 1, 2-19-2013) 
Secs. 14-121-14-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CATS 

Sec. 14-141. - Registration. 
(a)  Required. No later than January 1 in any year, any person residing in the city owning or possessing a cat shall register the cat with the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Proof of rabies inoculation. The city clerk shall not accept the registration of any cat unless the owner or owner's agent shall present a certificate to the effect that the animal has been inoculated against rabies. 
(c)  Fee. The fee for registration of a cat pursuant to this section shall be as established by the council. 
(d)  Issuance of tag. The city clerk shall, upon presentation of a proper certificate of inoculation and upon an application signed by the owner or agent of the owner of the cat, containing the name, kind, color, sex, age and description of any distinguishing feature or marking of the cat, issue to the owner a license, in the form of a tag or other suitable device. 
(Code 1974, §§ 6-50-6-53; Ord. No. 772, § 1, 3-18-2013) 
Sec. 14-142. - Liability of owner; evidence of negligence. 
    Every owner and every person possessing or harboring a cat in the city shall be liable for damages for any and all injuries to persons or property that may be caused by such cat on any public highway or other public place, to be determined and collected in appropriate legal proceedings thereof, in which proceedings any failure or refusal by such owner to comply with the requirements of this article shall constitute prima facie evidence of negligence. 
(Code 1974, § 6-55) 
Sec. 14-143. - Running at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, or any other person having the possession, care, custody or control thereof, to permit any cat to run at large upon the public streets, walks, parks or other public places within the city. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(5), 6-54) 
Sec. 14-144. - Procedure when cat has bitten person or is suspected of being rabid. 
(a)  Report. If any person is bitten by a cat, it shall be the duty of that person or the owner or custodian of the cat having knowledge of such incident to report such incident to the police department within 12 hours thereafter. If the owner or custodian of any cat has any reason to believe or suspect that such cat has become infected with rabies, it shall be the duty of that person to report this to the police department within 12 hours thereafter. 
(b)  Quarantine. If any report required by subsection (a) of this section is made, the animal control officer shall take such cat into his possession. The cat shall be held in quarantine until a laboratory analysis by a licensed veterinarian is made to determine whether the cat is infected. The chief of police shall promulgate and adopt such rules as deemed necessary for the procedure in all cases and for the disposition of any cat delivered into custody. 
(Code 1974, §§ 6-58, 6-59) 
Secs. 14-145-14-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DOG AND CAT KENNELS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Dog kennels, MCL 287.270, 287.270b. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-171. - Definition. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Kennel means any place where dogs or cats are sold, bred, raised or harbored for the purpose of resale, boarding, training or teaching for commercial purposes, as a hobby or other personal purpose; provided, however, this article shall not apply to kennels harboring no more than three dogs and no more than three cats. 
(Code 1974, § 6-100) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-172. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not more than $500.00 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1974, § 6-107) 
Sec. 14-173. - Zoning requirements. 
    No kennel shall be established or maintained in any area zoned for residential use pursuant to chapter 110. 
(Code 1974, § 6-103) 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 110. 
Sec. 14-174. - Condition and operation. 
    Kennels shall be kept free of dirt, filth, odors and disease, and shall be maintained in general sanitary conditions as near as practicable and shall be operated so as not to be harmful to the health, safety and general welfare of the public. Upon written complaint filed with the city, the animal control officer shall make inspections to determine the conditions of such kennel and shall report such conditions to the city. 
(Code 1974, § 6-105) 
Secs. 14-175-14-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 14-191. - Required; expiration; prerequisites for issuance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a dog or cat kennel commercially or as a hobby within the city unless such person shall have first obtained from the city clerk a license therefor as provided in this division. All such licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year. A license shall be issued to qualified individuals or entities by the city clerk upon presentation of a certificate of immunization that each dog and each cat has been inoculated against rabies for the current year, the registration of each animal's current license, and a certificate signed by the animal control officer stating that the regulations set out in section 14-174 have been fulfilled. 
(Code 1974, § 6-101) 
Sec. 14-192. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Litters. All persons owning, possessing, harboring or keeping in their premises more than three dogs or more than three cats which are three months of age or older shall be presumed to have established a kennel, except that the owner or keeper of a female dog or cat which has given birth to puppies or kittens shall not be required to obtain a kennel license for the litter for the first three months measured from the date of the birth of the litter. Birthing females must remain on-site with the litter, except in cases of illness or death. 
(b)  Existing kennels on residential property. 
(1)  Any person who lawfully owns or keeps more than three licensed dogs or more than three licensed cats on residentially zoned property, prior to January 20, 1992, may retain the licensed animals without obtaining a kennel license provided that he obtains a special pre-existing kennel permit from the city clerk exempting specific dogs or cats by license number. No additional such animals may be acquired. The special pre-existing kennel permit shall be valid for a term of one year from the date of issuance, and shall be annually renewable; however, no renewal shall be issued without a current inspection of the animals and the premises by the city's animal control officer. 
(2)  If for any reason a dog or cat exempted under this subsection is lost, stolen, or given away or dies, and there still remain on the premises more than three dogs or more than three cats, no additional or replacement animals of the same category may be acquired. 
(3)  If for any reason a dog or cat exempted under this subsection is lost, stolen, sold, or given away or dies and there still remain on the premises three or less dogs or three or less cats, there shall be an immediate revocation of the special permit; and no additional or replacement animals of the same category may be acquired without full compliance with this article. 
(4)  The special pre-existing kennel permit shall be issued if, after an inspection, it is determined by the animal control officer that: 
a.  The animals in the owner's or keeper's possession are not creating a nuisance; 
b.  There is adequate waste disposal; and 
c.  There exists no hazard to public safety, health and welfare. 
(c)  Veterinary clinics. Any licensed medical clinic specializing in the treatment of animals which does not commercially board dogs or cats that are not under medical treatment or medical observation shall be exempt from the kennel license requirements provided in this article. 
(Code 1974, § 6-104) 
Sec. 14-193. - Fee. 
    The fee for a kennel license required by this article shall be as established by the city council. No kennel license fee shall be assessed on account of any dog or cat less than three months of age. 
(Code 1974, § 6-102) 
Sec. 14-194. - Revocation. 
    Any license issued under this article may be revoked by the city whenever it is determined by the animal control officer that any licensee is operating and maintaining a kennel in violation of any of the terms and provisions of this article. A licensee shall have ten calendar days to appeal such revocation to the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 6-106) 
Secs. 14-195-14-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - CARRIER PIGEONS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Racing and carrier pigeons, MCL 433.351 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-221. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Carrier pigeons means and includes homing and racing pigeons which have the name of the owner stamped upon the wing or tail, or are banded upon the leg with the name or initials of the owner or with an identification or registration number stamped on the band. 
    Loft means any structure in which carrier pigeons are housed. 
    Racing pigeons means and includes any pigeon registered with any national pigeon racing organization. 
(Code 1974, § 6-71) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-222. - Authority to make additional regulations. 
    The engineering and building department may adopt such reasonable regulations as may be deemed necessary for compliance with this article. Such rules and regulations, when adopted, shall be placed on record in the office of the city clerk and copies thereof shall be furnished on request. 
(Code 1974, § 6-84) 
Sec. 14-223. - Location of lofts. 
    Any pigeon loft established, constructed or operated within the city shall not be located nearer than 20 feet to any residential structure or property line, or nearer than 200 feet to any school, church or place of public assembly. 
(Code 1974, § 6-79) 
Sec. 14-224. - Pigeons creating nuisance or perching on other property. 
    The owners and operators of pigeon lofts shall not allow the pigeons to perch or linger on the buildings or property of others and shall not operate a pigeon loft so as to create a nuisance or allow the pigeons to become a nuisance to the buildings or properties of other persons in the vicinity. 
(Code 1974, § 6-81) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, § 38-221 et seq. 
Sec. 14-225. - Disposal of loft scrapings and manure. 
    All pigeon loft scrapings and pigeon manure shall be placed in covered receptacles until final disposition. 
(Code 1974, § 6-82) 
Sec. 14-226. - Manner of calling pigeons. 
    The owner and operator of any pigeon loft shall summon and call the pigeons contained therein solely by inaudible means such as by use of flags or a silent whistle. 
(Code 1974, § 6-83) 
Secs. 14-227-14-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LOFT PERMIT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Carrier pigeon permits, MCL 433.352. 

Sec. 14-241. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct or operate a pigeon loft or to keep pigeons within the city without first obtaining a permit therefor. 
(Code 1974, § 6-72) 
Sec. 14-242. - Application. 
    An application for a permit required by this division shall be filed by the owner of the property on which the proposed pigeon loft is to be kept, with the operator or keeper of the loft joining and signing the application. The permit application shall be on a form provided by the city clerk and shall be accompanied by the required permit fee and a drawing showing the size and location of the loft, which shall be submitted to the engineering and building department for approval. The permit application shall further be accompanied by a typewritten schedule of the number of pigeons to be kept in the proposed loft together with the leg band identification number or name or initials stamped on each pigeon. 
(Code 1974, § 6-73) 
Sec. 14-243. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for a permit required by this division shall be as established by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 6-74) 
Sec. 14-244. - Issuance or denial. 
    If the requirements of this article are complied with, the city clerk shall issue the permit required by this division. If the city clerk deems that such requirements have not been complied with, the permit shall be refused until the applicant complies with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 6-75) 
Sec. 14-245. - Expiration; renewal. 
    Each permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of its issuance and shall be renewable upon application to the city clerk for renewal periods of one year. Each such application shall be accompanied by the fee established by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 6-76) 
Sec. 14-246. - Limitation on number of pigeons. 
    Each owner, operator or keeper of carrier pigeons to whom the city clerk has issued a loft permit shall keep no more than 40 pigeons. 
(Code 1974, § 6-77) 
Sec. 14-247. - Submission of revised information. 
    Each person holding a permit under this division shall be required to provide the city clerk with a revised schedule of additions to the number of pigeons kept in accordance with this article together with the identification for each pigeon in such form as is required for an original loft permit. 
(Code 1974, § 6-78) 
Sec. 14-248. - Commercial use of lofts prohibited. 
    The holders of permits under this division may use pigeon lofts for the breeding, keeping, training and flying of the carrier pigeons kept therein but shall not use such lofts for the breeding, keeping or raising of pigeons for commercial or market purposes. 
(Code 1974, § 6-80) 
Sec. 14-249. - Inspection of lofts; suspension or revocation. 
    All pigeon lofts shall be subject to inspection by the building and engineering department, and if not maintained in a clean, sanitary and orderly manner and in a condition comparable to neighboring buildings shall be subject to discontinuance at the order of the department or the city clerk, subject to review. The owner shall be allowed upon request to show cause to the department or the city clerk why such permit should not be suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1974, § 6-85) 
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Engineering and building department, § 2-111 et seq.; community development, ch. 26; environment, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; floods, ch. 46; franchises and right-of-way licenses and permits, ch. 50; scattering construction waste, § 74-144; leaving construction debris on sidewalk, § 82-6; permit for wrecking buildings, app. A, § A-75; permit for moving buildings, app. A, § A-76. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Electrician licenses. 
    No person shall do any act for which a license is required by the Electrical Administrative Act (MCL 338.881 et seq.) without such license. Application and examination for such licenses shall be by state examiner through the bureau of construction codes, department of commerce and industry affairs of the state, pursuant to such act. 
(Code 1974, § 9-110) 
Sec. 18-2. - Water supply cross connection control. 
(a)  Adoption of state rules. The city adopts by reference the Water Supply Cross Connection Rules of the state department of environmental quality, being R325.11401 to R325.11407 of the Michigan Administrative Code. 
(b)  Systems affected. This section will affect all public water system services branches that could present a hazard, including those that have been in existence for a good many years as well as new or proposed branches. 
(c)  Requirements. This section requires the installation of a city-approved backflow prevention device on all commercial and industrial water service branches connected to the city's public water system, unless the user can establish without a doubt that his operation presents neither an actual nor a potential health hazard as outlined by the state department of environmental quality. The installation of a backflow prevention device at the service does not relieve the user of the responsibility of providing a safe and adequate supply of potable water for the in-plant consumer. 
(d)  Inspections. It shall be the duty of the engineering and building department to cause inspections to be made of all properties served by the public water supply where cross connection with the public water supply is deemed possible. 
(e)  Fees. The city reserves the right to establish fees for services rendered by the city engineering and building department such as inspections, reinspections, surveys, plan examinations, and testing of devices. Fees are to be set by council action. 
(f)  Right of entry. The representative of the engineering and building department shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by city's water supply system for the purpose of inspecting the premises for possible cross connections. On request, the owners, lessees or occupants of the property shall furnish any pertinent information regarding the piping systems of the property. The refusal of such information or refusal of access shall be deemed evidence of the presence of cross connections. 
(g)  Authority to discontinue water service. The city engineering and building department is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue water service, after reasonable notice, to any property wherever precautionary measures are deemed necessary to protect the public water supply system. Water service to such property shall not be restored until violations are corrected. 
(h)  Enforcement. When violations are found and corrections are needed, the time allowed for compliance shall be contingent upon the degree of hazard involved. Also, a plumbing permit and an inspection are required by the city engineering and building department. 
(i)  In-plant water. The potable water supply made available on the properties served by the public water supply shall be protected from possible contamination as specified by this section and by the state and city plumbing code. Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as "WATER UNSAFE FOR DRINKING." 
(j)  Violations. Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this section, or any written order of the engineering and building department for the city in pursuance thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00 for each violation. 
(Code 1974, § 9-23.1) 
Cross reference- Water system, § 98-31 et seq. 
Secs. 18-3-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- State construction code, MCL 125.1501 et seq. 

Sec. 18-31. - Enforcement. 
    The city assumes responsibility for enforcement of the state construction code. Such code shall be enforced by the engineering and building department. 
(Code 1974, §§ 9-16(a), 9-20(a), 9-22(a), 9-23(a), 9-24(a)) 
State Law reference- Local enforcement of state construction code, MCL 125.1508b. 
Sec. 18-32. - Permit and inspection fees. 
    The fees for permits and inspections required by the state construction code shall be as established by the city council. 
Sec. 18-33. - Violations. 
    Except as specified in section 23(1) and (2) of Public Act No. 230 of 1972 (MCL 125.1523(1), (2)), violations of the state construction code are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $200.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 9-16(b), 9-20(d), 9-22(d), 9-23(d), 9-24(d), 9-100) 
Sec. 18-34. - Permits and bond. 
    Each applicant for a permit for the performance of demolition work on a structure located within the city shall, at the time of application, post a performance bond with the city in an amount equal to the estimated cost of performing the demolition project, which bond shall be forfeited to the city, in the event the project is not commenced within 90 days of application, not completed within the time period set forth in the application, or is interrupted for a period in excess of 90 days, following commencement. 
(Ord. No. 721, § 1, 6-15-2009) 
Secs. 18-35-18-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CONTRACTORS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Business licenses and permits, § 22-31 et seq.; building contractors and related businesses, app. A, § A-42. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Residential, commercial and industrial building contractor means any person engaged in the construction, alteration or demolition of residential, commercial or industrial structures, or a combination of residential, commercial and industrial structures, who for a fixed sum, price, fee percentage, valuable consideration or compensation, other than wages, undertakes or offers to undertake with another the erection, construction, replacement, repair, alteration or any addition to, subtraction from improvement, movement of, wrecking of or demolition of a residential, commercial or industrial structure or combination of residential, commercial and industrial structures, and who is skilled in the planning and superintending of residential, commercial and industrial construction or a combination of residential, commercial and industrial construction, and has a practical knowledge of same, and who is familiar with the state laws and the ordinances of the city governing residential, commercial and industrial construction. 
    Subcontractor means any tradesman who takes a contract from a general contractor or other subcontractor, including, but not limited to, masonry, carpentry, lathing, plastering, cement work, tile work, roofing materials, painting and waterproofing. Mechanics hired by a licensed general contractor on an hourly basis shall not be considered subcontractors. 
(Code 1974, § 9-63) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-62. - Conflicts with state law. 
    Whenever any conflict exists between the provisions of this article and the provisions of any state law on the same subject matter, the applicable provision of the state law shall prevail. 
(Code 1974, § 9-64) 
Sec. 18-63. - Violations; employment of unlicensed persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this article, or for any person to aid or abet any contractor in violation of the provisions of this article, or to connive at its violation, or to employ an unlicensed person or mechanic or to permit such employment for the purpose of doing or performing any of the acts required under the terms of this article to be done or performed by a person licensed under this article. 
(Code 1974, § 9-74) 
Secs. 18-64-18-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-81. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of residential, commercial or industrial building contractor or subcontractor without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1974, § 9-65) 
Sec. 18-82. - Exemptions. 
(a)  All registered architects and professional engineers may take out building permits in their name without securing a license under this division if they exercise complete supervision on construction of the building. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be deemed a restriction of the right of a property owner to build a residential structure on his own property for his own use or occupancy, provided that such right shall be limited to the construction of one residential structure in any 12-month period. 
(Code 1974, § 9-66) 
Sec. 18-83. - Application; evidence of qualifications. 
(a)  All applications for licenses required by this division shall be made to the city engineering and building department, which shall give approval or disapproval within ten days. 
(b)  The city engineer may require the applicant to submit reasonable evidence of his ability to perform work under his contract, to read and interpret plans and specifications, and to understand his obligations to the public, and be familiar with the provisions of the building code adopted by the city, chapter 110, pertaining to zoning, and the housing laws of the state. 
(Code 1974, § 9-67) 
Sec. 18-84. - Fee. 
    Every applicant for a license or license renewal under this division shall at the time of applying for such license pay the annual fee established by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 9-68) 
Sec. 18-85. - Liability insurance. 
    Before a license is issued under this division, the applicant shall file with the city engineer a certificate of insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state, insuring against claims for personal injury and property damage by members of the public resulting from negligent acts or omissions by the applicant or his agents or employees, all of which insurance shall cover public liability damage for amounts of $50,000.00 for each person and $100,000.00 for each accident, and $25,000.00 property damage per accident. No permit shall be issued for the construction, alteration or repair of buildings or equipment unless or until the necessary evidence of proper insurance has been filed. Every such certificate of insurance shall contain a provision that, before such insurance is cancelled, a notice shall be given by the insurer to the city engineer of the insurer's intention to cancel the policy not less than ten days after receipt of such notice. Failure of the applicant to comply with this provision will be considered sufficient reason to deny the license. 
(Code 1974, § 9-69) 
Sec. 18-86. - Expiration; renewal. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to this division shall expire on December 31 of each year. Permits may be renewed in the office of the city engineer during office hours on any day. 
(Code 1974, § 9-70) 
Sec. 18-87. - Denial, suspension or revocation. 
    The city engineer shall have the right to deny, suspend or revoke licenses issued pursuant to this division if it is considered to be in the best interest to safeguard life, health, property or the general public welfare. 
(Code 1974, § 9-71) 
Sec. 18-88. - Appeals. 
    When, upon action of the city engineer, issuance of a license required by this division is denied, or the license has been suspended or revoked, the contractor or subcontractor shall have the right to formally petition the city council for a hearing on the matter, and the city council may, at its option, set up a public hearing to determine the merits of the case and either affirm or disaffirm the action of the city engineer. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city council shall not in any way be deprived of due process of law, nor shall his right be negated to appeal to the proper courts. 
(Code 1974, § 9-72) 
Sec. 18-89. - Records. 
    Upon issuance of any license required by this division, the name, business address and classification of the licensee shall be kept as a public record in the office of the city clerk, and shall be available for public inspection. 
(Code 1974, § 9-73) 
Sec. 18-90. - Unlawful use of license. 
    No person having procured a license under this division shall permit or allow the use of his name by any other person, directly or indirectly, for the purpose of obtaining a permit to do any construction, installation, alteration or repairs to any building or structure within the city. 
(Code 1974, § 9-75) 
Secs. 18-91-18-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FENCES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 110. 

Sec. 18-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Barrier fence means a fence erected in a front yard, generally on a corner lot, that is designed and intended to prevent or discourage trespass across a lawn area, but does not enclose or encircle the lawn area. 
    Fence means any construction, barrier, or erection encircling either the whole or any portion of any given area. 
    Hedge means any bush or shrub, or any living green fence of any nature, encircling either the whole or any portion of any given area. 
    Landscape feature means a distinctive form placed in a front yard or exterior side yard solely for the purpose of visual esthetics or as a barrier to trespass, but which is not designed or intended to enclose or encircle a lawn area. 
    Partition fence means any fence or hedge which is, or will be, located along a side or rear property line. 
    Protective measures fence means a fence erected for the express purpose of protection of the enclosed area and its contents, in all areas other than residential areas. When such protective measures fence employs barbed wire along the uppermost edge, the minimum height for such fence, below the barbed wire extension, shall be eight feet. 
    Wall means the same as the word "fence" as defined in this section, and all definitions pertaining to a fence shall also pertain to a wall. 
(Code 1974, § 9-86) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-112. - Violations. 
    Unless stated otherwise in this article, violations of the following provisions are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00: 
18-113 
18-114 
18-115 
18-116 
18-119 
18-120 
(Code 1974, § 2-306(a)(13)) 
Sec. 18-113. - Permit for construction or repair. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or cause to be constructed any fence or wall upon any property within the city without first obtaining a permit in the manner set forth in this section. 
(b)  Application. When the owner of property desires to build, repair or relocate a fence or wall, the owner or the owner's contractor shall first apply to the city. The applicant shall provide the following information on the permit: 
(1)  The owner's name and the address of the property on which the fence or wall is to be erected. 
(2)  The name, address and license of the contractor if applicable. 
(3)  A certified property survey prepared by a registered engineer or land surveyor. 
(4)  A graphic portrayal on the property survey of the proposed location of the fence or wall on the property. 
(5)  A description of the size of the fence or wall and the kind of fence or wall the owner intends to erect on the property. 
(c)  Fee. Before a permit will be issued, a permit fee in the amount established by the city council shall be paid. 
(Code 1974, §§ 9-87, 9-88) 
Sec. 18-114. - Protective measures fences. 
    A permit granted by the engineering and building department shall be required of any person wishing to erect a protective measures fence. Such permit shall be granted only after demonstration of the need of such fence. The owner, or agent thereof, of a protective measures fence shall be granted permission to erect necessary and reasonable barriers along the uppermost edge of the protective measures fence that are deemed reasonable for the protection of property within the enclosed areas, in such manner as the engineering and building department shall approve. 
(Code 1974, § 9-96) 
Sec. 18-115. - Materials and design of partition fences. 
    A partition fence or wall constructed or reconstructed within the city shall comply with the following conditions and meet the following standards: 
(1)  Only chainlink, wood, vinyl-clad, PVC, or concrete materials or such other architecturally attractive materials, if approved by the city, shall be bonded or fastened to the posts. Ordinary cinderblock or smooth concrete block, farm fence or chicken wire fence materials are expressly prohibited. 
(2)  All structural parts of a masonry wall shall be securely bonded together with an approved bonding agent, and all structural parts of a fence shall be securely fastened together with fasteners of sufficient size, length and strength to meet design requirements. 
(3)  Wood fences shall consist of lasting and durable wood products customarily associated with outdoor fences. 
(4)  Masonry walls, including barrier walls, shall consist of or be composed of materials in compliance with the applicable requirements of section 110-682 or other such architecturally attractive materials if approved by the city. 
(5)  Except as otherwise permitted in this article, the use of any sharp object such as nails, spikes, broken glass or any other type of exposed, sharp, or pointed instrument designed and intended to discourage mounting or scaling, and which is attached to or imbedded in a fence or wall, is expressly prohibited. 
(6)  No part of any fence or wall shall be electrified in any way that is designed or intended to transmit an electric shock upon contact for the purpose of confinement or to repel trespass. 
(7)  Use of sharp or barbed wire materials may be permitted for security purposes only, and only as follows: 
a.  The wire shall be mounted on a fence or wall that encloses industrial or business property. 
b.  The wire shall be placed atop a wall or fence that is at least eight feet in height, measured from any point on the ground at the base of the wall or fence to the top of the wall or fence. 
c.  Straight wire shall be secured to arms that shall extend upward and inward from the top of the fence or wall, except the arms may extend upward and outward from the top of the fence or wall along a property line when the fence or wall is set back into the property a distance at least equal to the outward projection of the supporting arms at their maximum extension. Rolled or coiled wire shall be securely affixed to the top of the fence or wall. Where the outer diameter of a rolled or coiled wire shall extend beyond the exterior side of the fence or wall along a property line, the fence or wall shall be set back a distance at least equal to the maximum outward circumference of the roll or coil. 
(8)  Nothing in this article shall disallow the use of pointed or narrowly rounded tops on vertical wood members of a picket fence, or decorative points or similar architectural adornments atop a wrought iron fence. 
(9)  Landscape materials shall consist of live plant materials and/or architectural landscape materials customarily used in landscaping, such as but not limited to decorative rock, boulders, statuary, architectural lighting, reflection ponds, etc. 
(Code 1974, § 9-89) 
Sec. 18-116. - Maintenance. 
(a)  Fences shall be maintained so as to prevent them from sagging or leaning and shall be kept in a safe and attractive condition. Wood fences shall be chemically treated, painted or replaced as needed to maintain them in a safe and attractive manner, neat and orderly in appearance. 
(b)  Fences must be maintained so as not to endanger life or property. Any fence which, through lack of repair, type of construction, or otherwise, imperils life or property, shall be deemed a nuisance. The engineering and building department of the city shall notify the owner of the property upon which the fence is located of the existence of such a nuisance, and the nuisance must be abated within 30 days after receipt of such notice. 
(c)  Masonry walls, including barrier walls, shall be maintained in an attractive and safe manner, neat and orderly in appearance. 
(d)  All plant materials shall be live plantings only and shall be maintained in a living, growing condition, neat and orderly in appearance. 
(e)  It shall be deemed the responsibility of the owner of the fence, the owner being the owner of the address for which the permit was issued, to maintain the fence in a proper and safe manner. In the case of hedges or any living green fence of any nature, it shall be the responsibility of the owner to maintain and trim the fence properly and within the confines of his own lot line. 
(Code 1974, §§ 9-90, 9-97) 
Sec. 18-117. - Height restrictions. 
    A fence or wall designed and intended to partition, enclose or encircle property shall comply with the following restrictions by yard: 
(1)  Front yard. Fences in a front yard shall not exceed three feet in height, measured from the ground at the base of the structure to the top of the structure, outside the restricted clear corner vision requirements of this article, and shall not exceed two feet in height, measured from the ground at the base of the structure to the top of the structure, within the applicable restricted clear corner vision area. 
(2)  Exterior side yard. Fences in an exterior side yard shall not exceed a height greater than six feet, measured from the ground at the base of the structure to the top of the structure. 
(3)  Interior side yard. Fences in an interior side yard shall not exceed a height greater than six feet, measured from the ground at the base of the structure to the top of the structure. 
(4)  Rear yard. Fences in a rear yard shall not exceed a height greater than six feet, measured from the ground at the base of the structure to the top of the structure. 
(5)  Partition fences for privacy. Property owners desiring to build a fence, including a hedge fence or wall, for privacy along their rear or side yards in excess of the height restrictions set forth in this section must apply to the zoning board of appeals for special approval. 
(6)  Street corner clear vision restrictions. No fence, wall or hedge fence over two feet in height above the established sidewalk grade shall be permitted within 25 feet of any street intersection measured from the property line, so as to interfere with traffic visibility. 
(7)  Driveway clear vision restrictions. Except for split-rail or two-rail fences, no landscape feature, fence wall or hedge above the height of two feet shall be constructed or placed within a triangular area formed at the intersection of any driveway with any existing or proposed sidewalk, alley, street, or public way and by a straight line extending between such lines at a distance along each line of not less than six feet from their point of intersection. (See the diagram at the end of section 18-118.) 
(Code 1974, § 9-91) 
Sec. 18-118. - Restrictions on construction. 
(a)  Partition fences. Except as otherwise permitted in this article, no fence or wall designed and intended to partition, enclose or encircle residential property shall extend towards a street beyond the minimum required building setback lines of the district, and, except as permitted in section 18-117, no fence or wall designed or intended to partition, enclose or encircle residential property shall be erected on any property on, or parallel to, the front lot line, or within the restricted clear corner vision areas of this article. (See the diagram at the end of this section.) Partition fences and walls shall be restricted to the following locations by yard: 
(1)  Front yard. Shall not extend forward into the front yard beyond the wall of the principal building unless that wall sits behind the minimum required front yard setback line, in which case the fence or wall may extend forward beyond that wall into the front yard to the minimum required front yard setback line. (See the diagram at the end of this section.) 
(2)  Exterior side yard. Shall not extend outward into the exterior side yard beyond the wall of the principal building unless that wall sits behind the minimum required exterior side yard setback line, in which case the fence or wall may extend outward beyond that wall into the exterior side yard to the minimum required exterior side yard setback line. When the exterior side lot line of the property parallels the exterior side lot line of the property across the street and the rear lot lines of both properties abut the rear lot lines of the lots fronting the street on the opposite side of the block, a fence or wall may extend along the exterior side lot line to the rear lot line; except where the exterior side lot line intersects a driveway or an alley, the applicable clear corner vision restrictions of this article shall apply. (See the diagram at the end of this section.) 
(3)  Interior side yard. May extend along the interior side yard lot line from the front wall of the principal building to the rear lot line. 
(4)  Rear yard. May extend along the rear lot line from interior side lot line to interior side lot line, or, in the case of a corner lot, from the interior side lot line to the minimum required exterior side yard setback line, or to the exterior side yard property line if the conditions set forth in subsection (a)(2) of this section apply. 
(b)  Barrier fences. Nothing in this article shall prevent the erection of a barrier fence, hedge or wall designed to discourage trespass across any lawn area, including a lawn area within any minimum building setback requirement of the district, so long as the barrier fence observes the restrictions set forth in subsection (a) of this section and: 
(1)  Does not exceed three feet in height. 
(2)  Does not enclose or encircle the lawn area. 
(3)  Observes the clear corner setback restrictions of this article. 
A barrier fence, hedge or wall may be erected diagonal to, or perpendicular to, an intersecting front or exterior side yard property line, or along an interior side lot line, and may be part of a landscape feature. 
(c)  Landscape features. Nothing in this article shall prohibit the placement of a landscape feature in any front yard, but not within any public right-of-way, provided the applicable clear corner restrictions of this section are met. A landscape feature may consist of, but shall not be limited to, a landscaped earth berm which shall not exceed the height of a barrier fence, outdoor lighting fixtures, live landscape planting materials, and rocks or boulders. A split-rail or two-rail fence that is constructed solely for landscape effect, and which is not designed or intended to partition, enclose or encircle property, may also be permitted. 
(d)  Exterior appearance. Posts, when concealed by the exterior face of a wood fence, shall be placed towards the interior of the property so as to conceal them from view from the exterior side of the fence. All supporting members of any fence shall also be placed on the interior side of the fence so as to conceal them from view from the exterior side of the fence as well. Posts may be exposed to view on the exterior side of a fence only when they are of a finished architectural nature and are an integral part of the architectural appearance of a fence and not just for the purpose of supporting the fence. 
(e)  Construction requirements for residential fences and walls. The following conditions shall apply where applicable to all residential fences and walls: 
(1)  Vertical posts designed and intended to support a wire or wood fence or masonry panels shall extend into the ground to a depth of at least three feet six inches. 
(2)  Walls constructed of masonry materials shall, where required by code, have continuous foundations which shall extend into the ground to a depth of at least three feet six inches, shall be provided with a sloped masonry cap, and shall meet all the structural requirements for foundations and bearing walls as required in the building code. 
(3)  The structural design of a fence or wall shall comply with all requirements applicable to the type and kind of materials to be used in the fence or wall, as set forth and regulated in the building code. 


ALTERNATIVE RESIDENTIAL FENCE AND WALL LOCATIONS 
(Code 1974, § 9-92) 
Sec. 18-119. - Restrictions on fence construction. 
(a)  Front yard. No fence designed and intended to enclose or encircle property shall be erected on or along the front lot line. Hedge fences are excepted, provided they shall be maintained in a living, growing condition, neat and orderly in appearance, and provided further that they shall not exceed 36 inches in height beyond the restricted clear corner vision requirements of this article, and shall not exceed 24 inches in height within the restricted clear corner vision area. 
(b)  Side yard. No fences shall be erected on the side yard line exceeding six feet in height. No fence, except a hedge fence not exceeding 36 inches in height above established grade, shall be erected or maintained nearer the front property line than the front line of the main dwelling thereon. 
(c)  Rear yard. No fences shall be erected on the rear lot line exceeding six feet in height. 
(d)  Partition fences for privacy. Property owners desiring to build a fence for privacy in their rear yard exceeding the height restriction as set forth in this section may do so upon special approval of the zoning board of appeals, provided such fence does not exceed the setback requirements in the building code and chapter 110. 
(e)  Corner lots. No fence over 36 inches in height above the established sidewalk grade shall be permitted within 25 feet of any street intersection, so as to interfere with traffic visibility. 
(Code 1974, § 9-94) 
Sec. 18-120. - Location of fences in residential areas generally. 
(a)  Partition fences. Except as otherwise permitted in this article, no partition fence designed and intended to enclose or encircle property shall extend towards a street beyond the established building line; and, except as permitted in section 18-119, no fence designed or intended to enclose or encircle property shall be erected in any residential area on, or parallel to, the front lot line, or within the restricted clear corner vision area of this article. 
(b)  Barrier fence. Nothing in this article shall prevent the erection of a barrier fence designed to discourage trespass across a lawn, so long as the barrier fence does not enclose or encircle the lawn area. A barrier fence may be erected diagonal to, or perpendicular to, an intersecting front or exterior side yard property line, but shall observe the restrictions set forth in subsection (a) of this section. No barrier fence shall exceed 36 inches in height, and such fences shall be subject to the clear corner vision restrictions of this article or, in the case of a corner lot, the clear corner vision restrictions of section 110-681. A barrier fence may be part of a landscape feature. 
(c)  Landscape features. Nothing in this article shall prohibit the placement of a landscape feature in any front yard, but not within any public right-of-way, provided the clear corner restrictions of this section are met. A landscape feature may consist of, but shall not limited to, a landscaped earth berm which shall not exceed the height of a barrier fence, outdoor lighting fixtures, live landscape planting materials, and rocks or boulders. A spilt-rail or two-rail fence that is constructed solely for landscape effect, and which is not designed or intended to enclose or encircle property, may also be permitted. 
(d)  Clear corner restriction at driveways. Except for spilt-rail or two-rail fences, no landscape feature, fence, or hedge above the height of 24 inches shall be constructed or placed within a triangular area formed at the intersection of any driveway with any existing or proposed sidewalk, alley, street, or public way, by a straight line extending between such right-of-way lines at a distance along each line of not less than six feet from their point of intersection. 
(Code 1974, § 9-95) 
Sec. 18-121. - Screening fences and walls for nonresidential uses. 
(a)  Motor vehicle parts yards. No used motor vehicle parts business shall be established or thereafter maintained on any property unless or until a screening fence, not less than eight feet in height, but higher if necessary, to totally screen the yard from view shall be erected around the periphery of the area of the property on which the storage yard is to be located. Any such screen fence shall be maintained at all times in a clean, safe and attractive manner by the owner or the occupant of the facility, and in accordance with all applicable provisions of this article and the building code. It shall be unlawful to display any motor vehicle parts or materials on or in front of the fence. No such screening fence shall be located closer than ten feet to any property line which abuts a public street. 
(b)  Other uses. Other uses permitted in nonresidential zoning districts as set forth and regulated in chapter 110 shall comply with the screen wall requirements of section 110-682. 
(Code 1974, § 9-93) 
Sec. 18-122. - Fencing of junkyards or coalyards. 
    All fences built or repaired around junkyards or coalyards shall be designed as retaining walls where such fences are used to hold or retain materials or things of any kind and shall be limited in height to six feet; provided, however, that such fences may be erected to a height not to exceed nine feet if the written consent of not less than 50 percent of the owners of property residing within 500 feet of the junkyard or coalyard has been obtained, or unless otherwise restricted as to height by this article; and provided further that a fence of greater height may be erected if ordered by a court having jurisdiction thereof. 
(Code 1974, § 9-99) 
Secs. 18-123-18-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HOUSING AND PROPERTY MAINTENANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-151. - International property maintenance code. 
(a)  Adoption. That a certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the City Clerk of City of Trenton, being marked and designated as the International Property Maintenance Code, 2009 Edition, as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the code of the City of Trenton for regulating the design, construction, alteration, enlargement, repair, demolition, removal, maintenance and use of all building and structures; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions, and terms of said maintenance code on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this section, with additions, assertions, deletions and changes prescribed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Additions, insertions and changes. The International Property Maintenance Code is amended and revised in the following respects: 
    Section 101.1 is amended by inserting "City of Trenton" for "[NAME OF JURISDICTION]." 
    Section 103.5 is amended by inserting "See Chapter 13 of the Trenton City Code, Fee Schedule" for [APPROPRIATE SCHEDULE]." 
    Section 304.14 is amended by inserting "April 1" for the reference to "[DATE]" and "November 30" for the second reference to "[DATE]" in line one. 
(Code 1974, § 17-1; Ord. No. 671, §§ 1,2, 4-19-2004; Ord. No. 711, § 1, 1-22-2008; Ord. No. 748, § 1, 3-7-2011) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, MCL 117.3(k).

Sec. 18-171. - Adoption. 
    The Michigan Building Code and Michigan Residential Code, 2009 Editions, are hereby adopted, incorporated by reference, and shall be applied and enforced by the City pursuant to 1999 PA 245, together with their rules, promulgated pursuant to 1999 PA 230. 
(Code 1974, § 17-4; Ord. No. 752, § 1, 3-21-2011)

Sec. 18-172. - Availability of copies.

(Code 1974, § 17-5) 
Sec. 18-173. - Enforcement officer.
