ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 34-1-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency Management Act, MCL 30.401 et seq. 

Sec. 34-31. - Definitions 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Disaster means an occurrence or threat of widespread or severe damage, injury, or loss of life or property resulting from a natural or human-made cause, including, but not limited to, fire, flood, snowstorm, ice storm, tornado, windstorm, wave action, oil spill, water contamination, utility failure, hazardous peacetime radiological incident, major transportation accident, hazardous materials incident, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, or hostile military action or paramilitary action, or similar occurrences resulting from terrorist activities, riots, or civil disorders. 
    Emergency means any occasion or instance in which the governor determines state assistance is needed to supplement local efforts and capabilities to save lives, to protect property and the public health and safety, or to lessen or avert the threat of a catastrophe. 
    Emergency management means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions, other than functions for which the military forces are primarily responsible, for protection against and to minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or by natural disaster. 
    Emergency management volunteer means any person who serves without compensation in the emergency management organization. 
(Code 1974, § 10-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 30.401. 
Sec. 34-32. - General powers of mayor. 
(a)  The mayor may declare a local state of emergency if circumstances within the city indicate that the occurrence or threat of widespread or severe damage, injury, or loss of life or property from a natural or human-made cause exists and, under a declaration of a local state of emergency, issue directives as to travel restrictions on county or local roads. This power shall not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven days except with the consent of the city council. The declaration of a local state of emergency shall be promptly filed with the state unless circumstances attendant upon the disaster prevent or impede its prompt filing. 
(b)  If a disaster or an emergency occurs in the city and is beyond the control of local public or private agencies, the mayor may request the governor to declare that a state of disaster or state of emergency exists in the city, utilizing the procedure set forth in section 14 of the Emergency Management Act (MCL 30.414). The mayor shall comply with the order of the state director of emergency management and cooperate with the state director of emergency management in matters of emergency management. 
(c)  The mayor shall designate a line of succession among the department heads to exercise the powers and duties of the emergency management coordinator in the event of the absence or inability to serve of the coordinator. 
(Code 1974, § 20-3) 
Sec. 34-33. - Power of mayor pro tem to act during absence or disability of mayor. 
    In case of the absence or disability of the mayor, the mayor pro tem shall perform the duties of the mayor and have the powers granted to the mayor under the provisions of this article, during the period of the absence or disability of the mayor. 
(Code 1974, § 10-4) 
State Law reference- Emergency management powers of mayor, MCL 30.410. 
Sec. 34-34. - General emergency management powers of city; mutual aid agreements. 
(a)  The city may: 
(1)  Direct and coordinate the development of emergency operations plans and programs in accordance with the policies and plans established by the appropriate federal and state agencies. Each department or agency of the city specified in the emergency operations plan to provide an annex to the plan shall prepare and continuously update the annex providing for emergency management activities, including mitigation, preparedness, response, and recovery, by the department or agency and those other emergency activities the department or agency is specified to coordinate. Emergency operations plans and programs developed under this subsection shall include provisions for the dissemination of public information and local broadcasters shall be consulted in developing such provisions. Emergency operations plans and programs developed under this subsection shall include local courts. 
(2)  Appropriate and expend funds, make contracts, and obtain and distribute equipment, materials, and supplies for disaster purposes. 
(3)  Provide for the health and safety of persons and property, including emergency assistance to the victims of a disaster. 
(4)  Direct and coordinate local multi-agency response to emergencies within the city. 
(5)  Appoint, employ, remove, or provide, with or without compensation, rescue teams, auxiliary fire and police personnel, and other disaster workers. 
(6)  Appoint a local emergency management advisory council. 
(7)  If a state of disaster or emergency is declared by the governor, assign and make available for duty the employees, property, or equipment of the city relating to firefighting; engineering; rescue; health, medical, and related services; police; transportation; construction; and similar items or service for disaster relief purposes within or without the physical limits of the city as ordered by the governor or the state director of emergency management. 
(8)  In the event of a foreign attack upon this state, waive procedures and formalities otherwise required by law pertaining to the performance of public work, entering into contracts, the incurring of obligations, the employment of permanent and temporary workers, the utilization of volunteer workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase and distribution with or without compensation of supplies, materials, and facilities, and the appropriation and expenditure of public funds. 
(b)  For the purpose of providing assistance during a disaster or emergency, the city may enter into mutual aid or reciprocal aid agreements or compacts with counties, other municipalities, public agencies, federally recognized tribal nations, or private sector agencies, or all of these entities. A compact entered into pursuant to this subsection is limited to the exchange of personnel, equipment, and other resources in times of emergency, disaster, or other serious threats to public health and safety. The arrangements shall be consistent with the state emergency management plan. 
(c)  The emergency management coordinator may assist in the development or negotiation, or both, of a mutual aid or reciprocal aid agreement or compact made pursuant to section 4(3) of the Emergency Management Act (MCL 30.404(3)) and shall carry out the agreement or compact. 
(Code 1974, § 10-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 30.410. 
Sec. 34-35. - Emergency management coordinator. 
    The emergency management coordinator shall be the executive head of the emergency management department. The coordinator shall act for and at the direction of the mayor in the coordination of all matters pertaining to emergency management, disaster preparedness, and recovery assistance within the city. 
(Code 1974, § 10-5) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 
State Law reference- Emergency management coordinator, MCL 30.409. 
Sec. 34-36. - Department of emergency management; emergency management organization. 
    A department of emergency management is hereby created utilizing to the fullest extent personnel and facilities of existing city departments and agencies. The mayor shall be responsible for its organization, administration and operation. The emergency management organization shall consist of the following: 
(1)  A department of emergency management within the executive department of the city government. There shall be an executive head of the department of emergency management, appointed in the manner provided in the Charter for the appointment of the majority of administrative officials specifically enumerated in the Charter, who shall be known as the emergency management coordinator, and such assistants, clerical help, other employees and emergency management volunteers as are deemed necessary to the proper functioning of the organization. 
(2)  Five deputy coordinator with responsibility for financial services, law enforcement, fire control, engineering services, and health and medical services, appointed by the mayor. These shall, so far as possible, be additional duty assignments to existing personnel, and it is the intent of this article that emergency management and disaster assignments shall be as nearly consistent with normal duty assignment as possible. 
(3)  The employees, equipment and facilities of all city departments and agencies suitable for or adaptable to emergency management and designated by the mayor to participate in the emergency management activity. 
(4)  Emergency management volunteers, including persons and private agencies or governmental units offering services to the organization. 
(Code 1974, § 10-2) 
State Law reference- Municipal emergency management agencies, MCL 30.409. 
Sec. 34-37. - Emergency management plan. 
    An emergency management plan shall be adopted by resolution of the city council upon the recommendation of the mayor. In the preparation of this plan, as it pertains to city organization, it is the intent that the services, equipment, facilities and personnel of all existing departments and agencies shall be utilized to the fullest extent possible. When approved, it shall be the duty of all municipal departments and agencies to perform the functions and duties assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness at all times. All officers and employees of the city shall cooperate with and give active support to the mayor and emergency management coordinator in all emergency management operations and they shall comply with all orders of the mayor and emergency management coordinator issued pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1974, § 10-6) 
Sec. 34-38. - Emergency orders and regulations to supersede existing ordinances, orders and regulations. 
    At all times when the orders, rules and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this article shall be in effect, they shall supersede all existing ordinances, orders, rules and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. 
(Code 1974, § 10-7) 
Sec. 34-39. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of this Code for any person willfully to obstruct, hinder or delay the emergency management organization in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this article, or to do any act forbidden by any rule or regulation issued pursuant to the authority contained in this article. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to wear, carry or display any emblem, insignia or any other means of identification as a member of the emergency management organization of the city, unless authority so to do has been granted to such person by the proper officials. 
(Code 1974, § 10-8) 
Chapter 38 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; community development, ch. 26; transportation of explosives, § 42-291 et seq.; floods, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 54; manufactured homes, ch. 62; parks and recreation, ch. 70; solid waste, ch. 74; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; subdivisions and other divisions of land, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 98; vegetation, ch. 102; waterways, ch. 106; zoning, ch. 110. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Authority to make additional rules and regulations. 
    The city engineer shall have the power to formulate, promulgate, amend and repeal rules and regulations necessary and proper to accomplish the purposes of this chapter, subject to the approval of the city council, and may seek the advice of the environmental advisory board; however, no such rule or regulation and no such amendment or repeal shall enter into effect unless and until the provisions of this article have been satisfied. 
(Code 1974, § 12-65) 
Sec. 38-2. - Manner of promulgating rules and regulations. 
    All rules and regulations, and amendments and repeals thereof, under this article shall be promulgated by the city engineer after consulting the environmental advisory board, and shall have the same force and effect as the provisions of this article, provided they are approved by the city council after prior publication of the proposed rule or regulation in a paper of general circulation in the city, specifying the text of the proposed rule or regulation, and provided further that no rule or regulation, or amendment or repeal thereof, shall enter into effect until the lapse of 60 days after public notice of its adoption in a paper of general circulation in the city, and of specific notice by registered mail to any individual who is directly and peculiarly affected thereby. 
(Code 1974, § 12-66) 
Secs. 38-3-38-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ENVIRONMENTAL ADVISORY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-401 et seq. 

Sec. 38-31. - Continued. 
    The environmental control board is hereby reconstituted as the environmental advisory board, which is continued and shall serve in an advisory capacity. 
(Code 1974, § 12-54) 
Sec. 38-32. - Composition; appointment of members. 
    The environmental advisory board shall consist of seven members, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 12-55) 
Sec. 38-33. - Qualifications of members. 
(a)  Each member of the environmental advisory board shall have been a resident of the city at least two years prior to the date of his appointment, and shall be a qualified and registered elector of the city. 
(b)  At least two members of the environmental advisory board shall be persons having engineering degrees, unless the mayor finds after diligent effort that such persons are not available for such positions. In addition, the mayor shall make a diligent effort to appoint persons to the board having a variety of backgrounds and interests, so as to reflect a fair cross section of the populace of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 12-56) 
Sec. 38-34. - Term of office of members. 
    The term of the members of the environmental advisory board shall be three years. 
(Code 1974, § 12-58) 
Sec. 38-35. - Compensation of members. 
    Members of the environmental advisory board shall be compensated as provided in section 2-401. 
(Code 1974, § 12-57) 
Sec. 38-36. - Removal of members. 
    Members of the environmental advisory board may be removed by the city council pursuant to the provisions of sections 5.3 and 5.4 of the Charter. 
(Code 1974, § 12-59) 
Sec. 38-37. - Manner of filling vacancies. 
    Any vacancy in the environmental advisory board shall be filled by the mayor with the consent of the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Code 1974, § 12-60) 
Sec. 38-38. - Chairperson. 
    The chairperson of the environmental advisory board shall be selected by the mayor, and shall serve for a term of one year, subject to reappointment for an indefinite number of terms. 
(Code 1974, § 12-61) 
Sec. 38-39. - Meetings. 
    The environmental advisory board shall act officially only at meetings upon adequate notice to all members. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public, except: 
(1)  To the extent necessary to maintain information confidential concerning trade secrets, where so requested by the individuals possessing such trade secrets. 
(2)  When the board is in executive session, in situations involving deliberation as to recommendations or decisions to be rendered by the board. 
(Code 1974, § 12-62) 
Sec. 38-40. - Majority action required; quorum. 
    Official action may be taken by the environmental advisory board only by a majority of those members present at any meeting at which a quorum is present. Four members of the board shall constitute a quorum. 
(Code 1974, § 12-63) 
Sec. 38-41. - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the environmental advisory board shall be as follows: 
(1)  Rendering assistance and advice to the city engineer and to the city council in connection with air, water, and noise pollution, and other forms of environmental protection. 
(2)  Upon the consent and approval of the city council, employing competent legal and engineering consultants to advise the board in connection with any of the powers and duties of the board. 
(3)  Upon referral from the city engineer, reviewing proposed development plans and providing comments as to potential environmental impact and concerns within 30 days, or such other time as may be extended by the engineer. 
(Code 1974, § 12-64) 
Secs. 38-42-38-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ENVIRONMENTAL COST RECOVERY 

Sec. 38-71. - Authorized; procedure. 
(a)  The fire department shall have the power and authority to recover all costs and expenses incurred in conjunction with emergency incidents occurring within the city involving hazardous/toxic materials or hazardous/dangerous conditions. Such costs and expenses shall include, but not be limited to, abatement, disposal, cleanup, removal and remedial activities, including any related third-party costs and expenses necessary to ensure the safety of the city and its residents. Any such costs and expenses shall be the sole responsibility of the individual, owner and/or operator of the facility, property, vehicle, container, discarded material, solid waste or hazardous/toxic material causing or contributing to the emergency incident including pollution of the environment. All assessments against such responsible parties shall be paid to the city treasurer within 30 calendar days of the date of assessment, unless approval for other arrangements is granted by the city administration in cases of hardship, or unless an appeal is filed pursuant to section 38-72. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "hazardous/toxic materials" shall be defined to include those materials listed under 42 USC 9601(14) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA), 42 USC 9601 et seq. 
(c)  The fire marshal shall have the responsibility to investigate the emergency incident and determine its source and cause. The fire marshal shall also make an initial written recommendation to the chief of the fire department as to the circumstances surrounding the emergency incident and the type of hazardous/toxic materials or nature of hazardous/dangerous conditions involved therein, indicating the reasonable costs and expenses incurred in conjunction with the remedial activities as specified in subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  The chief of the fire department shall review the recommendation of the fire marshal and determine whether the emergency incident involved the presence of hazardous/toxic materials or hazardous/dangerous conditions and what reasonable costs and expenses, if any, are to be assessed against each responsible individual, owner and/or operator. 
(e)  The findings and determinations of the chief of the fire department shall be in writing and shall itemize all reasonable costs and expenses incurred in conjunction with the remedial activities as specified in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1974, § 12-119) 
Sec. 38-72. - Appeals. 
(a)  In the case of any assessment by the chief of the fire department pursuant to section 38-71 to which any individual, owner or operator directly and adversely affected thereby takes exception, such person may appeal the findings and determinations of the chief of the fire department to the city council for a recision or modification of such action. 
(b)  Such appeal shall be in writing and taken within ten days of such action by filing the notice of appeal with the chief of the fire department and the council, specifying the grounds thereof, accompanied by such fee as may be established in such cases by rule or regulation. 
(c)  The chief of the fire department and fire marshal shall forthwith transmit to the council all of the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(d)  The council shall select a reasonable time and place for the hearing of the appeal and give public notice thereof, as well as special notice thereof to the individual, owner, or operator. 
(e)  An appeal taken pursuant to this section shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, until the council renders its decision, unless the city administrator certifies to the council, after the notice of appeal has been filed with him, that, by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would cause irreparable harm or prejudice to the individual, owner or operator who has appealed the assessment. 
(f)  The council shall, in writing and within a reasonable time after the hearing, affirm, modify or rescind the action of the chief of the fire department or fire marshal appealed from, and to that end, shall have all the powers of the chief of the fire department or fire marshal. 
(g)  The findings and determinations of the council shall constitute the final and binding decision under this section, and shall not be subject to further review. 
(Code 1974, § 12-120) 
Secs. 38-73-38-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 694, § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 2005, amended article IV in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article IV, §§ 38-101-38-109 and 38-131-38-139, pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Code 1974, §§ 12-84-12-99. 
State Law reference- Soil erosion and sedimentation control, MCL 324.9101 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-101. - Definitions. 
    The City of Trenton adopts as reference the definitions contained in Part 91 and the Rules, as amended from time to time, unless expressly given a different meaning by this article. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
    Accelerated soil erosion means the increased loss of the land surface that occurs as a result of human activities. 
    Adjacent property means any property, public or private, not contained within the application, whether or not owned by the applicant. 
    Applicant means any person or company that is making application for a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit. Applicant may be the property owner or a designated agent of the property owner on which an earth change will take place. Designated agent must have a written statement from landowner authorizing him/her to secure a permit in the landowner's name. 
    Cease and desist order means an order that stops only that work relative to a project which is causing a violation of Part 91, the Rules, or this article until said violation is corrected. 
    Certificate of completion means a signed written statement by the city engineer that specific construction has been inspected and found to comply (including permanent stabilization) with all soil erosion and sedimentation control plans and specifications. 
    City engineer means the City Engineer of the City of Trenton or their duly authorized representative. 
    Department means the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality. 
    Earth change means A human-made change in the natural cover or topography of land, including cut and fill activities, which may result in or contribute to soil erosion or sedimentation of the waters of the state. Earth change does not include plowing and tilling of the soil for purpose of crop production. 
    Excavation or cut means any act by which soil or rock is cut into, dug, quarried, uncovered, removed, displaced or relocated and shall include the conditions resulting therefrom. 
    Floodplain means that area which would be inundated by storm runoff or floodwater equivalent to that which would occur with a rainfall or flood of 100-year recurrence frequency. 
    Grading means any stripping, excavating, filling, balancing, stockpiling or combination thereof, and shall include the land in its excavated or filled condition. 
    Lake means the Great Lakes and all natural and artificial inland lakes or impoundments that have definite banks, a bed, visible evidence of a continued occurrence of water, and a surface area of water that is equal to, or greater than, 1 acre. "Lake" does not include sediment basins and basins constructed for the sole purpose of storm water retention, cooling water, or treating polluted water. 
    Landowner means the person who owns or holds a recorded easement on the property or who is engaged in construction in a public right-of-way in accordance with Sections 14, 14, 15, and 16 of Act 368 of the Public Acts of 1925, as amended, being MCL 247.183-247.186. 
    Nonerosive velocity means a rate of water movement that is not conducive to the development of accelerated soil erosion. 
    Part 91 means Part 91, Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control, of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, Act Number 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, as amended from time to time, being MCL 324.9101 to 324.9123a. 
    Permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures means those control measures which are installed or constructed to control soil erosion and sedimentation and which are maintained after project completion. 
    Permittee : In all cases, the permittee will be the same as the landowner , as defined elsewhere in this section. 
    Person means a natural person, firm, corporation, partnership or association. 
    Rules means the rules promulgated pursuant to the Administrative Procedures Act of 1969, 1969 PA 306, being MCL 24.201-24.328 for the administration of Part 91 as amended from time to time. 
    Runoff means water that runs off the land as a result of melting snow or rainfall which does not percolate into the ground or which is not absorbed by vegetative transpiration or other natural process. 
    Sediment means solid particulate matter, including both mineral and organic matter, that is in suspension in water, is being transported, or has been removed from its site of origin by the actions of wind, water, or gravity and has been deposited elsewhere. 
    Soil erosion means the wearing away of land by action of wind, water, gravity or a combination of wind, water, or gravity. 
    Soil erosion and sedimentation control (SESC) permit means a permit issued to authorize an earth change to be performed under this article. 
    Stabilization means The establishment of vegetation or the proper placement, grading, or covering the soil to ensure its resistance to soil erosion, sliding, or other earth movement. 
    Stop work order means an order that stops all work on a project until any and all violations of Part 91 as amended from time to time, the Rules and this article are corrected, except for remedial measures to correct the violation. 
    Stream means a river, creek, or other surface watercourse which may or may not be serving as a drain as defined in Act No. 40 of the Public Acts of 1956, as amended, being MCL 280.1 et seq., and which has definite banks, a bed, and visible evidence of the continued flow or continued occurrence of water, including the connecting waters of the Great Lakes. 
    Stripping means any activity which removes or significantly disturbs the vegetative surface cover including clearing and grubbing operations. 
    Temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures means interim control measures which are installed or constructed to control soil erosion and sedimentation and which are not maintained after project completion. 
    Waters of the state means the Great Lakes and their connecting waters, inland lakes and streams as defined in rules promulgated under Part 91 as amended from time to time, Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control, of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994, PA 451, as amended, and wetlands regulated under Part 303, Wetlands Protection, of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994, PA 451, as amended. 
    Wetland means land characterized by the presence of water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, wetland vegetation or aquatic life, and is commonly referred to as a bog, swamp, or marsh and which is any of the following: 
(1)  Contiguous to the Great Lakes or Lake St. Clair, an inland lake or pond, or a river or a stream. 
(2)  Not contiguous to the Great Lakes, an inland lake or pond, or a river or stream; and more then five acres in size; except this subparagraph shall not be in effect, except for the purpose of inventorying, in counties less then 100,000 population until the department certifies to the commission it has substantially completed its inventory of wetlands in that county. 
(3)  Not contiguous to the Great Lakes, an inland lake or pond, or a river or stream; five acres or less in size if the department determines that protection of the area is essential to the preservation of the natural resources of the state from pollution, impairment, or destruction and the department has so notified the owner; except this subparagraph may be utilized regardless of wetland size in a county in which subparagraph (ii) is of no effect. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 38-102. - Authority. 
(a)  The city hereby adopts by reference Part 91, Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control, of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, Act Number 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, as amended, being MCL 324.9101-324.9123a.. 
(b)  The city hereby adopts by reference the latest rules promulgated by the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality relative to Part 91, as amended from time to time, and all current rules. 
(c)  The city hereby adopts by reference the standards and specifications of the Wayne County Conservation District. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-103. - Municipal enforcing agency. 
    The City of Trenton Engineering Department is designated as the municipal enforcing agency (MEA) with regards to administering and implementing soil erosion and sedimentation control in compliance with this article Part 91, as amended from time to time, and all current rules, within the municipal limits of the City of Trenton. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-104. - Compliance with article required for site plan or plat approval. 
    No site plan, plot plan or plat shall be approved under this article unless said site plan, plot plan or plat shall be approved until a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit with approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plans have been issued for earth changes that require a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit consistent with the requirements of this article, Part 91, as amended from time to time, and all current rules. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-105. - Compliance with article required for occupancy. 
    No certificate of occupancy for any building will be issued unless the applicant for said certificate shall have obtained a certificate of completion indicating compliance with all soil erosion and sedimentation control plans and specifications and completion of all permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Secs. 38-106-38-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 38-131. - SESC permits and fees. 
(a)  SESC permit requirement. Except as exempted by sections of this article, no person shall undertake any earth change (earth changes that are one acre or greater or within 500 feet of the waters of the state) unless they have a valid soil erosion and sedimentation permit with approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plans issued by the municipal enforcing agency. 
(b)  Permit application. A separate soil erosion and sedimentation control application along with soil erosion and sedimentation control plans shall be required for each soil erosion and sedimentation permit. Soil erosion and sedimentation control plans, specifications, cost estimates and timing schedules shall be submitted with each soil erosion and sedimentation control application for a soil erosion and sedimentation permit. The plans shall be prepared or approved and signed by a registered professional engineer, registered professional landscape architect, registered professional architect or other person who, in the opinion of the city engineer, has experience in soil erosion and sedimentation control methods and techniques. The municipal enforcing agency may waive the preparation or approval and signature by the registered professional engineer, registered professional landscape architect, or registered professional architect when the work entails little hazard to the adjacent property and does not include the construction of a fill upon which a structure may be erected. 
(c)  Soil erosion and sedimentation control application; soil erosion and sedimentation control plan requirements. The plans and specifications accompanying the soil erosion and sedimentation control permit application shall contain all necessary data and information as required by the municipal enforcing agency and the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality State prescribed information. All soil erosion and sedimentation control plans shall meet the Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Part 91, Rule 323.1703 requirements. Guidelines for the minimum requirements shall be made available upon request from the municipal enforcing agency. 
(d)  Soil erosion and sedimentation control fees . It is the intent of the city that administration of this article be self-sustaining from fees imposed and to distribute such charges as equitably and fairly as possible, therefore, the council shall from time to time adopt such resolutions setting forth a schedule of fees, as recommended by the city engineer, to be paid as shall be necessary to administer this article. Plan review fees shall be due upon submittal of application for permit and shall cover the initial plan review and review of up to two revisions. All subsequent revisions will require submission of an additional review fee equal to one-half of the original review fee. Permit and inspection fees shall be paid prior to issuance of the soil erosion and sedimentation control permit. Should earth change activities begin prior to the issuance of a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit, the applicant is subject to pay double the normal review, permit and inspection fees, as determined by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-132. - Bond requirements. 
(a)  Performance bond . A certified check, certificate of deposit, an irrevocable letter of credit, or a cash escrow deposit in the amount of the estimated cost of all temporary soil erosion control measures, or in a minimum amount established periodically by the city council, whichever is larger, will be required by the city for any permit required under this article. The total cost shall be estimated by a registered professional engineer, registered professional landscape architect, registered architect, or other qualified person, and shall be subject to review by the municipal enforcing agency. The estimate is due upon application for a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit, and shall account for all of the work contemplated under said permit within the time limit specified on said permit. 
(b)  Maintenance bond. A certified check, certificate of deposit, an irrevocable letter of credit, or a cash escrow deposit in the amount of one-third of the total cost of the permanent soil erosion control measures or in a minimum amount established periodically by the city council, whichever is larger, will be required by the city for a period of not less than two years after the certificate of completion is issued by the municipal enforcing agency for any permit required under this article. 
(c)  Waiver of bond requirements. The bond requirements stated above may be waived at the direction of the city engineer when the proposed earth change is considered minor in nature. Minor projects would be those projects classified as such after reviewed by the municipal enforcing agency. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-133. - Extension of time. 
(a)  If the permittee is unable to complete the work within the time specified on the permit, the permittee may, at least ten days prior to the expiration of the permit, present in writing to the municipal enforcing agency, a request for an extension of time setting for the reasons for the requested extension. In the event such an extension is warranted, the municipal enforcing agency may grant additional time for the completion of the work, but no such extension shall the release the permittee from the requirement under the preceding sections of this article, Part 91, as amended, and all current rules. 
(b)  If the permittee does not extend the permit in the proper fashion and allows the permit to expire, all work will be ordered to stop by a stop work order until such a time that the permit is extended properly by the permittee. The permittee will still be bound to maintain all temporary and permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures during the duration of the stop work order in conformance with this article, Part 91, as amended, and all current rules. 
(c)  The municipal enforcing agency may require a new soil erosion and sedimentation control permit to be applied for if in the opinion of the municipal enforcing agency that the conditions of the original soil erosion and sedimentation control permit are no longer valid due to substantial changes in the conditions of the permitted site. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-134. - Failure to complete work. 
    In the event of failure to complete the work or failure to comply with all of the requirements, conditions and terms of the soil erosion and sedimentation control permit and approved plans, this article, Part 91, as amended, and all current rules, the municipal enforcing agency may order such work as is necessary to eliminate any danger to persons, property or waters of the state and to leave the site in a safe condition and the municipal enforcing agency may authorize completion of all necessary temporary or permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures. The permittee shall continue to be firmly bound under a continuing obligation for the payment of all necessary costs and expenses that may be incurred or expended by the city in causing any and all such work to be done. Any unused portion of the cash deposit or amount collected under the irrevocable letter of credit shall be refunded to the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-135. - Denial of permit. 
    Soil erosion and sedimentation control permits will not be issued where: 
(1)  The proposed work would cause hazards to the public safety and welfare; or 
(2)  The work, as proposed by the applicant, will damage any public or private property or utilities or interfere with any existing drainage to any adjacent property or result in the deposit or placement, by any means, of debris or sediment on any public way or into any waters of the state or create an unreasonable hazard to persons or property; or 
(3)  The land area for which an earth change is proposed is subject to geological hazard to the extent that no reasonable amount of corrective work can eliminate or sufficiently reduce settlement, slope instability or any other such hazard to persons or property; or 
(4)  The land area for which an earth change is proposed may lie within the floodplain of any stream or watercourse (not specifically designated and delineated by the city as an area subject to flood hazard), unless a hydrologic report, prepared by a registered professional engineer, is submitted for review and approval. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-136. - Modifications of approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plans. 
    All modifications of the approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plans must be submitted and approved by the municipal enforcing agency. All necessary sustaining reports shall be submitted with any proposal to modify the approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plan. No earth change in connection with any proposed modification shall be permitted without the approval of the municipal enforcing agency. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-137. - Responsibility of permittee. 
    During earth change activities, the permittee shall be responsible for: 
(1)  The protection of the waters of the state from soil erosion and sedimentation as a result of an earth change. 
(2)  The prevention of damage to any public utilities or services within the limits of earth change and along any routes of travel of the equipment. 
(3)  The prevention of damage to adjacent property. No person shall excavate on land so close to the property line as to endanger any adjoining public street, sidewalk, alley or any public or private property without supporting and protecting such property from settling, cracking or other damage which might result. 
(4)  The permitted activity shall be completed in accordance with the approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plans and specifications, and in compliance with all requirements of this article, Part 91 Rules and the permit issued under this article. 
(5)  The prompt removal of all soil, miscellaneous debris or other materials applied, dumped or otherwise deposited on public streets, highways, sidewalks or other public thoroughfares during transit to and from the construction, where such spillage constitutes a public nuisance or hazard. 
(6)  Notification of the City of Trenton within one week after completing the permitted activity or one week prior to the expiration date of the permit issued under this article, whichever comes first. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-138. - General requirements. 
(a)  Any earth changes shall be conducted in such a manner which will effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion and resulting sedimentation. 
(b)  All persons engaged in earth changes shall design, implement and maintain acceptable soil erosion and sedimentation control measures in conformance with this article, Part 91, as amended, and all current rules promulgated by the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality which effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion. 
(c)  All earth changes shall be designed, constructed and completed in such a manner as to limit the exposed area of any disturbed land for the shortest possible period of time as determined by the municipal enforcing agency. 
(d)  Sediment caused by accelerated soil erosion shall be removed from runoff water before it leaves the site of the earth change. 
(e)  Any temporary or permanent soil erosion control and sedimentation control measures designed and constructed for the conveyance of water around, through or from the earth change area shall be designed to limit the water flow to a non-erosive velocity. 
(f)  All temporary soil erosion control and sedimentation control measures shall be installed before or upon commencement of the permitted earth change activity and maintain the measures on a daily basis. Temporary soil erosion control measures shall be removed after earth change areas are stabilized and permanent soil erosion control measures are installed. 
(g)  Permanent soil erosion control measures for all slopes, channels, ditches or any disturbed land area shall be completed within five calendar days after final grading or the final earth change has been completed. If it is not possible to permanently stabilize a disturbed area after an earth change has been completed or where significant earth change activity ceases, temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures shall be maintained until permanent soil erosion control measures are in place and the earth change area is stabilized. 
(h)  Compliance with all of the provisions of this article, Part 91, as amended, and all current rules shall not relieve the applicant or permittee from complying with all other applicable ordinances of the City of Trenton or from obtaining all other required federal, state or City of Trenton permits. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-139. - Perpetual maintenance requirements. 
    Persons carrying out soil erosion and sedimentation control measures under this article, and all subsequent owners of property concerning which such measures have been taken, shall maintain all soil erosion and sedimentation control measures including, but not limited to retaining walls, structures, plantings and other protective devices. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-140. - Minimum design standards and specifications for erosion and sedimentation control. 
    A person shall install and maintain temporary and permanent control measures in accordance with the standards and specifications of all of the following: 
(1)  Product manufacturer; 
(2)  Wayne Conservation District; 
(3)  Michigan Department of Environmental Quality; 
(4)  Michigan Department of Transportation; 
(5)  Those formally adopted by the City of Trenton Engineering Department. 
If a conflict exists between standards and specifications referenced in this section, then the city engineer or their designee shall determine which specifications are appropriate for the project. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-141. - Exceptions and waivers. 
(a)  The requirement of a permit under this article is hereby waived in the following instances: 
(1)  A beach nourishment project permitted under Part 325, Great Lakes and Submerged Lands, of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 PA 451, as amended being MCL 324.32501 et. seq. 
(2)  Normal road and driveway maintenance, such as grading or leveling, that does not increase the width or length of the road or driveway and that will not contribute sediment to the waters of the state. 
(3)  An earth change of a minor nature that is stabilized within 24 hours of the initial earth disturbance and that will not contribute sediment to the waters of the state. 
(4)  Installation of oil, gas, and mineral wells under permit from the supervisor of wells if the owner-operator is found by the supervisor of wells to be in compliance with the conditions of Part 91, as amended, and all current rules. 
(5)  An authorized public agency is exempt from obtaining a permit but shall notify the City of Trenton of each proposed earth change within the municipal limits of the City of Trenton. 
Although no permits are required under subsection (a)(1) through (5), of this section, the operations and earth changes exempted from obtaining permits must comply with this article, Part 91, as amended, and all current rules. 
(b)  Where it is alleged that there is error or misinterpretation in any order, requirement, decision, grant or refusal made by the city engineer, the municipal enforcing agency shall have the power to hear specific applications and may amend or change such order, based upon the requirements of this article, Part 91, as amended, and all current rules. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-142. - Inspection. 
(a)  The requirements of this article shall be enforced by the municipal enforcing agency. The municipal enforcing agency shall inspect the work and shall require adequate inspection of compaction by a soil engineer or by a soil testing agency, approved by the municipal enforcing agency, unless he determines that such inspection requirements may be waived due to the non-hazardous nature of the earth changes. 
(b)  Upon satisfactory execution of all approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plans and other requirements, the municipal enforcing agency shall issue a certificate of completion. If the municipal enforcing agency finds any existing conditions not as stated in any application, soil erosion and sedimentation control permit, or approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plan and specification, the municipal enforcing agency may refuse to approve further work until approval of a revised soil erosion and sedimentation control plan which will conform to the existing conditions. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-143. - Enforcement; right of entry for inspection. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the existence or pursuit of any other remedy, the City of Trenton may maintain an action in its own name in any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction against any person to restrain or prevent violations in this article. 
(b)  The municipal enforcing agency may enter at all reasonable times in or upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions and practices which may be a violation of this article or the latest rules of the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality promulgated pursuant to Part 91, as amended, and all current rules. 
(c)  The municipal enforcing agency may seek to enforce a violation of this article by notifying the person who owns the land on which the violation is occurring, by certified mail. The notice shall contain a description of the violation and what must be done to remedy the violation and shall specify a time to comply with this article. 
(d)  Within five days after a notice of violation has been issued under this section, a person who owns land subject to this article shall implement and maintain soil erosion and sedimentation control measures in conformance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-144. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be responsible with a municipal civil infraction and may be ordered to pay a civil fine of not more than $2,500.00. 
(b)  Any person who knowingly violates the provisions of this article, Part 91, as amended, and all current rules or knowingly makes a false statement in an application for a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit or in a soil erosion and sedimentation control plan is responsible for the payment of a civil fine of not more than $10,000.00 for each day of the violation. 
(c)  Any person who knowingly violates the provisions of this article, Part 91, as amended, and all current rules after receiving notification under section 38-143(c) is responsible for the payment of a civil fine of not less than $2,500.00 or more than $25,000.00 for each day of violation. 
(d)  A default in payment of a civil fine or costs ordered under this section or an installment of the fine or costs may be remedied by any means authorized under the Revised Judicature Act of 1961, 1961 PA 236, as amended, being MCL 600.101 et seq. 
(e)  In addition to a fine assessed under this section, a person who violates Part 91, as amended, and all current rules, or this article is liable to the State of Michigan for damages for injury to, destruction of, or loss of natural resources resulting from the violation. The court may order a person who violates this part to restore the area or areas affected by the violation to their condition as existing immediately prior to the violation. 
(f)  Lessees, contractors, or other individuals undertaking and earth change, as well as the landowner and on-site authorized agent, are liable for civil penalties prescribed in this section. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 38-145. - Enforcement authority. 
    The city engineer and his/her designees are hereby authorized to issue municipal civil infraction citations or notices of municipal civil infractions pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 694, § 2, 12-5-2005) 
Secs. 38-146-38-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NOISE CONTROL[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Noisy dogs, § 14-115; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-161. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. All terminology used in this article not defined in this section shall be in conformance with applicable publications of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) or its successor body. 
    A-weighted sound level means the sound pressure level in decibels as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. The level so read is designated dB(A) or dBA. 
    Commercial area means any area or property zoned OS-1 (office service district), B-1 (local business), B-2 (planned community business), B-3 (general business), CBD (central business district), WM (waterfront marina), or P-1 (vehicular parking) in chapter 110. 
    Construction means any site preparation, assembly, erection, substantial repair, alteration or similar action, excluding demolition, for or of public or private rights-of-way, structures, utilities or similar property. 
    Day-night average sound level (L dn ) means the 24-hour energy average of the A-weighted sound pressure level, with the levels during the period from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. the following day increased by ten dB(A) before averaging. 
    Decibel (dB) is a unit for measuring the volume of a sound, equal to 20 times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of the pressure of the sound measured to the reference pressure, which is 20 micropascals (20 micronewtons per square meter). 
    Demolition means any dismantling, intentional destruction or removal of structures, utilities, public or private right-of-way surfaces, or similar property. 
    Emergency means any occurrence or set of circumstances involving actual or imminent physical trauma or property damage which demands immediate action. 
    Emergency work means any work performed for the purpose of preventing or alleviating the physical trauma or property damage threatened or caused by an emergency. 
    Equivalent A-weighted sound level (L eq ) means the constant sound level that, in a given situation and time period, conveys the same sound energy as the actual time-varying A-weighted sound. 
    Gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) means the value specified by the manufacturer as the recommended maximum loaded weight of a single motor vehicle. In cases where trailers and tractors are separable, the gross combination weight rating (GCWR), which is the value specified by the manufacturer as the recommended maximum loaded weight of the combination vehicle, shall be used. 
    Impulsive sound means sound of short duration, usually less than one second, with an abrupt onset and rapid decay. Examples of sources of impulsive sound include explosions, drop forge impacts, and the discharge of firearms. 
    Industrial area means any area or property zoned I-1 (light industrial), I-2 (medium industrial) or I-3 (heavy industrial) in chapter 110. 
    Motor carrier vehicle engaged in interstate commerce means any vehicle for which regulations apply pursuant to section 18 of the Federal Noise Control Act of 1972 (PL 92-574), as amended, pertaining to motor carriers engaged in interstate commerce. 
    Motor vehicle has the meaning provided in the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.). 
    Motorboat means any vessel which operates on water and which is propelled by a motor, including, but not limited to, boats, barges, amphibious craft, water ski towing devices and hovercraft. 
    Motorcycle has the meaning provided in the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.). 
    Muffler and sound dissipative device mean a device for abating the sound of escaping gases of an internal combustion engine. 
    Noise means any sound which annoys or disturbs humans or which causes or tends to cause an adverse psychological or physiological effect on humans. 
    Noise disturbance means any sound which annoys or disturbs a reasonable person of normal sensitivities. 
    Powered model vehicle means any self-propelled, airborne, waterborne or landborne plane, vessel or vehicle which is not designed to carry persons, including, but not limited to, any model airplane, boat, car or rocket. 
    Public right-of-way means any street, avenue, boulevard, highway, sidewalk or alley, or similar place, which is owned or controlled by a governmental entity. 
    Public space means any real property or structures thereon which are owned or controlled by a governmental entity. 
    Pure tone means any sound which can be distinctly heard as a single pitch or a set of single pitches. For the purposes of this article, a pure tone shall exist if the one-third octave band sound pressure level in the band with the tone exceeds the arithmetic average of the sound pressure levels of the two contiguous one-third octave bands by five dB for center frequencies of 500 Hz and above and by eight dB for center frequencies between 160 and 400 Hz and by 15 dB for center frequencies less than or equal to 125 Hz. 
    Real property boundary means an imaginary line along the ground surface, and its vertical extension, which separates the real property owned by one person from that owned by another person, but not including intrabuilding real property divisions. 
    Residential area means any area or property zoned R-1 through R-3 (one-family residential), RM-1 (multiple-family residential-low rise), RM-2 (multiple-family residential-high rise), RT (two-family residential), or MH (mobile home park district) in chapter 110. 
    RMS sound pressure means the square root of the time average square of the sound pressure, denoted P rms . 
    Sound means an oscillation in pressure, particle displacement, particle velocity or other physical parameter, in a medium with internal forces, that causes compression and rarefaction of that medium. The description of sound may include any characteristic of such sound, including duration, intensity and frequency. 
    Sound level means the weighted sound pressure level obtained by the use of a sound level meter and frequency weighting network, such as A, B or C, as specified in American National Standards Institute specifications for sound level meters (ANSI SI.4-1971, or the latest approved revision thereof). If the frequency weighting employed is not indicated, the A-weighting shall apply. 
    Sound level meter means an instrument which includes a microphone, amplifier, RMS detector, integrator or time averager, output meter, and weighting network used to measure sound pressure levels, which satisfies the pertinent requirements in American National Standards Institute specifications for sound level meters (ANSI SI.4-1971, or the most recent revision thereof) for a type II meter. 
    Sound pressure means the instantaneous difference between the actual pressure and the average or barometric pressure at a given point in space, as produced by sound energy. 
    Sound pressure level means 20 times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of the RMS sound pressure to the reference pressure of 20 micropascals (20 × 10 -6 N/M 2 ). The sound pressure level is denoted L p or SPL and is expressed in decibels. 
    Vibration means an oscillatory motion of solid bodies of deterministic or random nature described by displacement, velocity or acceleration with respect to a given reference point. 
    Weekday means any day Monday through Friday that is not a legal holiday. 
(Code 1974, § 12-112) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 38-162. - Findings; general policy. 
    Whereas excessive sound is a serious hazard to the public health and welfare, safety and the quality of life, and whereas a substantial body of science and technology exists by which excessive sound may be substantially abated, and whereas the people have a right to and should be ensured an environment free from excessive sound that may jeopardize their health or welfare or safety or degrade the quality of life, therefore, it is the policy of the city to prevent excessive sound which may jeopardize the health and welfare or safety of its citizens or degrade the quality of life. 
(Code 1974, § 12-111(a)) 
Sec. 38-163. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to the control of all sound originating within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 12-111(b)) 
Sec. 38-164. - Enforcement actions. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, in lieu of issuing a notice of violation as provided for in subsection (c) of this section, the noise control officer responsible for enforcement of any provisions of this article may issue an order requiring abatement of any source of sound alleged to be in violation of this article within a reasonable time period and according to guidelines (to be approved by appropriate authority) which the noise control officer may prescribe. 
(b)  An abatement order shall not be issued when the noise control officer or other enforcement official has reason to believe that there will not be compliance with the abatement order. 
(c)  Except where a person is acting in good faith to comply with an abatement order issued pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section, violation of any provision of this article shall be cause for a notice of violation to be issued by the noise control officer or other responsible enforcement agency official according to procedures which the noise control officer may prescribe. 
(d)  The noise control officer shall apply to the appropriate court for an injunction to halt any sound which exposes any person, except those excluded pursuant to subsection (e) of this section, to continuous sound levels in excess of those provided in section 38-193. 
(e)  No order pursuant to subsection (d) of this section shall be issued if the only persons exposed to sound levels in excess of those listed in section 38-193 are exposed as a result of: 
(1)  Trespass; 
(2)  Invitation upon private property by the person causing or permitting the sound; or 
(3)  Employment by the person or a contractor of the person causing or permitting the sound. 
(f)  Any person subject to an order issued pursuant to subsection (d) of this section shall comply with such order until the sound is brought into compliance with the order, as determined by the noise control officer, or a judicial order has superseded the noise control officer's order. 
(g)  No provision of this article shall be construed to impair any common law or statutory cause of action, or legal remedy therefrom, of any person for injury or damage arising from any violation of this article or from other law. 
(Code 1974, § 12-118(b)-(e)) 
Sec. 38-165. - Enforcement officers. 
(a)  Noise control officers. The noise control program established by this article shall be administered by the chief of police of the city and/or the city engineer and/or their designees, as set forth in subsection (b) of this section, referred to in this article as noise control officers. 
(b)  Powers. In order to implement and enforce this article and for the general purpose of sound and vibration abatement and control, the noise control officer shall have, in addition to any other authority vested in him, the following powers: 
(1)  Review of public and private projects. The noise control officer may review public and private projects for compliance with this article, if such projects are likely to cause sound in violation of this article. 
(2)  Inspections. 
a.  The noise control officer or his representatives, upon presentation of proper credentials, may enter and inspect any private property or place, and inspect any report or records at any reasonable time when granted permission by the owner, or by some other person with apparent authority to act for the owner. When permission is refused or cannot be obtained, a search warrant may be obtained from a court of competent jurisdiction upon showing of probable cause to believe that a violation of this article may exist. Such inspection may include administration of any necessary tests. 
b.  The noise control officer may stop any motor vehicle, motorcycle or motorboat operated on a public right-of-way, public space or public waterway reasonably suspected of violating any provision of this article, and issue a notice of violation or abatement order, which may require the motor vehicle, motorcycle or motorboat to be inspected or tested as the police may reasonably require. 
(c)  Duties. In order to implement and enforce this article effectively, the noise control officer shall: 
(1)  Standards, testing methods and procedures. Promulgate standards, testing methods and procedures. Standards, testing methods and procedures as published by ANSI shall be used by the noise control officer. 
(2)  Investigate and pursue violations. In consonance with subsection (b)(2) of this section and other provisions of this article, investigate and pursue possible violations of this article. 
(3)  Delegation of authority. Delegate functions, where appropriate under this article, to personnel within the engineering and police department and to other agencies or departments, subject to approval of the city council. 
(4)  Periodic reports. Evaluate and report, annually, on the effectiveness of the city noise control program and make recommendations for any legislative or budgetary changes necessary to improve the program. This report shall be made to the city environmental control board, which may amend it after consultation with the noise control officer and then submit it to the council for approval. 
(Code 1974, § 12-113) 
Sec. 38-166. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  No person shall unreasonably make, continue or cause to be made or continued any noise disturbance. 
(b)  The following acts, and the causing thereof, are declared to be in violation of this article: 
(1)  Radios, television sets, musical instruments and similar devices. Operating, playing or permitting the operation or playing of any radio, television, phonograph, drum, musical instrument, sound amplifier or similar device which produces, reproduces or amplifies sound: 
a.  Between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day in such a manner as to create a noise disturbance across a real property boundary. 
b.  In such a manner as to create a noise disturbance at 50 feet (15 meters) from such device, when operated in or on a motor vehicle on a public right-of-way or public space, or in a boat on public waters. 
c.  In such a manner as to create a noise disturbance to any person other than the operator of the device, when operated by any passenger on a common carrier. 
(2)  Loudspeakers and public address systems. Using or operating any loudspeaker, public address system, or similar device: 
a.  Such that the sound therefrom creates a noise disturbance across a real property boundary; or 
b.  Between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day on a public right-of-way or public space. 
(3)  Animals and birds. Owning, possessing or harboring any animal or bird which frequently, or for continued duration, howls, barks, meows, squawks or makes other sounds which create a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary. 
(4)  Loading and unloading. Loading, unloading, opening, closing or other handling of boxes, crates, containers, building materials, garbage cans or similar objects between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day in such a manner as to cause a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary. 
(5)  Construction. Operating or permitting the operation of any tools or equipment used in construction, drilling or demolition work: 
a.  Between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day on weekdays or at any time on Sundays or holidays, such that the sound therefrom creates a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary, except for emergency work of public service utilities. 
b.  At any other time such that the sound level at or across a real property boundary exceeds an L eq of 90 dB(A) for the daily period of operation. 
This subsection shall not apply to the use of domestic power tools subject to subsection (b)(12) of this section. 
(6)  Vehicle or motorboat repairs and testing. Repairing, rebuilding, modifying or testing any motor vehicle, motorcycle or motorboat in such a manner as to cause a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary. 
(7)  Explosives, firearms and similar devices. The use or firing of explosives, firearms or similar devices which creates impulsive sound so as to cause a noise disturbance across a real property boundary or on a public space or right-of-way. 
(8)  Powered model vehicles. Operating or permitting the operation of powered model vehicles so as to create a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary, or in a public space, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day. Maximum sound levels in a public space during the permitted period of operation shall conform to those set forth for residential land use in table 1 of section 38-168. Maximum sound levels for residential property during the permitted period of operation shall be governed by section 38-168(a). 
(9)  Stationary nonemergency signaling devices. Sounding or permitting the sounding of any electronically amplified signal from any stationary bell, chime, siren, whistle or similar device, intended primarily for nonemergency purposes, from any place for more than five minutes in any hourly period. 
(10)  Emergency signaling devices. The intentional sounding or permitting the sounding outdoors of any fire, burglar or civil defense alarm, siren, whistle or similar stationary device except for emergency purposes or for testing as provided in this subsection. 
a.  Testing a stationary emergency signaling device shall occur at the same time of day each time such a test is performed, but not before 7:00 a.m. or after 10:00 p.m. Any such testing shall use only the minimum cycle test time; in no case shall such test time exceed 60 seconds. 
b.  Testing of the complete emergency signaling system, including the functioning of the signaling device and the personnel response to the signaling device, shall not occur more than once in each calendar month. Such testing shall not occur before 7:00 a.m. or after 10:00 p.m. The time limit specified in subsection a of this subsection shall not apply to such complete system testing. 
(11)  Motorboats. Operating or permitting the operation of any motorboat in any lake, river, stream or other waterway in such a manner as to exceed a sound level of 90 dB(A) at the nearest shoreline. 
(12)  Domestic power tools. Operating or permitting the operation of any mechanically powered saw, drill, sander, grinder, lawn or garden tool, snowblower or similar device used outdoors in residential areas between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day so as to cause a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary. 
(c)  The following acts or the causing thereof are prohibited: 
(1)  The removal or rendering inoperative by any person, other than for purposes of maintenance, repair or replacement, of any noise control device or element of design and/or muffler or sound dissipative device. 
(2)  The intentional removing or rendering inaccurate or inoperative of any sound monitoring instrument or device positioned in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1974, § 12-114) 
Sec. 38-167. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  The emission of sound for the purpose of alerting persons to the existence of an emergency; or 
(2)  The emission of sound in the performance of emergency work. 
(Code 1974, § 12-115(a)) 
Sec. 38-168. - Sound levels by receiving land use. 
(a)  Maximum permissible sound levels. No person shall operate or cause to be operated any source of sound in such a manner as to create a sound level which exceeds the limits set forth for the receiving land use category in table 1 when measured at or within the property boundary of the receiving land use but not less than 25 feet from the source. 
TABLE 1. SOUND LEVELS BY RECEIVING LAND USE
