10:00 p.m.-7:00 a.m. 60 
53 Business area At all times 63 Industrial area At all times 75  
(b)  Correction for character of sound. For any source of sound which emits a pure tone or impulsive sound, the maximum sound level limits set forth in subsection (a) of this section shall be reduced by ten dB(A). 
(Code 1974, § 12-116) 
Secs. 38-169-38-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MOTOR VEHICLE NOISE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Motor vehicle noise, MCL 257.707a et seq.; local motor vehicle noise control ordinances to be identical to state act, MCL 257.707e(2). 

Sec. 38-191. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Combination vehicle means any combination of truck, truck tractor, trailer, semi-trailer or pole trailer used upon the highways or streets in the transportation of passengers or property. 
    Decibel means a unit of sound level on a logarithmic scale measured relative to the threshold of audible sound by the human ear, in compliance with American National Standards Institute Standard S1.1-1960. 
    Decibels on the A-weighted network and dB(A) mean decibels measured on the A-weighted network of a sound level meter, as specified in American National Standards Institute Standard S1.4-1971. 
    Exhaust system means the system composed of a combination of components which provides for enclosed flow of exhaust gas from engine parts to the atmosphere. 
    Fast meter response means the meter ballistics of meter dynamic characteristics as specified by American National Standard S1.4-1971. 
    Gross vehicle weight rating means the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a vehicle. 
    Maximum noise means the noise emitted from a vehicle during that manner of operation which causes the highest dB(A) level possible from that vehicle. 
    Muffler means a device for abating the sound of escaping gases of an internal combustion engine. 
    Noise means any sound. 
    Total noise means noises radiating from a vehicle but does not include noises emitted from a horn, siren, bell or other similar device of an authorized emergency vehicle. 
(Code 1974, § 12-117) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 257.707a. 
Sec. 38-192. - Exhaust system. 
(a)  A motor vehicle, while being operated on a highway or street, shall be equipped with an exhaust system in good working order to prevent excessive or unusual noise and shall be equipped to prevent noise in excess of the limits established in this division. 
(b)  For purposes of this division, a motor vehicle does not include special mobile equipment as defined in the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.). 
(Code 1974, § 12-117) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 257.707b. 
Sec. 38-193. - Specific noise limits. 
(a)  A motor vehicle shall not be operated or driven in the city if the motor vehicle produces total noise exceeding one of the following limits at a distance of 50 feet, except as provided in subsections (a)(2)c and (a)(3)c of this section: 
(1)  A motor vehicle with a gross weight or gross vehicle weight rating of 8,500 pounds or more, or combination vehicle with gross weight or gross vehicle weight ratings of 8,500 pounds or more: 
a.  Ninety dB(A) if the maximum lawful speed is greater than 35 miles per hour. 
b.  Eighty-six dB(A) if the maximum lawful speed is not more than 35 miles per hour. 
c.  Eighty-eight dB(A) under stationary run-up test. 
(2)  A motorcycle or a moped: 
a.  Eighty-six dB(A) if the maximum lawful speed is greater than 35 miles per hour. 
b.  Eighty-two dB(A) if the maximum lawful speed is not more than 35 miles per hour. 
c.  Ninety-five dB(A) under stationary run-up test at 75 inches. 
(3)  A motor vehicle or a combination of vehicles towed by a motor vehicle not covered in subsection (a)(1) or (a)(2) of this section: 
a.  Eighty-two dB(A) if the maximum lawful speed is greater than 35 miles per hour. 
b.  Seventy-six dB(A) if the maximum lawful speed is not more than 35 miles per hour. 
c.  Ninety-five dB(A) under stationary run-up test 20 inches from the end of the tailpipe. 
(b)  A dealer shall not sell or offer for sale for use upon a street or highway in this state a new motor vehicle manufactured after April 1, 1978, which produces a maximum noise exceeding the following limits: 
(1)  A motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of 8,500 pounds or more: 83 dB(A). 
(2)  A motorcycle or a moped: 83 dB(A). 
(3)  A motor vehicle not covered in subsection (b)(1) or (b)(2) of this section: 80 dB(A). 
(c)  A person shall not operate a vehicle on a highway or street if the vehicle has a defect in the exhaust system which affects sound reduction, is not equipped with a muffler or other noise dissipative device, or is equipped with a cutout, bypass, amplifier, or a similar device. 
(d)  A person, either acting for himself or as the agent or employee of another, shall not sell, install, or replace a muffler or exhaust part that causes the motor vehicle to which the muffler or exhaust part is attached to exceed the noise limits established by this article or a rule promulgated under this article. 
(e)  A person shall not modify, repair, replace, or remove a part of an exhaust system causing the motor vehicle to which the system is attached to produce noise in excess of the levels established by this article, or operate a motor vehicle so altered. 
(f)  A dealer shall not sell a used or secondhand motor vehicle for use upon a street or highway which is not in compliance with this article. 
(g)  For purposes of this section, vehicles operated on other than a street or highway shall be treated as if they were being operated on a street or highway where the maximum lawful speed is not more than 35 miles per hour. 
(Code 1974, § 12-117) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 257.707c. 
Sec. 38-194. - Violations. 
(a)  A person who violates section 38-193(b), (d), or (f) is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of $100.00. 
(b)  A person who violates section 38-192 or section 38-193(a), (c), or (e) is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(c)  A person who, at the time of installation, knowingly installs a muffler or exhaust system which exceeds the decibel limits of this article shall be liable to the person who receives a citation for violation of section 38-192 for the amount of not less than $100.00, plus reasonable attorneys' fees and court costs. 
(d)  If it is shown that the noise level of a motor vehicle is in excess of the dB(A) levels established in this article, that evidence shall be prima facie evidence that the motor vehicle was producing excessive noise in violation of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 12-117) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 257.707d. 
Sec. 38-195. - Tests. 
    Test instrumentation and procedures used for implementation and enforcement of this article shall substantially conform with applicable standards and recommended practices established by the Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc., and the American National Standards Institute, Inc., for the measurement of motor vehicle sound levels. Rules establishing these test procedures shall be as promulgated by the state department of highways and transportation. 
(Code 1974, § 12-117) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 257.707e. 
Secs. 38-196-38-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - NUISANCES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Pigeons creating nuisance or perching on other property, § 14-224; creation of hazard or nuisance by swimming pools, § 18-362; fire hazards declared nuisance; abatement, § 42-2. 
State Law reference- Public nuisances, MCL 600.2801 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-221. - Definition. 
    Whatever annoys, injures or endangers the safety, health, comfort or repose of the public, interferes with or destroys or renders dangerous any street or highway, allows accumulation of junk or obnoxious matter on private property, or in any way renders the public insecure in life or property is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. Public nuisances shall include, but not be limited to, whatever is declared a nuisance by this Code or by the common and statutory law of the state. 
(Code 1974, § 19-99) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 38-222. - Deposits of offensive or unwholesome substances. 
    It shall be unlawful and is hereby declared a nuisance for any person to throw, place, deposit or leave in any street, lane, alley, public place or square any animal or vegetable substance, dead animal, fish, shavings, dirt, rubbish, excrement, filth, unclean or nauseous water or liquor, hay, straw, soot, offal, garbage, swill or other article or substance whatever which may cause any offensive, unwholesome or nauseous smell, or endanger the health of the public. 
(Code 1974, § 19-101) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 74. 
Sec. 38-223. - Deposits of injurious substances. 
    It shall be unlawful and is hereby declared a nuisance for any person to throw, place, deposit or leave in any street, highway, lane, alley, public place or square, or in any private place or premises, any glass, broken or unbroken, or any metal, stone, earthenware, tacks, cinders or other substances of a nature likely to cause injury to travelers or pedestrians, automobiles, bicycles or vehicles, or to injure any horse or other animal, or which might injure, cut or puncture any pneumatic tire. 
(Code 1974, § 19-102) 
Sec. 38-224. - Stagnant water; unwholesome or offensive excavations, cellars, sewers or other places. 
    If any land, excavation, cellar, sewer, place or premises within the city shall be damp, unwholesome, offensive or filthy, or be covered during any portion of the year with stagnant or impure water, or shall be in such condition as to produce offensive exhalations, the city council or health officer may require the land, excavation, cellar, sewer, place or premises to be drained, filled up, cleansed or purified by the owner or occupant or person in charge of such lot, premises or place. The existence of any condition specified in this section is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1974, § 19-103) 
Secs. 38-225-38-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ABATEMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Nuisance abatement, MCL 600.2940. 

Sec. 38-241. - Notice to owner or occupant. 
(a)  Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code, any officer of the city who shall determine that there exists a nuisance within the meaning of this Code shall cause a notice to be served on the owner or occupant of the premises on which the nuisance exists, requiring such person to abate such nuisance within the time specified in the notice. 
(b)  Service of the notice required by subsection (a) of this section shall be made: 
(1)  By delivering the notice to the owner or occupant personally or by leaving the notice at his residence, office or place of business with some person of suitable age and discretion; 
(2)  By mailing the notice by first class mail to each owner or occupant at his last known address; or 
(3)  If the owner or person is unknown, by posting the notice in some conspicuous place on the premises for five days. 
(Code 1974, §§ 19-109, 19-110) 
Sec. 38-242. - Failure to abate; abatement by city. 
    If any person fails to abate a nuisance in accordance with the notice required by section 38-241, the city shall do so and the cost thereof shall be charged against the owner or occupant of the premises and payment thereof shall be enforced as a special assessment as provided in the Charter and this Code. 
(Code 1974, § 19-111) 
Secs. 38-243-38-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - BLASTING, IMPULSIVE NOISE AND VIBRATION CONTROL FOR MINING 

Sec. 38-251. - Title, purpose and scope. 
(a)  This article shall be known and may be designated as the "City of Trenton Blasting, Impulsive Noise and Vibration Control for Mining article." 
(b)  In interpretation and application, the provisions of this article shall be held to the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(c)  It is not intended by this article to repeal, annul, or in any way impair or interfere with existing provisions of other laws or ordinances, except those specifically repealed by this article. Where this article imposes a greater restriction upon the use of premises than are imposed or required by such existing provisions of law or ordinance, the provisions of this article shall control. 
(Ord. No. 684, 3-21-2005) 
Sec. 38-252. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Blasting means the practice or occupation of rending heavy masses, especially of rock, by means of explosives, as in oil well drilling, quarrying. 
    Class A blasting means ongoing mining and excavating related blasting. 
    Decibel (dB) means a unit of measure, on a logarithmic scale to the base 10, of the ratio of the magnitude of a particular sound pressure to a standard reference pressure which, for purposes of this article, shall be 20 micronewtons per square meter (uN/m2). 
    Impulsive sound means either a single pressure peak of a single burst (multiple pressure peaks separated by intervals no greater than 1/10th of a second) for a total duration of no more than four seconds. 
    Ongoing mining and excavating related blasting means the blasting related operation has been in existence for six months or longer, or will be in operation for six months or longer, where explosives are used in the general course of operations. 
    Property-line-noise-source means any equipment or facility, or combination thereof, which operates within any land use. Such equipment or facility, or combination thereof, must be capable of emitting sound beyond the property line of the land on which operated. 
    Vibration means elastic oscillatory motion of the ground or structure located thereon of a transient or steady-state nature described by displacement, velocity, or acceleration of a particle or structure with respect to a given reference point. 
(Ord. No. 684, 3-21-2005) 
Sec. 38-253. - Permit. 
(a)  Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association to engage in any mining operations within the City of Trenton without having first secured a permit from the city. 
(b)  Application for permit. Applications for permits hereunder shall be made in writing to the city and shall be filed with the engineering and building department. Applications shall contain the name and address of the applicant, shall be signed by the applicant or his duly authorized officer or agent, shall contain a legal description of the property upon which the proposed operation is to be carried on, and a description of the proposed operation as to extent and nature. It shall set forth the name of the owner or owners of the land described therein, and if the applicant is not the owner, it shall have attached thereto the written consent of the owner or owners of such parcel of land for the proposed operation and authorizing the City of Trenton or their duly authorized representatives to obtain immediate entry onto the land, escorted by a representative of the owner, for the purpose of inspection. It shall also contain an agreement that the applicant, if granted a permit, will comply with all the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Permit fee; class A. A nonrefundable annual permit fee in the amount of $150.00 will be required at the time of application. 
(d)  Issuance, duration and expiration of permit. If approved by the city, subject to the regulations below and the provisions of state law, a permit shall be granted to the applicant. A class A permit shall be valid for a period of 12 months commencing with the issuance of the permit. Annual permit renewal may be approved by the city engineer if there have been no permit violations recorded within the previous year. 
(Ord. No. 684, 3-21-2005) 
Sec. 38-254. - Regulations. 
(a)  Impulsive noise regulations (blasting). No person shall cause or allow the emission of impulsive sound (airblast) from any property-line-noise-source to any receiving structure which exceeds the levels tabulated below for specific monitoring systems, when measured at any point within such receiving land, provided, however, that no measurement of sound levels shall be made less than 25 feet from the property-line-noise-source. 
0.1 Hz high-pass system 134 dB 2 Hz high-pass system 133 dB 5 or 6 Hz high-pass system 129 dB C-weighting slow-response system (events not exceeding two seconds duration) 105 dB (C)  
(b)  Vibration regulations. Vibration intensity shall not exceed a particle velocity of 0.5 inch per second for vibrations of semicontinuous nature when measurements are made on the ground next to the foundation or on the basement floor of any dwelling, church, school, or any other residential, commercial, or institutional structure. 
(c)  Vibration regulations; blasting. The intensity of ground motion produced by blasting operations either in construction or in operation of a business at a fixed location, when measured on the ground next to the foundation and not on a direct line between the structure and the point of the blast and at the same distance that the structure is from the point of the blast shall not exceed the following limits on particle velocity. 
Vibration frequencies less than 15 Hz: (a) 0.75 in./sec. for drywall construction (b) 0.50 in./sec. for plaster construction Vibration frequencies of 15 Hz to 40 Hz, peak particle velocity (PPV) limit shall be related to frequency (f) by: PPV = 0.05f (Examples: PPV limit @ 20 Hz - 1.0 in./sec.; @ Hz - 1.50 in./sec., etc.) Vibration frequencies 40 Hz and higher 2.00 in./sec.  
All particle velocity limits apply to the maximum of any one of the three components of motion, longitudinal (or radial), transverse, or vertical, and shall be interpreted as described in U.S. Bureau of Mines Report R. I. 8507 of Appendix B. 
(d)  General blasting regulations. Every permit holder shall be required to observe the following regulations in addition to any special condition or conditions imposed by the city council by any applicable provision of law. 
(e)  Class A permit regulations. The following regulations govern the issuance and use of a class A blasting permit. 
(1)  Blasting insurance required. Any person, firm, corporation or association holding a class A blasting permit must obtain public liability insurance, insuring himself and the City of Trenton in the amounts of $1,000,000.00/$2,000,000.00 aggregate for property damage and for personal injury. 
(2)  Blasting schedule; inspection. The person, firm, corporation or association holding a Class A blasting permit will provide the city with an estimated schedule of all blasting operations, and will also give the city written notice as to the time and occurrence of each blast prior thereto by at least two hours. The city shall have the right to have a staff representative on site at the time of each blasting upon notification to the person, firm, corporation, or association as to that effect. The person, firm, corporation, or association shall compensate the city at the rate of $50.00 per hour, or fraction thereof, for the services of the representative and this cost shall be borne by the permit holder, in addition to the cost of the permit fees. 
(3)  Use and handling of explosives. The use of explosives will only be undertaken by qualified personnel. No blasting operations shall be permitted within 100 feet of the property line of any dwelling, building, school, church, theatre, or other structure which the city engineer may deem hazardous. 
(4)  Seismograph readings. Seismograph readings will be provided by a firm selected by the permittee and approved by the city. Seismograph readings shall not exceed those as prescribed in subsection A of this article. The seismograph will be set up at locations to be determined by the permittee in consultation with the city, including one in the area of the closest Trenton residence. This, however, does not prevent the city from conducting it's own periodic seismographic measurements. In addition, the city shall have the option to select other sites as they feel is necessary to take an adequate reading as to any possible damage to adjacent structures. All costs incurred for the above requirements shall be borne by the person, firm, corporation or association. The Instrument shall be periodically certified and readings shall be consistent within the prescribed limits, and reported to the city monthly. Seismograph recordings will be made with an instrument yielding direct three-component measurement of particle velocity together with measurement of airblast on magnetic tape or film; it shall contain complete internal seismic calibration (i.e., recorder and seismeters) capability. 
(5)  Hours of blasting. Class A blasting permit holders will only be allowed to detonate a maximum of four blasts per week between the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, excluding city holidays which fall during the Monday through Friday period. Blasts other than on Tuesday and Thursday of any week shall require advance notice to the city. In the event a delay in blasting until 4:00 p.m. is necessary due to unforeseen circumstances detrimental to safety, the city engineer may permit a blast to take place after 4:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 684, 3-21-2005) 
Sec. 38-255. - Administration. 
    The city shall authorize the city engineer and his duly authorized agents with the responsibility of enforcing this article. This authorized agent shall be directly under the control of the city engineer and shall, for the purpose of this article, have the powers of a police officer. The city administrator, as legal agent for the city, is hereby authorized to take such legal action in the courts, in the name of the City of Trenton, as he determines necessary to enforce the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 684, 3-21-2005) 
Sec. 38-256. - Variance. 
    Application may be made to the city for a variance from the specific terms of this article in a particular case where the imposition of said article would impose an undue hardship and its strict adherence would not substantially the health, welfare, and safety of the public. The city may, in lieu thereof, impose such other conditions as would be consistent with such case and with the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 684, 3-21-2005) 
Chapter 42 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; emergency services and emergency management, ch. 34; setting fires in parks, § 70-116; burning garbage, § 74-36; placing material in containers that may cause fire, § 74-80; sewers, water mains and fire hydrants, § 86-191 et seq.; use of fire hydrants, § 98-35. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Violation of state law or regulations. 
    No person shall violate any act or law of the state or any rule or regulations adopted by any duly authorized state agency pertaining to fire, fire hazards or fire prevention. 
(Code 1974, § 14-1) 
State Law reference- State fire prevention code, MCL 29.1 et seq. 
Sec. 42-2. - Fire hazards declared nuisance; abatement. 
(a)  The existence of a fire hazard is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and such fire hazard may be abated, removed, corrected, and its continuance enjoined in the manner provided by law for the abatement of nuisances. 
(b)  Whenever the chief of the fire department shall deem a fire hazard to be imminently dangerous or menacing to human life so that the public safety requires its immediate abatement, removal, correction or discontinuance, he may bring, or cause to be brought, in the circuit court a suit for the purpose of abating, removing, correcting or discontinuing such fire hazard. 
(Code 1974, § 14-6) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, § 38-221 et seq. 
Sec. 42-3. - False fire alarms. 
    No person shall turn in, sound or cause to be communicated to the fire department a false alarm of fire. 
(Code 1974, § 14-2) 
State Law reference- False fire alarms, MCL 750.240. 
Sec. 42-4. - Obstructing or altering fire hydrants. 
(a)  No person shall place any building material or any other obstruction whatsoever, nor shall any person responsible for such material or obstruction permit it to remain, within 15 feet of any fire hydrant. 
(b)  With the exception of the fire and water departments, no person or organization, including a property owner's association, shall change, alter or in any way tamper with the color, design or operation of a fire hydrant located within the city, whether on public or private property. In the event a review by the city's fire department results in the identification of any alteration of any hydrant, the city may take restorative action, and the expense associated therewith shall become the responsibility of, and therefore billed to, the homeowner on whose property the hydrant is located or such other persons or organizations responsible for the alteration and reimbursement shall be made to the city within 30 days of receipt of the invoice. 
(c)  Any person on whose property such obstructions to a fire hydrant exists, shall have an affirmative duty to immediately remove or relocate the obstruction to afford ready access to the hydrant. 
(d)  Whenever the chief of the fire department shall deem such material to be an access obstruction which potentially endangers fire and rescue operations and requires immediate abatement, he may order the department to undertake such abatement at the owners expense, reimbursement for which shall be made within 30 days. 
(e)  Violations of this section shall constitute a municipal civil infraction with a minimum penalty of $50.00 per day per violation. 
(Code 1974, § 14-3; Ord. No. 717, § 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 6-7-2010) 
Sec. 42-5. - Use of fire hydrants. 
    No person, except members of the fire department, water department, engineering and building department, recreation department or department of public works, shall use any fireplug, except in the case of emergency, without first securing permission from the fire department for such use, and paying or agreeing to pay for the water used. In no case shall any wrench other than a regulation hydrant wrench be used on any fire hydrant. 
(Code 1974, § 14-4) 
Sec. 42-6. - Setting fire in hotel, roominghouse or other place of public abode. 
(a)  Any person who carelessly, recklessly or negligently sets fire to any hotel, roominghouse, lodginghouse or other place of public abode, or to any bedding, furniture, curtains, drapes or other furnishing therein so as to endanger life or property in any way, shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
(b)  In each sleeping room of all hotels, roominghouses, lodginghouses and other places of public abode, a plainly written notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place as notice of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1974, § 14-5) 
Sec. 42-7. - Obedience to firefighters and fire investigators. 
    Any person who, while in the vicinity of the scene of a fire or a fire investigation, willfully disobeys any reasonable order or rule of a commanding officer, firefighter, fire marshal or fire investigator which is intended to protect persons, property, or evidence, or prevent interference at the scene of such fire or fire investigation, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1974, § 14-7) 
State Law reference- Obstructing or resisting firefighters, MCL 750.241. 
Secs. 42-8-42-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-91 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-31. - Annual report of fire chief. 
    A report of the chief of the fire department shall be made annually and transmitted to the mayor. The report shall contain all proceedings under this chapter, with such statistics as the chief of the fire department may wish to include. The chief of the fire department shall also recommend any amendments to the fire prevention code adopted by this chapter which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. 
(Code 1974, § 14-17) 
Sec. 42-32. - Appointment of inspectors. 
    The chief of the fire department may appoint such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. 
(Code 1974, § 14-18) 
Sec. 42-33. - Interfering with or damaging property of department. 
    No person shall interfere with or damage any firefighting apparatus or equipment or anything pertaining to the city fire alarm system. 
(Code 1974, § 14-19) 
State Law reference- Destruction of fire department property, MCL 750.377b. 
Sec. 42-34. - Possession of duplicates of keys belonging to fire department. 
    No person shall make, or have in his possession, an impression or duplicate of any key belonging to the fire department without the express permission of the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1974, § 14-20) 
Secs. 42-35-42-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EMPLOYMENT[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Firefighters Training Council Act of 1966, MCL 29.361 et seq. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 42-61. - Declaration of vacancy. 
    The fire chief shall request authorization of the mayor to fill, as necessary, any vacancy in the fire department. Upon the mayor's approval, the city shall proceed to fill the vacancy in accordance with procedures prescribed in this division. 
(Code 1974, § 24-16) 
Sec. 42-62. - Appointments. 
(a)  Appointments for employment as officers in the fire department shall only be made after completely fulfilling the preliminary requirements and satisfactory completion of examinations to determine physical and mental fitness. Such examination shall be conducted as provided in this division, and appointments shall be made from a revolving list of qualified applicants after confirmation by the city administrator or mayor. 
(b)  Such list of applicants may be held in effect, and continuing appointments made therefrom, for a period of up to two years from the date of application, which may be periodically updated, or terminated earlier if found to be in the best interest of the city by approval of the mayor. 
(c)  In the absence or shortage of currently available applicants in the department's revolving file, the fire chief may contact local academies or cause public notice to be given for additional applicants, which notice shall be posted on the city's web-site and cable television or published in the local newspaper carrying official council proceedings, that applications for appointment and examination are being accepted by the city. Such applications shall be received and kept in a revolving file at the city's human resource office where it shall be periodically updated for eligibility. 
(Code 1974, § 24-17; Ord. No. 760, § 1, 2-6-12) 
Secs. 42-63-42-80. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Minimum Employment Standards 

Sec. 42-81. - Preliminary requirements. 
    The minimum requirements for fire service officer applicants shall, for the period of application and employment, be as follows: 
(1)  Be a citizen of the United States. 
(2)  Have attained the minimum age of 18 or as otherwise provided by law. 
(3)  Have obtained a high school diploma or have attained a passing score on the general education development test indicating a high school graduation level. 
(4)  Show proof of residency within six months following expiration of the initial probationary period of employment. 
(5)  Possess a valid Michigan motor vehicle operator's or chauffeur's license with a good driving record free of alcohol or drug related convictions, felony and misdemeanor convictions, and multiple civil infractions within the most recent ten-year period. 
(6)  Not have been convicted of a felony as determined by a police department search of local, state and national records. 
(7)  Possess good moral character as determined by a favorable comprehensive background investigation covering school and employment records, home environment and personal traits and integrity. Consideration will be given to any convictions under state, federal or local law, including traffic and conservation law, as an indicator of character. 
(8)  Meet physical requirements as set forth in NFPA 1582, Standard on Medical Requirements for Fire Fighters, promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association, 1997 edition. 
(9)  Meet minimum qualifications for the following categories: 
a.  Firefighter I, as set forth by the department of state police, firefighter training council. 
b.  Firefighter II, as set forth by the department of state police, firefighter training council. 
c.  Emergency Medical Technician Specialist (paramedic required at time of hire) as set forth by the state department of consumer and industry services. 
(Code 1974, § 24-18) 
Sec. 42-82. - Examinations. 
(a)  The examination process for the fire department will be in accordance with equal opportunity employment and related professional standards. 
(b)  Any written examinations shall be conducted by competent authority as designated by the city. 
(c)  The applicant for testing may be charged a fee equal to the actual costs of the examination, payable to the city in advance at the time of notification of the testing time and place. 
(d)  The city shall conduct, or cause to be conducted by persons with recognized experience, an impartial oral interview and a complete review of the applicant's background investigation. 
(e)  Upon the completion of the process described in this section, an employment list or roster for hiring shall be promulgated. 
(Code 1974, § 24-19) 
Sec. 42-83. - Appointment process and probationary period. 
    The fire chief shall make recommendations for appointment as outlined under section 42-62. All such appointees shall be prepared to report for duty within a reasonable period of time after proper notification to permit completion of psychological and physical evaluation and drug screening. Failure to report when required will result in the forfeiture of such appointment. Appointees shall be on probationary status with the department for a period of not less than one year after reporting for duty. If at any time during the probationary period it is found that the employee does not meet the necessary requirements as determined by periodic rating of his superiors, or is found in violation of any offense or regulation, the employee shall be immediately dismissed and replaced. 
(Code 1974, § 24-20) 
Secs. 42-84-42-100. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Continuing Employment Standards 

Sec. 42-101. - Conditions of employment. 
    All employees hired after September 15, 1975, shall be subject to the following continuing conditions of employment: 
(1)  An employee shall be required to maintain a standard of agility and fitness throughout his employment period. All employees shall be tested for fitness and agility at a minimum of once per year under the direction of the department head. The fitness and agility test shall be in accordance with acceptable medical standards and shall take into consideration such factors as an employee's height, weight and age. The employee shall maintain an acceptable score in order to pass the test. 
(2)  All employees shall be required to undergo and pass a medical examination at least once a year. The examination shall show that the employee is free from any physical or mental conditions which might adversely affect the required performance of his duties or which may endanger the employee's life or lives of others. All employees shall be required to have normal visual functions and visual acuity in each eye, correctable to 20/20. Employees must be physically sound, well developed physically, with height and weight in relation to each other, and to age as indicated by accepted medical standards, and in possession of their extremities. The employee shall be free from any chronic diseases, organic diseases, functional conditions or mental instability which may tend to impair his efficient performance of duty. This examination will be as prescribed by the city physician/facility, when requested by the department head. The examination will be at no cost to the employee. 
(3)  If an employee fails to retain or meet the requirements under subsections (1) and (2) of this section, such employee shall have a 30-calendar-day period from the date of the test or examination to meet such requirements. If found failing after reexamination, the employee shall then be subject to compliance as prescribed under the direction of the city physician/facility, which may or may not preclude active employment until such deficiency is corrected, or the employee may be placed on sick or medical leave for a period not to exceed six months or until such deficiency is corrected. If the impediment is not corrected at the expiration of the six-month period, the employee shall be placed on medical leave, or if qualified may request a disability pension, or may be terminated. 
(4)  If such an employee can produce, at his own expense, medical evidence by a licensed physician to the contrary, the employee's report, together with the city's report, shall be subject to an impartial decision by a third licensed physician selected by the two previous examiners. The expense shall be borne by the city, and that decision shall be binding. 
(Code 1974, § 24-21) 
Secs. 42-102-42-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISCIPLINE OF MEMBERS 

Sec. 42-121. - Offenses for which disciplinary measures may be taken; types of disciplinary action. 
(a)  A member of the fire department found guilty of violating any of the following offenses shall be subject to reprimand, suspension, forfeiture of pay, dismissal or such other lawful punishment as the chief of the fire department may direct: 
(1)  Cowardice. 
(2)  Willful disobedience of rules of the department or general or special orders of the department. 
(3)  Being under the influence of liquor or drinking any kind of intoxicating liquor while on duty, unless ordered by competent authority, or entering a place where intoxicating drinks are sold or kept, except in the line of duty. 
(4)  Entering a disorderly house or place where illegal commercial gambling is carried on, not in the performance of fire duty. 
(5)  Conduct unbecoming an officer. 
(6)  Insubordination or disrespect to a superior officer. 
(7)  Neglect of or inattention to duty. 
(8)  General incompetency. 
(9)  Sleeping while on active post duty. 
(10)  Being absent from duty without permission. 
(11)  Leaving his post without proper relief or purpose. 
(12)  Using coarse, profane or insolent language to a superior officer, a member of the fire department or any citizen. 
(13)  Not properly patrolling or guarding a post. 
(14)  Making a false statement or report. 
(15)  Neglecting to wear a proper uniform while on duty or neglecting to appear clean and tidy in person and dress. 
(16)  Accepting bribes of money or other valuables. 
(17)  Accepting any fee, reward or gift of any kind from any person for services rendered or pretended to be rendered as a member of the fire department without consent of the chief of the fire department. 
(18)  Gossiping about a member of the fire department concerning his personal character or conduct, which is detrimental to such member. 
(19)  Publicly criticizing orders given by a superior officer. 
(20)  Communicating or giving information to any person concerning the business of the fire department, which is detrimental to the fire department. 
(21)  Neglecting to pay a just indebtedness incurred while in the service, within a reasonable time. 
(22)  Assigning salary due or to become due to any person without permission from the chief of the fire department. 
(23)  Refusing to give his name or badge number when requested. 
(24)  Neglecting to turn over all property taken from persons to the proper officer without unnecessary delay. 
(25)  Neglecting to report any member of the fire department known to be guilty of violation of any rule, regulation or order issued for the guidance of the fire department. 
(26)  Failure to report a known violation of law or of this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
(27)  Ignorance of rules or orders. 
(28)  Immorality. 
(29)  Conviction of an offense in any court having criminal jurisdiction. 
(b)  Whenever it shall be deemed necessary for the preservation of good order, efficiency and discipline, the chief of the fire department may suspend any one of his subordinates from duty for the reasons enumerated in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1974, § 14-26) 
Sec. 42-122. - Filing of report of charges. 
    When the chief of the fire department suspends a member of the fire department, he shall, without delay, file a written report of the charges with the city council and furnish the suspended member with a copy of the charges. 
(Code 1974, § 14-27) 
Sec. 42-123. - Statement by suspended member; request for hearing. 
    Any suspended member of the fire department shall make a written statement to the chief of the fire department within 24 hours of his suspension. If he wishes a hearing on the charges, he shall make a written request of the city council within 48 hours from the time of his suspension. 
(Code 1974, § 14-28) 
Sec. 42-124. - Suspended members to turn over property belonging to city. 
    In all cases of suspension of any member of the fire department, the suspended officer or member shall immediately surrender to the chief of the fire department all property in his possession belonging to the city. Pending the disposition of the case, such property shall be retained by the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1974, § 14-29) 
Sec. 42-125. - Wearing uniform while suspended. 
    During a period of suspension, the suspended member of the fire department shall not wear his uniform. 
(Code 1974, § 14-30) 
Sec. 42-126. - Complaints initiated by members of department. 
    Except as otherwise provided in collective bargaining agreements, when any member of the fire department shall feel aggrieved or have a complaint against any member of the fire department, he shall have the right to file a written report of his complaint with the city council and the chief of the fire department and request a public hearing before the city council. The city council shall have the discretion to decide in committee to either grant or deny such hearing. 
(Code 1974, § 14-31) 
Secs. 42-127-42-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Emergency services and management, ch. 34. 

Sec. 42-151. - Service established; purpose. 
    There is hereby established an emergency service, to be known as emergency medical service, for the purpose of providing transportation to local hospitals for those persons injured or incurring sudden illness in the city requiring immediate hospital treatment. 
(Code 1974, § 14-37) 
Sec. 42-152. - Personnel; supervision. 
    The emergency medical service shall be operated by the personnel of the fire department under the direction of the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1974, § 14-38) 
Sec. 42-153. - Rules and regulations. 
    The chief of the fire department is hereby authorized to establish such reasonable rules and regulations as are necessary to give prompt and efficient service to persons incurring illness who are injured within the city, which rules and regulations are to be consistent with the provisions of this division and the Charter, and other city and state regulations. 
(Code 1974, § 14-39) 
Sec. 42-154. - Calls for service; nonemergency service calls. 
(a)  At the time of any emergency injury or sudden illness occurring in the city, a citizen may call the fire department emergency number to obtain the emergency medical service vehicle. 
(b)  All nonemergency service calls shall be made to private ambulance services. The emergency medical service shall not be operated for transportation for people suffering from illness or injuries which do not constitute emergencies when sufficient time exists to arrange transportation with a private ambulance service, or other means, without any detrimental effects to the person involved. 
(Code 1974, § 14-40) 
Sec. 42-155. - Fees. 
(a)  Fees for emergency medical services shall be as established by the city council. 
(b)  There will be no charge for emergency medical services to any team member participating as part of a recreational program sponsored by the city or the city school system. 
(Code 1974, § 14-41; Ord. No. 672, § 1, 6-7-2004) 
Sec. 42-156. - Transport of persons injured in traffic accidents. 
    The emergency medical service shall provide transportation of all injured persons in traffic accidents within the city. 
(Code 1974, § 14-42) 
Sec. 42-157. - Restrictions on transport. 
    Emergency medical service vehicles shall not transport patients outside of the city from one hospital to another within the city or transport patients from any hospital to anyplace within the city unless authorized by the fire chief. 
(Code 1974, § 14-44) 
Sec. 42-158. - Insurance coverage. 
    The city controller shall establish that the requisite insurance coverage is in effect to cover the operation of the emergency medical service. 
(Code 1974, § 14-45) 
Secs. 42-159, 42-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - COST RECOVERY FOR HAZARDOUS/ TOXIC MATERIAL INCIDENTS 

Sec. 42-161. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Dangerous goods. In Canadian transportation, hazardous materials are referred to as dangerous goods. 
    Emergency response means: 
(1)  The providing, sending and/or utilizing of public service, fire, police, rescue service, DPW or any other agent of the city at/to hazardous/toxic material incident or hazardous condition; and 
(2)  The providing, sending and/or utilizing or public service, fire, police, rescue service, DPW or any other agent of the city to any scene where a person and/or driver becomes helpless, endangered, or otherwise in need of assistance, by reason, in whole or in part, of a hazardous/toxic material incident and/or condition. 
    Expense of an emergency response means the direct and reasonable costs incurred by the city, or by a private person, corporation, or other entity operating at the request of or the direction of the city, through the extraordinary use of public services, when making an emergency response to the incident, including the costs of providing fire fighting, rescue service, and police at the scene of the incident. These costs further include, but are not limited to, all salaries, wages, worker's compensation benefits, and fringe benefits of the city personnel responding to the incident; the cost of equipment operation; the cost of materials obtained directly by the city; and the cost of any contract labor or materials ordered to mitigate the hazard. 
    Extremely hazardous substances (EHS) means chemicals determined by the Environmental Protection Agency to be extremely hazardous to a community curing an emergency spill or release as a result of their toxicities and physical/chemical properties, as defined by the Environmental Protection Agency, 40 CFR 355. 
    Hazardous chemicals means any chemical that would be a risk to employees if exposed in the workplace, as defined by the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration, 29 CFR 1910. 
    Hazardous condition means any condition that poses an unreasonable risk to safety, health and property. 
    Hazardous materials means any substance or material in any form or quantity, which poses an unreasonable risk to safety and health and property when, transported in commerce as defined by U.S. Department of Transportation, 49 CFR 171. 
    Hazardous materials incident is defined as the release, or potential release, of a hazardous material form its container into the environment. 
    Hazardous substances means any substance designated under the Clean Water Act and the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) as posing a threat to waterways and the environment when released, as defined by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 40 CFR 302. When used within OSHA 1910.120 refers to every chemical regulated by EPA as a hazardous substance and by U.S. Department of Transportation as a hazardous material. 
    Hazardous wastes means discarded materials regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency because of public health and safety concerns. Regulatory authority is granted under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA), as set forth by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 40 CFR 260-281. 
    Incendiary-type fires is defined for fire reporting purposes as evidence that leads to reporting person to conclude that a fire was deliberately set. Evidence includes physical material and observations of fire effects and may include witnesses or admissions. A deliberately set fire may be lawful or unlawful depending upon other circumstances relevant under applicable law, including intent, ownership of property ignited, and the presence or absence of permission. 
(Ord. No. 693, § 1, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 42-162. - Cost recovery. 
    Cost recovery emergency response for hazardous/toxic material incidents, hazardous conditions, and incendiary-type fires of any duration. 
(1)  The city shall be entitled to recover all costs and damages incurred in conjunction with emergency incidents involving hazardous/toxic materials or hazardous conditions of extended duration. Such costs and damages shall include, but not be limited to, those associated with incident abatement, cleanup and mitigation, including any related third party costs, which were necessary to ensure the safety of the city and its populace. 
(2)  Such costs and damages shall be the joint and distinct responsibility of the owner(s) and/or operator(s) of the property, equipment, vehicle or container causing or contributing to any emergency incident or hazardous condition of extended duration. All such costs and damages shall be paid within 30 days of demand by the city unless otherwise approved by city council. 
(3)  The city shall have a lien for all unpaid costs and damages incurred as above-described and may enforce such lien in the manner prescribed by the general laws of the state providing for the enforcement of tax liens. 
(Ord. No. 693, § 1, 12-5-2005) 
Sec. 42-163. - Costs recovery for incendiary-type fires of any duration. 
(a)  The city shall be entitled to recover all costs and damages incurred in conjunction with any incendiary-type fire. Such costs shall include, but are not limited to, those associated with the fire extinguishment and investigation. 
(b)  Such costs and damages shall be the joint and several responsibility of the person(s) found responsible for setting the fire by a court of competent jurisdiction. All such costs and damages shall be paid within 30 days of demand by the city. 
(c)  The city shall have a lien for all unpaid costs and damages incurred as above-described and may enforce such lien in the manner prescribed by the general laws of the state providing for the enforcement of tax liens. 
(Ord. No. 693, § 1, 12-5-2005) 
Secs. 42-164-42-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - COST RECOVERY FOR EMERGENCY RESPONSE TO MOTOR VEHICLE ACCIDENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 698, § 1, adopted Jan. 17, 2006, set out provisions intended for use as division 5. Inasmuch as Ord. No. 693, § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 2005, also enacted provisions designated as division 5 the provisions of Ord. No. 698 have been included as division 6. 

Sec. 42-171. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
(a)  Emergency response shall mean the providing, sending and/or utilizing of public service, fire, police, rescue service, DPW or any other agent of the city to any scene where a person and/or driver becomes helpless, endangered, or otherwise in need of assistance. 
(b)  Expense of an emergency response means the direct and reasonable costs incurred by the city; or by a private person, corporation, or other entity operating at the request of or the direction of the city; through the use of public services, when making an emergency response to the incident, including the costs of providing emergency transport at the scene of the incident. 
(c)  Level I response: A minor vehicle accident response which would require an engine to respond to the scene to assist and would require minimal involvement of fire department personnel. The response could include clearing of road hazards and would typically require 60 minutes of time or less on the scene. 
(d)  Level II response: This would involve a moderate vehicle accident response which would require an engine to respond to the scene to assist in the situation. It could involve the clean up of spills and debris removal and extrication and typically would require 60 minutes of time or less on the scene. 
(e)  Level III response: Vehicle accidents that require extended (over one hour) extrication, hazardous materials, or any other situation requiring fire department personnel for multiple engine/truck companies or rescue vehicle; victim entrapment with heavy rescue and/or extended extraction operations; could require removing or mitigating hazardous material incident, combating a working fire, and would require over one hour of time on the scene. 
(Ord. No. 698, § 1, 1-17-2006) 
Sec. 42-172. - Cost recovery. 
(a)  The city shall be entitled to recover from the owner, driver or named insured party, or combination thereof (responsible party), the expenses of an emergency response incurred when the city's fire department responds to a motor vehicle accident or any other incident involving a motor vehicle collision. 
(b)  Responsible parties are required to reimburse the City of Trenton for such costs in the following amounts: 
(1)  Actual costs up to the sum of $500.00 for a Level I response. 
(2)  Actual costs up to the sum of $750.00 for a Level II response. 
(3)  For Level III response: The billing submitted by the City of Trenton Fire Department in accordance with the City of Trenton Fire Department Equipment and Personnel Rate Schedule as established from time to time by resolution of council. 
(c)  All invoiced expenses of an emergency response shall be paid to the city treasurer within 30 calendar days of the date of the mailing to the responsible party, unless approval of alternative arrangements is granted by the fire chief in cases of hardship or unless an appeal is filed with the city. 
(d)  The city shall have a lien for all unpaid costs and damages incurred as above-described and may enforce such lien in the manner prescribed by the general laws of the state providing for the enforcement of tax liens. 
(e)  Failure to make payment of the cost recovery assessment by the responsible person(s) in a timely manner constitutes a municipal civil infraction. 
(f)  The city shall accept reimbursement from a responsible party's insurance carrier as payment in full of expenses of emergency response, in the case of bona fide residents of the city who appear as title owners of real property on the city's tax rolls but may balance bill non-residents for any non-covered portion. 
(Ord. No. 698, § 1, 1-17-2006; Ord. No 786, § 1, 12-14-2015) 
Secs. 42-173-42-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 675, § 10, adopted Dec. 20, 2004, repealed §§ 14-56 and 14-59-14-62 of the 1974 Trenton Code of Ordinances, which sections had been codified in this Code as §§ 42-181 and 42-184-42-188. Sections 1-3 of Ord. No. 675 enacted new provisions pertaining to similar subject matter and included at the editor's discretion as §§ 42-181, 42-184, and 42-185. 

Sec. 42-181. - International Fire Code adopted. 
    A certain document, one (1) copy of which is on file in the office of the City Clerk of Trenton, Michigan, being marked and designated as the 2015 International Fire Code, including Appendix B (Fire-Flow Requirements for Buildings), C (Fire Hydrant Locations and Distribution), D (Fire Apparatus Access Roads), F (Hazard Ranking), G (Cryogenic Fluids), H Hazardous Materials Management Plan and Hazardous Materials Inventory Statement Instructions), I (Fire Protection System Non-Compliant Conditions), as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the fire code of the City of Trenton for regulating and governing the safeguarding of the life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises as herein provided; and providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of such International Fire Code on file in the office of the City Clerk of City of Trenton, Michigan, are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 42-183 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 675, § 1, 12-20-2004; Ord. No. 710, § 1, 1-22-2008; Ord. No. 750, § 1, 3-21-2011; Ord. No. 789, § 1, 6-19-2017)

(Code 1974, § 14-57; Ord. No. 789, § 2, 6-19-2017)

Sec. 42-185. - Added and amended sections of fire code. 
    The following Sections of the Code shall be added or amended to read as follows: 
Section 102 
102.6 Referenced codes and standards. The codes and standards referenced in this code shall be those that are listed in Chapter 45 and such codes and standards shall be considered part of the requirements of this code to the prescribed extent of each such reference. Where differences occur between the provisions of this code and the referenced standards the provisions which establish the higher standard for the promotion of the safety and welfare of the public and the protection of the public, or as otherwise determined by State of Michigan law, shall apply. 
Section 103 
103.1 General. The Trenton Fire Department shall be responsible for fire prevention inspection activities and code enforcement of buildings and occupancies as related to the risk of fire or explosion within the City of Trenton. The department of fire prevention is established within the jurisdiction under the direction of the code official. The function of the department shall be the implementation, administration and enforcement of the provisions of this code and codes and standards referenced in Chapter 45 of this code. 
Section 104 
104.11.4 Unlawful boarding or tampering with fire department emergency equipment. A person shall not, without proper authorization from the fire official in charge of said fire department emergency equipment, cling to, attach to, climb upon or into, board, or swing upon any fire department emergency vehicle, whether the same is in motion or at rest, operate any emergency warning equipment, or to manipulate or tamper with, or attempt to manipulate or tamper with any levers, valves, switches, starting devices, brakes, pumps, or any equipment or protective clothing on, or a part of, any fire department emergency vehicle. 
104.11.5 Damage/injury to fire department equipment/personnel. It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or deface, or attempt or conspire to damage or deface, any fire department emergency vehicle or equipment at any time; or to injure, or attempt or conspire to injure, fire department personnel while performing departmental duties. 
Section 105 
105.1 General. Permits shall be in accordance with Section 105. Where reference is made to this section for permits elsewhere in this code and there are no provisions for issuing said permits by the department of fire prevention, the code official is authorized to waive the particular permit requirement. 
105.6 Required operational permits. The code official is authorized to issue operational permits for the operations set forth in Sections 105.6.1 through 105.6.46. Where there are no provisions for issuing said permits by the department of fire prevention, the code official is authorized to waive the particular permit requirement. 
105.6.13 Exhibits, crafts and trade shows. An operational permit is required to operate exhibits, crafts and trade shows. 
105.6.13.1 Permit fee. A minimum fee of $30.00 shall be applied to each exhibit, craft or trade show, except those operated by the City. 
105.6.15.1 Fireworks. An operational permit is required for the public display and retail display and sale of fireworks. Application for permits shall be made in writing at least 15 days in advance of the date of the public display, retail display or sale of fireworks. The sale, possession, and distribution of fire works for such display shall be lawful under the terms and conditions approved with the permit and for only that purpose. A permit granted hereunder shall not be transferable nor shall any such permit be extended beyond the time set forth therein unless approved by the fire official. The permit fee for public display and the retail display and sale of fireworks shall be $100.00, except as to the City. 
105.6.20 Hazardous materials. An operational permit is required to store, transport on site, dispense, use or handle hazardous materials in excess of the amounts listed in Table 105.6.21.

Section 106

2.  $45.00 per hour per reinspection during nonworking hours with a minimum assessment of 3 hours.

Section 109 
109.3 Violation Penalties. 
Persons who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the fire code official, or of a permit or certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment not exceeding 93 days, or both such fine and imprisonment; except for the code sections listed below shall be guilty of a municipal civil infractions punishable by not more than Two Hundred ($200.00) Dollars Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. The enforcing agency shall be the Trenton Fire Department.

Section 112 
112.1 Hazardous materials-fire department responsibility. The Trenton Fire Department shall be responsible for gathering and organizing information, identifying risks, and enforcing codes, standards, and laws relating to the production, storage and use of hazardous materials within the City of Trenton and the notification to fire fighting personnel of related hazards. The method and frequency shall be determined by the fire official or his duly authorized representative. 
112.2 Cost recovery-hazardous materials. The fire department may recover all costs for use of equipment, personnel, and supplies associated with incidents involving hazardous materials resulting from accidents, fires, spills, leaks, or release of product. Such costs shall include but are not limited to those associated with incident abatement, mitigation, and clean up; extinguishment; and stand-by including any related third party costs. Such costs shall be the responsibility of the owner, operator or agent of the building, property, equipment, vehicle, or container causing or contributing to a hazardous condition, fire, or dangerous situation. 
112.3 Cost recovery-fires. The fire department may recover all costs for use of equipment, personnel, and supplies associated with fire extinguishment when it is determined that such fire extinguishment was necessitated by a person's intentional disregard for the safety of persons or property, violation of law, or recklessness. 
112.4 Hazardous conditions. If upon the expiration of the time mentioned in a notice of violation, hazardous conditions, including but not limited to, obstructions or encroachments inhibiting access to or egress from a space or building, are not removed, the code official shall proceed to remove or have removed the same. The expense incurred shall be a debt to the City from the responsible person and shall be collected as any other debt to the City. 
112.5 False alarms. It shall be unlawful for any person to summon, in any way, the fire department unless a valid reason for their response is present. (See also the Trenton Code False Fire Alarm Ordinance.) (Sec. 14-20) 
112.6 Nonstandard Equipment. Equipment and devices which are not in compliance with recognized standards for design and construction may be approved upon presentation of satisfactory evidence that they are designed and constructed for safe operation. 
Section 202 
CODE OFFICIAL. The fire chief, fire marshal, code enforcement officer, or other designated authority charged by the applicable governing body with the duties of administration and enforcement of the code, or duly authorized representative. The term "fire official" may be used interchangeably with "code official" in this code. 
FIRE WATCH. A temporary measure intended to ensure continuous and systematic surveillance of a building or portion thereof by one or more qualified individuals for the purposes of identifying and controlling fire hazards, detecting early signs of unwanted fire, raising an alarm of fire and notifying the fire department by method(s) approved or recommended by the code official. 
Section 302 
302.1 Definitions. 
Ground Fire. An outdoor fire for the purpose of viewing or warming, or utilized to cook food for human consumption, or for ceremonial purposes, which burns only seasoned dry firewood or commercially available charcoal briquettes intended to minimize the generation of air contaminants. 
Section 307 
307.4 Location. The location of open burning shall not be less than 50 feet (15 240mm) from any structure, and provisions shall be made to prevent the fire from spreading to within 50 feet (15 240 mm) of any structure. 
Exceptions: 
1. Fires in approved containers that are not less than 15 feet (4572) mm) from a structure or not less than the appliance manufacturer's recommended safe distance. 
2. The minimum required distance from a structure shall be 25 feet (7620 mm) where the pile size is 3.4 feet (914 mm) or less in diameter and 2 feet (610 mm) or less in height. 
307.4.3 Ground Fires. A ground fire shall be the minimum size for the intended purpose but not larger than 3 feet by 3 feet by 3 feet in dimension and shall be contained in a safe manner. 
307.6 Fire department training. Open burning is allowed for the purpose of training fire fighters for fire fighting practice, or for the purpose of training the public, including workers or employees, or for the purpose of demonstration by the fire official or other trained fire personnel, when such burning is done in accordance with accepted practice. 
508.5 Fire hydrant systems. Fire hydrant systems shall comply with Sections 508.5.1 through 508.5.6 and shall be in accordance with Appendix C and City of Trenton Development Standards. 
508.5.4.1 Removal of obstructions. If upon the expiration of the time mentioned in a notice of violation, obstructions or encroachments to a fire hydrant, or to other fire protection equipment, are not removed, the code official shall proceed to remove or have removed the same. The expense incurred shall be a debt to the City from the responsible person and shall be collected as any other debt to the City. 
Section 610 
610.1 Exhaust fans. Exhaust fans for commercial cooking hoods shall be installed so that the fans are operational at all times cooking is occurring. This may be accomplished by a temperature monitoring device installed in on, or near the hood to activate the exhaust fan(s) at a pre-determined temperature, or as otherwise approved by the code official. 
901.6.2 Records. Records of all system inspections, tests, and maintenance required by the referenced standards shall be maintained on the premises for a minimum of 1 year and made available to the code official upon request. A copy shall also be sent to the code official by the service company or individual performing such work. 
903.2.10.3 Buildings over 30 feet in height. An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed throughout buildings with a floor level having an occupant load of 30 or more that is located 30 feet (9 1 44 mm) or more above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access. 
904.3.5 Monitoring. Automatic fire extinguishing systems shall be monitored by a supervising station in accordance with NFPA 72 as approved by the code official. Where a building fire alarm system is installed, automatic fire-extinguishing systems shall be monitored by the building fire alarm system in accordance with NFPA 72 and shall automatically annunciate their location at the building's fire alarm control panel and activate the building's appropriate fire protective signaling sequence. 
907.2.12 High-rise buildings. Buildings having floors used for human occupancy located more than 55 feet (16 764 mm) above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access shall be provided with an automatic fire alarm system and an emergency voice/alarm communication system in accordance with Section 907.2.12.2. 
907.4.4 Signs. Where fire alarm systems are monitored by a supervising station, an approved permanent sign that reads: THIS ALARM DOES NOT NOTIFY THE FIRE DEPARTMENT - TO REPORT A FIRE DIAL 911. Such sign shall be installed adjacent to each manual fire alarm box. 
Exception: Where the manufacturer has permanently provided this information on the manual fire alarm box and as approved by the code official. 
907.7.1 Annunciation. Where fire suppression systems exist in multi-tenant occupancies, i.e., strip malls, separate annunciation shall be required for each separately addressed tenant space unless otherwise approved by the code official. 
907.9.2 High-rise buildings. In buildings that have floors located more than 55 feet (16 764mm) above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access that are occupied for human occupancy, a separate zone by floor shall be provided for all of the following types of alarm-initiating devices where provided: 
1.  Smoke detectors 
2.  Sprinkler water-flow devices. 
3.  Manual fire alarm boxes. 
4.  Other approved type of automatic fire detection devices or suppression systems as required by the code official. 
907.10.2.1 Temporal Code-3. Audible alarm notification appliances shall sound in temporal Code-3 pattern as approved by the code official. 
907.10.2.2 Audible alarm appliance silencing. Where required by the code official, there shall be a means provided at the fire alarm control panel to silence audible alarm devices without resetting the panel. Where audible alarm devices are provided there shall be a means provided at the fire alarm control panel to silence the audible alarm devices without disabling the visual alarm devices or resetting the panel. 
907.12.1 Remote annunciation: Where required by the code official, a means of remote annunciation such as a light or other visible indicator shall be installed and marked with an approved description of the detector location in order to indicate the presence and location of detectors in accordance with NFPA 72. 
Section 1005 
1005.3.2.5. Smokeproof enclosures. In buildings required to comply with the high-rise provisions of the International Building Code or the provisions for underground buildings in the International Building code, each of the exits of a building which serves stories where the floor surface is more than (55 feet 16 764 mm) above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access or more than 30 Feet (9144 mm) below the level of exit discharge serving such floor levels shall be a smokeproof enclosure of pressurized stairway in accordance with the International Building Code. 
1005.3.6.1 Use in a means of egress. Exterior exit stairways shall not be used as an element of a required means of egress for occupancies in Group 1-2. For occupancies in other than Group 1-2, exterior exit stairways shall be permitted as an element or a required means of egress for buildings not exceeding five stories or (55 feet 16 764 mm) in height. 
Section 1201 
1201.1 Scope. Dry cleaning plants and their operations shall comply with the requirements of this chapter and NFPA 32, and the Michigan Fire Prevention Code 1941 PA 207, as amended or its equivalent 
Section 2201 
2201.1 Scope. Automotive service stations, marine service stations, fleet vehicle service stations and repair garages shall be in accordance with this chapter and the International Fuel Gas Code, International Building Code, and the International Mechanical Code, and the Michigan Storage and Handling of Flammable and Combustible Liquids Rules, as amended, or their equivalent. Such operations shall include both public accessible and private operations. 
Section 2206 
2206.1 General. Storage of flammable and combustible liquids shall be in accordance with Chapter 34 and Section 2206, and the Michigan Storage and Handling of Flammable and Combustible Liquids Rules, as amended, or their equivalent. 
2206.7.8 Gravity and pressure dispensing. Flammable or combustible liquids shall not be dispensed by gravity from tanks, drums, barrels or similar containers. Flammable or combustible liquids shall not be dispensed by a device operating through pressure within a storage tank, drum or container. Approved pumps taking suction from the top of the container shall be utilized. 
Section 2803 
2803.2 Identification. Cartons shall be identified on at least one side with the classification level of the aerosol products contained within the carton as follows: 
LEVEL 1, 2, OR 3 AEROSOLS 
The side of the carton marked shall be clearly visible when stored in configurations of two or more cartons. 
Section 3301 
3301.1.1 Explosive material standard. In addition to the requirements of this chapter, NFPA 495 shall govern the manufacture, transportation, storage, sale, handling and use of explosive materials, and the Michigan Explosives Law 1970- PA 202, as amended, or its equivalent. 
3301.1.3 Fireworks. The possession, manufacture, storage, sale, handling and use of fireworks are prohibited unless in compliance with the Michigan Fireworks Law 1931 PA 328, as amended, or its equivalent. 
3301.1.4 Rocketry. The storage, handling and use of model and high-power rockets shall comply with the requirements of NFPA 1122, NFPA 1125, and NFPA 1127, and the Michigan Model Rocket Law 1965 PA 333, as amended, or its equivalent. 
3301.2.4.2 Bond for public display: The permit holder shall furnish a bond in an amount approved by the city of Trenton for the payment of all potential damage caused either to the person or property due to the permitted display, and arising form any acts of the permit holder of the agent of the permit holder. 
Section 3308 
3308.1 General. The display of fireworks, including proximate audience displays and pyrotechnic special effects in motion picture, television, theatrical, and group entertainment productions, shall comply with this chapter and NFPA1123 or NFPA 1126. Approved public displays shall be handled by an approved competent operator, and the fireworks shall be arranged, located, discharged and fired in a manner that will not be a hazard to property or endanger any person. 
3308.11 Retail display and sale. A permit shall be required as set forth in Section 105.6 and regulated in accordance with this section. Fireworks displayed for retail sale shall not be made readily accessible to the public. A minimum of one pressurized-water portable fire extinguisher complying with Section 906 shall be located not more than 15 feet (4572mm) and not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) from the hazard. "No Smoking" sign complying with Section 310 shall be conspicuously posted in areas where fireworks are stored or displayed for retail sale. No person under the age of 18 years shall sell, purchase or possess fireworks unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. 
Section 3401 
3401.3 Referenced documents. The applicable requirements of Chapter 27, other chapters of this code, the International Building Code, and the International Mechanical Code pertaining to flammable liquids, and the Michigan Storage and Handling of Flammable and Combustible Liquids Rules, as amended, or their equivalent shall apply. 
3401.4 Permits. Permits shall be required as set forth in Sections 105.6 and 105.7, and the Michigan Fire Prevention Code 1941 PA 207, as amended or its equivalent. 
Section 3404 
3404.2.9 Aboveground tanks. Aboveground storage of flammable and combustible liquids in tanks shall comply with Section 3404.2 and Sections 3404.2.9.1 through 3404.2.9.6.10, and the Michigan Above-ground Storage Tank Rules, or their equivalent. 
3404.2.11 Underground tanks. Underground storage of flammable and combustible liquids in tanks shall comply with Section 3404.2 and Sections 3404.2.11.1 through 3404.2.11.5.2, and the Michigan Underground Storage Tank Rules, or their equivalent. 
Section 3405 
3405.2.4 Class I and II liquids. Class I and II liquids shall be transferred by one of the following methods: 
1.  From safety cans complying with UL 30. 
2.  Through an approved closed piping system. 
3.  From containers or tanks by an approved pump taking suction through an opening in the top of the container or tank. 
4.  Flammable and combustible liquids shall not be dispensed by gravity from tanks. 
5.  Approved engineered liquid transfer systems. 
Exception: Liquids in containers not exceeding a 5.3-gallon (20L) capacity. 
Section 3801 
3801.2 Permits. Permits shall be required as set forth in Sections 105.6 and 105.7 and the Michigan Fire Prevention Code 1941 PA 207, as amended, or its equivalent.
