    A person who violates any provision of this article or the terms or conditions of a permit is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, and shall be subject to fines of $100 per day. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the remedies available to the city in the event of a violation by a person of this article or a permit. 
(Ord. No. 658, § 1(271/2-67), 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 50-199. - Applicability generally. 
    The provisions of this article shall be imposed upon and enforced against all telecommunication systems in the city requiring a license or permit under state law from the city. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-71) 
Sec. 50-200. - Compliance with laws, regulations and orders. 
    All grantees and the city shall comply with all laws, rules, regulations and orders in the exercise and performance of their rights and obligations under this article and under any permit. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-72) 
Sec. 50-201. - Continuity of service. 
    It shall be the right of all subscribers to receive all available services insofar as their financial and other obligations to the grantee of a permit are honored. If the grantee elects to overbuild, rebuild, modify or sell the telecommunication system or the city terminates, revokes or fails to renew a permit within a reasonable time, a grantee shall do everything in its power to ensure that all subscribers receive continuous, uninterrupted service regardless of the circumstances. In the event of a change of grantee, the current grantee shall cooperate with the new grantee in maintaining continuity of service to all subscribers. If interruption of service is required by a grantee for modification, repairs or the like, the interruption shall be as brief as possible and at times when the impact on subscribers is at a minimum. Records of such interruption shall be kept. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-68) 
Sec. 50-202. - Acceptance of conditions by grantee; incorporation of application and ordinance in permit. 
    The grantee agrees to be bound by all of the terms and conditions of the permit and accepts unconditionally the permit and promises to comply with and abide by all of its terms, provisions and conditions. A grantee also agrees to provide all services set forth in its application and proposal, and, by its acceptance of the license or permit, a grantee specifically grants and agrees that its application and proposal is thereby incorporated by reference and made a part of the license or permit. In addition, a grantee specifically agrees that this article is incorporated by reference and made a part of the license or permit. In the event of a conflict between the application and proposal of the grantee, this article, and the license or permit, this article shall prevail. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-69) 
Sec. 50-203. - Tampering with equipment; fraudulent connections or sales. 
(a)  No person, whether or not a subscriber or user to the telecommunication system, may intentionally or knowingly remove or damage or cause to be damaged any wire, cable, conduit, equipment, or apparatus of the grantee, or to commit any act with an intent to cause such removal or damage, or tap, tamper with or otherwise connect any wire or device to a wire, cable, conduit, equipment and apparatus, or appurtenances of the grantee with the intent to obtain a signal or impulse from the telecommunication system without authorization from or compensation to the grantee, or obtain telecommunications service, or sell, rent, offer or advertise for sale, rental or use any instrument, apparatus, device or plans, specifications, or instructions for making or assembling any device to connect to the grantee's telecommunication system with intent to cheat or defraud the grantee of any lawful charge to which it is entitled. 
(b)  The prohibitions, penalties and remedies set forth in this section are in addition to any prohibitions, penalties and remedies for theft of service provided by state and federal law. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-70) 
Secs. 50-204-50-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES AND PERMITS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Permits, MCL 484.2251 et seq. 

Sec. 50-221. - Required. 
    No person shall install, construct, maintain or otherwise operate a telecommunication system in the city without a telecommunication license and no person shall transact business within the city limits on a telecommunication system without a permit. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-51(a)) 
Sec. 50-222. - Issuance. 
(a)  The city council may grant one or more licenses and permits for a telecommunication system in the city subject to this article. 
(b)  The city specifically reserves the right to grant, at any time, such additional licenses and permits for a telecommunication system as it deems appropriate. Additional licenses and permits shall not be deemed to modify, revoke, terminate or damage any rights previously granted to any other grantee. 
(c)  If a license application is filed proposing to install facilities within a franchise or permit territory which overlaps in whole or in part an existing area, a copy shall be served by the applicant by certified mail upon the current grantee. Proof of such service shall be provided to the city. No application for overlapping territory shall be processed until proof of service has been furnished to the city. It is not the intent of this article to either require or prohibit overbuilding. 
(d)  Applications for a new, renewed or amended permits or licenses shall be filed with the engineering and building department, which shall investigate the request and make recommendations to the council on the ability of the applicants to use the right-of-way consistent with the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. New, renewed or amended permits which expand the scope of service shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable pre-payment of the permit formation, renewal or amendment fee. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-52) 
Sec. 50-223. - Term. 
    Any license or permit and the rights, privileges, authority, and responsibilities established shall take effect and be in force from and after final acceptance. It shall continue in force and effect for a period established by the license or permit not exceeding 15 years, provided, within 30 days after the date of the city's final acceptance of a license or permit, the grantee files with the engineering and building department its unconditional acceptance of the license or permit, all required letters of credit, and construction surety and insurance certificates, and pays to the city treasurer all reasonable costs actually incurred by the city in preparing, considering and awarding the license or permit, including legal, engineering, technical, publication and other expenses, that is, the permit formation fee. If a grantee fails to timely comply with this section, it shall acquire no rights, privileges, or authority whatsoever from the city. The director of the engineering and building department may extend the term of a license or permit for a period not exceeding one year by written agreement with a grantee on reasonable and necessary terms. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-53) 
Sec. 50-224. - Fees. 
(a)  Permit or license fee. For the reason that the streets, highways and rights-of-way or easements to be used by grantee in the operation of its telecommunication system within the boundaries of the city are valuable public properties, some of which are acquired and maintained by the city at great expense to its taxpayers, and that the grant to grantee of the use of the streets, highways, rights-of-way or easements is a valuable property right without which the grantee would be required to invest substantial capital in right-of-way costs and acquisitions, a grantee shall pay a permit formation fee or license fee and renewal fees as determined from time to time by council resolution. 
(b)  Per linear foot or per site fee. In addition, a permittee or licensee shall pay a per linear foot fee or per site fee to the city for all lines, wires, cables, poles, conduits and the like that are erected upon, over, across or under the roads, bridges, streets, public rights-of-way or easements of the city, at the time of erection and annually, as may be established from time to time by the council. 
(c)  Miscellaneous provisions. 
(1)  Grantees sharing the same conduit shall each pay a full fee, formation fee or license fee. 
(2)  Grantees sending signals over an existing line owned by another telecommunication system upon which fees are already paid are not subject to additional per linear foot fees. 
(3)  Grantees using the same line to provide cable television service and to provide telecommunications services shall be subject to both a cable television franchise fee and all fees set by this article, except that the per linear foot fee shall not be charged. 
(4)  License and permit fees shall be in addition to any other tax, charge, fee, or payment due the city by a grantee. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-56) 
Sec. 50-225. - Provision of new services. 
    If the grantee of a permit provides a new service, facility, equipment, fee or grant to any other community which it serves within the state, the same shall be provided in or to the city. The city shall waive this requirement in a permit upon an affirmative demonstration that such service would be undesirable, impractical, infeasible or uneconomical in the city due to population, density or other relevant factors. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-58(a)) 
Sec. 50-226. - Insurance. 
    A grantee shall at all times during the life of a license or permit carry and require its contractors and subcontractors to carry out public liability, property damage, worker's disability, and vehicle insurance in such form and amount as shall be determined by the city as set forth in the license or permit. All required insurance coverage shall provide for 30 days' notice to the city in the event of material alteration or cancellation of such coverage prior to the effective date of such material alteration or cancellation. Failure of the grantee to provide appropriate insurance certificates to the city within 60 days after the execution of a license or permit shall render the license or permit null and void. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-58) 
Sec. 50-227. - Participation by city in legal proceedings; compliance with regulations. 
    A grantee agrees not to oppose intervention by the city in any suit or proceeding to which the grantee is a party relating to the city's permit or license. A grantee agrees to abide by all provisions of this article and its license and permit. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-63) 
Sec. 50-228. - Transfer. 
(a)  Neither a license or permit nor any of a grantee's interest therein or in the facilities shall be sold, assigned, transferred, pledged, leased, sublet, hypothecated or mortgaged in any manner, in whole or in part, to any person, nor shall title thereto, either legal or equitable, or any right or interest therein, or any property or assets relating to a license or permit or the facilities, pass to or vest in any person without the prior written consent of the city, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. A grantee shall not otherwise provide service to a person who the city contends is required to obtain a license or permit from the city and who lacks such license or permit. Nothing in this section shall prevent a grantee from assigning its rights and obligations to an affiliate (defined as any entity directly owned by the grantee or a parent entity of the grantee) or subsidiary of the grantee upon notice to the city. Any assignment or transfer to a subsidiary or affiliate of the grantee shall not relieve a grantee of its liability under this article. Further, nothing in this section shall prevent or prohibit a grantee or any of its parents, subsidiaries or affiliates from granting a security interest in the license or permit or the facilities arising from a financing transaction. The grant or waiver of any one or more of such consents shall not render unnecessary any subsequent consents, nor shall the grant of any such consent constitute a waiver of any other rights of the city. In the event of a foreclosure proceeding pursuant to the enforcement of a security interest granted by a grantee, or any parent or subsidiary of a grantee, the city shall have the right to approve the purchaser of the license or permit and/or the facilities at a foreclosure sale, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld or unduly delayed. The prohibition against sales, assignments, transfers and similar actions shall also fully apply to any transfer of control of the grantee ("control") and such transfer of control shall also require the prior written approval of the city, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld or unduly delayed. 
(b)  No license or permit or any part or portion of its interest in the license or permit may be sold, transferred or assigned until the facilities, equipment and personnel which the grantee has proposed in the current license or permit application to provide and install pursuant to the license or permit are 100 percent completed and operational for a minimum period of three years, except to grantee's parent, affiliate or subsidiary. 
(c)  Any attempted transfer of the license or permit, facilities, control or similar action by a grantee in violation of this section shall be ineffective and void and shall constitute a material event of default by the grantee. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-64) 
Sec. 50-229. - Construction and performance guarantee. 
    A grantee shall, prior to construction and within 30 days of the execution of a license or permit, file with the engineering a building department a letter of credit, surety bond or cash deposit in a reasonable amount set by the terms of the license or permit based upon the construction cost of the lines to be installed upon, over, across, or under the roads, bridges, streets, rights-of-way or easements in the city. The grantee and the city engineer may make arrangements for the periodic release of the cash deposit, surety bond or letter of credit in proportionate amounts as progress is made. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-65) 
Sec. 50-230. - Termination. 
(a)  In addition to all rights and powers reserved or pertaining to the city, the city reserves as an additional and as a separate and distinct remedy the right to terminate a license or permit and all rights and privileges of a grantee in any of the following events or for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  A grantee fails after 30 days' prior written notice to comply with any of the provisions of the license or permit or has, by act or omission, violated any term or condition; 
(2)  A grantee becomes insolvent or unable or unwilling to pay its debts, or is adjudged bankrupt; 
(3)  All or part of a grantee's facilities are sold under an instrument to secure a debt and are not redeemed by the grantee within 90 days from such sale; 
(4)  A grantee attempts to or does practice any fraud or deceit in its conduct or relations with the city under the license or permit; 
(5)  The city condemns all of the property of a grantee within the city by the lawful exercise of eminent domain; or 
(6)  The grantee abandons the telecommunication system or fails to seek renewal of its license or permit. 
(b)  No termination, except for reason of condemnation, shall be effective unless or until the city shall have adopted a resolution setting forth the cause and reason for the revocation and the effective date, which resolution shall not be adopted without 30 days' prior notice to the grantee and an opportunity for the grantee to be heard on the proposed resolution. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-66) 
Secs. 50-231-50-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MICHIGAN CONSOLIDATED GAS COMPANY FRANCHISE 

Sec. 50-251. - Grant of franchise. 
    Subject to all the terms and conditions mentioned in this article, consent is hereby given to Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, a corporation organized under the laws of the state (referred to in this article as the "company"), and to its successors and assigns, to lay, maintain, operate and use gas pipes, mains, conductors, service pipes, and other necessary equipment in the highways, streets, alleys, and other public places in the city, and a franchise is hereby granted to the company, its successors and assigns to transact local business in the city for the purposes of conveying gas into and through and supplying and selling gas in the city and all other matters incidental thereto. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-21) 
Sec. 50-252. - Gas service and extension of system. 
    If the provisions and conditions contained in this article are accepted by the company, then the company shall furnish gas to applicants residing therein in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations; provided that such initial installation and any extensions shall be subject to the main extension provisions, the area expansion program provisions (if and where applicable), and other applicable provisions now or from time to time hereafter contained in the company's rules and regulations for gas service as filed with the state public service commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-22) 
Sec. 50-253. - Use of streets and other public places. 
(a)  The company, its successors and assigns shall not unnecessarily obstruct the passage of any of the highways, streets, alleys, or other public places within the city and shall, within a reasonable time after making an opening or excavation, repair the opening or excavation and leave it in as good condition as before the opening or excavation was made. The company, its successors and assigns shall use due care in exercising the privileges contained in this article and shall be liable to the city for all damages and costs which may be recovered against the city arising from the default, carelessness, or negligence of the company or its officers, agents, and servants. 
(b)  No road, street, alley, or highway shall be opened for the laying of trunk lines or lateral mains except upon application to the highway commissioner or the city or other authority having jurisdiction in the premises, stating the nature of the proposed work and the route. Upon receipt of such application, it shall be the duty of the highway commissioners or the city council, or such other authority as may have jurisdiction, to issue a permit to the company to do the work proposed. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-23) 
Sec. 50-254. - Standards and conditions of service; rules, regulations and rates. 
    The company is now under the jurisdiction of the state public service commission to the extent provided by statute; and the rates to be charged for gas, and the standards and conditions of service and operations under this article, shall be the same as set forth in the company's schedules of rules, regulations, and rates as applicable in the several cities, villages, and townships in which the company is now rendering gas service or as shall hereafter be validly prescribed for the city under the orders, rules and regulations of the state public service commission or other authority having jurisdiction in the premises. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-24) 
Sec. 50-255. - Applicability to successors and assigns. 
    The words "Michigan Consolidated Gas Company" and "the company," wherever used in this article, are intended and shall be held and construed to mean and include both Michigan Consolidated Gas Company and its successors and assigns, whether so expressed or not. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-25) 
Sec. 50-256. - Term. 
    The franchise granted by this article shall continue in effect for a period of 30 years, subject to revocation at the will of the city at any time during such 30-year period. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-26) 
Secs. 50-257-50-280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - AMERITECH NEW MEDIA FRANCHISE 

Sec. 50-281. - Grant of franchise. 
    Consent is hereby given, along with a nonexclusive franchise, to Ameritech New Media Corporation, a corporation organized under the laws of the State of Delaware (referred to in this article as the "company") and to its successors and assigns to transact local business in the city for the purpose of providing cable television service within the jurisdictional limits of the city and, in conjunction therewith, to construct, maintain and operate a cable television franchise within the jurisdictional limits of the city and to utilize the streets, highways, alleys, and other rights-of-way in the city consistent with the franchise agreement by and between the city and Ameritech New Media, which shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and made part of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-31) 
Sec. 50-282. - Term. 
    The franchise granted by this article shall continue in effect for a period of 15 years. 
(Code 1974, § 271/2-32) 
Chapter 54 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14; environment, ch. 38; floods, ch. 46; manufactured homes, ch. 62; solid waste, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 98. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 54-1-54-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FOOD[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 
State Law reference- Food Law of 2000, MCL 289.1101 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-31. - Enforcement officers. 
    The power to enforce the provisions of this article is hereby vested in the health officer, the police chief and their deputies. 
(Code 1974, § 15-1) 
Sec. 54-32. - Inspections required. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer, police chief or their designees or deputies to visit and inspect at frequent intervals every place where food, beverages or confections intended for consumption by human beings are manufactured, kept, stored, prepared or offered for sale or other disposition. 
(Code 1974, § 15-2) 
Sec. 54-33. - Right of entry of city officials. 
    The city engineer and the police chief or their designees or deputies shall have full power at any time to enter every building, room, basement or cellar occupied or used, or which they have reasonable cause to believe is being used, for the production, manufacture, storage, sale or distribution of food, for the purpose of inspecting the premises and the utensils, fixtures, furniture, product, ingredients and machinery used therein. 
(Code 1974, § 15-3) 
Sec. 54-34. - Issuance of order to correct violation. 
    If, upon inspection, any food producing or food distributing establishment, conveyance, employee, operative, clerk, driver or other person is found to be violating any of the provisions of this article, or if the production, preparation, manufacture, packing, storing, sale, distribution or transportation of any food product is being conducted in a manner detrimental to the health of the employees or is injurious to the quality and food value of such food therein being produced, manufactured, packed, stored, sold or distributed, the officer or inspector making such examination or inspection shall thereupon issue an order or rule to the person in authority or in charge or control of such place, directing that the condition be corrected within such reasonable time as in his direction he deems proper. 
(Code 1974, § 15-4) 
Sec. 54-35. - Failure to comply with order; authority to close establishment. 
    If any person shall fail to make the improvements required by an order issued pursuant to section 54-34 within the time so limited, it shall be the duty of the city engineer or police chief to institute proceedings against the person for the violation of this article and close the business of such person until such improvements and repairs shall have been made and approved by the county department of public health. Should the unsanitary condition found warrant such action, the establishment may be immediately closed by the officer making the inspection, in which case he shall notify the person in charge of the establishment at the time of inspection, in writing, stating his reasons for closing the place, and a continuance to operate after receiving such a notice shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 15-5) 
Sec. 54-36. - Duty of police chief to check licensing. 
    It shall be the duty of the police chief and his duly authorized assistants to check all food establishments to determine whether or not they are provided with proper licenses as required by this article, and the police chief or his duly authorized assistants shall institute action to prosecute any person found to be operating without proper city license. 
(Code 1974, § 15-6) 
Sec. 54-37. - Personal cleanliness of employees. 
    It shall be unlawful for either the owner or proprietor of any firm or corporation maintaining, operating or managing any food establishment in the city to suffer, permit or allow any employee, officer or agent employed therein or thereabout in the handling of any food product intended for human consumption to be or remain in any unsanitary, filthy or dirty condition, either as to person or clothing, while so employed or engaged in the handling of such products intended for human consumption. 
(Code 1974, § 15-7) 
Sec. 54-38. - Condemnation of contaminated and adulterated food. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer, sanitary inspector or their assistants to seize, condemn or exclude from sale, delivery or distribution in the city any spoiled, contaminated or adulterated food or any food unfit for human consumption or any food which has been unnecessarily exposed to dust, flies, contamination by the public, vermin or other contaminating material in violation of the terms of this article. It shall further be the duty of the city engineer, sanitary inspector or other assistants to destroy or denaturize all food condemned as unfit for human consumption and issue an order or statement to the owner of such food, stating the reason therefor. 
(Code 1974, § 15-8) 
Sec. 54-39. - Keeping decayed food in receptacles with food intended for human consumption. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit or suffer any decayed food or meat or vegetable matter of any kind to remain in any receptacle, icebox or any other compartment wherein any fruits, meats, vegetables or other food intended for human consumption is kept for sale or other disposition. 
(Code 1974, § 15-9) 
Secs. 54-40-54-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OPEN AIR MARKETS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 54-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Open air market means a business establishment so developed that service to the patron may be extended beyond the walls of the business building, not requiring the patron to enter the structure. 
(Code 1974, § 15-111) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 54-62-54-80. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - License 

Sec. 54-81. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of selling fruits and vegetables, whether at wholesale or retail, or engage in the sale of plant materials not grown on the site or garden supplies in an open air market without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1974, § 15-112) 
Sec. 54-82. - Application; health department investigation and approval. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be made in writing to the city clerk, upon blanks to be provided by the city clerk, who shall refer all such applications to the state health department for investigation and approval. The application shall contain the following: 
(1)  The applicant's full name, residence and post office address, and whether the applicant is an individual, firm or corporation. If a partnership exists, the names of the partners must be given, together with their addresses. If the application is made by a corporation, the names and addresses of the officers must be given. 
(2)  The location of the applicant's place of business. 
(3)  An agreement that the applicant will permit the city engineer, police chief, sanitary inspector, and their respective representatives or assistants to inspect the establishment and everything in connection therewith at any time desired. 
(4)  The manner in which the applicant intends to dispose of the goods, whether at wholesale or retail or both, and any other pertinent information desired by the city engineer which may have reasonable bearing on the public health. 
(Code 1974, § 15-113) 
Sec. 54-83. - Investigation and recommendation by city engineer; issuance. 
(a)  Upon the signing of an application for a license required by this division by the applicant or someone duly authorized by him, the city engineer shall make or cause to be made an investigation to ascertain whether such applicant is in a position to observe, and is willing to observe, the terms and conditions of this division. 
(b)  If it shall appear to the city engineer, after such investigation, that the applicant is in a position to maintain a sanitary open air market establishment, and furnish clean, pure, healthy, wholesome and unadulterated food to customers, and is willing to observe the terms and conditions of this chapter and the regulations of the engineering and building department, if the application is approved, then the city engineer shall endorse upon such application a favorable report, and transmit the application to the city clerk, who shall issue a license to the applicant, granting permission to conduct the type of business designated in the application and no other. 
(Code 1974, § 15-114) 
Sec. 54-84. - Denial. 
(a)  If it shall be found by representatives of the state health department, after investigation, that the applicant for a license under this division is not maintaining, or cannot maintain, a sanitary open air market establishment, or is not furnishing clean, pure, healthy, wholesome and unadulterated food to customers, or that the applicant is unwilling to observe the terms and conditions of this chapter and the regulations of the city engineer, or that the applicant is not in a position to do so, then the city engineer shall endorse upon such application an unfavorable report, together with a recommendation that the applicant be denied a license by the city council. 
(b)  The city clerk shall, upon receipt of such a recommendation, present the matter to the city council at its first regular meeting following receipt of the application. The city council shall act upon the application. If the license is denied, the city clerk shall promptly notify the police chief, in writing, of such action. Upon receipt of such notice, the police chief shall immediately order the establishment closed. If the applicant shall not comply with the order, he shall be promptly prosecuted. 
(Code 1974, § 15-115) 
Sec. 54-85. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The city engineer, or any of his duly authorized agents, or the police chief, or any of his duly authorized agents, shall have authority to revoke or suspend any license issued under this division, for the violation of any of the terms of this division or the violation of the health food laws of the state or the violation of the criminal statutes of the state or of the United States. 
(b)  The licensee shall be given written notice of the revocation or suspension. The licensee shall be entitled to a hearing before the city council, if such hearing is demanded by him in writing and presented to the city clerk within ten days from the date of revocation or suspension of the license. The hearing shall be commenced at the following regular meeting of the city council, and the city council, after hearing both sides of the question, shall act as sole judge as to whether or not the revocation or suspension shall stand. 
(Code 1974, § 15-116) 
Secs. 54-86-54-100. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Sanitary Standards 

Sec. 54-101. - Compliance. 
    Every person who, as owner or manager, keeps, maintains or operates an open air market in the city shall be required to maintain the sanitary standards set forth in this subdivision. 
(Code 1974, § 15-122) 
Sec. 54-102. - Toilet facilities. 
(a)  All open air markets shall be provided with adequate toilet facilities conveniently located within the establishment. 
(b)  Toilet rooms shall not open directly into any food processing room. Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition and in good repair and shall be well lighted and ventilated. 
(Code 1974, § 15-123) 
Sec. 54-103. - Lavatory facilities. 
    All open air markets shall have lavatory facilities conveniently located which are provided with hot and cold running water. Hand-washing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees. 
(Code 1974, § 15-124) 
Sec. 54-104. - Metal sinks required for cleaning utensils and tools. 
    Metal sinks shall be provided in all open air markets for the purpose of cleaning utensils and tools used in the handling, display or dispensing of foods. 
(Code 1974, § 15-125) 
Sec. 54-105. - Hot running water required. 
    An adequate supply of running hot water shall be piped to all sinks located in open air markets. 
(Code 1974, § 15-126) 
Sec. 54-106. - Storage of food generally. 
    All food stored shall be elevated at least 12 inches above the floor unless packaged in watertight containers, and free of possible sources of contamination. No food shall be stored below sewer lines. 
(Code 1974, § 15-127) 
Sec. 54-107. - Protection of food from contamination. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, expose for sale, or have for other disposition any prepared food, for human consumption, or any cheese, candy, bread, cakes, figs, dates, prunes, raisins, mincemeat or other food, except fruits and vegetables, in broken packages unless the food shall be kept or stored in closed glass cases or other suitable containers, and protected from dust, dirt, flies, insects, and dogs, cats, rats and mice and other contaminating materials. 
(Code 1974, § 15-128) 
Sec. 54-108. - Certain food to be kept in dustproof covered containers. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, expose for sale, dispose of, or deliver any sugar, honey, pickles, olives, sauerkraut, jelly, peanut butter, applesauce, lard, bread, baked goods or any like products intended for human consumption unless the receptacles in which such product is contained shall be dustproof and covered. 
(Code 1974, § 15-129) 
Sec. 54-109. - Dairy products and eggs to be refrigerated. 
    All dairy products and eggs must be kept under refrigeration at all times at or below a temperature of 50 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Code 1974, § 15-130) 
Sec. 54-110. - Living or sleeping rooms connected with market. 
    Living or sleeping rooms in direct connection with any part of an open air market shall not be permitted. 
(Code 1974, § 15-131) 
Sec. 54-111. - Premises to be free from contamination and rodent-proof. 
    All open air markets shall be free from contamination and shall be rodent-proof. 
(Code 1974, § 15-132) 
Sec. 54-112. - Garbage and trash. 
    All waste, garbage and trash located on the premises of any open air market shall be kept in suitable receptacles, in such a manner as not to become a nuisance or cause the presence of rodents. 
(Code 1974, § 15-133) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 74. 
Sec. 54-113. - Worktables and benches. 
    All worktables and benches in open air markets shall be constructed of tight, smooth material and shall be free from cracks so as to be easily cleaned. 
(Code 1974, § 15-134)

ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-91 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-31. - Resisting or interfering with police officer. 
    No person shall resist any police officer of the city in the discharge of his duty, or fail or refuse to obey any lawful command of any police officer or in any way interfere with or hinder or prevent any such police officer from discharging his duty, or in any manner assist or give aid to any person in custody of a police officer to escape or to attempt to escape from custody, or rescue or attempt to rescue any person when in such custody. 
(Code 1974, § 26-1) 
Secs. 58-32-58-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EMPLOYMENT[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Commission on Law Enforcement Standards Act, MCL 28.601 et seq. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 58-61. - Declaration of vacancy. 
    The police chief shall request authorization of the mayor to fill, as necessary, any vacancy. Upon the mayor's approval, the city shall proceed to fill the vacancy in accordance with procedures prescribed in this division. 
(Code 1974, § 24-22) 
Sec. 58-62. - Appointments. 
(a)  Appointments for employment as officers in the police department shall only be made after completely fulfilling the preliminary requirements. Such examination shall be conducted as provided in this division, and appointments shall be made from a revolving list of qualified applicants after confirmation by the city administrator or mayor. 
(b)  Such list of applicants may be held in effect, and continuing appointments made therefrom, for a period of up to two years from the date of application, which may be periodically updated, or terminated earlier if found to be in the best interest of the city with approval of the mayor. 
(c)  In the absence or shortage of currently available applicants in the department's revolving file, the police chief may contact local academies or cause public notice to be given for additional applicants, which notice shall be posted on the city's web-site and cable television or published in the local newspaper carrying official council proceedings, that applications for appointment and examination are being accepted by the city. Such applications shall be received and kept in a revolving file at the city's human resource office where it shall be periodically updated for eligibility. 
(Code 1974, § 24-23; Ord. No. 759, § 1, 1-9-2012) 
Secs. 58-63-58-80. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Minimum Employment Standards 

Sec. 58-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Candidate means a person seeking employment as a sworn police officer empowered to enforce the general criminal statutes of the state. 
    Commission means the state commission on law enforcement standards. 
    Examination means a job-related examination developed in conformance with the American Psychological Association Division 14 principles for the validation and use of personnel selection procedures and all applicable federal and state laws. 
    Test battery means the commission's job-related pre-employment examinations designed to assess: 
(1)  Reading/writing skills; and 
(2)  Physical performance skills. 
(Code 1974, § 24-24) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-82. - Employment qualifications. 
    A person selected to become a law enforcement officer under the Commission on Law Enforcement Standards Act (MCL 28.601 et seq.) shall, for the period of application and subsequent employment: 
(1)  Show proof of residency within six months following expiration of the initial probationary period of employment. 
(2)  Be certified by the state commission on law enforcement standards (COLES) or, in the case of a new officer, be certifiable within one year, as a police officer at time of hire. 
(Code 1974, § 24-25) 
Sec. 58-83. - Selection and employment standards. 
    The city does hereby adopt and incorporate by reference the Selection and Employment Standards of the Michigan Law Enforcement Officers Training Council (MLEOTC), being R28.4102, R 28.4102a, R28.4108, R28.4301, and R28.4311 as amended from time to time by the state commission on law enforcement standards and promulgated pursuant to authority conferred by section 9 of Public Act No. 237 of 1965 (MCL 28.609). 
(Code 1974, § 24-26) 
Sec. 58-84. - Recruitment and employment practices. 
    Recruitment and employment practices and standards shall comply with the law applicable to law enforcement officer employment. 
(Code 1974, § 24-27) 
Secs. 58-85-58-100. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Continuing Employment Standards 

Sec. 58-101. - Conditions of employment. 
    All employees hired under this division after September 15, 1975, shall be subject to the following continuing conditions of employment: 
(1)  An employee shall be required to maintain a standard of agility and fitness throughout his employment period. All employees shall be tested for fitness and agility at a minimum of once per year under the direction of the department head. The fitness and agility test shall be in accordance with acceptable medical standards and shall take into consideration such factors as an employee's height, weight and age. The employee shall maintain an acceptable score in order to pass the test. 
(2)  All employees shall be required to undergo at least once a year and pass a medical examination. The examination shall show that the employee is free from any physical or mental conditions which might adversely affect the required performance of his duties or which may endanger the employee's life or lives of others. All employees shall be required to have normal visual functions and visual acuity in each eye, correctable to 20/20. Employees must be physically sound, well developed physically, with height and weight in relation to each other, and to age, as indicated by accepted medical standards, and in possession of their extremities. The employee shall be free from any chronic diseases, organic diseases, functional conditions or mental instability which may tend to impair his efficient performance of duty. This examination will be as prescribed by the city physician/facility, when requested by the department head. The examination will be at no cost to the employee. 
(3)  If an employee fails to retain or meet the requirements under subsections (1) and (2) of this section, such employee shall have a 30-calendar-day period from the date of the test or examination to meet such requirements. If found failing after reexamination, the employee shall then be subject to compliance as prescribed under the direction of the city physician/facility, which may or may not preclude active employment until such deficiency is corrected, or the employee may be placed on sick or medical leave for a period not to exceed six months or until such deficiency is corrected. If the impediment is not corrected at the expiration of the six-month period, the employee shall be placed on medical leave, or if qualified the employee may request a disability pension, or the employee may be terminated. 
(4)  If such an employee can produce, at his own expense, medical evidence by a licensed physician to the contrary, the employee's report, together with the city's report, shall be subject to an impartial decision by a third licensed physician selected by the two previous examiners. The expense shall be borne by the city and that decision shall be binding. 
(Code 1974, § 24-33) 
Secs. 58-102-58-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISCIPLINE OF MEMBERS 

Sec. 58-131. - Offenses for which disciplinary measures may be taken; types of disciplinary measures. 
(a)  A member of the police department found guilty of violating any of the following listed offenses shall be subject to reprimand, suspension, forfeiture of pay, or dismissal or suffer such other lawful punishment as the chief of police may direct: 
(1)  Cowardice. 
(2)  Willful disobedience of rules or general or special orders of the police department. 
(3)  Being under the influence of liquor or drinking any kind of intoxicating liquor while on duty, unless ordered by competent authority, or entering a place where intoxicating drinks are sold or kept, except in the line of duty. 
(4)  Entering a disorderly house or place where illegal commercial gambling is carried on, not in the performance of police duty. 
(5)  Willful maltreatment of a prisoner or any other person. 
(6)  Conduct unbecoming an officer. 
(7)  Insubordination or disrespect to a superior officer. 
(8)  Neglect of or inattention to duty. 
(9)  General incompetency. 
(10)  Sleeping while on active post duty. 
(11)  Being absent from duty without permission. 
(12)  Leaving his post without proper relief or purpose. 
(13)  Using coarse, profane or insolent language to a superior officer, to a member of the police department, or to any citizen. 
(14)  Not properly patrolling or guarding a post. 
(15)  Making a false statement or report. 
(16)  Neglecting to wear a proper uniform while on duty or neglecting to appear clean and tidy in person and dress. 
(17)  Accepting bribes of money or other valuables. 
(18)  Accepting any fee, reward or gift of any kind from any person arrested, or from any person in his behalf while in custody, or from any person for services rendered or pretended to be rendered as a member of the police department without consent of the chief of police. 
(19)  Gossiping about a member of the police department concerning his personal character or conduct, which is detrimental to such member. 
(20)  Publicly criticizing orders given by a superior officer. 
(21)  Communicating or giving information to any person concerning the business of the police department, which is detrimental to the police department. 
(22)  Communicating or giving police information which may aid a person to escape arrest, or to delay the apprehension of a criminal, or to secure the removal of stolen or embezzled goods or other property or money. 
(23)  Neglecting to pay a just indebtedness incurred while in the service, within a reasonable time. 
(24)  Assigning salary due or to become due to any person without permission from the chief of police. 
(25)  Refusing to give his name or badge number when requested. 
(26)  Neglecting to furnish persons arrested with a receipt for all personal property taken from them. 
(27)  Neglecting to turn over all property taken from persons arrested, or found, or seized, to the proper officer without unnecessary delay. 
(28)  Unjustified use of a revolver. 
(29)  Neglecting to report any member of the police department known to be guilty of a violation of any rule, regulation or order issued for the guidance of the police department. 
(30)  Failure to report a known violation of law or of this Code or other ordinance of the city. 
(31)  Ignorance of rules or orders. 
(32)  Immorality. 
(33)  Conviction of an offense in any court having criminal jurisdiction. 
(b)  Whenever it shall be deemed necessary for the preservation of good order, efficiency and discipline, the chief of police may suspend any one of his subordinates from duty for the reasons enumerated in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1974, § 26-25) 
Sec. 58-132. - Filing of charges. 
    When the chief of police suspends a member of the police department, he shall, without delay, file a written report of the charges with the city council and furnish the suspended member of the department with a copy of the charges. 
(Code 1974, § 26-26) 
Sec. 58-133. - Statement by suspended member; hearing. 
    Any suspended member of the police department shall make a written statement to the chief of police within 24 hours of his suspension. If he wishes a hearing on the charges, he shall make a written request of the city council within 48 hours from the time of his suspension. 
(Code 1974, § 26-27) 
Sec. 58-134. - Suspended members to turn over property belonging to city. 
    In all cases of suspension of any member of the police department, the suspended officer or member shall immediately surrender to the chief of police all property in his possession belonging to the city. Pending the disposition of the case, such property shall be retained by the chief of police. 
(Code 1974, § 26-28) 
Sec. 58-135. - Wearing uniform while suspended. 
    During a period of suspension, the suspended member of the police department shall not wear his uniform. 
(Code 1974, § 26-29) 
Sec. 58-136. - Complaints initiated by members. 
    When any member of the police department shall feel aggrieved or have complaint against any member of the police department, he shall have the right to file a written report of his complaint with the city council and the chief of police and request a public hearing before the city council. The city council shall have the discretion to decide in committee to either grant or deny the hearing. 
(Code 1974, § 26-30) 
Secs. 58-137-58-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CIVILIAN CROSSING GUARDS 

Sec. 58-161. - Generally; authority of chief of police. 
    The chief of police is hereby authorized and directed to appoint special guards, to be known as civilian crossing guards, in such numbers as he may deem necessary, to perform police duties under the direction of and in compliance with such rules and regulations as the chief of police shall promulgate. 
(Code 1974, § 26-41) 
Sec. 58-162. - Qualifications, appointment and removal. 
    The chief of police shall promulgate rules relating to the qualifications, appointment and removal of civilian crossing guards. 
(Code 1974, § 26-42) 
Sec. 58-163. - Compensation. 
    Civilian crossing guards shall serve with such compensation as may be provided for by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 26-43) 
Sec. 58-164. - Dress, insignia and equipment. 
    Civilian crossing guards shall wear such badges, dress and insignia as the chief of police shall direct, and shall be equipped in the manner which the chief of police deems necessary for the proper discharge of their duties. 
(Code 1974, § 26-44) 
Sec. 58-165. - Failure to respond for duty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any civilian crossing guard to knowingly and willfully neglect or refuse to respond for assignment or duty when called under the rules and regulations promulgated by the chief of police. 
(Code 1974, § 26-45) 
Sec. 58-166. - Unlawful use of uniform and authority. 
    It shall be unlawful for any civilian crossing guard to exercise his authority as a guard, or to wear the uniform or insignia, or to display his badge in an attempt to exercise his authority, except during the performance of actual authorized police duty. 
(Code 1974, § 26-46) 
Sec. 58-167. - Impersonating civilian crossing guard. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not duly appointed and sworn in as a civilian crossing guard to impersonate such officer, or to wear, carry or display the badge, designated dress or insignia of such civilian crossing guards. 
(Code 1974, § 26-47) 
Sec. 58-168. - Worker's compensation coverage. 
    Civilian crossing guards shall be entitled to all rights and benefits provided under the provisions of the Worker's Disability Compensation Act of 1969 (MCL 418.101 et seq.). 
(Code 1974, § 26-48) 
Secs. 58-169-58-190. - Reserved.

(Code 1974, § 26-62)

Other duties may be prescribed from time to time upon approval by the city council. (Code 1974, § 26-65) 
Sec. 58-198. - Unlawful use of uniform and authority. 
    It shall be unlawful for any parking enforcement attendant to exercise his authority as such attendant, or to wear the uniform or insignia, or to display his badge in an attempt to exercise his authority, except during the performance of actual authorized parking enforcement duty. 
(Code 1974, § 26-66) 
Sec. 58-199. - Impersonating parking enforcement attendant. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not duly appointed and sworn in as a parking enforcement attendant to impersonate such officer, or to wear, carry or display the badge, designated dress or insignia of such parking enforcement attendant. 
(Code 1974, § 26-67) 
Chapter 62 - MOBILE HOMES AND MANUFACTURED HOMES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 38; floods, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 54; solid waste, ch. 74; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; subdivisions and other divisions of land, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 98; vegetation, ch. 102; waterways, ch. 106; zoning, ch. 110; MH mobile home park district, § 110-311 et seq.; inspection of mobile home units, app. A, § A-81. 
State Law reference- Mobile homes and mobile home parks, MCL 125.2301 et seq.; local regulation of mobile homes, MCL 125.2307. 

Sec. 62-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mobile home means any vehicle used or so constructed so as to permit it to be used as a dwelling or sleeping place, which is or may be mounted on wheels, and is or may be propelled either by its own power or by another vehicle to which it may be attached. 
    Mobile home park means any site, lot, field or tract of land upon which three or more occupied trailer coaches are harbored, either free of charge or for revenue purposes, and shall include any building, structure, tent, vehicle or enclosure used or intended for use as a part of the equipment of such mobile home park. 
(Code 1974, § 20-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 62-2. - Mobile Home Commission Act adopted. 
    The Mobile Home Commission Act (MCL 125.2301 et seq.) is adopted by reference. 
Sec. 62-3. - Parking overnight on street or other public place. 
    No person shall park or cause to be parked any mobile home overnight on any street, alley, highway or other public place in the city. 
(Code 1974, § 20-2) 
Sec. 62-4. - Parking between setback line and curbline. 
    No mobile home shall at any time be parked between the established setback line and the curbline on any lot. 
(Code 1974, § 20-3) 
Sec. 62-5. - Clearance around mobile home. 
    No mobile home shall be used or occupied by any person unless there is a clear, unoccupied space of at least ten feet on all sides thereof. 
(Code 1974, § 20-4) 
Sec. 62-6. - Removal of wheels; blocking and stabilizing. 
    No person shall remove or cause to be removed the wheels or tires from any mobile home except for the purpose of repair, nor shall any person elevate, block or stabilize any such coach other than with jacks designated, provided and intended for such purpose. 
(Code 1974, § 20-5) 
Sec. 62-7. - Limitation on number of occupants. 
    No mobile home shall be occupied for sleeping purposes by a greater number of persons than the mobile home is designed and arranged to accommodate. 
(Code 1974, § 20-6) 
Sec. 62-8. - Mobile home park license. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain, conduct, carry on or operate a mobile home park without first having received a license from the city. 
(b)  State permit. No license shall be issued to any applicant for a license required by this section unless he first procures a permit from the state for operation of the mobile home park. 
(c)  Transfer. All licenses issued pursuant to this section shall be personal to the licensee and be nontransferable without the written consent of the city. 
(d)  Suspension or revocation. Any license granted pursuant to this section shall be subject to revocation or suspension by a court of proper authority and jurisdiction; provided, however, that the state health director, the county health officer, the city health officer, or any police officer having jurisdiction thereof shall first serve or cause to be served upon the licensee a written notice in which shall be specified the way in which such licensee has failed to comply with the state law or any special rules or regulations promulgated by the state health director pertaining thereto. The notice shall require the licensee to remove or abate such nuisance, insanitary or objectionable condition specified in such notice within five days, or within such longer period of time or extended period of time as may be allowed by the complainant. If the licensee fails to comply with the terms and conditions of the notice within the time specified or such extended period of time, the complainant may cause a civil action to be instituted to remove or abate such nuisance, insanitary or objectionable condition as complained of, in the court of proper authority and jurisdiction, in the name of the people, and, if found guilty of such violation, a decision may be entered by the court to revoke or suspend such license. 
(Code 1974, §§ 20-38-28-41) 
Chapter 66 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, ch. 58. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Loitering where prostitution or illegal business conducted. 
    No person shall loiter: 
(1)  In a house of ill fame or prostitution or place where prostitution or lewdness is practiced, encouraged or allowed to take place. 
(2)  In or about any place where an illegal occupation or business is being conducted. 
(Code 1974, § 19-1(b), (c)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.167(1)(i), (1)(j). 
Sec. 66-2. - Transporting persons to place where illegal business conducted. 
    No person shall transport any person, for consideration, to a place where an illegal occupation or business is being conducted, including the business of prostitution, illegal gambling or the illegal sale of liquor, for the purpose of enabling such person to patronize such a business. 
(Code 1974, § 19-1(e)) 
Sec. 66-3. - Loitering to solicit business for provision of legal services or bail. 
    No person shall loiter in or about any police station, jail, hospital, court building or any other public building or place for the sole purpose of soliciting engagement for the provision of legal services or the services of sureties upon criminal recognizances. 
(Code 1974, § 19-1(f)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.167(1)(k). 
Sec. 66-4. - Posting advertisements or other notices on utility poles. 
    No person shall tack, nail, paste or in any manner attach or affix to any telegraph, telephone, electric light, power or fire alarm pole any advertisement or any advertising matter, sign, notice or placard, in any street, alley, park, lane or public place in the city. 
(Code 1974, § 19-9) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 98. 
Sec. 66-5. - Use of tobacco on school property. 
(a)  Definitions. In this section: 
    School district means a school district, local act school district, or intermediate school district, as those terms are defined in the Revised School Code (MCL 380.1 et seq.), a joint high school district formed under such act, or a consortium or cooperative arrangement consisting of any combination of these. 
    School property means a building, facility, or structure and other real estate owned, leased, or otherwise controlled by a school district. 
    Tobacco product means a preparation of tobacco to be inhaled, chewed, or placed in a person's mouth. 
    Use of a tobacco product means any of the following: 
(1)  The carrying by a person of a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or other lighted smoking device. 
(2)  The inhaling or chewing of a tobacco product. 
(3)  The placing of a tobacco product within a person's mouth. 
(b)  Use prohibited. Except as otherwise provided in this section, a person shall not use a tobacco product on school property. 
(c)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to that part of school property consisting of outdoor areas, including, but not limited to, an open area stadium, during either of the following time periods: 
(1)  Saturdays, Sundays, and other days on which there are no regularly scheduled school hours. 
(2)  After 6:00 p.m. on days during which there are regularly scheduled school hours. 
(d)  Penalty. A person who is convicted of violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1974, §§ 19-151-19-154) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.473. 
Secs. 66-6-66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES INVOLVING DANGER OR INJURY TO THE PERSON 

Sec. 66-31. - Assault; assault and battery. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an assault or an assault and battery upon the person of another. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an assault or an assault and battery upon his or her spouse or former spouse and a person with whom he or she has had a child in common, or a resident or former resident of his or her household. 
(Code 1974, § 19-3) 
State Law reference- Assault and battery generally, MCL 750.81 et seq. 
Sec. 66-32. - Stalking. 
(a)  As used in this section: 
    Course of conduct means a pattern of conduct composed of a series of two or more separate noncontinuous acts, evidencing a continuity of purpose. 
    Emotional distress means significant mental suffering or distress that may, but does not necessarily require, medical or other professional treatment or counseling. 
    Harassment means conduct directed toward a victim that includes, but is not limited to, repeated or continuing unconsented contact, that would cause a reasonable individual to suffer emotional distress, and that actually causes the victim to suffer emotional distress. Harassment does not include constitutionally protected activity or conduct that serves a legitimate purpose. 
    Stalking means a willful course of conduct involving repeated or continuing harassment of another individual that would cause a reasonable person to feel terrorized, frightened, intimidated, threatened, harassed, or molested, and that actually causes the victim to feel terrorized, frightened, intimidated, threatened, harassed, or molested. 
    Unconsented contact means any contact with another individual that is initiated or continued without that individual's consent, or in disregard of that individual's expressed desire that the contact be avoided or discontinued. Unconsented contact includes, but is not limited to, any of the following: 
(1)  Following or appearing within the sight of that individual. 
(2)  Approaching or confronting that individual in a public place or on private property. 
(3)  Appearing at the workplace or residence of that individual. 
(4)  Entering onto or remaining on property owned, leased, or occupied by that individual. 
(5)  Contacting that individual by telephone. 
(6)  Sending mail or electronic communications to that individual. 
(7)  Placing an object on, or delivering an object to, property owned, leased, or occupied by that individual. 
    Victim means an individual who is the target of a willful course of conduct involving repeated or continuing harassment. 
(b)  An individual who engages in stalking is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  The court may place an individual convicted of violating subsection (b) of this section on probation for a term of not more than five years. If a term of probation is ordered, the court may, in addition to any other lawful condition of probation, order the defendant to do any of the following: 
(1)  Refrain from stalking any individual during the term of probation. 
(2)  Refrain from having any contact with the victim of the offense. 
(3)  Be evaluated to determine the need for psychiatric, psychological, or social counseling and, if determined appropriate by the court, to receive psychiatric, psychological, or social counseling at his own expense. 
(d)  In a prosecution for a violation of this section, evidence that the defendant continued to engage in a course of conduct involving repeated unconsented contact with the victim after having been requested by the victim to discontinue the such conduct or a different form of unconsented contact with the victim shall give rise to a rebuttable presumption that the continuation of the course of conduct caused the victim to feel terrorized, frightened, intimidated, threatened, harassed, or molested. 
(e)  A criminal penalty provided for under this section may be imposed in addition to any penalty that may be imposed for any other criminal offense arising from the same conduct or for any contempt of court arising from the same conduct. 
(Code 1974, § 19-22) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.411h. 
Sec. 66-33. - Voyeurism. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly go upon the property owned or leased by another and peer through windows, or other entryway, of a building on that property without the express or implied consent of the owner or duly authorized occupant. 
(Code 1974, § 19-1(a)) 
State Law reference- Window peepers, MCL 750.167(1)(c). 
Secs. 66-34-66-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PROPERTY RIGHTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 66-61. - Reward for information leading to conviction of persons damaging public property. 
(a)  The city shall pay a reward to any person furnishing information leading to the apprehension and conviction of persons who do damage to public property within the meaning of subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  The damage to public property must be to the extent that the damage causes the city to suffer a financial loss by reason of inability to identify the offenders, or by reason of inadequate insurance coverage by the offenders. 
(c)  The amount of the reward authorized by this section shall not be less than $25.00 or more than $100.00, with the ultimate determination of the amount to rest solely in the discretion of the city council. The city council may request a written report and recommendation from the department heads or department supervisors who have control of the public property damaged by the offenders. 
(d)  The reward money authorized by this section shall not be paid until the city attorney and chief of police have jointly certified to the city council that the information furnished was the substantial factor leading to the apprehension and conviction of the persons who damaged the public property. 
(e)  The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to any city employees or any members of their immediate families, or state, county or other governmental officials whose responsibilities include enforcement of laws. 
(Code 1974, § 26-4) 
Sec. 66-62. - Destruction of property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, injure, deface or in any manner interfere with or hinder the use of any public or private land, building, shrubbery, trees or appurtenances, or any public property whatsoever, including any property or equipment of any public utility serving the people of the city. 
(b)  No person shall willfully and maliciously destroy, injure, deface, damage or tamper with the personal property of another where the damage done is $500.00 or less. 
(Code 1974, § 19-8) 
State Law reference- Malicious and willful mischief and destruction, MCL 750.377a et seq. 
Sec. 66-63. - Graffiti prohibited; possession of spray paint by underage persons. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "spray paint" shall mean any adherent pigmented substance disbursed in particles by means of atomizer or other simple mechanical instrument or applicator. 
(b)  No person under 18 years of age shall purchase or possess, except on property owned or occupied by a parent or legal guardian of such person, any containers used to dispense, or capable of dispensing, spray paint. 
(c)  No person shall maliciously deface the real personal property of another, including public property or that of any public utility serving the city, by the application of spray paint to such property, without the authorization of the owner. 
(d)  The owner of any building or other structure defaced by the application of spray paint or other similar substance shall remove, paint over or otherwise permanently cover property defaced within a reasonable period, not to exceed ten days, after the discovery of its existence, so as to preclude further vandalism or decay of the structure or the immediate surrounding area, subject to weather permitting conditions. 
(e)  In addition to other penalties provided by this Code, any individual convicted of violating subsection (c) of this section may be required by the court, at the option of the owner of property defaced by the graffiti, to assist in its removal. 
(Code 1974, §§ 19-89-19-93) 
State Law reference- Malicious and willful mischief and destruction, MCL 750.377a et seq. 
Sec. 66-64. - Tampering with motor vehicles. 
(a)  Any person who shall tamper with a motor vehicle without the permission of the owner of the vehicle or who shall aid and abet another to do so, within the limits of the city, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person shall be guilty of this misdemeanor, who shall: 
(1)  Intentionally, and without authority from the owner, start or cause to be started the motor of any motor vehicle, or maliciously shift or change the starting device or gears of a standing motor vehicle to a position other than that in which it was left by the owner or driver of the motor vehicle; 
(2)  Intentionally cut, mark, scratch or damage the chassis, running gear, body, sides, top, covering or upholstering of any motor vehicle, the property of another, or intentionally cut, mash, mark, destroy or damage such motor vehicle, or any of the accessories, equipment, appurtenances or attachments thereof, or any spare or extra parts thereon being or thereto attached, without the permission of the owner thereof; 
(3)  Intentionally release the brake upon any standing motor vehicle, with intent to injure the machine or cause the vehicle to be removed without the consent of the owner; provided that this subsection shall not apply in case of moving or starting of motor vehicles by the police under authority of local ordinance or by members of the fire department in case of emergency in the vicinity of a fire; or 
(4)  Intentionally, and without authority from the owner, enter or attempt to enter a motor vehicle. 
(Code 1974, § 19-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.416. 
Secs. 66-65-66-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRESPASS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Trespass, MCL 750.546 et seq. 

Sec. 66-81. - Entry without authority. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person to break and enter, or to enter without breaking, any dwelling, house, tent, hotel, office, store, shop, warehouse, barn, factory or other building, boat, ship, railroad car or structure used or kept for public or private use, or any private apartment therein, or any cottage, clubhouse, boathouse, hunting or fishing lodge, garage or the outbuildings belonging thereto, or any other structure, whether occupied or unoccupied, without first obtaining permission to enter from the owner or occupant, agent or person having immediate control thereof; provided, that this section shall not apply to entering without breaking any place which at the time of such entry was open to the public unless such entry has been expressly denied, or to circumstances where the breaking and entering or entering without breaking was committed by a peace officer, or someone under his direction, in the lawful performance of his duties as a peace officer. 
(Code 1974, § 19-23) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.115. 
Sec. 66-82. - Entry after having been forbidden to do so; entry on posted property. 
    Any person who shall willfully enter upon the lands or premises of another without lawful authority, after having been forbidden so to do, or after such lands or premises have been previously posted with a conspicuous notice forbidding any trespass thereon by the owner or occupant, or agent or servant of the owner or occupant, or any person being upon the land or premises of another, upon being notified to depart therefrom by the owner or occupant, or agent or servant of either, who without lawful authority neglects or refuses to depart therefrom shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1974, § 19-20) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.552. 
Sec. 66-83. - Refusal to leave public premises. 
    No person shall remain in any public place or place open and accessible to the public after its regular closing hours and after having been instructed to leave by a person authorized to give such an instruction. 
(Code 1974, § 19-1(k)) 
Sec. 66-84. - Loitering. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to linger, loiter, sit or stand in any public room in any hotel, motel, or office or business establishment in the city, or any courthouse corridor, or any bus or railroad station, or the hallways or entrances of any public building, or any parking site or parking facility, accessible to the public, without authorization of the owner, or to use any public room for business or social purposes, or to obstruct the entrance to any business establishment, if contrary to the expressed wish of the owner, lessee, managing agent or person in control or charge of the building or premises. 
(b)  The term "public room," for the purpose of this section, includes any basement, attic, building entrance or doorway, lobby, hallway, stairway, mezzanine, elevator, foyer, public restroom, sitting room or other place used in common by the public, tenants, occupants, guests or customers, and situated in a hotel, motel, office building, public building or business establishment in the city. 
(c)  Violations of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, § 2-306(a)(36), 19-2) 
Secs. 66-85-66-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LARCENY AND RELATED OFFENSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Larceny, MCL 750.356. 

Sec. 66-101. - Larceny. 
    Any person who shall commit larceny or aid and abet another to commit larceny shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1974, § 19-16) 
State Law reference- Larceny prohibited, MCL 750.356 et seq. 
Sec. 66-102. - Retail theft. 
    A person who does any of the following in a store or in its immediate vicinity is guilty of a misdemeanor: 
(1)  While a store is open to the public, alters, transfers, removes and replaces, conceals, or otherwise misrepresents the price at which property is offered for sale with the intent not to pay for the property or to pay less than the price at which the property is offered. 
(2)  While a store is open to the public, steals property of the store that is offered for sale. 
(3)  With intent to defraud, obtains or attempts to obtain money or property from the store as a refund or exchange for property that was not paid for and belongs to the store. 
(Code 1974, § 19-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.536d. 
Sec. 66-103. - Obtaining money by false pretenses. 
    Any person who shall obtain money by false pretenses or aid and abet another to do so, within the limits of the city, shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1974, § 19-17) 
State Law reference- False pretenses, MCL 750.218 et seq. 
Sec. 66-104. - Altering serial numbers; possession or sale of goods with altered serial numbers. 
(a)  A person who obscures, defaces, alters, obliterates, removes, destroys, or otherwise conceals or disguises any registration, serial, or other identifying number embossed, engraved, carved, stamped, welded, or otherwise placed or situated in or upon goods or property held for sale in the ordinary course of business with the intent to render the goods or property unidentifiable shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  A person who is a dealer in or collector of any merchandise or personal property or the agent, employee, or representative of a dealer or collector and who possesses goods or property with the intent to sell the goods or property in the ordinary course of business knowing the registration, serial, or other identifying number has been obscured, defaced, altered, obliterated, removed, destroyed, or otherwise concealed or disguised shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  A person who is a dealer or collector of any merchandise or personal property or the agent, employee, or representative of a dealer or collector and who sells goods or property in the ordinary course of business knowing that the registration, serial, or other identifying number has been obscured, defaced, altered, obliterated, removed, destroyed, or otherwise concealed or disguised shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1974, § 19-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.536a. 
Sec. 66-105. - Possession of stolen property. 
    Any person who shall have possession of stolen property or who shall aid and abet another to do so, within the limits of the city, shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1974, § 19-18) 
State Law reference- Receiving or concealing stolen property, MCL 750.116. 
Sec. 66-106. - Bad checks. 
(a)  A person shall not make, draw, utter, or deliver any check, draft, or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository with intent to defraud and knowing at the time of the making, drawing, uttering, or delivering that the maker or drawer does not have sufficient funds in or credit with the bank or other depository to pay the check, draft, or order in full upon its presentation. 
(b)  A person shall not make, draw, utter, or deliver any check, draft, or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository with intent to defraud if the person does not have sufficient funds for the payment of the check, draft, or order when presentation for payment is made to the drawee. This subsection does not apply if the lack of funds is due to garnishment, attachment, levy, or other lawful cause and that fact was not known to the person when the person made, drew, uttered, or delivered the check, draft, or order. 
(c)  As against the maker or drawer thereof, the making, drawing, uttering or delivering of a check, draft or order for payment of money which is refused for payment by the drawee, when presented in the usual course of business, shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and of knowledge of insufficient funds in or credit with such bank or other depository, provided such maker or drawer shall not have paid the drawee thereof the amount due thereon, together with all costs, within five days after receiving notice that such check, draft or order has not been paid by the drawee. 
(d)  Where such check, draft or order is not accepted and is stamped or otherwise indicated on its face by the bank or depository with the words "insufficient funds" or with words to that effect or a notice to that effect is attached to the unaccepted check, such endorsement shall be admissible as proof of presentation, nonpayment and nonacceptance by the bank or depository, and shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud, and of knowledge of insufficient funds or credit with such bank or other depository.
