    Newspaper means and includes any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the federal postal service in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law, and, in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year and sold to the public. 
    Private premises means any dwelling, house, building or other structure, designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place means any and all streets, boulevards, avenues, lanes, alleys or other public ways, and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, plazas, grounds and buildings. 
(Code 1974, § 3-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-442. - Purpose. 
    To protect the people against the nuisance of and incident to the promiscuous distribution of handbills and circulars, with the resulting detriment and danger to public health and safety, the public interest, convenience and necessity requires the regulation thereof and to that end the purposes of this article are specifically declared to be as follows: 
(1)  To protect local residents against trespassing by solicitors, canvassers or handbill distributors upon the private property of such residents if they have given reasonable notice that they do not wish to be solicited by such persons or do not desire to receive handbills or advertising matter. 
(2)  To protect the people against the health and safety menace and the expense incident to the littering of the streets and public places by the promiscuous and uncontrolled distribution of advertising matter and handbills. 
(Code 1974, § 3-16) 
Sec. 66-443. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to newspapers or to the distribution of mail by the United States. 
(Code 1974, § 3-18) 
Sec. 66-444. - Distributing or scattering in public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any handbill in or upon any public place within the city or to hand out or distribute or sell any handbill in any public place; however, it shall not be unlawful for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any handbill in any public place to any person willing to accept such handbill. 
(Code 1974, § 3-19) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 66-445. - Placing in vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any handbill in or upon any automobile or other vehicle. The provisions of this section shall not be deemed to prohibit the handing, transmitting or distributing of any handbill to the owner or other occupant of any automobile or other vehicle who is willing to accept the handbill, or the placement of handbills on vehicles in a manner that will prevent them from being blown about or scattered by the elements. 
(Code 1974, § 3-20) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
Sec. 66-446. - Distribution on uninhabited or vacant private premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant except in a manner that will prevent such handbills from being blown about or scattered by the elements. 
(Code 1974, § 3-21) 
Sec. 66-447. - Distribution on posted property. 
(a)  Soliciting or canvassing on private property which is posted with signage indicating "No Trespassing", "No Canvassing", "No peddlers or Agents" or "No Advertisements" or similar notice, indicating in any manner that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or to have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any such handbills left upon such premises, is prohibited however, it shall be the duty of the owner, landlord or person in control of any premises remaining vacant for a period more than five days to post in a conspicuous position on the premises such signage as is indicated by the section. 
(b)  The term "vacant," as used in subsection (a) of this section, shall not be deemed to include temporary absence from the premises by its regular occupants. 
(Code 1974, § 3-22; Ord. No. 791, § 1, 11-6-2017) 
Sec. 66-448. - Distribution on inhabited private premises. 
    No person shall distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any handbill in or upon any private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant or any other person then present in or upon such private premises; however, in the case of inhabited private premises which are not posted as provided in this article, the person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such inhabited private premises, if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or elsewhere, except that mailboxes may not be so used when prohibited by federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1974, § 3-23) 
Sec. 66-449. - Distribution on private premises prohibited during certain hours. 
    No handbills may be distributed on private premises before 9:00 a.m. or later than 9:00 p.m. of any day. 
(Code 1974, § 3-27) 
Chapter 70 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 38; outdoor assemblies, § 66-381 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; vegetation, ch. 102; waterways, ch. 106. 
State Law reference- Authority to operate system of public recreation, MCL 125.51 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Public hearing required for certain physical changes in public parks. 
(a)  This section shall only apply to those parks that are owned, leased or otherwise under the control of the city. This section does not apply to any park facility that is owned by another unit of government. 
(b)  In this section, the term "physical changes" means the following: 
(1)  Any physical change to the existing grade of the land in excess of three feet or more. 
(2)  Any new recreation equipment where expenditure is in excess of $10,000.00 per park, in any one purchase. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to ordinary repairs or maintenance programs. 
(d)  A public hearing shall be held before the city council prior to any physical changes being implemented, as defined in this section, with respect to the city park system. 
(e)  Notice of the public hearing shall be published at least one week prior to the public hearing. The city shall also notify, by mail, all owners of record of property and the occupants of all residential properties located within 300 feet of construction limits of the physical change. 
(Code 1974, § 23-49) 
Secs. 70-2-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-401 et seq. 

Sec. 70-31. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a parks and recreation commission of the city to act solely in an advisory capacity. 
(Code 1974, § 23-16) 
Sec. 70-32. - Composition; appointment of members. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall consist of nine members, who shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation of a majority vote of the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-17) 
Sec. 70-33. - Persons ineligible for membership. 
    No person shall be eligible for appointment to the parks and recreation commission who is the holder of any public office, elective or appointive, under the Charter. 
(Code 1974, § 23-18) 
Sec. 70-34. - Director of parks and recreation to serve as nonvoting member. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall serve as a nonvoting permanent member of the parks and recreation commission. 
(Code 1974, § 23-19) 
Sec. 70-35. - Term of office of members. 
    All members of the parks and recreation commission, other than the director of parks and recreation, shall serve a term of three years. 
(Code 1974, § 23-20) 
Sec. 70-36. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the parks and recreation commission occurring before the expiration of any term of office shall be reported by the commission to the mayor and city council and filled by appointment for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1974, § 23-21) 
Sec. 70-37. - Organizational meeting; officers; bylaws. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall immediately after appointment meet and organize by the election of one of its members as chairperson, and by the election of such other officers as it deems necessary. The commission shall adopt bylaws for the orderly conduct of its meetings and for the proper process of its functions. 
(Code 1974, § 23-22) 
Sec. 70-38. - Regular meetings. 
    Regular meetings of the parks and recreation commission shall be held monthly and as often as may be deemed necessary by the chairperson. 
(Code 1974, § 23-23) 
Sec. 70-39. - Filing of minutes. 
    A copy of the minutes of all parks and recreation commission meetings shall be filed with the city clerk for submittal to the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-24) 
Sec. 70-40. - Commission to act in advisory capacity. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall act as an advisory commission to the city council and the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1974, § 23-25) 
Sec. 70-41. - Recommendation of master plan for city recreation programs. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall consider, study and recommend an overall master plan for the development of citywide recreation programs. 
(Code 1974, § 23-26) 
Sec. 70-42. - Recommendations on land acquisitions. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall review and from time to time make recommendations to the city council on necessary land acquisition to assist in the development of the city parks and recreation program. 
(Code 1974, § 23-27) 
Sec. 70-43. - Recommendations regarding new parks and improvements to existing parks. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall consider, study and make recommendations relative to the development of parks and recreation programs in new areas, and shall also consider and study and make recommendations for improvements of existing parks and recreation programs. 
(Code 1974, § 23-28) 
Sec. 70-44. - Assistance by other city agencies. 
    The parks and recreation commission may call on any department, board or commission of the city for such technical and advisory assistance as may be needed. 
(Code 1974, § 23-29) 
Sec. 70-45. - Expenditures. 
    The parks and recreation commission and its members shall not incur any expense or create any obligation or liability upon the city. If any expenditure of city funds may be required in connection with the functioning of the parks and recreation commission, prior approval of such expenditures shall first be obtained from the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-30) 
Secs. 70-46-70-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DIRECTOR OF PARKS AND RECREATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 

Sec. 70-71. - Appointment. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall be appointed by the mayor on the basis of his training, education and experience in physical education and public recreation activities and shall be a full-time administrative officer. 
(Code 1974, § 23-41) 
Sec. 70-72. - Director to be administrative head of department of parks and recreation; accountability to mayor. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall be the administrative head of the department of parks and recreation, and he shall be accountable and responsible to the mayor for the performance of his duties. 
(Code 1974, § 23-42) 
Sec. 70-73. - General duties. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall perform such duties as may be prescribed by this Code, the Charter or state law or as may be required of him by the mayor or city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-43) 
Sec. 70-74. - Duty to provide recreational activities. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall provide recreational and out-of-doors activities for the inhabitants, and especially for the children, of the city and shall provide for a full and complete yearround adult and children recreational program. 
(Code 1974, § 23-44) 
Sec. 70-75. - Maintenance of park property. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall maintain and repair parks, playgrounds, public grounds and play areas, including the interior and exterior of all community buildings and park service buildings, and provide for the safe storage and maintenance of all park and recreational equipment. 
(Code 1974, § 23-45) 
Sec. 70-76. - Recommendations to city council. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall recommend to the city council the acquisition and establishment by the city of all necessary parks, playgrounds, athletic fields, summer camps and facilities required to organize, establish, equip, maintain and operate the department of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1974, § 23-46) 
Sec. 70-77. - Arrangements for use of board of education park facilities and equipment. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall communicate and arrange with the city board of education for the use of park facilities and equipment belonging to the board of education, for such time as may be available to the city, and to provide and arrange a program for such use thereof. 
(Code 1974, § 23-47) 
Sec. 70-78. - Inventory of parks and recreation equipment. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall prepare for the mayor and city council, within 30 days following the end of each six months of the fiscal year, an inventory of all equipment under the control of the parks and recreation department. 
(Code 1974, § 23-48) 
Secs. 70-79-70-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONDUCT IN PARKS 

Sec. 70-101. - Basis of city actions or decisions. 
    All actions and decisions of the director of parks and recreation under the provisions of this article shall be based upon the following: 
(1)  Public safety. 
(2)  Preserving the right of the public to the parks. 
(3)  Avoiding damage to the parks. 
Sec. 70-102. - Closing time for parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be or remain in any city park between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. The provisions of this section do not apply to any persons who have received special permission from the city council or its designee to remain in the park during those hours. Special permission may be granted to those who have established to the city council or its designee that reliable and adequate adult supervision will be present during such extended time period. 
(b)  Notice of the park closing hours shall be conspicuously posted. 
(c)  Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(23), 23-1) 
State Law reference- Trespass, MCL 750.546 et seq. 
Sec. 70-103. - Animals generally. 
(a)  No person shall lead or allow to be loose upon city park premises any animal, except that dogs may be taken into the park system provided they are held by a suitable leash not more than six feet in length. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  A person with disabilities because the person with disabilities is being led or accompanied by a guide or leader dog, hearing dog, or service dog if the guide or leader dog is wearing a harness or if the hearing dog or service dog is wearing a blaze orange leash and collar, hearing dog cape, or service dog backpack, and the person with disabilities being led or accompanied has in his possession a pictured identification card certifying that the dog was trained by a qualified organization or trainer. 
(2)  A trainer of guide or leader dogs, hearing dogs, or service dogs because the trainer is being led or accompanied by a guide or leader dog, hearing dog, or service dog if the guide or leader dog is wearing a harness or if the hearing dog or service dog is wearing a hearing dog cape or service dog backpack, if the trainer is being led or accompanied by an adult dog for the purpose of training the dog, and if the trainer has in his possession picture identification and identification stating that he is a representative or employee of an organization or trainer, or is a trainer, included on the state department of labor list of organizations or trainers that train guide or leader dogs, hearing dogs, or service dogs. 
(c)  As used in subsection (b) of this section: 
    Adult dog means a domestic dog of the species Canis familiaris that is 12 months of age or older. 
    Audibly impaired means audibly impaired as defined in section 1 of Public Act No. 82 of 1981 (MCL 752.61). 
    Blind person means a blind person as defined in section 1 of Public Act No. 260 of 1978 (MCL 393.351). 
    Deaf person means a deaf person as defined in section 1 of Public Act No. 82 of 1981 (MCL 752.61). 
    Person with disabilities means a person who is audibly impaired, blind, deaf, or otherwise physically limited. 
    Physically limited means physically limited as defined in section 1 of Public Act No. 1 of 1966 (MCL 125.1351). 
(d)  Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(24), 23-59) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Rights of persons with disabilities or trainer relative to guide, hearing, leader or service dogs, MCL 750.502c. 
Sec. 70-104. - Horses and similar animals. 
    No person shall drive any horse, mule, pony or other such riding animal in any of the parks of the city, unless bridle paths have been established, in which case no person shall drive any such animal in the park except on such designated bridle path Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(25), 23-60) 
Sec. 70-105. - Injuring or interfering with animals or birds. 
    No person shall trap, catch, wound or kill or treat cruelly, or attempt to trap, catch, wound or kill, any bird or animal, or molest or rob any nest of any bird or animal, in the city park system. 
(Code 1974, § 23-61) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 
Sec. 70-106. - Sports, games and other amusements. 
    No person shall engage in any sport, game, exercise or amusement in the city park system except such portions thereof as may be designated for such activities by the director of parks and recreation and then only under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by him. 
(Code 1974, § 23-62) 
Cross reference- Amusements and entertainment, ch. 10. 
Sec. 70-107. - Use of vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall bring or use any vehicle upon any portion of the city park system where such vehicles are prohibited from being brought or used by direction of the director of parks and recreation. 
(b)  The police department is hereby authorized to remove and/or impound any and all vehicles which have been brought into or used in the city park system, where any such vehicles are prohibited from use by direction of the director of parks and recreation, excepting those vehicles legally parked in a designated parking area. 
(Code 1974, § 23-63) 
Sec. 70-108. - Offering articles for sale; peddling or soliciting. 
    No person shall offer or exchange for sale any article or thing, or do any hawking, peddling or soliciting, or buy or offer to buy any article or thing, or take up any collection or solicit or receive contributions of money or anything of value in the city park system, except when authorized to do so by permit from or contract with the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1974, § 23-64) 
Cross reference- Peddlers and transient merchants, § 22-301 et seq. 
Sec. 70-109. - Public meetings or entertainments. 
    No person shall call or hold any public meeting or give any concert or public entertainment of any kind in the city park system without the express consent of the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1974, § 23-65) 
Cross reference- Outdoor assemblies, § 66-381 et seq. 
Sec. 70-110. - Entering restricted areas. 
    No person shall enter upon any portion of the park system where persons are prohibited from going as indicated by sign or notice. 
(Code 1974, § 23-66) 
Sec. 70-111. - Improper speech or conduct. 
    No person shall use any abusive, threatening, insulting, indecent, profane or obscene language, or language calculated to occasion a breach of the peace, or be guilty of any indecent act or behavior in the city park system. 
(Code 1974, § 23-67) 
Sec. 70-112. - Sleeping; using hammocks. 
    No person shall sleep in the city park system between 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., or place, swing, occupy or use any hammock therein. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(27), 23-69) 
Sec. 70-113. - Use of playground equipment by adults. 
    No person 18 years of age or more shall in any manner use any of the playground apparatus or devices meant exclusively for the use of children. 
(Code 1974, § 23-70) 
Sec. 70-114. - Throwing missiles; shooting golf balls. 
    No person shall throw or cast any stones or other missiles within the city park system or shoot any golf balls or other similar missiles in any part of the park unless there is an area specifically designated for such activity. 
(Code 1974, § 23-71) 
Sec. 70-115. - Obstructing traffic. 
    No person shall set or place, or cause to be set or placed, any goods, wares or merchandise or property of any kind so as to obstruct travel in the city park system. 
(Code 1974, § 23-72) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
Sec. 70-116. - Setting fires. 
    No person shall light or make use of any fire in the city park system, except such portions thereof as may be designated by the director of parks and recreation and the fire prevention division of the fire department for such purpose and then only under regulations as are prescribed by such officer and division. 
(Code 1974, § 23-73) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 42. 
Sec. 70-117. - Intoxicants. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, sell, give away or drink any intoxicating liquor, beer or wine in any city park or in the city park system, unless a valid permit has been issued as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Upon written application to the director of parks and recreation, or his designee, a limited permit may be issued for discreet consumption of alcoholic beverages for family or social parties, and recognized club activities. Such permit, if issued, shall be subject to the rules and regulations and restrictions imposed by the department of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1974, § 23-74(b), (c)) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquors, ch. 6. 
Sec. 70-118. - Depositing refuse; use of receptacles. 
    No person shall deposit, dump, throw or place any coal, ashes, dust, manure or rubbish in or upon any part of the city park system. Paper, garbage or refuse matter shall not be so deposited except in receptacles provided for that purpose. 
(Code 1974, § 23-75) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 74. 
State Law reference- Littering, MCL 324.8901 et seq. 
Sec. 70-119. - Posting or displaying advertisements. 
    No person shall display any placard or advertisement of any kind in the city park system, nor shall any person stencil or otherwise affix any notice or bill, advertisement or other paper upon any structure or thing in or about the park premises. 
(Code 1974, § 23-76) 
Sec. 70-120. - Gambling. 
    No person shall play at games of chance or use any gambling device in the city park system. 
(Code 1974, § 23-77) 
State Law reference- Gambling, MCL 750.301 et seq. 
Sec. 70-121. - Damaging property or trees. 
    No person shall cut, break, climb on, or in any way injure or deface any tree, shrub, plant, or turf or any of the buildings, fences, bridges, lamps or posts or other structure or property within the city park system. 
(Code 1974, § 23-78) 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 102. 
Sec. 70-122. - Disorderly conduct. 
    No person shall make, countenance or assist in making any improper noise or engage in any riot, disorderly conduct or collect with other persons in crowds for unlawful purposes or to the annoyance, obstruction or disturbance of other persons in any city park. 
(Code 1974, § 23-79) 
State Law reference- Malicious mischief, MCL 750.377a et seq. 
Sec. 70-123. - Interference with park police officers or other employees. 
    No person shall resist any park police officer or city employee exercising his duty within the park area or fail or refuse to obey any lawful command of any such park police officer or park employee or in any way interfere with or hinder or prevent any such park police officer or park employee from discharging his duty, or in any manner assist or give aid to any person in custody to escape or to attempt to escape from custody, or rescue or attempt to rescue any person when in such custody. No person shall interfere with or in any manner hinder any employee of the city while engaged in constructing, repairing or caring for any city park property. 
(Code 1974, § 23-80) 
Secs. 70-124-70-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CITY EVENTS 

Sec. 70-151. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Special event includes the city's Midsummer Festival, Fireworks Display, Treadmill Run, and Taste of Trenton, or other similar type events located within the city, coordinated or sponsored by the city, and designated as such by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-91) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-152. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the terms of this article shall be subject to a fine of not more than $100.00, plus court costs. 
(Code 1974, § 23-95) 
Sec. 70-153. - Prohibited activities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in attendance at any special event to engage in any of the following conduct or activities in an area designated for a special event by resolution of the city council: 
(1)  Bring any animal (including any fish or reptile) into the area designated for the special event, whether or not in a restraining device, unless the animal is necessary to assist the handicapped, or is registered to participate in an official event, contest, or other activity authorized by the city or the other collective sponsors of the special event. 
(2)  Bring or ride any bicycle, unicycle, moped, or motorized scooter into the area designated for the special event, unless the cycle is registered to participate in an official event, contest, or other activity authorized by the city or the other collective sponsors of the special event or required by the owner to assist with a handicap; however, it shall be permissible to walk such devices to any storage rack, if any, which is provided by the city or sponsors for that purpose. 
(3)  Wear or utilize any skateboard, roller skates, roller blades, or other similar device in the special event area. 
(4)  Take or carry any radio, tape player, stereo, boom box, speakers, or other device which audibly transmits music, voice, or other sound into the special event area; however, it shall be permissible for an individual to wear a radio, tape, or compact disc device transmitting sound only through earphones or headphones to the carrier. 
(5)  Possess open intoxicants or consume alcoholic beverages in the area designated for the special event unless such beverages are purchased from and dispensed by an individual or entity licensed to sell such beverages, which has permission from the state liquor control commission for outdoor sales if applicable, and such entity is approved by the city council to sell such beverages for consumption in the area designated for the special event subject to those restrictions as to time, dates, and locations as it may impose. 
(6)  Bring into the area designated for the special event any container of alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1974, § 23-92) 
Sec. 70-154. - Enforcement. 
    Refusal or failure to comply with this article shall be cause for removal of the individual from the special event or arrest or issuance of a citation for violation of this article by a police officer, and removal of the contraband item from the designated area. 
(Code 1974, § 23-93) 
Sec. 70-155. - Authority to make additional rules and regulations. 
    The city hereby authorizes the designated coordinating agency or sponsor to adopt such other reasonable rules and regulations as may be necessary for the orderly conduct of activities at and during the special event. 
(Code 1974, § 23-94) 
Sec. 70-156. - Additional restrictions on consumption and possession of alcoholic beverages. 
    Nothing in this article shall prohibit the city from enforcing the provisions of chapter 6 regarding consumption and possession of alcoholic beverages or the penalties therein. 
(Code 1974, § 23-96) 
Chapter 74 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Disposal of sick, injured or dead animals, § 14-3; disposal of carcasses, § 14-55; disposal of waste; incinerators, § 22-148; environment, ch. 38; deposits of offensive or unwholesome substances, § 38-222; floods, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 54; garbage and trash, § 54-112; manufactured homes, ch. 62; depositing refuse; use of receptacles in parks, § 70-118; trash containers; removal of trash, § 82-134; utilities, ch. 98; solid waste collection, app. A, § A-12. 
State Law reference- Solid waste management, MCL 324.11501 et seq.; litter control, MCL 324.8901 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ashes means the solid residue of combustion of fuel used in heating and cooking operations, as occurring in households, apartments, offices or other business places, but shall not include residue from industrial plants or operations. 
    Brush means brush vegetation or tree trimmings, other than grass, weeds, leaves and small garden plants from the normal household. 
    Commercial rubbish means the miscellaneous waste and materials resulting from the operation of mercantile enterprises, and includes packing boxes and cartons, excelsior, paper and rubbish from offices, stores and mercantile establishments but excludes construction and trade wastes. 
    Domestic rubbish means waste materials resulting from normal household or living conditions such as paper, rags, bottles, tin cans, cardboard, wornout clothing, furniture, excelsior and similar substances. 
    Garbage means waste foodstuffs or table wastes, of vegetable or animal origin, together with other incidental admixtures. 
    Garden rubbish means garden plants and debris from residential yards. It shall not include rubbish from work of landscape gardens or private companies such as landscaping firms or nurseries. 
    Loader pickup means any amount of concrete, dirt, bricks, sod, shingles or other debris which must be collected with a front loader. 
    Special pickup means large, bulky objects such as appliances, furniture, windows, building materials, brush, tree limbs or other items too large to place in containers or too heavy to be collected by refuse collection personnel. 
    Trade waste means the waste material resulting from industrial operations and is not classified as municipal waste, except as otherwise provided. 
    Transfer station means the city facility available for residents' or local businesses' dumping of refuse. 
    Yard waste means lawn clippings and leaves from the normal household. 
(Code 1974, § 16-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-32. - Violations. 
    Unless otherwise designated as a municipal civil infraction, any person who shall fail to heed a warning ticket issued by the city for violation of any provisions of this article, and shall thereafter violate any provisions of this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1974, § 16-8) 
Sec. 74-33. - Authority to make additional rules and regulations. 
    The director of public works is hereby authorized to make such rules and regulations from time to time as appear necessary within the scope of this article. Any violation of the rules or regulations so made by the director of public works constitutes a violation of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 16-2) 
Sec. 74-34. - Assistance with enforcement. 
    The director of public works shall, in cases where violation of any provision of this article exists, be empowered to call upon the police department, fire department or health department for assistance when needed for enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 16-7) 
Sec. 74-35. - Collection schedule. 
    The director of public works shall establish schedules designating the days collection service is to be rendered and methods of collection of waste matter, and shall by appropriate means provide the citizens of the city with information concerning such schedule. A schedule may be secured at the office of the director of public works. 
(Code 1974, § 16-19) 
Sec. 74-36. - Burning garbage. 
    It shall be unlawful to burn garbage in the city, except in cases where the city health officer or fire marshal shall deem it necessary to dispose of any material by burning and then only pursuant to a permit issued by the fire marshal or chief of the fire department. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(15), 16-3) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 42. 
Sec. 74-37. - Limitations on persons collecting refuse. 
    No agent, servant, officer or employee of the city or any contractor licensed by the city, or any other person engaged in the work of collecting and removing refuse, shall interfere with, disturb, break, destroy, handle, take or use any article or substance, or trespass upon any property except insofar as shall be necessary in the work of such collection and removal, or remove or take any article of refuse for his own use. Refuse collection personnel are not permitted to enter houses and buildings for the collection of refuse, nor shall they accept any money for their services from persons served. 
(Code 1974, § 16-20) 
Sec. 74-38. - Hours of collection. 
    The collection of waste matter shall not commence before 7:00 a.m. or be continued after 7:00 p.m., except for the protection of the public health or welfare, in which case the director of public works may require the extending of the time limit established in this section. 
(Code 1974, § 16-21) 
Sec. 74-39. - Placement and removal of containers generally. 
    Receptacles, containers or bundles of combustible rubbish and combustible rubbish mixed with garbage containers shall be placed on the outside of the sidewalk after sundown of the day preceding the day scheduled for collection. All empty receptacles or containers are to be removed from the street the same day that the collection is made. Receptacles, containers and bundles of articles of noncombustible rubbish shall be placed on the outside of the sidewalk after sundown of the day preceding the day scheduled for collection, which collection day may be separate from the day scheduled for the collection of garbage and combustible rubbish, as set by the director of public works or his authorized representative. All empty receptacles or containers are to be removed from the street the same day that the collection is made. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(15), 16-22) 
Sec. 74-40. - Placement and removal of containers of garden and domestic rubbish and garbage. 
    All garden and domestic rubbish and garbage shall be kept in receptacles to be located within the rear property lines where an alleyway is provided. Where an alleyway is not provided, all garden and domestic rubbish and garbage shall be placed in receptacles, and shall be placed at the curbline at a place most accessible to the collector. Receptacles shall be placed within the property lines adjacent to the alley, or at the curbline, whichever applies, after sundown of the day preceding the day scheduled for collection, and all empty receptacles or containers shall be removed the same day the collection is made. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(15), 16-23) 
Sec. 74-41. - Collection from private property. 
    Rubbish shall not be collected by the city from private property except under the following circumstances: The city may provide curbside collection of residential rubbish from individual single-family condominium units with fully enclosed attached garages providing secure storage, located in private developments in which the dwelling units are individually owned and individually taxed by the city, provided there exists within each such development access to each of the individual dwelling units sufficient to accommodate the weight, size and turning radius of the city's regular rubbish disposal vehicles, as certified in writing to council by the director of public works and the city engineer prior to the initiation of service. 
(Code 1974, § 16-24) 
Sec. 74-42. - Duty of occupants to provide containers. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the occupant of every dwelling, flat, apartment house or other building or other persons disposing of any rubbish or garbage to provide sufficient containers to hold the accumulation of normal rubbish between collections. 
(Code 1974, § 16-25) 
Sec. 74-43. - Responsibility of landlords to dispose of rubbish. 
    Rubbish from dwellings run by landlords must be disposed of by the landlords, whether or not they reside on the premises. 
(Code 1974, § 16-34) 
Sec. 74-44. - Construction waste. 
(a)  Construction waste from building construction, alterations or repairs and earth dirt from excavating, unusual or special manufacturing or trade wastes shall not be collected by the city; however, in cases where the occupant of a private dwelling does his own work and does not pay private persons or contractors to perform such work, the city will make special pickups upon call and upon such dates and times as the director of public works designates. 
(b)  Any rubbish from contractors, builders, remodelers, landscapers, nurserymen or other tradesmen must be disposed of by the persons generating the rubbish. 
(Code 1974, § 16-35) 
Sec. 74-45. - Dirt, concrete or metal; bulky objects. 
    Large amounts of dirt, concrete, or metal and bulky objects such as old furniture which are too large to place in containers must be separated and will be collected by the city forces as a special pickup on days to be designated by the director of public works if the rubbish to be collected is a result of residents doing work or causing rubbish to be placed for collection themselves. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(16), 16-36) 
Sec. 74-46. - Tree limbs, brush, grass clippings and leaves. 
(a)  All tree limbs, trimmings, brush and clippings too large or bulky to be placed in containers will be collected by the city where such limbs, trimmings or clippings are not the result of work by a private contractor, provided they are cut in lengths not to exceed four feet in length or four inches in diameter. Logs over four inches in diameter must be cut in lengths not to exceed three feet and be stacked for easy removal by collection forces. All such materials shall be placed at the sidewalk and collected by the city at such time as designated by the director of public works. 
(b)  All grass clippings and leaves shall be bagged in the authorized mesh bags or otherwise reusable containers provided they are labeled as containing yard waste. No plastic or paper bags shall be permitted for the disposal of clippings or leaves. During the fall leaf season, leaves may be deposited along the street edge for pickup as part of the city's regularly scheduled leaf pickup program. 
(c)  Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(16), 16-37) 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 102. 
Sec. 74-47. - Newspapers and magazines. 
    Newspapers, magazines or cardboard too bulky to put in containers will be collected with the regular rubbish provided they are tied in bundles not to exceed 100 pounds in weight. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(16), 16-38) 
Sec. 74-48. - Fee for loader pickups. 
(a)  The fee for loader pickups shall be as established by the city council per cubic yard of material collected. 
(b)  In the event payment is not made when billed, the expense shall be charged to the owner of the real estate by placing the cost of the pickup on the tax roll. 
(c)  The fee for reclaiming refrigerant materials from refrigerant charged appliances, including but not limited to, refrigerators, freezers, and air conditioners, shall be as established by the city council payable to the city in advance of any special pickup. 
(Code 1974, § 16-39; Ord. No. 656, § 1, 7-15-2002) 
Sec. 74-49. - Use of transfer station. 
(a)  The refuse transfer station will be available for residents' dumping free of charge. Proof of residency is required. 
(b)  Businesses registered and located within the city shall be allowed dumping privileges at the transfer station at the rate established by the city council. All dumping charges that are not paid on time shall be deemed delinquent, to which there shall be added and collected a ten percent penalty. Dumping privileges will be revoked for those businesses the accounts of which are in arrears until such time as all fees and charges are paid in full and the city shall in the interim not enter into any contract with any such business in default to the city, pursuant to section 12.2 of the City Charter. 
(Code 1974, § 16-40; Ord. No. 667, § 1, 1-5-2004) 
Sec. 74-50. - Discarding refrigerant-charged appliances. 
    No discarded appliance charged with a refrigerant, including but not limited to refrigerators, freezers, and air conditioners, shall be collected as refuse by the city without proof of payment of the refrigerant recovery fee set forth in section 74-48 to the engineering and building department. Upon payment of the fee, a sticker, indicating proof of payment, will be provided to the applicant which must be visibly affixed to the outside of the discarded appliance to be set at curbside for collection. The appliance may be scheduled for a special pickup at the time of payment, or by phone, for the next regularly scheduled designated pickup day. No such appliances shall be disposed of by any person at the city's refuse transfer station. 
(Ord. No. 656, § 2, 7-15-2002) 
Sec. 74-51. - Special pick-ups. 
    Special pick-up services will be provided for those items defined in section 74-31, to residential customers by appointment only, made through the department of public works during regular business hours, for a fee established and set forth in sections A-12 and A-19 of appendix A, which fee shall be billed and payable monthly. Contractor generated materials are specifically prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 739, § 1, 8-2-2010) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 739, § 1, adopted August 2, 2010, added section "special pick-ups" as section 74-50. Editorially changed to section 74-51. 
Secs. 74-52-74-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTAINERS 

Sec. 74-71. - Approved waste and refuse containers. 
(a)  General container standards for household waste. The city shall distribute, at no charge, to each single-family residential unit one city-approved trash cart for household waste only, which shall be property of the city, but remain with the residential unit and identified by address. Homeowners in need of additional trash carts may purchase them from the city. Only trash carts issued by the city are permitted to be used for solid waste collections for single-family residences. Each trash cart shall be maintained in a nuisance and odor-free condition and shall be closed at the top to prevent the scattering of contents by weather conditions or animals. No container with yard waste inside will be accepted. 
(b)  Other approved containers. Other household waste containers for multifamily residential units (such as dumpsters) may be used with the express approval of the director of public services or such other officials designated by the city. 
(c)  Homeowner must utilize containers. Beginning seven days following the official announcement by the city of the conversion, it shall be the duty of every occupant, tenant and proprietor of any residential unit to arrange for, use and on collection days, place in a suitable position for ready access to the refuse collector, trash cart containers capable of holding all refuse which would ordinarily accumulate on such premises between the times of successive collections. The owner of any multiple dwelling shall furnish or require the tenant thereof to use a proper trash cart container. Trash cart containers located at multiple-family dwellings shall be marked so as to indicate the residential unit to which they belong. 
(d)  Illegal containers. All containers other than city-issued trash carts with permissible waste therein, are deemed to be illegal containers and will not be picked up. 
(e)  Yard waste containers. Additional and distinct trash cart containers, brown in color with green lids and appropriately labeled, must be used for the containment and collection of yard waste, including grass, leaves, weeds, garden clippings and small tree trimmings. Such containers must be purchased from the city, and must likewise be placed within reach of the street by the mechanical arm of the city's collection vehicle. Only yard waste in such containers will be collected by the city. Materials may not extend out of top of such containers more than one-half of height of the lid. Any large tree limbs will require a special pick-up. Plastic bags may not be placed in the containers as such material is not biodegradable and will not be collected. 
(Code 1974, § 16-26; Ord. No. 706, § 1, 3-5-2007) 
Sec. 74-72. - Noncompliance. 
    If proper containers are not utilized as required by this article, trash will not be picked up and the occupant of the premises shall be notified of the violation. If within one week, the notice is not complied with, it shall be considered a violation of this Code. Violations of the provisions of this section shall constitute a municipal civil infraction, and result in the issuance of a municipal civil infraction notice, for which the fine is $10.00 per violation, payable at city hall. Failure to pay the fine within 14 days shall result in the issuance of a civil infraction citation for which the fine is $50.00 per violation. Multiple violations for the same offense will result in additional fines in accordance with section 2-376. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(15), 16-27; Ord. No. 706, § 2, 3-5-2007) 
Sec. 74-73. - Unsafe containers. 
    Any containers having damaged wheels or hinges shall be so marked by the resident for repair or replacement, and will be collected for warranty repair or replacement. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(15), 16-33; Ord. No. 706, § 3, 3-5-2007) 
Sec. 74-74. - Collection of refuse; placement. 
(a)  All residential household and yard waste shall be placed in approved containers in a position accessible to collection crews, adjacent to the curb within reach of the seven-foot mechanical arm, from the street or alley. During winter months, solid waste shall not be placed on top of the snow bank, nor shall it be placed in the roadway. The owner shall either shovel out an area behind the curb in which to place his/her wastes or he/she shall place it in his/her cleared driveway. Collection crews will not collect waste unless it is placed within reach of the public street or alley. Residential units shall bring their solid waste to the public right-of-way for collection. Should collection crews be unable to discharge the contents of trash carts into collection vehicles using normal handling procedures, the trash carts, including their contents, will be left at curbside. The owner shall make provisions to assure that the solid waste therein can be collected on the next collection day. Collection crews will not empty trash carts by means other than mechanical dumping. 
(b)  Vehicles must be parked so as not to hinder locating or collecting the refuse placed at the curb. 
(c)  The city will not be liable for damage to any property where sanitation crews are required to collect refuse from a location other than within reach of the curb. 
(d)  Business establishments shall provide access to collection sites. All business establishments are responsible for their collection sites. Those sites blocked by vehicles or other obstructions will not be collected. 
(e)  No trash carts or other containers for refuse other than those approved by the city shall be placed, kept, stored or located within the right-of-way of a street or alley; provided, however, that the city may authorize the location of such containers within the public right-of-way at specified places and times when such location is necessary for the expeditious collection and disposition of refuse. 
(Ord. No. 706, § 4, 3-5-2007) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 706, § 4, adopted March 5, 2007, repealed the former § 74-74, and enacted a new § 74-74 as set out herein. The former § 74-74 pertained to use of paper or plastic bags in lieu of metal containers and was derived from Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(15), 16-28. 
Sec. 74-75. - Use of containers other than approved containers. 
(a)  It shall be permissible to use cardboard drums or bushel baskets for the storage of grass clippings, newspapers, garden rubbish or other materials not likely to cause offensive odors or attract flies or rodents; however, no garbage, or cans or containers containing food scraps or other table rubbish, shall be placed in such containers. 
(b)  Shopping bags, cardboard or wooden boxes, barrels, paper sacks of other than approved types or bushel baskets will not be considered as proper containers and will be collected as rubbish upon notification by collectors, except as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(15), 16-29) 
Sec. 74-76. - Garbage to be wrapped and drained. 
    All garbage shall be securely wrapped and drained of excess liquid before being placed in containers. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(15), 16-30) 
Sec. 74-77. - Placing ashes in containers. 
    All charcoal or ashes from barbecue pits, fireplaces or other stoves shall be thoroughly cold and doused with water before being placed in rubbish containers. Large amounts of ashes from heating systems or other sources must be placed in metal containers. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(15), 16-31) 
Sec. 74-78. - Manure and offal to be wrapped. 
    Any manure or offal from household pets or domestic animals must be placed in paper bags or wrapped so as not to be obnoxious or offensive. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(15), 16-32) 
Sec. 74-79. - Interference with containers or contents. 
    No person shall move, molest, burn or interfere with any refuse container or its contents or any waste material set out for collection by the city, except employees of the city charged with such duty. 
(Code 1974, § 16-5) 
Sec. 74-80. - Placing materials in containers that may cause fire. 
    No person shall place any substance or hot materials in refuse containers that may cause fires. 
(Code 1974, § 16-4) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 42. 
Secs. 74-81-74-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMERCIAL RUBBISH 

Sec. 74-101. - Compliance. 
    No commercial waste shall be collected unless such waste is places for collection in accordance with this division. 
(Code 1974, § 16-55) 
Sec. 74-102. - Commercial refuse containers. 
    The director of public works shall provide a list of approved suppliers of detachable metal refuse containers of two to six cubic yards, which can be moved and dumped by a front loading hoisting unit. The containers shall be placed, at the discretion of the director of public works, in locations convenient to establishments producing large quantities of refuse. In such cases, users may be required to share the use of such containers with other users nearby. The size and number of such containers shall be determined by the director of public works. 
(Code 1974, § 16-44) 
Sec. 74-103. - Commercial rubbish to be placed in special containers approved by city. 
(a)  Commercial rubbish shall be placed in special commercial containers approved by the city. These containers will be placed and serviced by the city in accordance with provisions of this division. 
(b)  Commercial establishments generating limited quantities of rubbish shall have the option of purchasing from the city, and utilizing in lieu of commercial containers, not more than two residential sized trash carts for the disposal of their rubbish, provided they are sufficient to fully enclose the rubbish. Pickups will be scheduled to coincide with residential pickups in their area. 
(c)  Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, § 16-45; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 7-6-2010) 
Sec. 74-104. - Duty to provide clean and sufficient containers. 
    The proprietor, manager or agent of a commercial establishment where wastes accumulate shall keep clean, proper and sufficient containers as required by this division for the storage of rubbish between collections. 
(Code 1974, § 16-46) 
Sec. 74-105. - Collection charges. 
(a)  The rubbish collection charges for each container emptied by the city pursuant to this division shall be as established by the city council 
(b)  Rubbish collection charges shall be billed quarterly in the same manner as water and sewage charges to the city. In the event payment is not made when billed, the expense shall be charged to the owner of the real estate by placing the cost of such collection on the tax roll. 
(Code 1974, § 16-47; Ord. No. 669, § 1, 3-15-2004) 
Sec. 74-106. - Purchase of refuse containers. 
    All stores, office buildings, bowling alleys, theaters, service stations, restaurants, apartments, townhouses, small industries, schools and like establishments which generate more rubbish than rubbish generated by an average domestic household shall be required to purchase average suitably sized refuse containers to store refuse prior to pickup by the city. Refuse containers are to be purchased directly from approved suppliers. 
(Code 1974, § 16-48) 
Sec. 74-107. - Manner of placing rubbish in containers. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of each user of commercial rubbish containers to place all materials for disposal inside of a container meeting the requirements of this division. All boxes must be broken down, cut up and flattened before placing in containers. Boxes or containers over three feet in length and two feet in width or depth must be cut up so they will lie flat in the containers. The contents of boxes or containers used for collection of rubbish inside of business places must be removed from the boxes or containers prior to being emptied into the containers. 
(b)  Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(17), 16-49) 
Sec. 74-108. - Certain items not to be placed in containers. 
(a)  Large pieces of metal such as parts of cars, fenders, mufflers, or gas tanks or large pieces of lumber over three feet in length shall not be placed in containers required by this division. Also, flammable materials, and liquids such as paint, oils, lubricants, etc., shall not be placed in containers required by this division. No building materials or rubbish from contractors or tradesmen shall be put in such containers. 
(b)  Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(17), 16-50) 
Sec. 74-109. - Doors and lids of containers to be kept closed. 
    Each user shall close the doors or lids of containers required by this division after placing material inside. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(17), 16-51) 
Sec. 74-110. - Area around containers to be kept clean and free from litter. 
    In no case shall establishments store, pile or scatter rubbish for collection on the ground around or near containers required by this division. The area adjacent to such containers shall in all cases be kept clean and free from litter. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(17), 16-52) 
Sec. 74-111. - Contents of containers to be protected from wind. 
    The contents of all containers required by this division shall be protected so that wind cannot blow out and scatter the contents over the streets, alleys and public ways of the city. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(17), 16-53) 
Sec. 74-112. - Vehicles blocking containers. 
    No vehicle shall be parked in such a manner that detachable containers are not accessible by the collection truck during the hours designated for collection. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(17), 16-54) 
Sec. 74-113. - Collection regulations; collection schedule. 
(a)  Properly stored commercial rubbish shall be collected by the city under such rules and regulations as the city engineer shall from time to time establish. 
(b)  The city shall empty containers as required, but not more than twice per week unless the size and volume of business warrants collections more than twice per week and if the necessity for extra pickups is due to users abiding by terms of this division. 
(c)  Collection frequency as outlined in section 74-35 shall be subject to change when affected by conditions beyond the control of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 16-56) 
Sec. 74-114. - Excessive amounts of waste. 
(a)  Reasonable and ordinary quantities of commercial waste from any establishment or business shall be collected by the city. 
(b)  When, in the opinion of the city engineer or his agents, any person operates any mercantile, manufacturing, trade or food establishment or other place or business where a large quantity of commercial waste is produced as an incident to the conducting of such establishment or business, and produces and accumulates excessive quantities or rubbish, the director shall require such person to remove such commercial waste as his own expense and in such manner as not to violate any of the provisions of this Code. 
(c)  If such person fails or neglects to remove such excess, the city shall remove the excess and shall charge the cost thereof to such person. If payment therefor is not made when billed, the expense of disposing of such excess waste shall be charged to the owner of the real estate by placing the cost of such disposal on the tax roll. 
(Code 1974, § 16-58) 
Secs. 74-115-74-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LITTER CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Littering, MCL 324.8901 et seq. 

Sec. 74-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Litter means all rubbish, refuse, waste material, garbage, offal, paper, glass, cans, bottles, trash, debris or other foreign substances of every kind and description. 
    Public or private property or waters includes, but is not limited to, the right-of-way of any road or highway, any body of water or watercourse, or the shores or beaches thereof, and shall include the ice above such waters, or any park, playground, building, refuge or conservation or recreation area or any residential or farm properties or timberlands. 
(Code 1974, § 16-69) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-142. - Violations. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a municipal civil infraction, for which the fine is $50.00. The court, in lieu of any other sentence imposed for such violation, may direct a substitution of litter-gathering labor, including, but not limited to, the litter connected with the particular violation. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(17), 16-77) 
Sec. 74-143. - Littering prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person knowingly, without the consent of either the public authority having supervision of public property or the owner of private property, to dump, deposit, place, throw or leave, or cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving, of litter on or into any public or private property, including privately owned or leased trash receptacles, or waters other than property specifically designated and set aside by the owner or operator for use by the general public. 
(Code 1974, § 16-70) 
Sec. 74-144. - Scattering construction waste. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit construction waste from building operations such as paper, cloth, rocks, litter or any other debris to be scattered on public or private property in the city. 
(Code 1974, § 16-71) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
Sec. 74-145. - Posting and publication of requirements; city receptacles. 
    The city may post notice signs and otherwise publicize the requirements of this article. The city may establish and maintain receptacles for the deposit of litter on the city property and publicize the location thereof. 
(Code 1974, § 16-72) 
Sec. 74-146. - Duty of abutting property owners to keep streets, alleys and easements free of litter. 
(a)  In the case of any alley, street or easement, where any substance has been deposited in violation of this article, it shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of any lot or premises to remove from one-half of the alley, or street or easement adjoining such lot or premises all such substances. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every occupant of premises abutting upon an alley, street or easement to keep his adjoining one-half of the alley, street or easement in a clean, neat and orderly condition and to keep all weeds and grasses removed or cut to a height not to exceed one foot at all times. 
(Code 1974, § 16-73) 
Sec. 74-147. - Causing litter to fall into path of or hit vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly cause any litter or any object to fall or to be thrown into the path of or to hit a vehicle traveling on any street or highway in the city. 
(Code 1974, § 16-74) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
Sec. 74-148. - Litter to be placed in receptacles. 
    Newspapers, handbills and wastepaper or other litter shall not be scattered or thrown upon public or private property but shall be deposited in private or public rubbish receptacles. 
(Code 1974, § 16-75) 
Sec. 74-149. - Use of public sidewalk receptacles. 
    Public sidewalk receptacles are for use of pedestrians only and shall not be used by vendors or by occupants of adjacent premises. 
(Code 1974, § 16-76) 
Chapter 78 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Special assessments, ch. XI. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance levying or imposing any special assessment saved from repeal, § 1-12(9); administration, ch. 2; community development, ch. 26; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 

Sec. 78-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cost, when referring to the costs of any improvement, shall mean the cost of surveys, plans, rights-of-way, spreading of rolls, notices, advertising, financing, construction, condemnation and legal fees, and all other costs incident to the making of such improvement, the special assessment therefor and financing thereof. 
    Public improvement means any public improvement, any part of the cost of which is to be assessed against any one or more lots or parcels of land to be especially benefitted thereby, in proportion to the benefit derived or to be derived therefrom, except as may be otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1974, § 27-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-2. - Special assessments authorized. 
    The entire cost and expense, or any part thereof, of all public improvements may be defrayed by special assessment upon the lands especially benefited by the improvement, in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1974, § 27-18) 
Sec. 78-3. - Initiation of proceedings. 
    Proceedings for making public improvements to be paid for by special assessment may be initiated by resolution of the city council or by petition of not less than 51 percent of the property owners of land in the proposed public improvement district. 
(Code 1974, § 27-19) 
Sec. 78-4. - Form of initiatory petitions. 
    All petitions for public improvements shall be addressed to the city council and shall set forth the proposed public improvement and the proposed public improvement district. All signatures on the petition shall be obtained within 30 days before the date of filing the petition with the city clerk, and such petitions shall include an affidavit by one or more of the circulators that the signatures appearing thereon are genuine and each signer declares himself to be the owner of the interest in the land indicated. 
(Code 1974, § 27-20) 
Sec. 78-5. - Initiatory petition signatures when title is not held in fee simple. 
    For the purpose of obtaining signatures to a petition required by this chapter, the signature of one tenant, in the case of tenants by the entireties, or joint tenancies, shall be considered adequate. In the case of tenancy in common, signatures of all common tenants shall be a requirement, and in the case of property being held under land contract, the party in whose name the property is assessed for taxation shall be deemed to be the owner. 
(Code 1974, § 27-21) 
Sec. 78-6. - Filing of initiatory petition. 
    All petitions required by this chapter shall be filed with the city clerk, who shall report the receipt of all such petitions to the city council at the next regular meeting following receipt of the petition. 
(Code 1974, § 27-22) 
Sec. 78-7. - Review and recommendation of city departments on initiatory petition. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a petition required by this chapter from the city clerk, the city council shall submit a copy thereof to each of the city departments for the purpose of review and examination. 
(b)  The city departments shall, upon completion of the review and examination of the petition, submit to the city council a written report in relation to its application with their respective department. The reports should include recommendations as to the necessity, feasibility and desirability of the proposed improvement, and any other facts or recommendations which will aid the city council in determining whether the improvement shall be made, and how the improvement shall be financed. 
(c)  The city engineer's report shall include ascertaining the assessed valuation of all property affected by the proposed improvement, the number of parcels which show tax delinquency, the number of parcels owned by public authorities, the number of parcels which are vacant, an estimated cost of the proposed project, the need for the improvement, and the extent of the improvement and proposed boundaries of the district. The city engineer's report shall be filed with the city clerk, together with his recommendations as to what proportion of the cost should be paid by special assessment and what proportion, if any, should be borne by the city at large, and any other facts or recommendations which will aid the city council in determining whether the improvements shall be made, and how the improvements shall be financed. 
(Code 1974, § 27-23) 
Sec. 78-8. - Hearing on initiatory petition. 
(a)  In the absence of written objections being received from the city departments, the city council shall resolve to proceed with the prescribed special assessment procedure for the making of any public improvement by holding a public hearing on the petition for the public improvement. 
(b)  Should the written reports from the city departments disclose objections, the city council shall provide a hearing to be held on the advisability of proceeding with the petitioned improvements, which meeting shall be held not less than one week after notice thereof has been sent by first class mail to all property owners who have petitioned for the proposed improvement. 
(c)  At the time and place specified in the notice for the public hearing, the city council shall meet and hear any person to be affected by the proposed public improvement. The hearing may be adjourned from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 27-24) 
State Law reference- Required notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq. 
Sec. 78-9. - Council resolution required prior to undertaking improvement. 
    No public improvement to be financed in whole or in part by special assessment shall be undertaken, or any contract let therefor, before adoption by the city council of a resolution finally determining to proceed with such improvement, and establishing a special assessment district therefor. 
(Code 1974, § 27-25) 
Sec. 78-10. - Estimate of costs and public hearing required; notice of hearing. 
    No resolution finally determining to proceed with an improvement and establishing any special assessment district therefor shall be adopted until cost estimates have been prepared and a public hearing has been held on the advisability of so proceeding, which hearing shall be held not less than ten days after notice thereof has been published and sent by first class mail to all property owners in the proposed district, as shown by the current assessment roll of the city, in accordance with Public Act No. 162 of 1962 (MCL 211.741 et seq.). 
(Code 1974, § 27-26) 
Sec. 78-11. - Determination to make improvements; objections. 
(a)  If, after public hearing, the city council shall determine to proceed with the improvement, it shall so determine by resolution. The resolution shall include the determination of the necessity for the improvement; set forth the nature thereof; designate the limits of the special assessment district to be affected; describe the improvements to be assessed; determine the part or proportion of the cost to be paid by lands especially benefited thereby, and the part or proportion, if any, to be paid by the city at large; and determine the number of installments in which the assessment may be paid, the rate of interest, not exceeding six percent, to be charged, and if any balance is to be deferred. The city council shall direct the city engineer to prepare plans, profiles and specifications for the work to be done. 
(b)  If, prior to the adoption of the resolution, there are any objections in writing filed with the city clerk by the owners of property in the district which, according to the estimates, will be required to bear more than 50 percent of the amount of such special assessment, the passage of such resolution shall require the affirmative vote of five members of the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 27-27) 
Sec. 78-12. - Completion of plans; advertisement for bids. 
(a)  When the plans, profiles and specifications have been completed, the city engineer shall return the plans, profiles and specifications to the city council, and the city council shall, if the work is to be done by independent contractors, order the advertisement for sealed bids for the work, in accordance with the purchasing procedure. 
(b)  The advertisement for sealed bids shall specify that no contract shall be let until the special assessment roll has been confirmed and no bid may be withdrawn for 45 days after the opening thereof. 
(c)  If the work is to be done by the city, the city engineer shall present a revised estimate of cost at the time the plans, profiles and specifications are returned to the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 27-28) 
Sec. 78-13. - Determination of costs; preparation of roll. 
    After the opening of sealed bids, the city council shall revise the estimated cost of the improvement upon the basis of bids received, or, where the work is to be done by the city, shall revise the estimated cost on the basis of the estimate of the city engineer, after receipt of such estimate, and shall direct the city assessor to make a special assessment roll of the part or proportion of the cost to be borne by the lands especially benefited, according to the benefits received, and report the roll to the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 27-29) 
Sec. 78-14. - Certification and filing of roll. 
    When the city assessor shall have completed the special assessment roll, he shall attach thereto or endorse thereon his certificate to the effect that the roll has been made by him pursuant to a resolution of the city council, giving the date of adoption, and that in making the assessments he has, as near as may be, according to his best judgment, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in such resolution and to the Charter, and to the provisions of this chapter. Thereupon, he shall file such special assessment roll with the city clerk, who shall present the roll to the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 27-30) 
Sec. 78-15. - Review of roll; notice of hearing. 
    Upon receipt of the special assessment roll, the city council shall order it filed in the office of the city clerk for public examination and shall fix the time and place when it will meet and review such roll, which meeting shall be held not less than ten days after notice thereof has been published and sent by first class mail to all property owners in the proposed district, as shown by the current assessment roll of the city, in accordance with Public Act No. 162 of 1962 (MCL 211.741 et seq.). 
(Code 1974, § 27-31) 
Sec. 78-16. - Hearing on roll; corrections and changes. 
    The city council shall meet and review the special assessment roll at the time and place appointed, or at an adjourned date therefor, and shall consider any objections thereto. The city council may correct the roll as to assessments or description of any lot or parcel of land, or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in such roll shall be noted in the city council's minutes. After the hearing and review, the city council may confirm such special assessment roll, with corrections as it may have made, if any, or may refer it back to the city assessor for city revision, or may annul any proceedings in connection therewith. 
(Code 1974, § 27-32) 
Sec. 78-17. - Confirmation of roll. 
    The city clerk shall, upon confirmation of a special assessment roll by the city council, endorse the date of confirmation upon the roll. The roll, upon confirmation, shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1974, § 27-33) 
Sec. 78-18. - Special assessment to constitute lien on property; character of lien. 
(a)  All special assessments contained in any special assessment roll, including any part thereof to be paid in installments, shall, from the date of confirmation of such roll, constitute a lien upon the respective lots or parcels of land assessed, and, until paid, shall be a charge against the respective owners of the lots and parcels of land, and a debt to the city from the persons to whom they are assessed. 
(b)  The lien shall be of the same character and effect as the lien created by the Charter for city taxes, and shall include the accrued interest and fees. 
(Code 1974, § 27-34) 
Sec. 78-19. - Use of special assessment funds restricted. 
    Except as otherwise provided in the Charter, moneys raised by special assessment for any public improvement shall be credited to a special assessment account, and shall be used to pay for the cost of the improvement for which the assessment was levied, and all expenses incidental thereto, to repay any principal or interest on money borrowed therefor, and to refund excessive assessments. 
(Code 1974, § 27-35) 
Sec. 78-20. - Due date of assessments; installment payments; delinquent payments. 
    All special assessments shall become due upon confirmation of the assessment roll or in annual installments not to exceed ten in number, as the city council may determine at the time of confirmation. If payment is to be made in annual installments, the city council shall determine that the first installment shall be due upon confirmation, and that subsequent installments shall be due on July 1 in each succeeding year and shall be placed upon the annual city tax roll. If payments are delinquent, an interest charge until the due date of each such deferred installment shall be provided for, not to exceed six percent per year, subject to the right of advance payment of any such installment with interest to the date of payment. 
(Code 1974, § 27-36) 
Sec. 78-21. - Transmittal of assessment to treasurer for collection; notice to property owners for payment. 
    Whenever any special assessment roll is confirmed and is payable, the city council shall direct the city clerk to transmit the assessment roll to the city treasurer for collection.
