The city treasurer shall mail statements of the several assessments to the respective owners of the several lots and parcels of land assessed, as indicated by the records of the city assessor, stating the amount of the assessment and the manner in which it may be paid; however, failure to mail any such statement shall not invalidate the assessment or entitle the owner to an extension of time in which to pay the assessment. 
(Code 1974, § 27-37) 
Sec. 78-22. - Spreading of installments on tax roll. 
    Second installments of special assessments shall be spread upon the city tax roll for the year in which it falls due, in a column headed "special assessments," together with interest on all unpaid installments from the date of confirmation of the roll, on July 1 in the year in which the installment is spread upon the roll; provided that any fraction of a month shall be considered a full month. Thereafter, one installment shall be spread in the same manner upon each annual tax roll, together with the accumulated interest upon all unpaid installments. 
(Code 1974, § 27-38) 
Sec. 78-23. - Collection procedure. 
    After each special assessment or installment thereof has been placed on the tax rolls, the assessment or installment shall be collected by the city treasurer with the same rights and remedies as provided in the Charter for the collection of taxes. Special assessments or installments thereof which become due on July 1 of any year shall be collected in all respects as are city taxes due on July 1 of the same year, and if uncollected on the following March 1 shall be returned to the county treasurer as unpaid taxes, as provided in section 9.19 of the Charter. Initial special assessments or installments which become due other than on July 1 shall, if unpaid for 90 days or more on May 1 of any year, be certified as delinquent to the city council by the city treasurer, and the city council shall place such delinquent assessments on the tax roll for that year, together with accrued interest to July 1 of such year. The total amount of such assessment and interest shall thereafter be collected in all respects as are city taxes on July 1 of that year, and shall be subject to the same fees and penalties as are city taxes due on that date, and if uncollected on the following March 1 shall be returned to the county treasurer as unpaid taxes, as provided in section 9.19 of the Charter. 
(Code 1974, § 27-39) 
Sec. 78-24. - Action to collect assessment; effect of irregularities. 
    In addition to any other remedies, and without impairing the lien therefor, any delinquent special assessment, together with interest and penalties, may be collected in an action in the name of the city against the person assessed, in any court having jurisdiction of the amount. If, in any action, it shall appear that, by reason of any irregularity or informality, the assessment has not been properly made against the defendant, or upon the lot or premises sought to be charged, the court may nevertheless, on satisfactory proof that expense has been incurred by the city, which is a proper charge against the lot or premises in question, render judgment for the amount properly chargeable against such defendant, or upon such lot or premises. 
(Code 1974, § 27-40) 
State Law reference- Assumpsit to collect special assessments, MCL 211.501 et seq. 
Sec. 78-25. - Certification of cost of improvement. 
    Upon completion of a public improvement made pursuant to this chapter, the financing thereof and the payment of the cost thereof, the city clerk shall certify to the city council the total cost of such improvement, together with the amount of the original roll for the improvement. 
(Code 1974, § 27-41) 
Sec. 78-26. - Additional assessments to cover deficiency in costs. 
    Should the assessments in any special assessment roll, including the amount assessed to the city at large, prove insufficient to pay for the improvement for which it was levied and the expense incident thereto, or to pay the principal and interest on bonds issued in anticipation of such assessment roll, then the city council may make additional assessments to supply the deficiency against the city and the several lots and parcels of land, in same ratio as the original assessments. The additional pro rata assessment shall not exceed 25 percent of the assessments as originally confirmed, unless a meeting of the city council is held to review such additional assessment, for which meeting notices shall be published and mailed, as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1974, § 27-42) 
Sec. 78-27. - Disposition of funds when assessment exceeds cost of improvement. 
    In cases in which special assessments prove larger than the actual cost of the improvement and expenses incidental thereto, the excess may be placed in the general fund of the city, if such excess is five percent or less of the assessment, but, should the assessment prove larger than necessary by more than five percent, the entire excess shall be refunded on a pro rata basis to the owners of the property assessed. The refund shall be made by a credit against future unpaid installments to the extent that such installments then exist, and the balance of such refund shall be in cash. No refunds may be made which contravene the provisions of any outstanding evidence of indebtedness secured in whole or part by special assessments. 
(Code 1974, § 27-43) 
Sec. 78-28. - Limitation on suits and actions. 
    No suit or action of any kind shall be instituted or maintained for the purpose of contesting or enjoining the collection of any special assessment: 
(1)  Unless, within 30 days after the confirmation of the special assessment roll, written notice is given to the city council of intention to file a suit or action, stating the grounds on which it is claimed such assessment is illegal; and 
(2)  Unless such suit or action shall be commenced within 60 days after confirmation of the roll. 
(Code 1974, § 27-44) 
Sec. 78-29. - Illegal assessments; reassessment procedure. 
    Whenever any special assessment shall, in the opinion of the city council, is invalid by reason of irregularity or informality in the proceedings, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge such assessment to be illegal, the city council shall, whether the improvement has been made or not, or whether any part of the assessment has been paid or not, have the power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made. All proceedings on such reassessment, and for the collection thereof, shall be conducted in the same manner as provided for in the original assessment, and whenever any sum or part thereof levied upon any property in the assessment so set aside has been paid and not refunded, the payment so made shall be applied on the reassessment, or if the payments exceed the amount of the reassessment, refunds shall be made. 
(Code 1974, § 27-45) 
Sec. 78-30. - Effect of vacating special assessment. 
    No judgment or decree nor any act of the city council vacating a special assessment shall destroy or impair the lien of the city upon the premises assessed for such amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the premises, or which by regular mode of proceeding may have been lawfully assessed thereupon. 
(Code 1974, § 27-46) 
Sec. 78-31. - Special requirements for street paving improvements. 
    Special assessments made for the purpose of paying the cost of paving any local street shall be assessed pro rata and according to the frontage of each parcel abutting upon the improvement. In the case where the paving abuts the side of any corner lot, the corner lot shall be assessed 60 percent thereof, and the remaining 40 percent shall be assessed pro rata and according to the frontage of each parcel lying within 50 percent of the block in which the corner lot is located. If, from the shape or size of any such parcel of land, the assessment thereof, according to the formula set out in this section, would be unjust or disproportionate to the assessments on the other parcels of land in the district, the city council may assess such parcel of land as in its opinion may be just. 
(Code 1974, § 27-47) 
Sec. 78-32. - Special requirements for sidewalk improvements or nuisance abatement. 
    The assessment for the cost of the construction or maintenance of any sidewalk, or the abatement of any hazard or nuisance to be made pursuant to subsections (v), (w), (x) and (y) of section 2.3 of the Charter, or for any similar assessment against the individual or property, shall be made by resolution of the city council. Notice of the time at which the city council will act thereon shall be given by first class mail to the owner of the property to be assessed, as shown by the current tax roll of the city, except that no notice shall be required in the case of assessments for the removal of weeds or any hazards. For the purpose of collection of such assessments, the adoption of such resolution shall be equivalent to the confirmation of a special assessment roll. The amount of any such special assessment shall become a debt to the city, upon adoption of such resolution, and shall be subject to the collection fees, and become a lien, as provided in section 11.10 of the Charter. 
(Code 1974, § 27-48) 
Sec. 78-33. - Procedure for single lot assessments. 
    When any expenditure is made on account of any separate or single lot, parcel of land, or premises, which, by the provisions of the Charter or by law, the city is authorized to charge and collect as a special assessment against the lot, parcel of land, or premises, and which assessment is not of that class of special assessments required to be made pro rata upon lots or parcels of land in a special assessment district, a statement of the labor or services for which such expenditure was incurred, verified by the controller, with a description of the lot and the name of the owner or person chargeable therewith, if known, shall be reported to the city council in the manner prescribed by it. The city council shall determine the part of such expenditure that shall be charged, and the person against whom, if known, and the premises upon which the charge shall be levied as a special assessment. As often as the city council deems expedient, the city clerk shall give notice of the several amounts so determined and reported to the several persons chargeable therewith. The notice shall be sent by first class mail to the last known addresses of such persons as shown on the assessment roll of the city, or by publication. The notice shall state the basis of the assessment, and the amount thereof, and shall give a reasonable time, not less than 30 days, within which payment shall be made to the city treasurer. In all cases where payment is not made within the time set, the fact shall be reported by the city treasurer to the city assessor, who shall charge such amounts, together with a penalty of ten percent of such amounts, against the persons or real property chargeable therewith, on the next tax roll. 
(Code 1974, § 27-49) 
Chapter 82 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any road, street, sidewalk or alley saved from repeal, § 1-12(10); any ordinance establishing the grade or any road, street or sidewalk saved from repeal, § 1-12(11); consumption of alcoholic beverages in public places, § 6-1; peddlers and transient merchants, § 22-301 et seq.; community development, ch. 26; environment, ch. 38; floods, ch. 46; franchises and right-of-way licenses and permits, ch. 50; manufactured homes, ch. 62; distributing or scattering in public places, § 66-444; parks and recreation, ch. 70; special assessments, ch. 78; subdivisions and other divisions of land, ch. 86; street and subdivision names, § 86-136; streets, § 86-161 et seq.; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94; driving across sidewalk or pedestrian right-of-way into business premises, § 94-5; vegetation, ch. 102; certain varieties of trees and shrubs prohibited in public places, § 102-38; fastening materials on public property which impede growth, § 102-43; injuring trees and shrubs in public places, § 102-44; waterways, ch. 106; interfering with streets while launching or hauling out boats, § 106-2; zoning, ch. 110; frontage on public street, § 110-683; permit for moving buildings, app. A, § A-76. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Special assessment not to excuse violations. 
    Whenever any person fails to perform any act required by this chapter for which a special assessment may be made as prescribed in this Code, this shall not relieve such person from the penalty prescribed for violations of this Code in section 1-8. 
(Code 1974, § 28-6) 
Sec. 82-2. - Damaging or interfering with streets, barricades or signs. 
    No unauthorized person shall move, alter, deface, injure or destroy any part or accessory of any street or alley or any sign or barricade erected or placed to protect, warn or guide the public. 
(Code 1974, § 28-1) 
State Law reference- Malicious mischief, MCL 750.377a et seq. 
Sec. 82-3. - Obstructing street or other public place. 
    No person shall obstruct or encumber any street, alley or any public space with any article or thing whatsoever. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(28), 28-2) 
Sec. 82-4. - Encroachments over street or sidewalk. 
    No person shall suspend anything above any sidewalk or within any street area unless expressly authorized by this Code. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(28), 28-3) 
Sec. 82-5. - Display of merchandise or placement of signs in streets or sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall place, store or exhibit any goods, wares or merchandise or material for sale, nor solicit for sales of goods or services, upon any public street or alley in the city, or place any sign or advertising device thereon. Violations of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) above, a participating merchant may utilize public street space duly authorized and designated for the display and sale of merchandise during a city sponsored "special event" only, as defined in this code, by first obtaining a permit for the event from the city, which permit shall be displayed on site at all times during the event. Use of the street by a merchant, or other person authorized by the merchant, in the "special event" area, without a valid permit shall constitute a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $250.00 per day. 
(c)  No merchant shall place, store or exhibit any goods, wares or merchandise or material which are not maintained in its regular inventory, upon any public sidewalk in the city during a "special event", nor permit or engage another to solicit, display or offer for sale any such goods or merchandise, in the sidewalk area immediately in front of or adjacent to their property. 
(d)  No merchant shall place, store or exhibit any goods, wares, merchandise or material on the public sidewalk, or allow another to do so, in such a manner so as to obstruct the free and unobstructed passage of pedestrians. 
(e)  Violations of subsections (c) or (d), shall constitute a municipal civil infraction with a fine of $50.00 per day 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(28), 28-4; Ord. No. 774, § 1, 5-6-2013) 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 
Sec. 82-6. - Leaving construction debris on sidewalk. 
    No person owning, building or repairing any house or other building shall permit any lumber, brick, plaster, mortar, earth, clay, sand, stone or other material to remain on the sidewalk after sunset of the day upon which it was placed there, without permission, in writing, from the chief of police, subject to any safeguards prescribed by the chief of police. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(28), 28-5) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
Sec. 82-7. - Removal of snow, ice and rubbish from sidewalk. 
    The occupant of any premises, or the owner of any unoccupied premises, is required to keep the sidewalks in front of or adjacent to such premises cleared, insofar as it is practicable and reasonable, from snow, ice, rubbish, excessive dirt or any encumbrance, to facilitate pedestrian use. Whenever any snow or ice has fallen or accumulated, it shall be cleared within 12 hours after it has fallen or accumulated. If the owner or occupant fails to comply with this requirement, the city may remove the snow, ice, rubbish or other material and charge the cost against the abutting property as provided in section 78-32. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(28), 28-33) 
Sec. 82-8. - Removal of snow and debris from condominium developments. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a duly authorized annual request from the condominium association representing a condominium development consisting of single-family units with individual off-street parking, the city may provide street snow clearing and sweeping services on qualified streets within the development subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  That the entrance street to the development not be gated or otherwise have an obstructed or controlled access; 
(2)  That the streets to be cleared in the development are first examined and certified made by the city engineer as being of sufficient size, shape and weight-bearing capacity to accommodate the city's existing equipment; 
(3)  That the development consists of units with off-street parking; 
(4)  That the association, together with the individual owners, have enacted and actively enforce requirements that vehicles parked on the street be removed during sweepings and snow fall events so as to facilitate clearing, the failure of which shall relieve the city of any obligation to clear and may, in the event of repeated violations, result in forfeiture or denial of future service; 
(5)  That the association and its members acknowledge that clearing of private streets in which there is no public right-of-way will necessarily result in the unnatural accumulation of snow which may be relocated by the clearing equipment into driveways, driveway approaches, sidewalks and private lawns causing access obstructions and/or property damage for which the city will not be responsible, and that such clearing will occur on a nonpriority basis permitting the primary streets and public roads in the city to be cleared first; 
(6)  That the association shall execute on behalf of its members, and submit at the time of application, the city's waiver, release and indemnification agreement waiving and releasing the city from claims for property damage and personal injuries associated with the clearing service. Failure to do so shall result in denial of applications. 
(b)  Applications for service must be made annually to the city and postmarked no later than december 15th of each year to assist the city in planning for the provision of the additional service. 
(Ord. No. 695, § 1, 11-21-2005) 
Secs. 82-9-82-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Curb cuts and sidewalks replacement, app. A, § A-4. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 82-31-82-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CROSSWALK, CURB CUT OR DRIVEWAY PERMIT 

Sec. 82-51. - Required. 
    No person shall construct, alter or change any crosswalk or driveway apron or any opening in or through any curb in any street or public way without first procuring a permit from the city engineering and building department and paying the charges established by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 28-17) 
Sec. 82-52. - Agreement to construct driveway apron prerequisite to issuance of curb cut permit. 
    No permit to cut any curb shall be issued by the engineering and building department unless the applicant shall agree in such application, as a condition of the issuance of the permit, to install a driveway apron of concrete or other material of comparable quality within 90 days after completion of the cut. 
(Code 1974, § 28-18) 
Sec. 82-53. - Plans and specifications. 
    No work for which a permit is required under this division shall be done by any person except in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the engineering and building department. Such plans and specification shall be approved if they are consistent with all laws and ordinances and do not endanger public safety. 
(Code 1974, § 28-19) 
Sec. 82-54. - Bond or insurance. 
    No permit shall be granted for any work under this division until a bond or policy of insurance has been filed with the engineering and building department. The bond or policy of insurance shall be in the sum of $1,000.00, unless a larger bond shall be required by the city council at the time any permit is granted by it upon appeal. All bonds or policies of insurance shall be conditioned to pay all damages to the streets of the city and to hold the city harmless of every other damage of every other nature, whether to persons or property, for which the city may be held liable by reason of, or which is occasioned by, the doing of a thing or the exercise of the privilege for which the permit upon which the bond or policy of insurance was based, was granted. 
(Code 1974, § 28-20) 
Sec. 82-55. - Appeals. 
    If the engineering and building department shall refuse to issue any permit required by this division, the applicant may appeal to the city council, which shall grant a hearing thereon. The decision of the city council on such appeal shall be final. In granting a permit after such hearing, the city council may impose such conditions therefor as it may deem desirable to protect the safety of persons and property during the moving of any building and the replacement of any utility wires, poles and other street appurtenances as may be moved or taken down therefor. 
(Code 1974, § 28-21) 
Sec. 82-56. - Inspection of work. 
    All work done pursuant to any permit issued under this division shall be inspected by the city engineer or his duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1974, § 28-22) 
Sec. 82-57. - Suspension or revocation. 
    The city engineer may suspend or revoke any permit issued pursuant to this division where either the workmanship or materials used do not conform to the plans and specifications approved or required upon issuance of the permit, or when the terms of any permit or this chapter are violated. No person shall perform any work authorized by any permit or cause any such work to be performed while that permit is suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1974, § 28-23) 
Secs. 82-58-82-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 82-81. - Permit required; posting of permit. 
    No person shall construct any sidewalk without first procuring a permit from the engineering and building department. Permits issued pursuant to this division shall be prominently displayed on the construction site for which the permit is issued. 
(Code 1974, § 28-29, 28-30) 
Sec. 82-82. - Specifications. 
    No person shall construct any sidewalk except in accordance with the lines, grade, slope and specifications established by the city engineer. Such specifications shall be consistent with public safety. 
(Code 1974, § 28-31) 
Sec. 82-83. - Sidewalk repairs. 
    Whenever it becomes necessary to repair any existing sidewalk in the city, the entire cost of the repairs shall be paid from the general fund of the city. It shall be the responsibility of the city engineer to report to the city council all existing sidewalks in need of repair, and the approximate cost of repairing the sidewalks, and file a completed report with the city council at the conclusion of the repairs. 
(Code 1974, § 28-32) 
Secs. 82-84-82-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 82-101. - Authority to make additional rules and regulations. 
    The engineering and building department may make such additional rules and regulations, subject to the approval of the city council, pertaining to the making of openings or excavations in streets, in the building of any vault, stair or area in or under the streets, as are necessary to secure the health and safety of the public and for the protection of property. Such rules and regulations shall constitute the standards upon which the permit required by this division shall be issued. 
(Code 1974, § 28-40) 
Sec. 82-102. - Permit required. 
    No person shall make any excavation or opening in or under any street or public place without first procuring a permit therefor from the engineering and building department. 
(Code 1974, § 28-39) 
Sec. 82-103. - Barricades required. 
    No person making an opening in a street, alley or public place shall fail to guard the opening fully during the period of construction, and no person using or causing any such opening to be used shall fail to guard or barricade the opening while in use, so as to protect the safety of the public. 
(Code 1974, § 28-41) 
Sec. 82-104. - Duty to close opening. 
    No person using any street opening or causing a street opening to be used shall fail to close the opening in accordance with the directions of the engineering and building department. 
(Code 1974, § 28-42) 
Sec. 82-105. - Payment of costs. 
    Each applicant for a permit to open a street shall pay the cost of making the opening and restoring the surface of the street to its proper condition, which cost shall be as established by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 28-43) 
Secs. 82-106-82-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FARMERS' MARKET 

Sec. 82-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Farmer means any person offering for sale any farm product, be it produce, meat, eggs, poultry or otherwise. It need not be raised by the farmer. 
    Invention means any item, be it metal, crockery, cloth, glass, wood or otherwise, that is offered for sale. It need not be made by the person offering it for sale. 
    Location means any paved or improved city-owned parking lot or street so designated by the director of the parks and recreation department and agreed by council resolution. 
    Time means from 9:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. Saturday only, starting June 1 and ending October 31, unless given special permission by council resolution. In a special permission, the council can insist on special conditions such as time, place, items or otherwise not mentioned in this article. 
(Code 1974, § 121/2-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-132. - Participation in program; exemption from license requirement. 
    Any person wishing to take part in the farmers' market program and invention sale may do so, provided he makes an affidavit to the city clerk to this effect. A certificate shall be issued in such case, showing that the affiant is exempt from the provisions of the city ordinance requiring a license. There will be no charge. 
(Code 1974, § 121/2-2) 
Sec. 82-133. - Operation of program. 
    The farmers' market program shall be under the direction of the parks and recreation program and shall abide by all rules and regulations promulgated by the city and the state. 
(Code 1974, § 121/2-3) 
Sec. 82-134. - Trash containers; removal of trash. 
    Each participant in the farmers' market shall provide his own container for his own trash and take it with him at the designated closing time or when he leaves. 
(Code 1974, § 121/2-4) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 74. 
Sec. 82-135. - Designation of sales areas. 
    The director of parks and recreation or his assistants shall designate each sales area in the farmers' market to the certificate holder. 
(Code 1974, § 121/2-5) 
Sec. 82-136. - Advertising. 
    The director of parks and recreation may have erected any large signs, billboards or newspaper advertisements deemed necessary for the success of the farmers' market program. 
(Code 1974, § 121/2-6) 
Sec. 82-137. - Prohibited conduct. 
    Any person participating in the farmers' market who conducts his stand or himself in a way that is a nuisance shall be asked or forced to leave and his certificate revoked. 
(Code 1974, § 121/2-7) 
Sec. 82-138. - Compliance with state and federal regulations. 
    All state and federal regulations, if any, must be observed at the farmers' market as provided for by law. The certificate in this case is not an exemption. 
(Code 1974, § 121/2-8) 
Chapter 86 - SUBDIVISIONS AND OTHER DIVISIONS OF LAND[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, accepting or vacating any plat saved from repeal, § 1-12(12); community development, ch. 26; environment, ch. 38; floods, ch. 46; manufactured homes, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; utilities, ch. 98; vegetation, ch. 102; waterways, ch. 106; zoning, ch. 110; subdivision plan review fees, app. A, § A-86. 
State Law reference- Land Division Act, MCL 560.101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 86-1-86-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SUBDIVISIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Lateral sewer means one which serves or is intended to serve as an outlet for a local district and empty into a trunk outlet with other districts. 
    Parking space means an area of not less than 180 square feet exclusive of drives or aisles giving access thereto, accessible from streets or alleys, and to be usable for the storage or parking of self-propelled passenger automobiles. 
    Subdivide has the meaning ascribed to it in the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
    Trunk line sewer means one which serves or is intended to serve as a common outlet for a number of district laterals. 
(Code 1974, § 29-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Subdivision defined, MCL 560.102(f). 
Sec. 86-32. - Variances. 
(a)  Where the planning commission finds that extraordinary hardships may result from strict compliance with this article, it may vary the regulations so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured; provided that such variation will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of the general city plan or this article. 
(b)  In granting variances and modifications, the planning commission may require such conditions as will, in its judgment, secure substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements so varied or modified. 
(Code 1974, § 29-7) 
Secs. 86-33-86-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLATS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 86-61. - Approved plats deemed part of city plan. 
    Every plat approved by the planning commission shall, by virtue of such approval, be deemed to be an amendment of, or an addition to, or a detail of, the city plan and a part thereof. 
(Code 1974, § 29-2) 
Sec. 86-62. - Approval of plat by council required prior to transmitting plat to other approving authorities. 
    No plat shall be transmitted to any county or state approving authority for official action as required by the state platting procedure until each plat shall have, in the first instance, been approved by the city council, in accordance with the regulations of this article and the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(Code 1974, § 29-3) 
Sec. 86-63. - Descriptions of subdivided lands not to be by metes and bounds. 
    No description of any lot or parcel in a plat of a subdivision shall be by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transfer of the lot or parcel. 
(Code 1974, § 29-4) 
Sec. 86-64. - Property not to be conveyed by reference to non-recorded plat. 
    No person shall sell or convey any lot in any plat by reference thereto until the plat has been duly recorded in the office of the county register of deeds. 
(Code 1974, § 29-5) 
Sec. 86-65. - Sale of improperly subdivided land. 
    Any sale of or option or contract to sell land subdivided contrary to the provisions of this article shall be voidable as provided in section 267 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.267). 
(Code 1974, § 29-6) 
Secs. 86-66-86-80. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Preliminary Plat[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Preliminary plats, MCL 560.111 et seq. 

Sec. 86-81. - Application for approval. 
    An application, in writing, shall be submitted to the planning commission by the owner or his authorized representative for approval of a preliminary plat of any proposed subdivision lying in the limits of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 29-18) 
Sec. 86-82. - Contents. 
    Three copies of the preliminary plat at a scale of not more than 200 feet to the inch showing the following shall be submitted with the application for approval of the preliminary plat: 
(1)  The title under which the proposed subdivision is to be recorded, a description of the land to be platted, the name and address of the owner and the technical author of the plan. 
(2)  The location of existing property lines, streets, buildings, watercourses, railroads, utilities and other physical features. 
(3)  The location of the adjoining streets, utilities, buildings and other physical features which relate to the development of the subdivision. 
(4)  The location, name and width of proposed streets, alleys, easements and public utilities, parks, plantings, lots and building lines on the property to be subdivided. 
(5)  Any engineering data deemed necessary relative to the topography, street cross sections, sewer elevations, water elevations and other pertinent matters. 
(6)  The proposed use of the property. 
(7)  The areas proposed to be dedicated for public purposes. 
(8)  The proposed grade elevations at street intersections or breaks of grades. 
(9)  The date, north point and graphic scale. 
(Code 1974, § 29-19) 
State Law reference- General specifications for preliminary plat, MCL 560.111. 
Sec. 86-83. - Filing fee. 
    The subdivider shall pay a filing fee to the city treasurer at the time a preliminary plat is filed with the planning commission. The fee shall be as established by the city council and shall cover the cost of advertising and notices, the cost of checking statements, and the cost of recording the approved plat. 
(Code 1974, § 29-20) 
State Law reference- Fees authorized, MCL 560.246. 
Sec. 86-84. - Tentative approval. 
    Preliminary plats shall be subject to the tentative approval of the planning commission, which shall take into consideration the city requirements and the most appropriate use of the land. Particular attention will be given to the standards of design, the justification for the development of public improvements and the subdivision conformity to the existing street plan. The width, location and arrangement of streets, the dimensions of lots, the location of utilities and other features will be studied. No preliminary plat shall be approved by the planning commission without first affording a public hearing thereon. 
(Code 1974, § 29-21; Ord. No. 702, § 1, 3-6-2006) 
State Law reference- Tentative approval of preliminary plat, MCL 560.112. 
Sec. 86-85. - Subdivider to be advised of required changes if plat is disapproved. 
    If the preliminary plat is not approved, a list of the changes necessary to render the plan acceptable shall be made known to the subdivider. 
(Code 1974, § 29-22) 
Sec. 86-86. - Signing of approved plans; filing of copies. 
    Plans tentatively approved by the planning commission shall bear the signature of the chairperson of the commission and one copy shall be filed in the office of the city engineer, one copy shall be filed in the office of the city clerk, one copy shall be filed with the planning commission and one copy shall be returned to the subdivider. 
(Code 1974, § 29-23) 
Sec. 86-87. - Approval of preliminary plat does not constitute acceptance of subdivision. 
    The approval of a preliminary plat shall not constitute an acceptance of a subdivision. 
(Code 1974, § 29-24) 
Secs. 86-88-86-100. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Final Plat[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Final plats, MCL 560.131 et seq. 

Sec. 86-101. - Time limit for filing. 
    The final or record subdivision plat shall be submitted to the planning commission in quadruplicate within one year after approval of the preliminary plat.f If the final plat is not filed within one year after approval of the preliminary plat, the approval of the preliminary plat shall become null and void unless an extension of time is applied for and the application is granted by the planning commission. 
(Code 1974, § 29-25) 
Sec. 86-102. - Preparation. 
    If a preliminary plat meets the approval of the planning commission, then the subdivider may proceed to make an accurate survey of the property and prepare the final plat. 
(Code 1974, § 29-26) 
Sec. 86-103. - Standards; contents. 
    The final plat shall be prepared and presented in accordance with the provisions of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and, in addition, shall show the following: 
(1)  The plat shall make reference to any private restrictions which shall accompany the plat, and shall contain proper acknowledgement of the owner and mortgagees accepting the platting restrictions. 
(2)  In addition to the requirements of subsection (1) of this section, the planning commission shall require a statement from each subdivider indicating: 
a.  Ownership of the property proposed to be subdivided as evidenced by an abstract of title certified to date, or, at the option of the proprietor, a policy of title insurance. 
b.  The improvements and utilities to be installed by the subdivider. 
c.  The private restrictions to be imposed upon the property after subdivision. 
d.  The streets, alleys and parks as agreed upon with the planning commission with a recital that the streets, alleys and parks are dedicated to the use of the public. 
e.  That the easements indicated on the plat are not dedicated to the public, but the right to use the easements is reserved for public utilities and that no permanent structures are to be erected within the lines of the easements. 
f.  The total area in acres of the tract to be subdivided. 
g.  The net area in lots. 
h.  The total lot frontage in feet, classified as to residential frontage, business frontage and industrial frontage. 
i.  The area in streets. 
j.  The area in parks. 
k.  The improvements and utilities to be installed by the subdivider as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1974, § 29-27) 
State Law reference- Final plat specifications, MCL 560.132 et seq. 
Sec. 86-104. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 702, § 2, adopted March 6, 2006, repealed § 86-104, which pertained to the requirement of a hearing before action on a final plat and was derived from Code 1974, § 29-28. 
Sec. 86-105. - Notice of hearing. 
    Any final plat submitted to the planning commission shall contain the name and address of the person to whom the notice of the hearing for approval of the plat shall be sent. The notice shall be sent to the person at the address shown on the plat, by registered mail, of the time and place of the hearing not less than five days before the date fixed therefor. Similar notice shall be mailed to the owners of land immediately adjoining the platted land, as their names and addresses appear upon the latest city tax record. 
(Code 1974, § 29-29) 
Sec. 86-106. - Approval, modification or disapproval. 
(a)  The planning commission shall examine the map for compliance with the preliminary plat and the required changes thereof and shall approve, modify or disapprove the final plat within 60 days after submission thereof to it, provided that the applicant for the planning commission's approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of such period. 
(b)  If the planning commission fails to approve, modify or disapprove the plat within 60 days after submission, or within such period of time as has been extended, it may be transmitted to the city council for final determination. The city council shall have the power to accept or reject the approval, modification or disapproval of any plat by the planning commission. 
(Code 1974, § 29-30) 
Secs. 86-107-86-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS AND DESIGN STANDARDS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to require improvements, MCL 560.182. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 86-131. - Approval of plans and specifications; supervision of work. 
    Plans and specifications for installations made pursuant to this division must be approved by the city engineer and the construction must be carried out under the direction of the office of the city engineer in strict accordance with the specifications established by ordinance or resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 29-88) 
Sec. 86-132. - Prerequisites to acceptance of plat. 
    A plat will not be approved or dedication of a street accepted unless the improvements required by this division are made, or a surety bond with two sureties or a surety company bond is furnished to guarantee the improvements. 
(Code 1974, § 29-89) 
Sec. 86-133. - Time limit for completing improvements. 
    Whenever any utility or other improvement is required to be installed under the provisions of this division, the installation shall be completed within a period established by resolution of the city council, such period commencing from the date of approval of the plat, unless delay is caused by strike, disaster, calamity, war, riot, insurrection, act of God or other cause beyond the control of the owner. 
(Code 1974, § 29-90) 
Sec. 86-134. - Inspector. 
    The city engineer shall assign a city inspector to inspect work done pursuant to this division for such time as may be necessary to ensure full compliance with the required specifications. The wages of the inspector shall be paid from a sum for inspection to be deposited by the subdivider with the city treasurer. 
(Code 1974, § 29-91) 
Sec. 86-135. - Conformity to master thoroughfare plan. 
    All subdivisions shall be in harmony with the master thoroughfare plan. 
(Code 1974, § 29-42) 
Sec. 86-136. - Street and subdivision names. 
(a)  Except as to certain nonthrough streets, described in Section 166, all proposed streets, obviously in alignment with another already existing and named street must bear the same name as the existing street. New street names shall not duplicate existing street names except as provided herein, and all names must be approved by the planning commission. 
(b)  Duplication of proposed subdivision names with the names of existing subdivisions shall not be permitted. 
(Code 1974, § 29-31; Ord. No. 701, § 1, 2-21-2006) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 86-137. - Monuments. 
    Monuments shall conform to and shall be placed as required by the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(Code 1974, § 29-62) 
State Law reference- Monuments, MCL 560.125. 
Sec. 86-138. - Use and area restrictions. 
    Property use and area restrictions must be in accordance with chapter 110, pertaining to zoning. 
(Code 1974, § 29-74) 
Sec. 86-139. - Procedure when use of property is more restricted than zoning designation. 
    Wherever property is subdivided with the intention that it shall have a use more restricted than that designated in chapter 110, such use shall be stated either in an application for an amendment to chapter 110 or in a separate statement filed with the planning commission. 
(Code 1974, § 29-75) 
Sec. 86-140. - Property unsuitable for building. 
    No property shall be subdivided for residential use if such is considered unsuitable for building purposes by the planning commission. 
(Code 1974, § 29-76) 
Sec. 86-141. - Number and location of business lots. 
    Business lots, when platted, shall bear a reasonable relation in number to the probable future number of families constituting the purchasing power of the neighborhood. The planning commission will reserve the right to allocate business lots in accordance with its master plan and chapter 110, pertaining to zoning. 
(Code 1974, § 29-77) 
Sec. 86-142. - Paved surfaces generally. 
    Off-street parking facilities in conjunction with business lots, sidewalks and roadways, including curbs, shall be installed in every new subdivision. 
(Code 1974, § 29-43) 
Sec. 86-143. - Alleys. 
    Alleys, having a minimum width of 24 feet, are required in the rear of all local business and commercial lots. A diagonal cutoff shall be made at all acute and right angle intersections of alleys sufficient to provide an inside turning radius of 30 feet. At the intersection of alley lines with street lines, a corner cutoff line shall be provided between points established by measuring a distance of five feet in both directions along the alley line and the street line from the point of their intersection. 
(Code 1974, § 29-55) 
Sec. 86-144. - Easements. 
    Where alleys are not provided, easements of not less than six feet in width shall be provided on each side of rear lot lines and of side lot lines where necessary for utilities. Easements shall be direct and continuous from block to block. Easements along natural watercourses and channels shall conform substantially with the lines of the natural waterways and may be required to be wider than six feet. 
(Code 1974, § 29-56) 
Sec. 86-145. - Open space; park, school and playground sites. 
    Due consideration shall be given by the subdivider and the planning commission to the dedication or reservation of suitable sites for future schools, parks and playgrounds. The location of such sites shall conform as nearly as possible to the master plan of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 29-73) 
Sec. 86-146. - Conformance with zoning requirements for off-street parking facilities. 
    The subdivider and the planning commission shall consider the off-street parking provisions as provided for in chapter 110, pertaining to zoning, and make adequate allowance for such off-street parking. 
(Code 1974, § 29-69) 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 110. 
Sec. 86-147. - Size of off-street parking areas. 
    Off-street parking facilities, on the basis of one parking space, exclusive of drives or aisles giving access thereto, shall be provided for each 60 square feet of platted business area. 
(Code 1974, § 29-57) 
Secs. 86-148-86-160. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Streets[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 

Sec. 86-161. - Relation to adjoining street system. 
(a)  The arrangement of streets in a new subdivision shall make provision for the continuation of principal existing streets in adjoining or adjacent subdivisions, insofar as they may be necessary for public requirements. In general, streets shall be of a width as great as that of the street so continued or projected. The centerline of such streets shall continue with the centerline of existing streets. 
(b)  In general, the streets shall extend to the boundary of the subdivision to provide proper access to adjoining property, and provide for proper connection with the highway system of contiguous land. 
(c)  Where the planning commission has adopted a plan or plat of a neighborhood or area of which the subdivision is a part and the proposed plat provides coordination with the street systems of the city different from that of continuations of projections of existing streets and the subdivider's plat conforms in general to such neighborhood or area plat or plan of the planning commission, the planning commission may approve the subdivider's plat. 
(d)  Where the plat submitted covers only a part of the subdivider's tract, a sketch of a proposed future street system of the unsubmitted part shall be considered in the light of adjustments and connections with the street system of the part not submitted. 
(e)  Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed arterial street, the planning commission may require marginal access streets, reverse frontage with screen planting contained in a non-access reservation along the rear property line, deep lots with rear service alleys, or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. 
(Code 1974, § 29-44) 
Sec. 86-162. - Access of lots to streets. 
    All lots, parks or public properties must have means of ingress and egress, either by a street, lane or drive. Building permits shall not be issued for the construction of buildings which do not have access on a public street. There shall be no reserve strips controlling access to a street, except where the control of such strips is definitely placed with the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 29-45) 
Sec. 86-163. - Accommodation of future streets when parcel is divided into large tracts. 
    Where a parcel of land is subdivided into larger tracts than for building lots, the platting shall not be such as to stop the opening of major streets and the extension of adjacent minor streets, which in the judgment of the planning commission should ultimately be opened and extended. 
(Code 1974, § 29-46) 
Sec. 86-164. - Intersections. 
    Streets shall intersect each other at as nearly right angles as is practicable. Streets converging at one point shall be reduced to the least practicable number. 
(Code 1974, § 29-47) 
Sec. 86-165. - Streets in relation to railroads. 
(a)  Whenever a subdivision is to be laid out adjacent to a railroad right-of-way, a street shall be placed parallel to the railroad. 
(b)  The intersection of the centerline of the parallel street with that of any street which crosses the railroad shall not be less than 300 feet from the line of the railroad right-of-way. 
(Code 1974, § 29-48) 
Sec. 86-166. - Dead-end streets. 
    Dead-end streets will not be approved if they exceed 750 feet in length or do not lend themselves to adequate fire protection as determined by the fire department and planning commission. Every permanent dead-end street shall be of such width at the closed end so as to permit a turn-around having an outside roadway radius so as to permit the proper turn-around area as approved by the planning commission. 
(Code 1974, § 29-49; Ord. No. 700, § 1, 2006) 
Sec. 86-167. - Half streets. 
    The dedication of half streets will be permitted where a subdivision adjoins undeveloped property. If there already exists a dedicated and recorded half street or alley on an adjoining plat, the other half must be dedicated on the proposed plat to make the street or alley complete. 
(Code 1974, § 29-50) 
Sec. 86-168. - Width. 
(a)  The width for major streets shall conform to the width designated on the master thoroughfare plan. 
(b)  The minimum width for minor streets shall be 60 feet, except in cases where the topography or special conditions make a street of less width more suitable. The planning commission may waive the requirements of this subsection. 
(Code 1974, § 29-51) 
Sec. 86-169. - Grade. 
(a)  Profiles may be required of all streets at the discretion of the planning commission. 
(b)  The minimum grade allowed shall be four-tenths of one percent. 
(c)  The street cross section shall provide a slope from the property line to the curb. There shall be a minimum grade or wash of one-fourth inch per foot for the sidewalk and a minimum grade of three-eighths inch per foot for the area between the sidewalk and the curb. 
(Code 1974, § 29-52) 
Sec. 86-170. - Corner radius. 
    Curb corners shall be rounded with a radius of not less than 20 feet. Intersections where the interior angle is less than 60 degrees shall have the curb corners rounded with at least a 30-foot radius, and when the interior angle is less than 135 degrees it is recommended that the corner be rounded with a minimum radius of ten feet. Property lines at such corners shall be rounded or otherwise set back sufficiently to permit such construction. 
(Code 1974, § 29-53) 
Sec. 86-171. - Access to streets across ditches and watercourses. 
    Subdividers shall provide access to all proposed streets across watercourses or ditches in a standard manner approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1974, § 29-54) 
Sec. 86-172. - Street trees. 
    Whenever the planning commission deems it desirable in order to ensure continuity of purpose, street trees shall be planted in conformance with a planting plan approved by the city planning commission. 
(Code 1974, § 29-58) 
Sec. 86-173. - Street signs. 
    When, in the opinion of the planning commission, the identity of any street appears desirable, the establishment of street signs of the same type and design in general use within the community shall be required. 
(Code 1974, § 29-59) 
Secs. 86-174-86-190. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Sewers, Water Mains and Fire Hydrants[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; utilities, ch. 98. 

Sec. 86-191. - Required; installation. 
(a)  The installation of storm sewers, sanitary sewers, stormwater inlets, house connections from sewers to beyond the lot line location, water mains with house connections to the city main and fire hydrants at a location to be approved by the chief of the fire department shall be required in every subdivision. 
(b)  Whenever a trunk line sewer is to be installed, the city council shall establish by resolution the metes and bounds of the area it is intended to serve. 
(c)  Any person desiring to tie a lateral sewer into a trunk line sewer shall pay to the city the cost of installing the trunk line sewer, according to the ratio the area of the district to be served by the lateral sewer bears to the area established to be served by the trunk line sewer. Any cost of installation to be paid under the provisions of this subsection shall be deposited with the city before any installation is commenced. 
(d)  The cost of installation of lateral storm and sanitary sewers shall be paid by the subdivider. 
(e)  The cost of trunk line storm and sanitary sewers shall be paid by the subdivider or, if the land is unplatted, by the owner thereof. 
(Code 1974, § 29-60) 
Sec. 86-192. - Sewer and water installations on nonconforming lots. 
    Public sewer or water service shall not be provided for any dwelling or other structure located on a lot or plat subdivided or sold in violation of this article, except that such service may be installed in any structure when deemed necessary by the health department for the protection of the public health. 
(Code 1974, § 29-61) 
Secs. 86-193-86-210. - Reserved. 
Subdivision IV. - Lots and Blocks 

Sec. 86-211. - Building lines. 
    Building lines shall conform to the requirements of chapter 110, pertaining to zoning, and the master thoroughfare plan as provided by Public Act No. 285 of 1931 (MCL 125.31 et seq.). 
(Code 1974, § 29-63) 
Sec. 86-212. - Residential blocks. 
    Residential blocks shall not be less than 220 feet wide. Residential blocks shall not be less than 660 feet or more than 1,200 feet long. Where the blocks are more than 800 feet long, and the planning commission finds additional cross access desirable for the public welfare, a ten-foot crosswalk shall be provided near the center of the block. 
(Code 1974, § 29-64) 
Sec. 86-213. - Business, commercial and industrial blocks. 
    Business, commercial and industrial blocks shall not be less than 340 feet wide or less than 340 feet long. Where blocks are more than 340 feet long, a ten-foot crosswalk shall be provided near the center of the block. 
(Code 1974, § 29-65) 
Sec. 86-214. - Size of residential lots. 
    No lot classified as residential shall be platted that is less than 50 feet in width and less than 6,000 square feet in area; provided, however, that the lot sizes of any plat shall conform to the lot area as established by chapter 110 for the zoning district in which the lots are located. 
(Code 1974, § 29-66) 
Sec. 86-215. - Manner of measuring wedge-shaped lots. 
    Where it may be necessary to plat wedge-shaped lots in order to effect the best lot arrangement of a parcel of land, the lot width shall be measured at the front building line when the front lot line is narrower than the rear lot line. When the rear line of a wedge-shaped lot is narrower than the front lot line, the lot width shall be measured on a line 35 feet from and parallel to the rear property line. 
(Code 1974, § 29-67) 
Sec. 86-216. - Size of business or commercial lots. 
    No lot or parcel classified as business or commercial shall be platted that is less than 40 feet in width or less than 6,800 square feet in area. The area of the lot or parcel shall be sufficient in size as to provide an area for off-street parking equal to three times the size of the first floor area of the building, exclusive of aisles and drives, and the off-street parking shall be located within a distance of 300 feet from the building. Alleys shall be dedicated as required by the master plan or as approved by the planning commission. 
(Code 1974, § 29-68) 
Sec. 86-217. - Side lot lines. 
    All side lot lines should be at right angles to straight street lines, or radial to curved street lines, unless a variation from this rule will give a better street and lot plan. 
(Code 1974, § 29-70) 
Sec. 86-218. - Lots with double frontage. 
    Lots with double frontage shall be discouraged insofar as possible, but, if provided, the lots must have sufficient depth so that a reasonable front yard may be provided on both street frontages to protect similar frontages on adjacent lots in each direction. 
(Code 1974, § 29-71) 
Sec. 86-219. - Corner lots. 
    Corner lots shall have extra width sufficient to permit the maintenance of building lines on both front and side. In normal cases, the width required will not be less than the amount of the established building lines on the side street, plus the irreducible buildable width and such side yard requirements as are provided for in chapter 110, pertaining to zoning. 
(Code 1974, § 29-72) 
Secs. 86-220-86-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DIVISION OF SUBDIVIDED LOTS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Further partition or division of property, MCL 560.263. 

Sec. 86-251. - Purpose. 
    This article is enacted to provide for the partitioning or dividing of lots, outlots or other parcels of land in existing recorded plats into not more than four parts. 
(Code 1974, § 29-102) 
Sec. 86-252. - Procedure; conformance with zoning regulations. 
    Upon the filing of a petition, by the owners of all interest therein, with the city council, platted lots, outlots, or parcels of land in existing recorded plats may be partitioned or divided upon resolution of the city council into not more than four parts, each of which shall, in regard to width, depth and area, conform to the terms and provisions of chapter 110, pertaining to zoning. 
(Code 1974, § 29-103) 
Sec. 86-253. - Lots not served by public water and sewer system. 
    Lots, outlots or parcels of land in existing recorded plats not served by public sewer and public water systems shall not be further partitioned or divided unless the resulting lots, outlots or parcels are less than the minimum width and area provided under the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(Code 1974, § 29-104) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Lot widths, MCL 560.186. 
Sec. 86-254. - Division when land is to be owned by adjacent landowner. 
    Nothing in this article shall prevent the city council from approving the division of any lot, outlot or parcel of land in a case where the owner of the divided parcel owns land immediately adjacent thereto or in a case where there is presented to the city council an executed agreement to sell and convey such divided parcel to the adjoining owner and where the combined width and area of the divided parcel and the adjacent parcel shall, as a single parcel, conform to the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 29-105)
