Chapter 94 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations not codified in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-12(15)a; any ordinance ordering, requiring or authorizing the erection or installation of traffic control signs, signals devices or markings saved from repeal, § 1-12(15)b; taxicabs, § 22-361 et seq.; motor vehicle noise, § 38-161 et seq.; transportation of explosives, § 42-291 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 58; placing handbills in vehicles, § 66-445; obstructing traffic, § 70-115; causing litter to fall into path of or hit vehicle, § 74-147; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; off-street parking requirements, § 110-673; off-street parking space lay-out, standards, construction and maintenance, § 110-674; vehicle storage, app. A, § A-10. 
State Law reference- Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL 257.1 et seq.; powers of local authorities, MCL 257.605, 257.606, 257.610; Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963, MCL 480.11 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced in accordance with the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages as adopted in this chapter and the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.). 
Sec. 94-2. - Interpretation. 
    In the event of a conflict between the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages as adopted in this chapter and this chapter, the provisions of this chapter shall control. In the event of a conflict between the provisions of this chapter and the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.), the Michigan Vehicle Code shall control. In the event of conflict between the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages as adopted in this chapter and the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.), the Michigan Vehicle Code shall control. 
Sec. 94-3. - Vehicle Code adopted. 
    Pursuant to 1999 P.A. 258, 259 and 260, there is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference, the Michigan Vehicle Code (MVC), 2012 edition, being 1949 P.A. 300, MCL 257.1 through 257.923, as amended from time to time, including but not limited to MCL 257.625(1)(c) and the penalties associated therewith. An official copy of such code is on file in the office of the city clerk and the same is hereby adopted by reference as fully set forth herein, save and except for those provisions thereof which are hereinafter amended or deleted and save and except that if any of the provisions of such codes conflict with any other ordinance of the city, the other provision of the traffic code as amended, or the ordinance of the city, as the case may be, shall control. 
(Ord. No. 677, § 1, 11-15-2004; Ord. No. 742, § 1, 11-1-2010; Ord. No. 762, § 1, 5-7-2012) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt Michigan Vehicle Code by reference, MCL 117.3(k). 
Sec. 94-4. - Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages adopted. 
(a)  Pursuant to 1999 P.A. 258, 259 and 260, there is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference, the Michigan Vehicle Code (MVC), 2005 edition, being 1949 P.A. 300, MCL 257.1-257.923, as amended from time to time. An official copy of such code is on file in the office of the city clerk and the same is hereby adopted by reference as fully set forth herein, save and except for those provisions thereof which are hereinafter amended or deleted and save and except that if any of the provisions of such codes conflict with any other ordinance of the city, the other provision of the traffic code as amended, or the ordinance of the city, as the case may be, shall control. 
(b)  References in the Michigan Vehicle Code to "local authorities" shall mean the City of Trenton. 
(c)  The following definitions and procedures formerly applied to the 1979 Edition of the Uniform Traffic Code, shall continue in force and effect without reference to specific sections of the 1979 Edition of the Uniform Traffic Code which is hereby repealed: 
R 28.1140 (Rule 140). Permit for loading or unloading at an angle to the curb. No person shall back a vehicle to the curb for purposes of loading or unloading merchandise, materials or passengers without first securing a special permit issued by the city for that purpose. The traffic engineer may authorize the clerk to issue special permits to permit the backing of vehicles to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. A permit may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the owner of the vehicle. A permit shall grant to such person the privileges which are stated in the permit and which are authorized in this code. A permit must be visibly displayed in the front window of the backed vehicle. The fee for the issuance of such a permit shall be as established by the city council. 
Prior ordinances to remain in effect. All intersection stops and yield right-of-way requirements, regulations on stopping, standing or parking, prima facie speed limits, one-way streets, roadways and alleys, crosswalks, restricted turns, through streets, play streets, angle parking zones, all-night parking restrictions, curb loading zones, public carrier stands, parking meter zones and spaces, weight restrictions, no passing zones, and traffic control devices heretofore established and effective on the effective date of this code shall be deemed established hereunder and shall remain effective until otherwise rescinded or modified. A list of traffic ordinances which are saved from repeal may be found on file in the office of the city clerk, namely, section 3 of Ordinance No. 371-44. 
Parking permits in front of residence. Upon certain conditions hereinafter set forth, parking permits shall be issued to any resident by the chief of police, granting the resident permission to park an automobile in a restricted parking space on the street directly in front of such resident's home, provided such home is not located in a commercial building of any kind. Such resident shall make application to the chief of police setting forth all relevant information as required by the chief of police. Based upon such application, the chief of police shall have authority to grant such parking permit, which shall be in the form of a suitable sticker stating the name of the holder, his address, and the date of issuance and signed by the chief of police. The holder shall then attach such sticker to the windshield of his automobile; provided, however, that such permit shall not grant the holder any privilege to park in any area where or when parking is prohibited, and provided further that no permit shall be issued to anyone residing in a multiple dwelling except in the discretion of the chief of police with regard to the number of residential units and the available space for parking fronting such residence. Under no circumstances shall more than one permit be granted to each dwelling unit. 
Restrictions on trucks and commercial vehicles upon use of streets. No person shall operate or stop, stand or park any truck or commercial vehicle with a gross weight in excess of 20,000 pounds in the following designated areas except for local delivery and buses: all portions of the northbound and southbound lanes of West Jefferson Avenue between King Road and Van Horn Road. 
"Local delivery" is defined, for purposes of this section, to mean a delivery or pickup of materials, manufactured products, goods, wares or merchandise from or to any residential or business establishment located within the weight restricted area. 
Ice cream trucks, stopping for, special equipment requirements. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  "Ice cream truck" means every motor vehicle in which ice cream, ice milk, frozen dairy products or ice flavored with syrup is carried for purposes of retail sale on the streets of the city. 
(2)  "Vend" or "vending" means offering ice cream, ice milk, frozen dairy products or ice flavored with syrup for sale from a motor vehicle on the streets of the city. 
(b)  Drivers to stop for ice cream trucks. 
(1)  The driver of a vehicle meeting or overtaking from either direction an ice cream truck stopped on the street shall stop before reaching the truck when the flashing lights and stop signal arm described in subsection (c)(2) are in use. After stopping, a driver may proceed past such truck at a reasonable and prudent speed, not exceeding 15 miles per hour, and shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian who crosses the roadway to or from the ice cream truck. 
(2)  The driver of a vehicle on a street with separate roadways need not stop upon meeting or passing an ice cream truck on a different roadway. 
(c)  Equipment requirements for ice cream trucks. In addition to other equipment required by law, every ice cream truck shall be equipped with: 
(1)  Signal lamps mounted at the same level and as high and as widely spaced laterally as practicable. These lamps shall be five to seven inches in diameter and shall display two alternately flashing amber lights on the front of the vehicle and two alternately flashing red lights on the rear of the vehicle, both lights visible at 500 feet in normal sunlight upon a straight level street. 
(2)  A stop signal arm that can be extended horizontally from the left side of the truck duplicating the design size and specifications shown in subsection (4). This arm shall be red and white in color and contain two alternately flashing lights three to five inches in diameter visible at 300 feet to the front and rear in normal sunlight upon a straight level highway. The color of the two lights facing to the front shall be amber and the two lights facing to the rear shall be red. The bottom of the signal arm shall be between 40 and 48 inches above the highway. 
(3)  A convex mirror mounted on the front so the driver in his normal seating position can see the area in front of the truck obscured by the hood. 
(4)  The stop signal arm required by subsection (c)(2) shall be as follows: 


Stop Signal 
(5)  Ice cream vendors shall have until January 1, 1977, to comply with the equipment requirements of this section. 
(d)  Use of special lights and stop arm on ice cream trucks. 
(1)  The driver of an ice cream truck stopped on the streets for the purpose of vending shall actuate the special flashing lights and extend the stop signal arm required by subsection (c)(2). 
(2)  These lights and the stop signal arm shall not be used when the truck is in motion or at any time the truck is stopped for a purpose other than vending. 
(e)  Inspection required. Every ice cream truck shall be inspected by the police department once each year prior to its use in this city for the purpose of retail sales of frozen dairy products. The police department shall inspect each ice cream truck to determine whether it complies with this section and other state and local laws. 
(f)  Vending restrictions. 
(1)  A person shall not vend on main thoroughfares or in the central business district on streets where the speed limit exceeds 25 miles per hour or other areas of the city where sale is already prohibited by local ordinance. 
(2)  A person shall not vend within 500 feet of any property used as a school from one hour before the regular school day to one hour after the regular school day, provided this subsection shall not apply on days when school is not attended by children or on school property when vending has been approved in writing by the principal. 
(3)  A person shall vend only when the ice cream truck is lawfully parked or stopped. 
(4)  A person shall vend only from the side of the truck away from moving traffic and as near as possible to the curb or edge of the street. 
(5)  A person shall not vend to a person standing in the roadway. 
(6)  A person shall not stop on the left side of a one-way street to vend. 
(g)  Backing restricted. The driver of an ice cream truck shall not back the truck to make or attempt a sale. 
(h)  Unauthorized riders prohibited. 
(1)  The driver of an ice cream truck shall not permit any unauthorized person to ride in or on the vehicle. 
(2)  A person shall not ride in or on an ice cream truck unless employed by its owner or unless authorized in writing to do so by the owner or police department. 
Parking motorcycles on residential streets restricted. A motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall not be operated on residential streets after 12:00 p.m. and before 8:00 a.m. of each day; unless while taking the shortest and most direct route to or from the driver's residence from the nearest state trunkline. 
Speed limit of motorcycles on residential streets. The speed limit on all residential streets for motorcycles or motor-driven cycles shall be 25 miles per hour. 
Obedience to angle parking signs or markings. Upon those streets which have been signed or marked for angle parking, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs, and within the designated space for one vehicle, so indicated by the markings. 
Restricted parking for certain trucks and buses. No person shall park any truck or bus weighing more than 5,000 pounds or measuring more than 30 feet in length, or any truck having a trailer or semitrailer attached, or permit any such truck or any trailer or semitrailer, whether coupled or not, to stand upon any part of any street or alley of the city for a period exceeding four hours, except for the purpose of loading or unloading, the making of emergency repairs, or at the direction or permission of the police department. 
Parking restricted during rubbish collection and snow removal. 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  Snow removal; penalty for violation; enforcement. It shall be unlawful to park, leave unattended or fail to remove any motor vehicle or trailer on any public street, highway or alleyway, or cause such vehicle or trailer to remain parked, after a snow fall and/or drifting snow of four inches or more, prior to the removal by city plowing of such street. All vehicles and/or trailers found to be in violation of this subsection shall be ticketed and the owner, if possible, notified to remove the vehicle from the public street, highway or alleyway. In addition, the vehicle and/or trailer may be removed from the public street, highway or alleyway at the expense of the vehicle owner. Such expense shall include all towing and storage charges attached to the vehicle. Enforcement of this subsection shall be under the direction of the police department personnel. 
(c)  Notification of restrictions. The director of the public services or his designee shall cause notification to be given to all person residing and those doing business in the area of the restrictions and penalties set forth by this section. Notification shall be made once by mail within a 90-day period from October 15, 1978, and three times by publication in the official city newspaper within the 90-day period. 
(d)  Exemption. A person may obtain a hardship permit from the police department by completing an application provided therefor, and signing an affidavit indicating that the residence does not have off-street parking, or off-street parking in inadequate by reason of his physical condition. 
(e)  Applicability. This section shall apply to all public streets, highways or alleyways located within the boundaries of the city. 
Stopping, standing and parking between property and curblines. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in that portion of the highway located between the property lot line or curb or edge of roadway, except where that area is designated as permitted parking and standing. 
(Code 1974, §§ 21-15-21-17; Ord. No. 659, § 1, 11-4-2002; Ord. No. 664, § 1, 9-2-2003; Ord. No. 677, § 1, 11-15-2004; Ord. No. 697, § 1, 1-3-2006) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt Uniform Traffic Code by reference, MCL 257.951. 
Sec. 94-5. - Driving across sidewalk or pedestrian right-of-way into business premises. 
(a)  No person, while driving a motor vehicle, shall cross any sidewalk or pedestrian right-of-way for the purpose of gaining access to any business premises unless such person or the occupant of the motor vehicle does so for the purpose of transacting business on the premises. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, the term "transaction of business" shall mean that one of the purposes of any person in entering a business premises in a vehicle shall be with the intent of engaging in a transaction with the proprietor of the business premises which is normally incidental to the nature of the business for which the public is invited and for which the premises is licensed. It shall be presumed that the entry upon such premises by any pedestrian or any person in the motor vehicle, without actually engaging in a business transaction, shall constitute prima facie evidence of violation of this section. 
(Code 1974, § 21-4) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 94-6. - Abandoned or junked vehicles on private property. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this subsection: 
    Dismantled vehicle and partially dismantled vehicle mean a vehicle from which some part which is ordinarily a major component of such vehicle has been removed or is missing. 
    Nonoperating vehicle means a vehicle which, by reason of dismantling, disrepair or other cause, is incapable of being propelled under its own power. 
    Unlicensed vehicle means a vehicle which is not equipped or displayed with a current year registration plate as required under the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.). 
    Vehicle means a wheeled vehicle which is self-propelled or intended to be self-propelled. 
(b)  No person shall abandon any vehicle or leave any vehicle on any private property within the city for such time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle reasonably to appear to have been abandoned. Violations of the provisions of this subsection are a municipal civil infraction for which the fine is $50.00. 
(c)  In the event of unique hardship arising from literal enforcement of this section, an owner of a vehicle may store or park on the owner's premises one unlicensed vehicle if the vehicle is operable and registered in the owner's name and such owner secures a permit to store or park such vehicle from the chief of police or his designee. Such permit shall be issued upon a further showing that doing so will not endanger public health or safety. Such permit shall state the reason for exemption, the conditions of the permit and the period of the permit. At any time that the chief of police or his designee determines the permit holder is in violation of the conditions of the permit, he shall notify the permit holder by written notice of the violation and such permit holder shall have 48 hours to comply with this section. Failure to comply with such notice shall be a violation of this section. 
(Code 1974, §§ 2-306(a)(22), 21-83, 21-85, 21-90) 
State Law reference- Abandoned vehicles, MCL 257.252a et seq. 
Sec. 94-7. - Penalties; violation. 
(a)  Any provision of this chapter, including the Uniform Traffic Code adopted and amended herein, which describes an act or omission which constitutes a civil infraction under the terms of the Michigan Vehicle Code, shall be processed as a civil infraction and any person found to have committed a civil infraction may be ordered to pay a civil fine of not more than $100.00 and costs, unless provided otherwise by section 907 of the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.907). 
(b)  Violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, including the Motor Vehicle Code and the Uniform Traffic Code, adopted and amended herein, not constituting a civil infraction as herein provided, shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment of not more than 93 days, or both. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, violations of MCL 257.625(1)(c) shall be punishable by one or more of the following: 
(1)  Community service for not more than 360 hours. 
(2)  Imprisonment for not more than 180 days. 
(3)  A fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $700.00. 
(Ord. No. 659, § 2, 11-4-2002; Ord. No. 664, § 2, 9-2-2003; Ord. No. 742, § 1, 11-1-2010; Ord. No. 762, § 1, 5-7-2012) 
Sec. 94-8. - Unlicensed vehicles on public property. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle, nor shall a vehicle's registered owner permit his or her vehicle to be parked, upon any public street or highway, unless there is attached to, and displayed on, the vehicle a current and valid registration plate issued for that vehicle. 
(b)  Display of a current registration plate shall not be required upon any damaged or disabled vehicle in the street, for not more than 72 hours, solely for the purpose of facilitating its removal by a licensed wrecking service, as evidenced by written contract, only if parked in front of the owner's residence and, if advance notice of the parking is provided to the police department. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction of not more than $50.00 per day. 
(Ord. No. 704, § 1, 10-16-2006) 
Sec. 94-9. - Required insurance. 
    Pursuant to 1956 P.A. 218, as amended, there is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference, those provisions of the Michigan Insurance Code requiring the owner or registrant of any motor vehicle or motorcycle, which is required to be registered in the State of Michigan, to maintain security for payment of benefits under personal protection insurance, property protection insurance, and residual liability insurance in accordance with MCL 500.3102 through 500.3103, as amended from time to time. An official copy of such code is on file in the office of the city clerk and the same is hereby adopted by reference as fully set forth herein, save and except for those provisions thereof which are hereinafter amended or deleted. 
(Ord. No. 779, § 1, 12-2-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 779, § 1, adopted December 2, 2013, set out provisions intended for use as § 54-8. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 54-9. 
Sec. 94-10. - Texting or emailing by operator from moving vehicle. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, a person shall not read, manually type, or send a text message on a wireless two-way communication device that is located in the person's hand or in the persons' lap, including a wireless telephone used in cellular telephone service or personal communication service, while operating a motor vehicle that is moving on a highway or street in this state. 
(b)  As used in this subsection, a wireless two-way communication device does not include a global position or navigation system that is affixed to the motor vehicle 
(c)  Subsection (a) does not apply to an individual who is using a device described in subsection (a) to do any of the following: 
(1)  Report a traffic accident, medical emergency, or serious road hazard to authorities. 
(2)  Report a situation in which the person believes his or her personal safety is in jeopardy. 
(3)  Report or avert the perpetration or potential perpetration of a criminal act against the individuals or another person. 
(4)  Carry out official duties as a police offer, law enforcement official, member of a paid or volunteer fire department, or operator of an emergency vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 734, § 1, 6-7-2010 
Sec. 94-11. - Penalties. 
    An individual who violates section 94-10 is responsible for a civil infraction and shall be ordered to pay a civil fine as follows: 
(1)  For a first violation, $100.00. 
(2)  For a second or subsequent violation, $200.00. 
(Ord. No. 734, § 1, 6-7-2010 
Secs. 94-12-94-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BICYCLES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Operation of bicycles and toy vehicles, MCL 257.656 et seq; authority to regulate bicycles, MCL 257.606(1)(i). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-31. - Enforcement; penalty. 
(a)  Any person 16 years of age and under who violates any of the provisions of this article relating to the vehicle traffic laws or the bicycle safe riding rules and regulations and the official police instructions for the safe operation of a bicycle shall be, for the first offense, reprimanded in writing by the police department, addressed to the parents or guardian of the offender, stating the nature of the violation and a warning that a repetition of the violation, or any other violation, must be prevented by the parents or guardian or the offender's registration certificate will be suspended for a period of time at the discretion of the police department and during that period of time the offender cannot ride his bicycle on the streets, highways, pathways and other public places. On the second offense the offender will be summoned to appear at police headquarters with his bicycle, accompanied by a parent or guardian, and, after a hearing on the violation, the offender's bicycle may be impounded for a period of time not to exceed 30 days at the discretion of the police department or its representative with the approval, if possible, of the parent or guardian. On the third offense, the offender may be referred to the juvenile court authorities in accordance with those procedures. It is ordained that no violation of this article relating to the vehicle traffic laws or the safe bicycle riding rules and the official instructions for the safe operation of a bicycle, as prescribed in this article, shall be considered a criminal offense or made a matter of a court record where the offender is 16 years of age or under. 
(b)  Any person over 16 years of age shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by the payment of a fine not to exceed $100.00, or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed 90 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1974, § 21-74) 
Sec. 94-32. - Operational rules. 
(a)  Every person operating a bicycle shall at all times operate the bicycle with due regard for the safety of other persons and vehicles lawfully upon the streets, highways, pathways and public places, as well as for his own safety, and shall at all times and under all conditions yield the right-of-way to pedestrians on the streets, highways, pathways, sidewalks, and public places and on the crosswalks. 
(b)  Every person operating a bicycle shall comply with all vehicle traffic laws and all vehicle traffic signs and signals erected for the regulation of traffic, including bike trail signs, except where such laws, by their nature, do not apply to bicycles. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a bicycle upon the streets, highways, pathways, sidewalks and public places of the city during the period of sunset to sunrise unless such bicycle is equipped with light safety equipment as provided by section 94-4 adopting and amending the Uniform Traffic Code. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to operate a bicycle upon the streets, highways, pathways, sidewalks and public places of the city that is not equipped with adequate brakes. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of all persons operating a bicycle to ride single file, in a straight line and as near the righthand curb as possible, on all main thoroughfares and in central business sections, and when riding on other streets persons operating a bicycle must not ride more than two abreast, unless otherwise specifically designated on bike trails, routes or pathways. 
(f)  Before turning or changing the direction of any bicycle upon any street, highway, pathway or public place, it shall be the duty of the bicycle rider to give a signal, by the extension of the hand, to indicate the direction in which it is the intention to proceed. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating a bicycle upon any street, highway, pathway or public place to attach himself to any other moving vehicle. 
(Code 1974, § 21-73) 
Secs. 94-33-94-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 94-51. - Registration and identification tag required. 
    No person who resides within the city shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles unless such bicycle has been registered and a registration identification tag is attached thereto as provided in this division. Violations of the provisions of this section are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1974, § 2-306(a)(1), 21-63) 
Sec. 94-52. - Application. 
    Application for a bicycle registration and registration identification tag shall be made upon a form provided by the city and shall be made to the police department of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 21-64) 
Sec. 94-53. - Fee. 
    The registration fees required by this division shall be as established by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 21-65) 
Sec. 94-54. - Identification tag not to be issued to persons not entitled to possession of bicycle. 
    The police department shall not issue any registration identification tag for any bicycle where there are reasonable grounds to believe that the applicant is not the owner of, or entitled to the possession of, such bicycle. 
(Code 1974, § 21-66) 
Sec. 94-55. - Inspection of bicycle prior to registration. 
    The police officer assigned such responsibility may inspect each bicycle before registering the bicycle, and may refuse a registration for any bicycle which he determines is in unsafe mechanical condition. 
(Code 1974, § 21-67) 
Sec. 94-56. - Records. 
    The police department shall keep a record of the number of each bicycle registration, the date registered, the name and address of the person to whom it was registered, and the number on the frame of the bicycle, and a record of all bicycle registration fees collected by him. The police department may require owners to place identification numbers on the frames of bicycles, which the city may designate. 
(Code 1974, § 21-68) 
Sec. 94-57. - Issuance of tag; affixing to bicycle. 
(a)  The police department, upon registering a bicycle, shall also issue a registration identification tag bearing the registration number assigned to the bicycle and the name of the city. 
(b)  The police department shall cause the registration identification tag to be affixed to the frame of the bicycle for which issued in such position as to be plainly visible. 
(Code 1974, § 21-69) 
Sec. 94-58. - Removal of tag. 
    No person shall remove a registration identification tag from a bicycle except upon a transfer of ownership or in the event the bicycle is dismantled and no longer operated upon any street in the city. 
(Code 1974, § 21-70) 
Sec. 94-59. - Transfer of tag. 
    Upon the sale or other transfer of ownership of a registered bicycle, the person transferring the bicycle shall have the registration identification tag assigned to the transferee. 
(Code 1974, § 21-71) 
Sec. 94-60. - Registration and equipment requirements for bicycle rental agencies. 
    A rental agency shall not rent or offer any bicycle for rent unless the bicycle is registered and a registration identification tag is attached thereto as provided in this division, and the bicycle is equipped with the lamps and other equipment required by the Uniform Traffic Code adopted by section 94-4. 
(Code 1974, § 21-72) 
Secs. 94-61-94-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SNOWMOBILES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Snowmobiles, MCL 324.82101 et seq.; local regulation of snowmobiles, MCL 324.82124. 

Sec. 94-81. - Authority to adopt restrictions on operation on public property. 
    The city council may, by resolution, prohibit the operation of snowmobiles within the right-of-way of the public roads or streets or other city property when in its opinion the public safety and welfare so requires. 
(Code 1974, § 21-42) 
Sec. 94-82. - Special programs and events; designation of park areas for use of snowmobiles. 
    Notwithstanding the prohibitions of this article, the director of parks and recreation shall have the authority to supervise and regulate events or programs in connection with events conducted by the parks and recreation department in which snowmobiles are used. The director of parks and recreation shall have the authority to designate city park areas that he shall deem available for the use of snowmobiles. 
(Code 1974, § 21-41) 
Secs. 94-83-94-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SHOPPING CENTER TRAFFIC AND PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parking area means an area near or contiguous to a shopping center and used by the public as the means of access to and egress from the stores and business establishments at the shopping center and for the free parking of motor vehicles of patrons of the shopping center. 
    Shopping center means a minimum area of three acres of land on which there is located one or more stores or business establishments and where there is provided a parking area. 
(Code 1974, § 21-116) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 94-112. - Authority to regulate traffic and parking. 
    The city council may, upon the request of either the owner or the person in charge of the general operation and control of the parking area of a shopping center, by ordinance: 
(1)  Order stop signs, yield signs or other traffic control devices erected at specified entrance or exit locations to a shopping center or at any intersection in the parking area. 
(2)  Regulate traffic in the parking area, including regulation by means of traffic control signals. 
(3)  Prohibit or regulate the turning of vehicles or specified types of vehicles at intersections or other designated locations in the parking area. 
(4)  Regulate the crossing of any roadway in the parking area by pedestrians. 
(5)  Designate any separate roadway, drive or lane in the parking area for one-way traffic. 
(6)  Prohibit, regulate, restrict or limit the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified areas of the parking area. 
(7)  Designate safety zones, loading zones and other restricted areas in the shopping center. 
(8)  Provide for the removal and storage of vehicles parking or abandoned in the parking area during snowstorms, floods, fires or other public emergencies, or found unattended in the parking area, where they constitute an obstruction to traffic or where stopping, standing or parking is prohibited, and for the payment of reasonable charges for such removal and storage by the owner or operator of any such vehicle. 
(9)  Adopt such additional reasonable rules with respect to traffic and parking in a parking area as local conditions may require for the safety and convenience of the public or of the users of the shopping center. 
(Code 1974, § 21-117) 
Sec. 94-113. - Authority to adopt rules and regulations for specific parking lots. 
    The police chief shall have the authority to adopt such additional reasonable rules and regulations with respect to traffic and parking in the West Grange Shopping Center, Trafford Square Shopping Center, and Fort-King Plaza Shopping Center parking areas as local conditions may require for the safety and convenience of the public and users of the shopping centers. 
(Code 1974, § 21-128) 
Secs. 94-114-94-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WEST GRANGE SHOPPING CENTER, TRAFFORD SQUARE SHOPPING CENTER AND FORT-KING PLAZA SHOPPING CENTER 

Sec. 94-131. - Scope; enforcement. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to the West Grange Shopping Center, Trafford Square Shopping Center and Fort-King Plaza Shopping Center areas and shall be enforced by the police department. 
(Code 1974, § 21-123) 
Sec. 94-132. - Installation of traffic control devices. 
    The police chief shall install, at the owners' expense, necessary stop signs, yield signs or other traffic control devices at all entrance or exit locations, and at any intersection, in the parking area of the West Grange Shopping Center, Trafford Square Shopping Center and Fort-King Plaza Shopping Center. 
(Code 1974, § 21-124) 
Sec. 94-133. - Installation of signs regulating parking. 
    The police chief shall install, at the owners' expense, necessary signs to prohibit, regulate, restrict or limit the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified areas of the West Grange Shopping Center, Trafford Square Shopping Center and Fort-King Plaza Shopping Center parking areas. 
(Code 1974, § 21-125) 
Sec. 94-134. - Designation of safety zones, loading zones and other restricted areas. 
    The police chief shall install, at the owners' expense, appropriate signs to designate safety zones, loading zones and other restricted areas in the West Grange Shopping Center, Trafford Square Shopping Center and Fort-King Plaza Shopping Center parking areas. 
(Code 1974, § 21-126) 
Sec. 94-135. - Removal of abandoned and illegally parked vehicles. 
    The police chief shall have the authority to provide for the removal and storage of vehicles parked or abandoned in the West Grange Shopping Center, Trafford Square Shopping Center and Fort-King Plaza Shopping Center parking areas during snowstorms, floods, fires or other public emergencies or found unattended in the parking areas where they constitute an obstruction to traffic or where stopping, standing or parking is prohibited, and to provide for the payment of reasonable charges for such removal and storage by the owner or operator of any such vehicle. 
(Code 1974, § 21-127) 
Secs. 94-136-94-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MOTOR CARRIER SAFETY 

Sec. 94-161. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bus means any motor vehicle designed for carrying 16 or more passengers, including the driver. The term "bus" does not include a school bus, a bus defined and certificated under the Motor Bus Transportation Act (MCL 474.101 et seq.), or a bus operated by a public transit agency operating under any of the following: 
(1)  A county, city, township, or village as provided by law, or other authority incorporated under Public Act No. 55 of 1963 (MCL 124.351 et seq.). 
(2)  An authority incorporated under the Metropolitan Transportation Authorities Act of 1967 (MCL 124.401 et seq.), or that operates a transportation service pursuant to an interlocal agreement under the Urban Cooperation Act of 1967 (MCL 124.501 et seq.). 
(3)  A contract entered into pursuant to Public Act No. 8 of 1967 (Ex. Sess.) (MCL 124.531 et seq.), or Public Act No. 35 of 1951 (MCL 124.1 et seq.). 
(4)  An authority incorporated under the Public Transportation Authority Act (MCL 124.451 et seq.), or a nonprofit corporation organized under the Nonprofit Corporation Act (MCL 450.2101 et seq.) that provides transportation services. 
(5)  An authority financing public improvements to transportation systems under the Revenue Bond Act of 1933 (MCL 141.101 et seq.). 
    Commercial motor vehicle means any self-propelled or towed vehicle designed or used on public highways to transport passengers or property, except for a bus exempted from the definition of same, if the vehicle is one or more of the following: 
(1)  Has either a gross vehicle weight rating or an actual gross weight or gross combination weight rating or an actual gross combination weight of 10,001 or more pounds. 
(2)  Is designed for carrying 16 or more passengers, including the driver. 
(3)  Is used in the transportation of hazardous materials in a quantity that requires the vehicle to be marked or placarded pursuant to 49 CFR parts 100 to 180. 
    Gross combination weight and GCW mean the combined weight of a combination of vehicles and any load on those vehicles. 
    Gross weight, gross vehicle weight and GVW mean the combined weight of a motor vehicle and any load on that vehicle. 
    Hazardous material vehicle inspection or repair facility means a commercial enterprise that performs inspections, certification, testing, or repairs to commercial motor vehicles transporting hazardous materials as required by 49 CFR parts 100 to 180 and includes motor carriers that perform the inspections, certification, testing, or repairs to vehicles owned or leased by the motor carrier. 
    Motor carrier means a carrier of passengers or property in a commercial motor vehicle and includes a person who owns or leases a commercial motor vehicle or that assigns employees to operate the vehicle. The term "motor carrier" includes a motor carrier's agents, officers, and representatives, as well as employees responsible for hiring, supervising, training, assigning, or dispatching of drivers and employees concerned with the installation, inspection, and maintenance of motor vehicle equipment and accessories. 
(Code 1974, § 21-161) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 94-162. - Penalty; authority to stop and inspect vehicles. 
(a)  Any driver or operator who violates this article or a rule promulgated under the Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963 (MCL 480.11 et seq.), or any owner or user of any truck, truck tractor, or trailer, or any officer or agent of any individual, partnership, corporation, or association or their lessees or receivers appointed by any court, which is the owner or user of any vehicle, who requires or permits the driver or operator to operate or drive any truck, truck tractor, or trailer in violation of this article or a rule promulgated under such act is responsible for a civil infraction for each violation. 
(b)  A peace officer or an officer of the motor carrier division of the department of state police, upon reasonable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is being operated in violation of this article or a rule promulgated pursuant to such act may stop the motor vehicle and inspect the motor vehicle. If a violation is found, the officer may issue a notice to appear for that violation. 
(Code 1974, § 21-165) 
Sec. 94-163. - Prosecution of violations. 
    When this article or a rule promulgated under the Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963 (MCL 480.11 et seq.) has been violated, the offense may be prosecuted in any county, city or jurisdiction in or through which the motor vehicle, driver or operator implicated was situated or passed when the offense was committed. 
(Code 1974, § 21-164) 
Sec. 94-164. - Qualifications of drivers. 
    A person shall not drive, and an individual, partnership, association, corporation, or their lessees or receivers appointed by any court shall not employ, engage, hire, or contract for hire any person to operate, drive, or maintain, any bus, truck, truck tractor, or trailer, or certain other motor vehicles, unless the person meets the qualifications as set forth by the Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963 (MCL 480.11 et seq.) and the department of state police under the authority of such act. 
(Code 1974, § 21-162) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 480.12a. 
Sec. 94-165. - Standards for vehicles. 
    A person shall not operate any truck, truck tractor, or trailer or permit any person to drive any bus, truck, or truck tractor, or certain other motor vehicles, which does not meet driver or operator safety standards, and safety standards for equipment and devices on buses, trucks, truck tractors, or trailers, or certain other motor vehicles, and the loading and unloading thereof as set forth in the Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963 (MCL 480.11 et seq.) and rules promulgated by the department of state police. 
(Code 1974, § 21-162) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 480.12b. 
Sec. 94-166. - Standards for facilities. 
    A person shall not operate or maintain any facility used in connection with the transportation of persons or property by any bus, truck, truck tractor, or trailer which facility does not meet safety standards for the operation and maintenance of such facility as set forth in Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1963 (MCL 480.11 et seq.) or rules promulgated by the department of state police. 
(Code 1974, § 21-162) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 480.12c. 
Chapter 98 - UTILITIES[1]
